My research is focused on developing new vision based techniques for the inspection of complex surfaces.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Alan Jocelyn
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Alan Jocelyn
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have extensive experience from many years working in the aerospace industry.

Current Projects

Laser transparent ceramics - Sucessful Application for PhD studentship with Great Western Research with LisTechnology Ltd for Laser Induced Superplasticity Technology Ltd.'The world's first laser based manufacturing cell'.

The RAMP (Revolutionary Aerospace Machining Processes) project aims to investigate the further deployment of High Performance Machining (HPM) in the Aerospace industry, especially of new materials such as titanium, Waspalloy, and Jetheat. HPM technology is no longer novel but its utilisation within the aerospace industry is still limited, mainly for machining aluminium components.

RAMP Lab Ultra High Performance Machining seminar - RAMP seminar.

I am chairman of the Association of Aerospace Universities http://www.aau.ac.uk http://www.aau.ac.uk/west_of_england.htm.

I am a member of the AEIGT group Aerospace Innovation and Growth Team working group 3 as a representative of the AAU. The AeIGT is made up of industry, Government and academia representatives working together to ensure the competitiveness of UK Aerospace over the next twenty years.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Alan Winfield
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Alan Winfield
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am an engineer and academic. By day I manage the research and knowledge transfer activity in computing engineering and maths, within UWE, Bristol; evenings and weekends I conduct research in mobile robotics within the Intelligent Autonomous Systems lab, now part of the Bristol Robotics Lab.

I am deeply interested in mobile robots for two reasons: (1), they are complex and potentially useful machines that embody just about every design challenge and discipline there is and (2), robots allow us to address some deep questions about life, emergence and intelligence in a radically new way, that is by building models. Thus, robotics is for me both engineering and experimental philosophy.

I am committed to the widest possible dissemination of research and ideas in science, engineering and technology and I believe that robots provide us with a wonderful vehicle for public engagement. Actually I would go a stage further and argue that intelligent robots will become ubiquitous in the near future and we therefore need to start a dialogue now about the ethical and moral questions that will arise.

Area of Expertise

Experience and Qualifications

Preferred Knowledge Transfer Activities

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Alexander Lenz
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Alexander Lenz
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am working on Biological Inspired Gaze Stabilisation Algorithms.

In a EPSRC funded project with the Universities of Edinburgh and Sheffield we are aiming to apply and evaluate novel, biologically inspired algorithms for adaptive control. Our problem of choice is the gaze stabilisation, as achieved by the vestibulo-ocular reflex in animals and humans. The project seeks to characterise and artificially implement (using FPGAs) the distributed plasticity utilised in the biological control systems in order to show fast, precise and complex movements even under the changing dynamics of the oculomotor plant.

This includes research papers in stability and stratified fluid flows, and Continuing Professional Development for teachers in mechanics. My research interests are pseudospectra and energy growth in single, and two-fluid flows.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Alistair Clark
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Alistair Clark
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am a Principal Lecturer in Operational Research (OR), and Research Leader of the School of Mathematical Sciences.

My research interests centre on the development of models and heuristic methods for problems of production planning and scheduling. Such problems are often highly complex and can be solved to optimality for only very small instances. As a result, approximate models and solution methods are developed, suitable for operational use, making use of mathematical programming and metaheuristic approaches. I am also interested in project planning and scheduling, and the application of OR in poor countries, using free (or nearly-free) software.

I was formerly a Production Systems Specialist at UniSoma (an OR consulting and systems development company in Brazil), an academic adviser at IBM's Latin American Institute of Technology, an analyst in the UK Government OR Service, a lecturer at several UK universities, and a VSO volunteer teacher in Wa, Ghana. I have led production planning and scheduling consulting and systems development assignments for Polyenka, Thomson Consumer Electronics, Matthew Clark Brands plc, and Tilibra, Brazil's market leader in school and office stationary. I have also co-ordinated statistical data-gathering and analysis studies for Rhodia, and advised in several other production planning projects. I have close links with the University of So Paulo (USP), the Federal University of So Carlos (UFSCar), and the University of Campinas (Unicamp), all in the state of So Paulo, Brazil. I belong to the UK Operational Research Society (ORS) on whose Council I represent the Western region of England.

Current projects I'm involved in are:

1. "Integrated Setup Sequencing and Lot-Sizing in Production Scheduling", funded by the EPSRC, with the Federal University of S Carlos, Brazil, funded by the CNPq.

2. "Improvements to Cell Suppression in Statistical Disclosure Control", funded by the Office of National Statistics, UK.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Ana Sendova-Franks
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Ana Sendova-Franks
rdf:Description.p:biography:
My research interests are in the areas of Social Insects, Mathematical Biology, Biometry, Collective Intelligence and Collective Robotics.

Research Interests - Social Organisation in Ants

Sociality in animals is the highest level in the hierarchy of biological organisation. Sociality in animals has advanced furthest in social insects. Hence, colonies of social insects are considered to be eusocial or truly social. Division of labour is the fundamental concept through which the mechanisms underlying the transition to eusociality, both in terms of proximate and ultimate causation, are best addressed. In terms of ultimate causation (evolutionary history), division of labour begins between reproductive and non-reproductive tasks. In social insect colonies division of labour has advanced to the next stage, that is within the non-reproductive tasks such as, for example, brood care, building or foraging. According to Hamilton's rule, for eusociality in ants to evolve division of labour among non-reproductive tasks needs to be effective enough to maximise the production of young and make it cost effective for those individuals who have forfeited direct reproduction to raise the progeny of their relatives. Indeed, as E. O. Wilson once pointed out, a colony of ants is like a 'factory within a fortress'. In other words an ant colony is a superbly designed organisation for the production of young. The fundamental issue here is how this is achieved. Individual ants can perceive only local conditions. No one is in charge and no one oversees the global situation, to plan and to give orders. How can populations of workers be effectively allocated to populations of tasks in such a concurrent, decentralised social organisation?

The approach taken in addressing this issue involves self-organisation theory and its associated bottom-up modelling, that is modelling of collective structures and processes from individual rules of behaviour. My approach has been to test hypotheses about such rules of individual behaviour empirically in the context of the whole colony where all workers are made individually recognisable.

Goals/Research Projects

To understand the principles of concurrent decentralised organisation that have allowed ant colonies to fulfil their function with wide ecological success under natural selection.

Ph.D. Students

Sarah Backen (1996 - 2000, BBSRC funded, University of Bath, with Professor Nigel Franks)

Elizabeth Langridge (1998 - 2006, part-time, with Professor Nigel Franks, University of Bristol)

Matthew Wilson (2000 - 2003, EPSRC funded, with Professor Chris Melhuish, UWE)

Samuel Scholes (2001 - 2005, EPSRC funded, with Professor Chris Melhuish, UWE)

Advisor

Antony Alexiev (2003 - , ORS funded, Supervisor Professor Nigel Franks, University of Bristol)

Academic Background

1983 - 1988 - B.Sc. in Biology and M.Sc. in Entomology, University of Sofia, Bulgaria

1988 - 1989 - Research Assistant, Faculty of Biology, University of Sofia

1989 - 1993 - Ph.D. in Biology and Statistics, University of Bath

1995 - 1998 - Postdoctoral Research Associate (Leverhulme Trust), Department of Biology and Biochemistry and Department of Mathematical Sciences, University of Bath

1994 - 1999 - Various teaching posts, Department of Biology and Biochemistry, University of Bath

2000 - 2003 - M.Sc. in Applied Statistics, Sheffield Hallam University (supported by UWE)

Current post since 1st January 2000

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Angela Helvin

rdf:Description.p:biography: I did my first degree in Statistics and Information Systems, after which I accepted a research post with Shell and the University of Bristol. My research focus was on the application of wavelets in time series analysis, the effects of under-sampling and artefacts of aliasing in locally stationary wavelet processes. Immediately before taking up my post as a Lecturer in Statistics at UWE I was with marketing and database consultancy agency, Talking Numbers, where I specialised in providing statistical training and analytics/consultancy in areas such as market segmentation, (customer) profiling and modelling consumer behaviour for a range of clients including British Gas, the Department of Health, Oxfam, LloydsTSB, Thomson and Nationwide Building Society.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Anthony May

Subsequently I worked on non-linear aspects of pneumatic transmission lines and signal generators for my PhD - again from Exeter. I am currently leading a number of Teaching Company Scheme projects, my research interests centre on design and analyses where fluid dynamics and/or thermodynamics play an important part.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Bhuvan Sharma
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Bhuvan Sharma
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am working as a Research Associate in the Advanced Computation in Design and Decision Making Group of the School of Computer Science. I am actively into application of Evolutionary concepts and Algorithms in the engineering design and optimization. I am a graduate of the prestigious IIT, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur. After graduating from IIT, I worked for Infosys Technologies Ltd, (a leading software services company in India) before going for Masters from University of Birmingham, in the field of Natural Computation. I was also a part of team in Global Symphony Software Services, that provided Supply Chain Management solutions to Manugistics, USA (leader in Supply Chain solutions), before moving to the University of West England, Bristol.

My special interests are in the field of evolutionary computation, and its application to real world problems. No wonder my favourite quote - 'If man can learn from the mistakes of the past, why can't a computer be programmed to do so. Thats what evolutionary computation is all about', draws inspiration from my present works. My research focus is on the complexity of design problem. Since the complexity of such problems warrant special attention in the formulation of problem itself, evolutionary Algorithms (which work on the principle of simulating the evolution, a very complex process itself) can give potential insights about the complexity of problem. The behavior of the variables (environment, in Darwinian evolution) in the problem domain can be easily captured by the changes in the population members (problems solutions represented as individuals in a population) in the evolotionary process. What one can understand through the exercise is the role of variables in the problem at hand. I have worked on interesting projects in the field of evolutionary computation. To know more about me, browse through the links on my home page, and/or send me an email .

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Chris Bytheway
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Chris Bytheway
rdf:Description.p:biography: After leaving Plymouth University I worked as an electronic hardware design engineer, designing automotive diagnostic equipment. I then came to work for UWE in the Intelligent Autonomous Systems Laboratoryas a technical support engineer. I specialise in mechanical and electronic hardware design and am now the leading CAD designer for the lab specialising in 3D modellign and rapid prototyping for the many research projects in the new Bristol Robotics Laboratory, BRL. Recent projects include Major lab projects include SolarBot, MicroLinuxBot, LinuxBot, U-Bots, WhiskerBot, Cerebellum and currently working on EchoBot III.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Chris Melhuish
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Chris Melhuish
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am Director of the Bristol Robotics Laboratory (BRL), which is a partnership between the University of Bristol (UoB) and the University of the West of England, Bristol (UWE). The BRL partnership extends the previous facilities of the Intelligent Autonomous Systems Laboratory (IAS) of which I was the Director. I currently hold two chairs: Professor of Intelligent Autonomous Systems a the University of the West of England and Professor of Robotics and Autonomous Systems at the University of Bristol.

I am interested in making robot systems which can behave autonomously in an intelligent manner. I am currently working on collective as well as single robot systems, energy autonomy, and bio-inspired systems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Chris Simons
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Chris Simons
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Chris joined UWE as a Senior Lecturer five years ago, having previously provided software design and methodology consulting for various industrial clients worldwide for a number of years. Chris now teaches Agent-Based Computing, Components and Services, and Software Design. 

Chris's research interests have taken him along the part-time PhD route where his interests lie in the role of computational intelligence in supporting software designers in the upstream conceptual design phases of software engineering design. Chris was a Co-investigator on the EPSRC 'Designing for the 21st Century' Cluster - Discovery in Design: People-centered Computational Issues, and is currently an Associate Director of the Institute for People-centred Computation.

When time allows, Chris enjoys getting away to scuba-dive the many wrecks and reefs found around the UK coastline.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Chris Toomer
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Chris Toomer
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I graduated from Imperial College, London, with a Ph.D. in mathematics and geophysical fluid dynamics, and am a chartered aerospace engineer. Before joining UWE I held Senior Scientist posts at BAE Systems Sowerby Research Centre in Bristol and at ETH Zurichs Supercomputing Center where I was also Head of the Computational Modelling research group. My research interests are in computational fluid dynamics applied to modelling the cardiovascular system, wind turbines and their siting, bridge instabilities and hypersonic aerothermodynamics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Chris Wallace
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Chris Wallace
rdf:Description.p:biography:
My first degree was in Mathematics and Statistics at Auckland University in New Zealand, my second in Information Sciences (OR and Computing) at Victoria University in Wellingtion. I first worked in Quality Control in industry and as a biometrician for the Minstry of Agriculture and Fisheries. I moved into computing, mainly COBOL, and worked as a project leader for a NZ software house before migrating back to the UK in the late '70s. I joined Michael Jackson Systems Limited and worked in commerce with COBOL and JSP (Jackson Structured Programming) in London for some years before moving to Bristol Polytechnical (UWE as was) where I have been based, with a few outages, since the mid 1980's.

I became interested in Smalltalk and object orientation early on and ran some of the first OO courses in the UK with John Daniels (Syntropy), later taking a year's secondment with Object Designers as a consultant. Throughout my time at UWE I have taught a wide range of computing and information systems courses and have much been involved in curriculum development, laterly as Field Leader in Computing.

In 1999, I left (temporarily as it turned out) and spent 3 years sailing with my wife in our 38ft Halberg-Rassy, Perdika, down to New Zealand and back. In 2003, I took up a post in the Information Systems School. One major teaching and research area is Web Applications development which extends to XML technologies and web2.0 ideas generally. I'm project leader on the development of the faculty's XML-based information system, FOLD [which you are using right now] which is based on the native XML database, eXist. Another significant area is Systems Engineering, where I am module leader of the Systems Engineering module on the CPDA Masters degree. Other interests include rigorous modelling with the Alloy language (Daniel Jackson at MIT)and process modelling.

At the moment I am working on a wikibook on XQuery, a cookbook of XQuery examples. The topic currently under development is the use of XQuery with the semantic web.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Christophe Bru
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Christophe Bru
rdf:Description.p:biography:
My research involves the study of the different cost estimation methodologies available, identifying their limitations (may it be generally or particularly to specific customer needs) and prototyping novel solutions. We have a strong relationship with our industrial partners who are mostly, but not limited to, aerospace manufacturing companies. Although I acquired in depth knowledge of paramateric cost estimation, I mainly focus on generative cost estimation due to its potential in delivering more accurate estimations. The increased accuracy is accompanied by a larger volume of output data, which led me to develop cognitive visualisation tools in order to permit a quick and thorough analysis of this data. The tools consist in a mixture of both textual and graphical approaches, providing both hypertextual and exploratory data mining solutions.

Area of Expertise

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Colin Fudge
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Colin Fudge
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Professor Colin Fudge is Pro Vice- Chancellor (research, RAE 2008, estates and facilities management) at the University of the West of England. He has worked in central and local government, academia and the private sector. He was previously Pro Vice-Chancellor and Dean, Faculty of the Built Environment, UWE (1995-2005), Director of Environmental Services, Bath City Council (1991-95), Honorary Professor of Urban Environment, University of Cardiff (1991-05) and a Senior Lecturer at the School for Advanced Urban Studies, University of Bristol (1975-1983 and 1986-1991). He was Deputy Permanent Secretary, Ministry for Planning and Environment, State of Victoria, Australia (1983-1986).

He holds degrees in Architecture and Town and Regional Planning and is a member of the Royal Town Planning Institute. He was awarded an Honorary Fellowship of the Royal Institute of British Architects (2001) and the title of Royal Professor by the Swedish Academy of Sciences in 2002.

Among his other appointments are Chair, European Union Expert Group on the Urban Environment (1993-), Founding Director of the WHO Collaborative Research Centre on Healthy Cities and Urban Policy (1996-), Chair, European Sustainable Cities and Towns Campaign (1998-), Visiting Professor, European University Institute, Florence, Italy (1999-), Chalmers University (2002-) and Board Member, International Scientific Board, Chalmers University, Gothenburg, Sweden (2005-). He is Chair of the International Expert Panel advising the Swedish Research Councils on their Climate Change and Sustainability Research Programme 2006-2010. He is a member of the Alliance for Global Sustainability (MIT, ETH Zurich, Chalmers, Tokyo Universities) and is a Board Member for the LSE International Cities Programme.

At a regional level Professor Fudge is Chair, Creating:Excellence, the South West regional centre of excellence for regeneration; the South West regional representative for CABE (the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment); Chair, South West Design Forum; Chair, SW HERDA Research Committee; Founding Director of South West Round Table on Sustainable Development; Member of the SWRDA Working Group on Europe; Member of the Bristol Initiative and the Boards for Bristol Science City and Emersons Green Science Park (Bristol). He is Chair of the Great Western Research Sustainability Panel and on the Governing Board.

He has been involved in and/or led research projects for ESRC, EPSRC, British Academy, EU, ODPM, DEFRA, WHO and OECD. He was also on the AHRC working group on the research programme Landscape and the Environment 2004/2005. He was the adviser DG Research on the EU Vth Framework Research Programme and the City of Tomorrow and Cultural Heritage programmes in particular. He is currently involved in the Anglo-Swedish Ministerial Round Table on climate change and adaptation strategies and the British Presidency Ministerial meetings on Sustainable Communities. He is an adviser to two of the Swedish research councils, FORMAS and MISTRA. He chaired the Scientific Committee for the Life in the Urban Landscape international conference in Sweden in 2005 and international conferences in Japan, Germany, Portugal and Denmark and is Chair of the Urban Design Group international conference in 2006.

His research interests are in the areas of urban regeneration, sustainability and environmental policy and how they interrelate with social, economic, design and technological issues and perspectives. He has a strong regional, national and international reputation as evidenced by his numerous awards and advisory appointments. He has written more than 80 articles and reports, 10 books, numerous book chapters and presented more than 100 conference papers.

He has extensive experience of working internationally on urban and regional issues, public management and policy implementation in Sweden, Finland, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Japan and southern Africa for EU, WHO, UNESCO, UNDP, OECD, DfID and SIDA.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Dan Dixon
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Dan Dixon
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have 10 years of commercial web design and development experience. My main interests are around designing holistic services (but focused on the web/internet as an enabler) that make the best use of the social aspects of shared use.

In 1997 I started off at web design agency Syzygy in the years of the dotcom boom. I quickly moved from a pure technical role into a project management and production capacity, ending up as Production Director. While there I worked on sites for well known names like BP, Boots and Mazda as well as helping out with start ups like QXL, Schoolsnet and evolvebank.

Then it was a move into a big media organisation, as the fall out from the internet bubble was settling. I took a role in the BBC managing various portfolios of web applications and helped define what Product Management was for the beeb's online products/services. For most of my time there I was in the communities team; designing/developing/managing the software platforms that supported all the bbc.co.uk online communities.

Most recently I worked for the Social Software company Headshift as a Senior Consultant. Whilst there I worked with clients to help them understand, and make the most of, what gets called Web 2.0, social or participative media.

I didn't aim for this at the beginning, I started out studying Egyptology and Philosophy at university.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Danny Froud
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Danny Froud
rdf:Description.p:biography: Simply speaking, I aim to build the Terminator, only more intelligent. Consequently I am currently researching mobile embodied multimodal sensory systems and bio-inspired techniques for integration, interpretation and interaction.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: David Evans
rdf:Description.foaf:name: David Evans
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have been at UWE since September 2004 researching cost estimation. Within the cost estimation literature and in practice within organisations a range of cost estimation methods are used to predict costs prior to activities being undertaken. Estimates generated utilising different estimation methods provide different projections of the anticipated cost. The differences could have a significant impact on the overall viability of a project or the selection of the optimum design for the product or process.

At present there is no model available that considers the effect of various influencing factors to determine the most appropriate cost estimation method for a given task. This leads to uncertainty about which method should be used and a loss of accuracy or wasted effort if a suboptimal method is chosen. My research aims to address the problem by establishing the factors that influence the performance of the estimating methods and the requirements of the different estimating methods.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: David Wyatt
rdf:Description.foaf:name: David Wyatt
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have a great deal of experience (8 years) in Games design and programming in Assembler, C and Basic on the following Home Computer platforms: Commodore 64, Amiga, Atari ST , Spectrum, PC and BBC Model B. Much early development work was carried out at home using the BBC Model B but this eventually led to a post at Arc Developments where I wrote a published game called Robozone 64 for the Commodore 64 platform. My main interest in computer games has always been in their construction rather than in playing them although these aspects are not mutually exclusive.

I have an interest in the games research field, in particular, Games AI, which is thought by the industry and general public to be the aspect of game design and game-play most in need of development. This research could encompass Evolutionary Computation, Multi-agent Systems and complex Agent-Interactions, leading to some form of emergence and autonomous behaviour. In particular, I am interested in Language Evolution - in building simulations to investigate the types of behaviour (emergent or otherwise) that such systems are capable of and how these behaviour can be harnessed in application to known problems within the Games (and other related) industry.

In September 2004, I completed a PhD entitled Applying the XCS Learning Classifier System to Continuous-Valued Data Mining Problems. The XCS Learning Classifier System has been shown to have a capability for data-mining through rule induction, that is, a technique by which various characteristics of a given problem space may be deduced and presented to the user in a readable format. There should exist a close interaction between user and machine-based adaptive search process. Information provided by the search process should aid the user in developing a better understanding of the problem domain. In addition, it was hoped that the user's knowledge and intuition can be captured through an iterative refinement of the problem space. The issue of presenting human-readable information about continuous-valued problem spaces to the user was addressed as well as an investigation of capabilities the system has to deal with changes in the underlying environment caused by a user-actioned refinement of the problem space. The thesis introduced two novel approaches to learning motivated by the need to learn fairly accurate models quickly. I am an active researcher in the Evolutionary Computation field and a member of the Learning Classifier Systems Group (a research group at UWE).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Deborah Street
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Deborah Street
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Responsibilies

I am a statistician working within the Department of Mathematics and Statistics. My teaching is focussed in two areas :

Statistics : the use of Multivariate Statistics such as Cluster Analysis, Principal Components/Factor Analysis, C&RT and CHAID data mining techniques, Correspondence Analysis and Structured Equation Modelling . I am also

Research Methods : Preparation for research; the development of research ideas, questions, hypotheses, and research proposals at Postgraduate level. I am currently module leader for UFPEEV-15-M REsearch Methods, and UFPEPT-15-M Research Methdos for Software Engineering.

Research Interests

I am currently involved in the following projects :

Redesigning the Research Methods Curriculum

Project description

  Current research and development work at UWE has created an online e-learning resource, the Research Observatory (RO), which is currently used in a blended manner to support distant and classroom teaching of the research methods courses across the university and within CEMS/BIT. This project focuses upon redesigning the research methods curriculum by enabling the students to design appropriate online learning contexts for their subjects, and establishing ways to evaluate these through student feedback and dissertation/project work at undergraduate and postgraduate levels. The RO has been used to support dissertation students across the university on attended and blended courses for the past year. Up to now, it has only been used individually by students on MSc programmes across CEMS to support their studies. We have received positive feedback on the metaphoric context that the RO uses to help the students construct their own meaning for their research studies. However, we recognize that this context will not be suitable for all users, and is likely to present particular difficulties for students with Autistic Spectrum Disorders (ASD) and learning styles that emphasize systemizing and underemphasize empathy. For this reason we have developed a structure for the RO that can now accommodate multiple contexts.   

The students will actively participate by using the tablet computers to draw and design their own, preferred learning contexts and to use the content of the RO as classroom exercises to stimulate discussion and reflection.  Tablet computersare the ideal medium for this as they allow the students to interact through a tactile and intuitive interface, which is both mobile and flexible. 

Specifically the objectives are to:

  • Introduce tablet computers into existing group teaching sessions as a means of enabling classroom interaction with online contexts and content in the RO
  • Enable some students in undergraduate mathematics and statistics to design evaluation frameworks for the existing RO which will be utilised by MSc students at the onset of their interaction with it.
  • Enable MSc students to utilise, evaluate and design, review and refine preferred learning contexts for studying research methods in their own subject fields through the use of the pen-based writing and drawing capabilities of the tablet computers
  • Individually engage with a number of students with diagnosed ASD in designs for their preferred online learning contexts- this part of the project running alongside the group work.
  • Facilitate collaboration amongst students on both content and context in the RO by using tablet computers in conjunction with interactive whiteboards and projection technologies in the classroom.

See : http://hptft.uwe,ac,uk

 

The Research Observatory and Second Life The RO is currently used in a blended manner to support distant and classroom teaching of the research methods courses across the university and will now focus upon redesigning the research methods curriculum by enabling the students to design appropriate learning contexts for their subjects and integrating the use of these contexts and the primary curriculum content into classroom sessions. There is a clear synergy between the project plan outlined above and the sociovirtual learning opportunities presented by the Second Life environment, so that students collaborative work on learning contexts design could be extended beyond the physical classroom but without dislodging the social engagement that will be driving the curriculum redesign. In this way the RO project could become a truly ubiquitous learning resource that binds and pervades into the realms of the physical classroom, the VLE, the classic web interface and the social web. The RO development team is also currently researching the online learning preferences of students with diagnosed Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD). ASD sufferers usually find it hard to engage in real life social learning situations. The RO team would strive to ascertain whether students with ASD would find it easier to engage in a virtual social learning experience. In summary, our proposal is to build a Research Observatory in Second Life. The building will act as a hub for all other resources and activities that currently form or will form part of the RO. The team will design collaborative tasks that groups of students will complete in Second Life. The tasks will seek to maximise group creativity and will encourage students to be enterprising and to engage in discovery, synthesis and fact finding missions. 

See: http://www.ro.uwe.ac.uk  

Publications:

ODoherty, R., Street D., & Webber, C., (2007) The Skills and Knowledge of the Graduate Economist, CHUDE, RES and The Economics Network, Warwick

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Haya El-Ghalayini
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Haya El-Ghalayini
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I received a BSc Degree and MSc Degree in Computer Science from Kuwait University, Kuwait. I started my PhD in October 2003 at UWE about working on Reverse Engineering Domain Ontologies to Conceptual data Models. During my PHD research I have been lead author on 3 accepted conference papers, one of them has been accepted from the best papers to be published as a journal paper.

Research

Since the early 1990s, ontologies have been used within several artificial intelligence research projects to facilitate the sharing and reuse of knowledge. Lately, ontologies have become the focus for research in several other areas, including knowledge engineering and management, information retrieval and integration, digital libraries, the semantic web, and e-commerce.

Ontologies facilitate the integration of heterogeneous data sources by resolving semantic heterogeneity between them. This research aims to study the possibility of generating a domain conceptual model from a given ontology with the vision to grow this generated conceptual data model into a global conceptual model integrating a number of existing data and information sources. This is explained in the Graduate School 2005 paper Reverse Engineering Ontology to Conceptual Data Models.

Publications

3 accepted conference papers, one of them has been accepted from the best papers to be published as a journal paper.

El-Ghalayini, H., Odeh, M., and McClatchey, R. (2006). Engineering conceptual data models from domain ontologies: Critical Evaluation. In: Proceedings of the 4th International Multi-conference on Computer Science and Information Technology (CSIT06). Amman, Jordan, pp. 42-53.

El-Ghalayini, H., Odeh, M., McClatchey, R. and Solomonides, T. (2005). Reverse engineering domain ontologies to conceptual data models. In: Hamza, MH, ed. Proceedings of the 23rd IASTED International Conference on Databases and Applications (DBA). Innsbruck, Austria, pp. 222-227.

El-Ghalayini, H., Odeh, M., McClatchey, R., and Arnold, D. (2006). Deriving conceptual data models from domain ontologies for bioinformatics. In: Proceedings of the 2nd IEEE International Conference for Information and Communication: From Theory to Application (ICTTA06). Damascus, Syria, pp. 1011-1012.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Ian Gilhespy
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Ian Gilhespy
rdf:Description.p:biography: I am a technical engineer for BRL lab. I specialised in digital - analogue electronics and computing. I'm currently interested in multi-processor, object orientated embedded systems. Major lab projects include DiveBot, LinuxBots and WhiskerBot.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Ian Horsfield
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Ian Horsfield
rdf:Description.p:biography: I am a Senior technical expert for the BRL lab. I have nearly 20 years experience in industrial electronics, automation and design. My major lab projects include U-Bots, Grey Walter replica Turtles, Millennium Dome robots, I have also contributed to the design of the LinuxBots.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Ian Parmee
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Ian Parmee
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have some fifteen years experience of the utilisation of evolutionary and adaptive computing relating to the solution of complex industrial and commercial problems. My nine year involvement with the establishment and development of the highly successful Plymouth Engineering Design Centre (PEDC) at the University of Plymouth has seen extensive collaboration and / or consultancy with a wide range of industrial organisations. These include Rolls Royce, Rolls Royce Associates, British Energy, Lafarge Braas, British Aerospace, Perkins Technology, Unilever Research and Alsthom. I have been particularly involved in the development of evolutionary and adaptive computing strategies for generic application across a broad spectrum of application areas. Having held Directorship of the Centre for several years I have now expanded the activities of ACT (Advanced Computational Technologies) to better promote and support the take-up of these technologies within the industrial and commercial sectors.

I am involved in a number of Networks funded by the European Community and UK Research Councils. I was formerly chair of the Industrial Liaison Committee of the European Network of Excellence in Evolutionary Computation and remain a member of the Management Committee, I now also chair the EPSRC Network in Adaptive Computing in Design and Manufacture which comprises both industrial and academic members. I have published extensively in high-quality international journals and conference proceedings whilst contributing to and editing a number of books relating to the development and utilisation of the technologies.

I have organised and chaired the biennial Conference 'Adaptive Computing in Design and Manufacture' since 1994. This event has always attracted international contributors and delegates most of whom are leaders in the field of evolutionary computing application. In addition, I have been actively involved in the organisation of the leading evolutionary computing conferences holding various chairs on their organising committees. The same level of involvement is apparent in a number of highly regarded engineering design and optimisation events. I sit on program committees relating to many of these conferences supporting the selection of high-quality papers and perform the same activities for a number of international journals. I have presented several invited Keynote talks at high-profile events and contributed many invited papers, tutorials and workshops to the leading conferences.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Ian Smith
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Ian Smith
rdf:Description.p:biography: I am primarily responsible for the supervision and management of the Facultys Business Liaison and Placements Team, which incorporates all Faculty activities related to placements, short courses, consultancy work, Knowledge Transfer Partnerships (KTPs), business liaison, careers and alumni.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Ioannis Ieropoulos
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Ioannis Ieropoulos
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am a research associate at the Bristol Robotics Laboratory, which is a partnership between the University of Bristol and the University of the West of England. I am also a member of the Microbiology Research Laboratory, in the Applied Sciences Faculty, UWE.

My research interests are in the areas of energetic autonomy for robotic systems with a particular focus in the Microbial Fuel Cell technology and its potential both as an onboard self-sustainable power supply and an off-board stationary means of generating clean energy.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Jim Smith
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Jim Smith
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Research Interests

My primary research interests are in the field of Computational Intelligence, that is computer systems which display what can appear to be intelligent behaviour arising from the interaction of many simple parts. The applications of these techniques fall into two main areas. The first of these is Data Mining, where I have developed and applied a variety of algorithms such as unsupervised neural networks (in various guises) to the problem of discovering useful patterns and relationships in data. The second large area is Heuristic Optimisation, which can be thought of as searching through a (possibly infinite) set of candidate solutions to a problem in order to find one that is preferably the best, or at least of high enough quality to be acceptable. Usually this involves the development, theoretical analysis, and application of novel algorithms for problems which are not amenable to solutions by exact methods or other classical techniques either because of the sheer number of possible solutions (in the case of combinatorial optimisation) or other features such as discontinuities etc. (for continuous problems).

One of the aims of this work is to develop algorithms that are able to adapt their behaviour to the nature of the problem being tackled so as to provide more robust "user friendly" techniques. On another level we can view this studies as part of an investigation into "learning how to learn". Some methods of achieving this behaviour via self-adaptation of recombination and mutation operators were explored in my doctoral thesis: Self Adaptation in Evolutionary Algorithms, (which you can download in compressed postscript or pdf versions. I am particularly interested in the relationship between the nature of the operators that emerge and the underlying structure of the search landscapes. More recently this work has expanded to include the consideration of Memetic Algorithms, which are combinations of Local Search Heuristics with Evolutionary Algorithms. I am particularly interested in the use of different techniques for adapting the local searchers used dynamically during the course of optimisation.

Whilst conducting these more theoretical studies, I have attempted to keep my feet on the ground by working on a number of difficult "real world" problems, such as VLSI Design Verification, Adaptive Image Segmentation and Classification, Lot-sizing, and bio-informatics problems such as Protein Structure Prediction and Protein Structure Comparison.

Current projects include:

      the EU-FP6 funded project DynaVis, which aims to apply Machine Learning techniques to create dynamically reconfigurable machine vision systems for manufacturing quality control,

      Research collaborations with the UK Office of National Statistics to investigate the use of Evolutionary Algorithms for Statistical Disclosure Control

      EPSRC research project investigating mathematical modelling of statistical disclosure control with ONS

      Higher Education Academy project to create on-line material for teaching Artificial Intelligence

Area of Expertise

Machine Learning, Data Mining, Artificial Intelligence, Optimisation, with experience of applications to areas such as Microprocessor Design, Production Planning, Product Inspection ("Intelligent" Machine Vision), Process Control, Bio- and medical- informatics

Experience and Qualifications

Previous employment as financial systems manager in industry. PhD in A.I. Ten years experience of lecturing in AI and related subjects. Supervision of several successful PhD students working on a range of industrial applications of AI techniques. Various consultancy projects. Various EC-funded projects using, Research in theropetical background of, and algorithmic improvements to , AI, in particular Meta-heuristic methods.

Preferred Knowledge Transfer Activities

Consultancy intervention projects based at the university, or on industrial premises. Non-executive Directorship. KTP Projects. Support of placement students (UG/PG/PhD opportunities) in related projects.

Professional Activities

  •  Member of IEEE Computational Intelligence Society Emerging Technologies Task Force on  Memetic Computing

         Member of Editorial Board of the journal Evolutionary Computation

         Member of the Council of Authors of the  International Society of Genetic and Evolutionary Computation

         Programme co-chair for Parallel Problem Solving from Nature 8  held in Birmingham, UK, 18th-22nd September 2004.

         Founder and Organiser (with Natalio Krasnogor and Bill Hart ) of the annual International  Workshops on Memetic Algorithms (WOMA) which have been co-located with the GECCO (2000, 2001, 2003) and PPSN  (2002, 2004 )conferences 

         Member of the Training Committee and the Management Committee of Evonet and EvoNet II , the European Network of Excellence in Evolutionary Computing,

         Member of the Education Committee of COIL (the EU funded Computuation Intelligence CLuster)

         Guest Editor of Journal of Evolutionary Computation, Volume 12, number 3, Special Issue on Memetic Algorithms

         Reviewer for the journals Theoretical Computer Science,  Evolutionary Computation , the IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation, IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man and Cybernetics, IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and EURASIP Journal on Applied Signal Processing and others.

         Programme Committee member for Parallel Problem Solving from Nature (PPSN), IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computation (IEEE CEC), Genetic and Evolutionary Computing Conference (GECCO), Evonet Workshops on Evolutionary Signal Processing,  Memetic Theory in Artificial Systems and Societies (METAS 2005)

Area of Expertise

My principal role is as Head of the School of Mechanical, Manufacturing & Aerospace Engineerig.  My areas of interest primarily lie in the area of manufacturing systems and centre around the use of simulation based tools to support manufacturing system facilities design and evaluation. I also teach in the area of Lean Manufacturing and cover related topics.

In addition to my major management role in the University I am Director of the Bristol and Southwest Consortium for Continuing Professional Development in Aerospace. This is a partnership scheme with Bristol University and delivers postgraduate level CPD to those working in the aerospace industry.

My areas of expertise are Business / manufacturing Systems Simulation and modelling - general manufacturing / supply chain / lean and also / costing and cost modelling.

Experience

I have been teaching for nearly 20 years at a range of levels within the University and have extensive teaching experience. I have run a number of externally funded projects including Knowledge Transfer projects - KTP's, EPSRC funded PhD projects and projects directly funded by industrial partners.

I received my PhD from the University of the West of England in 1998 for research into automated design and analysis tools. I am the Head of School of Mechanical, Manufacturing and Aerospace Engineering at UWE. My research interests centre around Knowledge Based Engineering (KBE) and automated design and structural analysis tools, based on heuristics and Case Based Reasoning methodologies.

I am responsible for all Graduate School enquiries and I am the first point of contact for all postgraduate students. I deal with all PhD applications and help the research team with general administration duties; I also provide a reception service for the External Affairs office and manage the diary for the Director of Postgraduate Research Mr Tony Solomonides.

Personal

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Larry Bull
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Larry Bull
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Interests

I am Professor of Artificial Intelligence, based in the School of Computer Science (UWE). My research interests are in techniques that draw on the natural world, such as evolutionary computation, reinforcement learning, and neural computation. My main focus for the last few years has been Learning Classifier Systems (LCS).

Area of Expertise

Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Mining Adaptive Control

Experience and Qualifications

Development of machine learning systems in commercial environments. Instigation and management of multi-institution EPSRC research projects. B.Sc. Computing for Real-Time Systems (1992). Ph.D. Artificial Symbiology (1995). Head: Artificial Intelligence Group

Preferred Knowledge Transfer Activities

Consultancy. Research project partner (DTI, EU, EPSRC,etc.). KTP Projects. Supervision of part-time PhD students. Support of placement students.

People

At present I am supervising a number of PhD students: Toby O'Hara, examining neural learning classifier systems; Kreangsak Tamee, looking at clustering in large data sets; Matt Smith, using Genetic Programming for data mining; Faten Kharbat, using LCS for breast cancer diagnosis; Adam Budd, exploring constructivism in neural learning classifier systems; Johnson Abraham, looking at data mining in Interactive Evolutionary Design; and Andrea Staggemeier, using GAs, memetic algorithms and other techniques for scheduling tasks.

I have had a number of students finish: Andy Tomlinson, whose thesis was entitled Corporate Classifier Systems(1999); Manu Ahluwalia - Coevolving Functions in Genetic Programming (2000); Natalio Krasnogor - Studies on the Theory and Design Space of Memetic Algorithms (2002); Jacob Hurst - Learning Classifier Systems in Robotic Environments (2002); Claudio Bonacina - Evolutionary Computing in Multi-Agent Systems (2003); David Wyatt - Applying the XCS Learning Classifier System to Continuous-Valued Data Mining Problems (2004); Christopher Stone - Learning Classifier Systems for Decision Making in Continuous-Valued Domains (2005); and, Matt Studley - Learning Classifier Systems for Multi-objective Robot Control (2006).

Projects

Non-Linear Media Based Computers (EPSRC: Mingwen Ma, Chris Stone, Rita Toth and Ivan Uroukov, 2004-2008) Novel Computation project to develop and test a new approach to enable desired computations/behaviour from networks of non-linear media in collaboration with Sussex and Leeds.

Super-Computer Data Mining (EPSRC: Matthew Studley, 2004-2006) Creation of a UK machine learning data mining tool, in collaboration with Manchester and UEA.

Cluster on Non-Linear Media Based Computers (EPSRC: 2003-2004) Novel Computation cluster in collaboration with Andy Adamatzky and Ben DeLacyCostello.

A Learning Classifier System Approach to Neural Constructivism (EPSRC ROPA: Jacob Hurst, 2002-2004) Use of LCS to control mobile robots where each rule is a neural network and their complexity emerges during learning.

Data Mining (LloydsTSB: Praminda Caleb-Solly, 2001-2003) Project to use a number of machine learning techniques for analysis of various types of financial data.

Distributed Adaptive Control for Road Traffic Systems (EPSRC: Andy Tomlinson, 2001-2003) A project applying LCS to road traffic signal control in collaboration with the traffic group at UCL.

Evolutionary Robotics (BT Labs and UWE CollR: Jacob Hurst, 1999-2002) A project using self-adaptive LCS for learning in mobile robot systems.

Vintage (EU ESPRIT: YiJa Cao and Neil Ireson, 1998-2000) A European project which built a distributed LCS kernel, with applications in distributed control and scheduling.

Adaptive Economic Trading Agents (HP Labs: myself, 1998-1999) A one-year project to examine the use of learning agents in a simulated continuous double-auction market.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Laurent Dala
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Laurent Dala
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Professional Career

After being graduated from the French Grandes Ecoles, ESTP and ESTA, I joined the French National Aerospace Research Centre (ONERA) as an Aerodynamicist. During 5 years, I was in charge of the Technical Assistance to CNES (French Space Agency) on the problems of aerodynamics affecting longitudinal stability in sub/transonic flows on the Ariane Launchers. I was also involved in Numerical and Experimental studies on longitudinal characteristics and uncertainties in hypersonic flows (from perfect gas to real gas including non-equilibrium effects) for the space planes. In this role since 1992, I have started visiting Russia, especially TsAGI (Central Aerohydrodynamic Institute) in Zhukovsky. During my time at ONERA, I also carried out studies in laminar flow control in sub/transonics and design of the wings for the new supersonic civil transport "Alliance".

I also worked as a consultant for Bugatti car company on the EB110 super sport.

In January 1995, I joined the University of Manchester (UK) - Aerospace Department as a Research Assistant in Aerodynamics to do my PhD thesis, which I completed in April 1997. My PhD was devoted to Hypersonic Viscous Flows Including Non-Equilibrium Real gas Effects, especially to the development of an accurate and fast Navier-Stokes CFD code based on the Flux Vector Splitting method.

After the completion of my PhD thesis, I joined the Institut AroTechnique (IAT/CNAM) in France as a Principal Aerodynamicist. I was responsible for CFD/Wind Tunnel Tests development in the Institute. I was involved in different projects such as the design of the new full-scale aero-acoustics wind tunnel located in Saint Cyr (France) devoted to cars.

In 2000, I joined CargoLifter (International Airship Company), in Germany as the Chief Aerodynamicist and Section Manager of the Flight Science Division.

Before joining the University of the West of England, I spent 2 years at the Aircraft Research Association Limited (ARA).

Since 2005, I have been appointed Chairman of the Advisory Group for the European Project NACRE (New Aircraft Concepts Research)

Lecturing

  • Visiting Professor at the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology (Zhukovsky-Russia)
  • Visiting Lecturer in Aerodynamics and Aerothermics at the IPSA School of Engineering (Institut Polytechnique des Sciences Appliques-Paris)
  • Assistant-Lecturer in CFD, in Experimental Aerodynamics and in Mathematics at the University of Manchester (UK)

Research

  • Hypersonic Flows, including non-equilibrium real gas effects
  • Flow Control
  • Shock wave reduction in supersonics
  • Morphing structures
  • Airships
  • Instability Mechanism in Boundary Layers

Personal Interests

I am an active member of the Rock and Roll social club in UK. I also practice fencing and I enjoy reading and Travelling

To provide admin/PA support to the Faculty Administrator and also team supervisor to the Executive Office Staff.

Personal

When I get the chance, I enjoy some healthy (and not so healthy) pursuits such as swimming, walking and eating out.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Lyndon Smith
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Lyndon Smith
rdf:Description.p:biography: Lyndon Smith is Reader in Computer Simulation and Machine Vision and Co-director of the Centre for Intelligent Manufacturing and Machine Vision Systems (CIMMS) at the University of the West of England, Bristol (UWE). Following a BSc (Hons) in Physics in 1986, he went on to obtain an MSc in Automation in 1988 and a PhD in computer simulation of a manufacturing process in 1997. In 1998 and 1999 Dr. Smith was Director of Computer Simulation at a research laboratory at The Pennsylvania State University in the USA. His research activities have resulted in the publication of over ninety technical papers, authorship of a book and editorship of a second book, as well as frequent refereeing of journal papers and the chairing of international research conferences in the USA and Europe. A major and on-going area of interest is research into novel vision based devices for skin analysis for providing indicators of the presence of melanoma (see below). This has involved collaboration with a consultant plastic surgeon and has resulted in a successful DPhil and two on-going PhD supervisions. He has also authored successful grant applications from numerous organisations, including the EPSRC and the European Commission; and is on the editorial board of a number of international journals (and has acted as guest editor for two international journals). Dr Smith has expertise in areas that are particularly relevant to on-going funding applications, specifically: machine vision and modelling of the resulting data. The former has taken the form of the design and build for a range of machine vision systems (with a particular emphasis on medical applications), as well as research into relevant algorithms for data recovery and analysis. This latter often takes the form of pattern recognition and modelling for applications such as surface inspection and analysis of 3D features. Lyndon Smith has achieved simulation and modelling of complex 3D forms through employment of techniques that have ranged from multivariate analysis through to neural networks. He also developed a new technique for analysis of complex irregular morphologies, which employed a combination of machine vision analysis and stochastic 3D shape constructions and packings. An area of research of particular interest is that of computer vision based analysis of 3D skin surface texture for early detection of melanoma. Lyndon Smith designed and built an instrument known as the PS Device which employs photometric stereo for recovery of 3D skin surface texture. Dr Smith has used the instrument at Frenchay Hospital, in collaboration with a consultant plastic surgeon (who is very enthusiastic regarding the work).  Further success of this research has been demonstrated by the recently awarded DTI grant and a landmark collaboration with the worlds leading medical manufacturer of 2D lesion analysis equipment. This funding and industrial involvement offers potential to make rapid progress in this medically related research which eventually aims to enable production of a device for primary healthcare use, which will provide additional indicators of malignancy by capturing and analysing 3D lesion texture data. The photometric stereo approach for skin analysis has proved to be so useful that the MRC has funded a research project where it will be employed for early detection of Plagiocephaly in small children. This project (again in collaboration with Frenchay Hospital), which involves cranial measurement and morphological analysis for children, has required many metrological and analytical skills.   Lyndon Smith is currently supervising five PhD candidates as well as performing research and publishing outcomes in international journals. Another important duty as a reader has been to secure funding for research. Successful applications have been made to numerous public and private organisations in the UK, Europe and the USA.  Recently Dr Smith and his colleagues have been successful in obtaining significant support for their medical related research from the Department of Trade and Industry and the Medical Research Council; and this has resulted in some very useful outcomes.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Marcus Lynch
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Marcus Lynch
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Responsibilities

Research Interests

  • Models of social change
  • Information Systems Theory and methodologies
  • Information Systems in the Voluntary Sector
  • The Utility (or Otherwise) of Organisational Learning Approaches in HE
  • Ethical Implications of Information Systems
  • Disability & Information Systems
  • Experiential action-research into the effects of increasing HE workload on staff health and morale
  • Novel approaches to equipment interface design for musicians and sound engineers
  • Community radio
  • Supporting self-facilitating groups
  • Production methodologies for multi-platform content creation and distribution
  • Arts & Performance Technologies

Academic History

My first degree in 1977 was from St Andrews University in Chemistry (Bsc Hons IIii), but, in practice, was as much in student politics, music and organisation theory! After graduating I taught Science for a term in a secondary school, before being very fortunate to receive funding from Glaxo to work for my P hD under the inspirational Prof Hans Suschitsky at Salford University. Gaining my PhD in 1981, I stayed at Salford as a Postdoctoral Research Fellow, until the Thatcher cuts of 1981 made me realise that a future career as a lecturer in Chemistry might not be as straightforward as I hoped.

Changing track in 1982, my background gained me a job as paid Organiser with West Midlands Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, where I worked through the height of protests against Cruise missiles. After 3 years, with my interest in organisations and systems analysis heightened by my experiences of disarmament campaigning, I studied for my MSc in Information Technology at Aston University, with a dissertation on Systems Analysis of Voluntary Organisations.


Moving to Yorkshire, I taught Information Technology at Bradford & Ilkley Community College. In 1989, I set up a freelance consultancy business (Progressive Consultancy & Training), working with voluntary and educational organisations such as Greenpeace International and the British Library. During this time, I regularised my income with part-time teaching of HCI and Soft Systems Methodology at Leeds Polytechnic and with the Open University. My time teaching with the Open University reinforced my use of facilitative, participative approaches in teaching, which continues in my teaching practice today.

Coming to the South West in 1991, I continued to teach Systems and Design part-time with the Open University and, in 1992 I gained part-time employment with Bristol Polytechnic. In 1994, I was appointed to a full-time post at UWE initially teaching Information Systems approaches and methodology use, as well as being a key person in developing the area of Professional Issues in Computing in the Facultys teaching provision before passing it on to other colleagues to further develop. I have been teaching creative technology subjects since 2000.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Mark Butler
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Mark Butler
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have a PhD in Biologically Inspired Computation from The University of Liverpool and an MEng in Computer Science and Electronic Engineering from the University of Birmingham.

I worked as a researcher at HP Laboratories in Bristol, UK, for six years in the area digital media. While at HP I worked on the Digital Media Platform and SIMILE, a joint project between HP Laboratories, MIT CSAIL, MIT Libraries and the World Wide Web Consortium investigating the application of the Semantic Web to digital libraries. I also worked on UAProf and CC/PP, two related standards for describing the capabilities of devices such as smartphones, both based on RDF. I was lead developer on DELI, an open source toolkit that supports using CC/PP and UAProf in a Java servlet environment. This was used as the basis of the UAProf Validator produced by the Open Mobile Alliance. I was Specification Co-Lead on Java Specification Request 188 and I chaired the W3C CC/PP Working Group.

I also worked at Unilever Research Port Sunlight in their Adaptive Computation Group for two years investigating applying biologically inspired computing to product design.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Martin Jonik
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Martin Jonik
rdf:Description.p:biography:
My main interest is in simulation particularly of manufacturing, and the investigation of tools and techniques for providing simulation using an open architecture. This makes it possible to run simulations using different platforms and in communication with other software.

I have been working on this problem as a member of staff and for my PhD.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Martin Longbottom
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Martin Longbottom
rdf:Description.p:biography: I have worked for 38 years in the Aircraft industry, and after a number of years of retirement returned to University of the West of England to do research into machining problems, specifically into the temperature generated when metals are cut.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Martin Pearson
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Martin Pearson
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am working on Biologically Inspired Sensory Control Algorithms.

I am a PhD student employed as a Research Associate on an EPSRC funded project known as Whiskerbot. It is a joint project with the ABRG, based in the University of Sheffield, to develop a neurophysiologically inspired artificial interpretation of the mammalian whisker sensory system. We also intend to explore the possibility of implementing the bio-inspired algorithms directly into hardware using programmable logic devices.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Martin Robinson
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Martin Robinson
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Martin is a software developer, sound designer/engineer and electronic musician. His research interests are concerned with adaptive/interactive sound design and music applied to performance, installation and computer games. Martin has previously held lecturing posts at Middlesex University and Birmingham City University. He received a first class BA(Hons) in Music and Music Technology from Middlesex University in 1996 followed by an MA in Electronic Arts (with distinction) in 2003 and a PGCertHE in 2007. His creative work has included collaborations with choreographers, musicians and artists resulting in performances and installations in London (The Place, Sadler's Wells, Union Chapel, V&A, The Museum of Childhood), Nottingham, Gloucester (Gloucester Cathedral), Amsterdam (Belle Vue Theatre), Poland and Australia. Martin has also worked on projects for BBC Radio Drama. In addition to his work in Higher Education Martin has developed education courses for artists and industry including: Sonic Arts Network (UK), iMal (Belgium) and EA Games.

More detailed informations is available within the UWE firewall and externally

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Masoud Rabbanichadgani
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Masoud Rabbanichadgani
rdf:Description.p:biography: I received my BSc and MSc degree in Mechanical Engineering in 1995. I have worked on Automatic Weighing Systems, Computer Controlled Sun Tracking Systems and the design of various test systems. At present I am a PhD student at the University of the West of England studying to gain a PhD in the field of Real Time Condition Monitoring. My research interests are instrumentation, real time systems, condition monitoring and the application of artificial neural networks.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Matthew Green
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Matthew Green
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have responsibility for any administration matters related to PhD students whose surnames begin with the letters L-Z. I am available to give advice to students and staff on procedures and regulations related to MPhil and PhD degrees. I am also Clerk to the Research Degrees Board and look after research student and staff accommodation.

From time to time I am called upon to organise special events such as the Graduate School Poster and Social Day and the annual Conference. I also represent the Research Office at postgraduate open evenings and where possible assist the External Affairs team on undergraduate open days.

When I am able to drag myself away from my heavy workload, I can be found practicing the static trapeze and making interesting sounds with a piano. Besides all this I can always find time for a pint or two down the pub and I am a natural at lounging!

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Melvyn Smith
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Melvyn Smith
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am Reader in Machine Vision, Director of the Centre for Innovative Manufacturing and Machine Vision Systems (CIMMS) and Co-director of the Machine Vision Laboratory.

I am interested in undertaking research in computer / machine vision that is of benefit to industry, society and the environment by winning research and development contracts from both commercial and publicly funded bodies world-wide and demonstrating excellence in research through international publication. I am member of the EPSRC Peer Review College, am on the editorial board of four journals, and regularly serve on conference programme committees and act as reviewer for the leading journals in imaging and pattern analysis.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Mike Keavey
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Mike Keavey
rdf:Description.p:biography: Mike Keavey received his MA from the University of Cambridge after three years at Churchill College reading mathematics. He was later awarded a PhD in mechanical engineering for research into shape optimisation carried out at Liverpool Polytechnic. He has over thirty years experience in the development of finite element methods and software with organisations such as the UKAEA and the CEGB Research Division. His current research is mainly concerned with nonlinear constitutive models and solution algorithms, whilst his underlying personal interest is in the generic aspects of multiphysics simulation and the role of declarative and object oriented philosophies in the design of engineering software.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Nick Plant
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Nick Plant
rdf:Description.p:biography:
My main teaching/research/consultancy/knowledge exchange interests:-

  • Professional practice in the curriculum
  • Curriculum-related knowledge exchange - action research, consultancy, volunteering and service learning
  • e-enabling in community organisations; ICT in the community and voluntary sectors
  • The strategic potential of end user technologies
  • Creative ICT and digital multimedia
  • Knowledge exchange through University-community partnership working
  • information systems practice including professional, practical and communications skills for information systems professionals

My official UWE CV online includes biographical details, more on the above, publications, etc...

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Paul Head
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Paul Head
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Area of Expertise

Management and quality systems in organisations. Improvement tools and techniques for operational systems and processes.

Experience

Over 30 years experience in organisational improvement including Total Quality Management and ISO 9000 consultancy and training. Sector experience include, telecommunications, electronics design and manufacture, software development, heavey and precision engineering, health service, financial sector - banking, insurance and legal firmsboth large and small organisations. I am also a member of the IEE.

Preferred Knowledge Transfer Activities

Consultancy intervention, KTP Projects, student placement projects and support, short courses and applied research. Possible techniques or tools include lean manufacturing, agile operations, TQM, Keizen

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Paul Matthews
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Paul Matthews
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Paul's background is in web and database development, knowledge management and information services in international non-profit organisations. His recent work with the Overseas Development Institute included the development of collaboration platforms, in addition to intranet-based application integration and the introduction of social media, bibliographic tools and content management. While at ODI, Paul also contributed to research projects investigating the potential of ICT in developing countries.

Prior to the ODI Paul worked as a consultant on information services for the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization where he contributed to the development of web-based information services.

Paul has worked on a number of database and web consultancy assignments in the UK and on overseas international cooperation projects.

Responsibilities

Programme Leader for MSc Information and Lbrary Management

Module Leader for:

  • Information Architecture
  • Information Systems and Services

Research Interests

Adoption of social media in Voluntary and Community Organisations.

ICT for International Development (ICT4D)

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Paul White
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Paul White
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Area of Expertise

Experience

I have a bachelors degree in Mathematical Sciences, a master degree in Computational Statistics and Numerical Methods and a PhD in theoretical and applied statistics.

External consultancies are arranged through the Applied Statistics and Quantitative Modelling consultancy unit (ASQM) which is based in the School of Mathematical Sciences. Consultancies internal to UWE are organised through ASQM or through the Statistical Support Unit for Research.

I am a facilitator of one-day courses in applied statistics. Course participants can be internal, or external, to the University. I Frequently run one-day courses that include -

1. An Introduction to SPSS

2. An Introduction to Inference

3. Regression Modelling

4. Logistic regression Modelling

5. Applied Multivariate Analysis

6. Analysis of variance.

Preferred Knowledge Transfer Activities

Consultancy intervention projects based at the university, or on industrial premises. Non-executive Directorship. KTP Projects. Support of placement students (UG/PG/PhD opportunities) in related projects.

Short term or long term consultancy advice to organisations and companies (arranged through ASQM).

Delivery of short courses (off the shelf courses or bespoke courses).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Peter Hale
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Peter Hale
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am a Researcher in the final year of my PhD. I specialise in devising ways of making it easier for users to create their own software, to achieve this I apply Semantic Web techniques. My current research is on a technique of 'User Driven Modelling/Programming'. My intention is to enable non-programmers to create software from a user interface that allows them to model a particular problem or scenario. This involves a user entering information visually in the form of a tree diagram. I am attempting to develop ways of automatically translating this information into program code in a variety of computer languages. This is important and useful for many employees that have insufficient time to learn programming languages. My aim is to give those whose main expertise is not programming alternatives to developing using spreadsheets or HTML. These alternatives can make it easier for software systems to manage and enable sharing of the information and programs people create. My PhD subject is User Driven Programming.

I have created examples of User Driven Modelling, which I am developing to aid computer literate users to create software models. These examples are applied to aircraft cost optimisation, though the technique should have a wide range of applications firstly in modelling and eventually more general applications. I am putting as many as possible of these examples onto a web site and seeking comments and feedback for testing these techniques.

I'm an International Research Associate for the Institute for End User Computing http://www.ieuc.org/home.html. I'm interested in becoming involved with KTP (Knowledge Transfer Partnerships) and/or Consultancy for software development.

I am married, and my wife's name is Jo.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Peter Rawlings
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Peter Rawlings
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Area of Expertise

My main areas of expertise are information systems development - data management and modelling. I have used SQL/Oracle database management systems. I have been involved in veterinary and medical epidemiology, particularly modelling approaches and influence of climate on disease outbreaks. I am now teaching project management, using my experience in national and international research projects as the basis.

Experience and Qualifications

I have been a consultant in several different situations: for the IT National Training Organisation on "The current status of IT graduates from Higher Education in UK" in cooperation with Professor Ken Jukes; for the Institute for Animal Health, Pirbright, Surrey on Arboviral diseases in Southern Africa; for SODETEG (France) and the African Development Bank on a study called "Etude de faisibilit de l'levage dans les provinces du nord du Gabon", which looked at the introduction of small scale livestock farming in an endemic human sleeping sickness area of Africa. Before joining UWE, I was a Senior Scientific Officer for the Institute for Animal Health, Pirbright Laboratory on an EU funded project entitled "African horse sickness in Europe". I was also a consultant for the International Trypanotolerance Centre, The Gambia for "Development of a prototype expert system for tsetse trypanosomiasis challenge assessment" as a sequel to being a Technical Cooperation Officer/Entomologist for the Overseas Development Administration and the International Trypanotolerance Centre, The Gambia on the project entitled "Assessement of tsetse challenge to village-based trypanotolerant cattle.

Preferred Knowledge Transfer Activities

Work with the health sector on project management and information systems development projects, such as a small project with a Pulmonary Rehabilitation Outreach Project in South West Bristol area.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Philip Sewell
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Philip Sewell
rdf:Description.p:biography: I received my BEng degree in Mechanical Engineering in 1999 and a PhD in the field of Prosthetic Design in 2003 from the University of the West of England. My research interests include the design of novel tools for the development of the prosthetic fitting process, the development of techniques to determine the stress distributions between the residual limb and prosthetic socket, and experimental and numerical stress analysis.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Praminda Caleb-Solly
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Praminda Caleb-Solly
rdf:Description.p:biography: I am a lecturer based in the faculty of Computing, Engineering and Mathematical Sciences at the University of the West of England. My main teaching subject area is Human-Computer Interaction. I trained as an electronic engineer and have an MSc in Biomedical Instrumentation Engineering. I have a long-standing involvement in the application of adaptive non-linear learning techniques to a range of medically related problems. My main research interests lie in the area of adaptive computing techniques for knowledge discovery. I am also interested in the development of interactive evolutionary systems and related HCI issues and this was the main theme of my PhD work.
