rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Quan Min Zhu
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Quan Min Zhu
rdf:Description.p:biography:
My research interests are in the field of Nonlinear system modelling, identification, and control, and Electro-acupuncture instrumentation.

I am editor for the International Journal of Modelling, Information and Control.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Ramin Amali
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Ramin Amali
rdf:Description.p:biography: I have received my BEng, MSc and PhD in the field of Mechanical Engineering. My research background includes the design of technical apparatuses and devices and has recently investigated combining Artificial Intelligence techniques and Finite Element Analysis to solve direct and inverse domain problems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Rhys Gwynllyw
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Rhys Gwynllyw
rdf:Description.p:biography: My research interests are in Computational Fluid Dynamics, specifially in Groundwater Flows, Non-Newtonian Flows, and Superfluid Taylor-Couette Flows. I also have a research interest in Computer Aided Assessment in Mathematics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Richard McClatchey
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Richard McClatchey
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Area of Expertise

Databases, large-scale distributed systems and object-based system modelling, recently Grid computing

Experience

I am a Fellow of the British Computer Society and Chartered IT Practioner. I'm also a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical Engineers and a Chartered Engineer. I have 25 years experience in consultancy and applied research.

Research Interests

My interests are applied computer science consultancy including KTP Projects. Research project partnerships (DTI, EC, EPSRC,etc.). Supervision of part-time and full-time PhD or MPhil students. Non-executive Directorships

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Rob Stephens
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Rob Stephens
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Research Interests

Application of the dialogic theory of M.M. Bakhtin into a computing and information systems context.

Evolution of computing and information systems in society

Computing Ethics

Knowledge acquisition and representation

Web-site designer and administrator for Living Easton (local community and history group).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Robert Laister
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Robert Laister
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have been a Lecturer in Applied Mathematics at UWE since 1997.

I am experienced in non-local reaction-diffusion equations, delay-differential equations, differential-algebraic equations (DAEs), and quasi-linear PDEs.

My other research interests are Parabolic PDE with delay, Non-local elliptic and parabolic PDE, Reaction-diffusion equations, Degenerate diffusion and quasilinear PDE, Differential algebraic equations (DAE), and Applications in population dynamics / mathematical biology.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Robert Marsh
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Robert Marsh
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I am a research fellow in the Systems Engineering, Estimation and Decision Support research group in CEMS. My current research interests are related to cost estimation in early design, used to inform decision making in the design process. These interests are also aligned to modelling the inspection process, and the resolution of uncertainty in the inspection process, which formed part of my PhD. A categorised list of research areas follows:

The semantic representation of manufacturing models for the purposes of cost estimation.

The representation and resolution of epistemic uncertainty in manufacturing models.

The automated, modular construction of models.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Siamak Noroozi
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Siamak Noroozi
rdf:Description.p:biography: I am a Principal Lecturer and the MMA schools Research Leader. I am also the director of the Computational Mechanics (CM) research group at UWE. I am a Sheffield University graduate and have been research active since 1982. I have been involved in the development of Finite Element (FEA) and Boundary Element Analysis (BEA) programmes since 1982. In 1986 I developed a theory that combined FEA with BEA. I have linked my research to many other areas such as: the development and implementation of curvilinear anisotropy in FEA for the analysis and simulation of natural composite materials; BEA and its application to potential problems; biomechanics of prosthetic socket fit; Load determination between prosthetic socket and residual limb for people with below knee amputations; condition monitoring of rotating machinery; condition monitoring of advanced manufacturing cells; advanced theoretical and experimental stress analysis including the application of FEA, transducers and photo-elastic methods; Aero-elasticity of smart bend twist adaptive wind turbine blades etc. Since 1996 I have worked on the development of real time solvers for solving both direct and inverse problems which has resulted in the development of a generalised hybrid inverse problem engine. Over a number of years, I have worked with many industrial companies such as Conder, Renishaw, Airbus at different levels, from running professional courses to working with them on collaborative PhD and MEng research projects such as investigating and testing novel composite (CFRP, GFRP) products and joints, developing condition monitoring systems and machine tool calibration transducer artefacts etc. I have many successful PhD completions and have over 70 high quality publications.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Sophie Cunliffe
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Sophie Cunliffe
rdf:Description.p:biography:
My first degree was in Mechanical Design, Materials and Manufacture at the University of Nottingham. Having secured a Dyson Schlorship I went on to complete a Masters degree in Industrial Design Engineering at The Royal College of Art as a joint course with Imperial College London. During my time at The Royal College of Art I worked with the Helen Hamlyn Research Centre taking a socially inclusive approach to design through practical research and projects with industry.

Since graduation my commercial experience has included working as a Product Design Engineer for Logistix, a promotional marketing agency, developing fast moving consumer goods, promotional and retail products for large household brands such as Coca Cola, L'Oreal and Nokia. Further to this, I moved on to work for Dyson as a Design Engineer within their International Team developing next generation product ideas.

I have worked as a Visiting Lecturer within UWE's Creative Product Design course since January 2006, before taking up a full time position as Lecturer of Product Design in August 2006.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Stephen Ryrie
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Stephen Ryrie
rdf:Description.p:biography: My research interest are Mathematics, and Population Dynamics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Stewart Green
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Stewart Green
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have been a Senior Lecturer in the Faculty of Computing, Engineering and Mathematical Sciences (CEMS) at the University of the West of England since 1992. While working at UWE, I attained my doctorate on a synthesised approach to goal-oriented requirements engineering from Imperial College, London. Before starting at UWE, I was a Research Assistant at King's College, London, where I worked on the Generic Modelling and Requirements Capture (GMARC) project. I worked there after completing an MSc in the Foundations of Advanced Information Systems at Imperial College.

Prior to moving into Higher Education, I spent eleven years in industry working in turn for ICL, British Aerospace, and Prime Computers. At Prime I helped to develop the data dictionary product and an automatic transaction generator.

My interests in computing include software engineering, in particular requirements engineering and formal methods; I am also interested in the relationship between organisational processes and computer-based process support. Outside work I play tennis, and I also enjoy reading and listening to music.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Terry Winnington
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Terry Winnington
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I Originally trained as a Mechanical Engineer with Westland Aircraft Ltd having joined them as an apprentice in 1965! I have University teaching Experience in UK and Africa. I have worked in industry for 20 years managing R and D Projects, and Businesses. My experience is in Aerospace, Consumer Durables, White Goods, and Chemical Processing. My management roles as General Manager and Managing Director.

I Joined UWE in September 2003 as a Senior Lecturer.

My Research interests include - Systems Engineering and Project Management.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Tim Swift
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Tim Swift
rdf:Description.p:biography:
I have been employed at the University of the West of England as a senior lecturer in Mathematics since January 2000.  Before that, I worked as a teacher and researcher in Mathematics at the following institutions:  University of Cambridge; University of Edinburgh; University of Southampton; La Sainte Union College.

I have a wide variety of experience in undergraduate and postgraduate teaching across the spectrum of Pure and Applied Mathematics, this experience being gained over a period of 25 years.  I have taught students of Mathematics as well as students in other disciplines such as Biology, Business, Chemistry, Computer Science, Economics, Education, Engineering, and Physics.

My research background is in Mathematical Physics, especially the theory of general relativity, and in Differential Geometry, especially infinite-dimensional geometry.  My recent work has been in symplectic geometry.  I am interested also in the applications of Mathematics to modelling biological systems.

I was born in Holmfirth - in the West Riding of Yorkshire - and I spent the first 18 years of my life in a nearby village.  My post-school formal education took place at the University of Cambridge and at the University of Southampton.  My interests outwith Mathematics include the following:  cinema; international affairs; jogging; languages; music; theatre; travel; walking.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Toby OHara
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Toby OHara
rdf:Description.p:biography: After 20 years as a software engineer, I began a PhD in evolutionary computing and in particular an accuracy based Learning Classifier System (XCS) with neural representation. My future work will, if fate allows, continue to research hybrids involving accuracy based classifier systems and neural networks. In these systems the classifiers or rules partition the problem space and give a rating or score to each artificial neural network that describes a partition or partitions. In addition rules containing more than one network can use the second network trained by supervised learning for other tasks such as anticipating future states.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Tony Drewry
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Tony Drewry
rdf:Description.p:biography:
Expertise

My main areas of expertise are in System Analysis, Data modelling, and Databases, Web Design and Development

Experience

Employment in industry building Oracle databases; 15 years teaching and building Web Based Information Systems

Preferred Knowledge Transfer Activities

Consultancy. Research project partner (DTI, EU, EPSRC,etc.). KTP Projects. Supervision of part-time PhD students. Support of placement students.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Tony Pipe
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Tony Pipe
rdf:Description.p:biography:
My research interests are Bio-electronics, Biologically plausible robotics, Fuzzy Learning Classifier Systems.

The Bio-electronics group that I'm involved, with has a scope that ranges from applications of electronics to medical systems through to biologically-inspired machine intelligence. Current topics that the group are involved with include; hormone level tracking using microscopic magnets, electroacupuncture, Immunotronics (self-healing VLSI circuits), embedding mammalian brain function in VLSI circuits, implementing evolutionary computation, neural networks and fuzzy systems directly on VLSI circuits, and developing the silicon retina into a visual object recognition system.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Vicki Pearcy
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Vicki Pearcy
rdf:Description.p:biography: I am responsible for the recording of faculty H&S issues, such as management of hazardous equipment, risk assessments, accident reporting, updating of the CEMS H&S handbook, etc. Member of several working groups dealing with manual handling, VDU risk assessments, etc. Also responsible for developing and carrying out H&S training as and when required, as well as H&S induction training for all new staff members. Also, the organisation and issue of eye test authorisation scheme. Providing administrative support to Technical Resources Manager, co-ordinating of technical support staff appraisal process. I also provide secretarial support to H&S Committee.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Vicky Pearcy
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Vicky Pearcy
rdf:Description.p:biography: I am responsible for the recording of faculty H&S issues, such as management of hazardous equipment, risk assessments, accident reporting, updating of the CEMS H&S handbook, etc. Member of several working groups dealing with manual handling, VDU risk assessments, etc. Also responsible for developing and carrying out H&S training as and when required, as well as H&S induction training for all new staff members. Also, the organisation and issue of eye test authorisation scheme. Providing administrative support to Technical Resources Manager, co-ordinating of technical support staff appraisal process. I also provide secretarial support to H&S Committee.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Vince Coveney
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Vince Coveney
rdf:Description.p:biography: I Received a BA in Physics from York and a PhD from the CNAA in tribology (cavitation between immersed rollers). After doing research in printing (at UMIST) and on the dynamic mechanical behaviour of superconductors and other materials at low temperatures (Bristol) I worked on the development, characterisation and application of elastomeric materials at the Malaysian Rubber Producers' Research Association at Hertford. At UWE since 1991, my current research interests cover: the science and engineering of elastomers; measurement, modelling and simulation for engineering in urology; other aspects of soft tissue behaviour; hand-arm-vibration syndrome.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Windy Hon
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Windy Hon
rdf:Description.p:biography: The main role of my task is responsible for student administration for letters from A to K. I am the clerk for the Faculty Research Committee and the Graduate School Executive. I also edit the Research and Graduate School Newsletter and organise special events like Poster and Social Event and Graduate School Student Conference.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Liz Falconer
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Liz Falconer
rdf:Description.p:biography:
E-Learning Development Co-ordinator

I am the E-learning Co-ordinator for the university and am situated in IT Services. I work closely with all faculties and services to support technology enhanced learning developments, and whilst not a member of CEMS faculty, I am working with a number of course teams on developments for distance and online learning. I am also the leader of a project to provide an interactive online research methods teaching and learning resource, the Research Observatory (http://www.uwe.ac.uk/ro), which is being developed to provide an effective support resource for students undertaking research as all or part of their studies, and also as a vehicle for research into learning environment and interface design.

I started my working life as an Environmental Health Officer in a local authority in Cheshire in 1978, moving on to private industry (British Oxygen) after 6 years of public sector practice in health and safety at work. In 1987 I joined University College Salford, later part of the University of Salford, lecturing in occupational safety and health. My interest in distance and online learning developed as the designer and course director of the MSc in Occupational Safety and Health, a flexible, multi-mode programme that used Blackboard 5TM as the VLE platform. In 2001 I moved to the University of Bath as Director of the Centre for Distance Education, and then joined UWE in July 2003. I completed my MPhil at Manchester Polytechnic in 1992 and my PhD at Salford University in 2001.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Manuel Frutos-Perez
rdf:Description.foaf:name: Manuel Frutos-Perez
rdf:Description.p:biography:
E-Learning Development Officer

I am the E-learning Development Officer for the university and am situated in IT Services. I work closely with all faculties and services to support technology-enhanced learning developments, and whilst not a member of CEMS faculty, I am working with a number of course teams on developments for distance and online learning. I started my academic career teaching Spanish Culture at the Johannes Kepler University of Linz in Austria after completing my first degree in Spanish and German Philology at the University of Salamanca in Spain. I moved to London in 1997 where I held different academic posts teaching Spanish language and culture at several institutions (University of Greenwich, London Business School, Goldsmiths College, Open University and Tower Hamlets College). After completing my MA in Management of Language Learning at the University of Greenwich I went on to work as an E-learning Academic Consultant for the Open University of Catalonia (UOC) in Spain from 2000 until joining UWE in 2003. The UOC is Europe's first completely virtual university. Since my time in Linz I have always been interested in the use of ICT for teaching and learning and have participated in the production of interactive CD-ROMs with the Open University and WIDA Software. I have also written and contributed to numerous textbooks and e-learning interactive materials.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIANW2-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Test Spec
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The subject of the project will be agreed between the student, the tutor and the Module Leader. Suitable topics may stem from staff, the student, the student's employer or other outside organisations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UMSCC6-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: International Business in the Emerging Markets

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: USSJ8L-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: The Art of Signal & Image Enhancement

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE73-30-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Digital Design & Instrumentation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Digital Electronic Circuits

Number systems. Logic gates. Boolean algebra. Logical minimisation. Combinational logic design. Static and dynamic hazards. Implementation using discrete gates, multiplexers, ROMs, PLAs, FPGAs. Sequential logic components. Clocking. Registers. Counters. Detect and steer method. Introduction to VHDL.

Digital System Design

State diagrams, tables and equations. State reduction. Structured state assignment. Incompletely specified state tables. Design process of synchronous sequential circuits. ASM charts and blocks. Data processor design. ASM tables and state assignment. Implementation using decoders, multiplexers and programmble devices.

Electronic interface

Monitoring and control systems, open and closed loop arrangements. Sensors including temperature, displacement and torque measurements. Basic electric circuit principles, properties of resistors, power dissipation, electric fields, simple DC circuit analysis, Kirchoffs laws. Simple AC circuit analysis, RMS, phase and frequency. Electronic components: diodes, LED, photodiode, bipolar transistor as a switch, operational amplifiers. A/D and D/A conversion.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7M-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Modern Power Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
VECTOR REPRESENTATION of POWER FLOW: Reactive Power Injection, Static Var Generation, Var Compensator under microprocessor control.

SYSTEM STABILITY: Transient and Dynamic Stability, Load Angle Oscillation, The Equal Area Criterion. LOAD FLOW STUDIES: Bus Classification, a PQ Bus, a PV Bus and a Swing Bus.

SHORT CIRCUIT ANALYSIS: Fault level for both Symmetrical & Un-Symmetrical, Low & High Impedance Faults, Short Circuit Limitations, Real Time Fault Location Based on ANN and Fuzzy.

PROTECTION SCHEMES: Distance Protection, Differential Protection, Back Up Protection, Over Current Protection and associated electronics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHP-10-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Programming in C
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Sequence, Iteration and Selection constructs within a HLL. - Simple data types, structured data types: arrays and structs. - Access scope of local and global variables. - The use of functions with parameters. - Arithmetic and logical operations. - Handling strings. - Use of pointers to access arrays and structs. - Data i/o using keyboard and screen. - Simple file handling. - Familiarisation with IDE (Integrated Development Environment) and command line operation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHU-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: IT Infrastructure
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Computer systems architecture: CPU, peripherals, memory. Operating systems: managing resources, processes, peripherals, memory and filestore. Assembly languages; general-purpose high level languages; scripting languages. Basic language processing: Assemblers, compilers.

Computer communication systems and networks: layered architectures, transmission media, error control, local area networks - topologies and protocols, LAN components. Wide area networks - circuit and packet switching. The Internet Protocol (IP) - addressing, ARP, ICMP, routing in IP. Broadband ISDN. Transport protocols. Application protocols.

Semantics and syntax of functional, rule based and object-orientated computer languages. Java Programming: Data types, statements, expressions, control and loop structures, simple data structures. Fundamental principles of object-orientated programming - inheritance, encapsulation and polymorphism.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEJ4-40-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Individual Project (Computing)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The subject of the project will be agreed between the student, his/her tutor and the Module Leader. Suitable topics may stem from staff, the student, the student\'s employer or other outside organisations.

Whatever the subject the student will be expected to treat material critically and to demonstrate his/her understanding of the relevance of material studied on the course to the specific topic studied.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEJA-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Operating Systems Programming
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Operating System Organisation: Models - monolithic, layered, process, object, virtual machines; client-server; network and distributed operating systems, kernel organisation, data structure and resources.

Process and Object Management: Kernel services; interrupt handlers; process-object descriptors; tables, state transitions; scheduling algorithms and load balancing; object invocation.

Interprocess Communication: Event handling; message passing; synchronous-synchronous shared memory. Concurrency and synchronisation: safety and liveness properties; semaphores; critical regions; monitors; message passing; multi-threaded processes. Memory Management: Real Memory Management; Organisational algorithms and policies; Virtual Memory Management; Organisation of paged and segmented systems; algorithms and strategies for page placement and replacement; Memory Management Units; garbage collection.

I/O Management: The Posix system call interface and I/O descriptors; Device Driver Design; Buffering and interrupt handling.

File and Persistent Object Management: File organisation; directories and naming; index nodes; disk block management.

Writing Device Drivers: Hardware detection and initialisation. Types of devices. Set-up and management strategies.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8Y-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Dissertation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The information systems dissertation is an individual research project which enables the student to select and investigate a topic of interest beyond or even outside the normal level of treatment in the taught modules. It is intended to be an academic intellectual exploration of a relevant topic or issue undertaken through selection, analysis and synthesis of the literature. Its primary aim, therefore, is to expose the student to the rigours of researching, planning and time management associated with any significant individual study and through this exposure to provide a focus for the development of appropriate tools, skills and disciplines necessary for the successful completion of the project.

The subject of the dissertation may stem from the student's own interests, perhaps developed from their placement or other prior experience, or from the research interests of staff.

In all cases students are expected to: identify aims and scope of their investigation; undertake a survey of relevant literature; treat material critically and demonstrate their understanding of the relationship between material covered in the taught modules and the specific topic studied. The literature survey may be supplemented with empirical work if appropriate. In concluding the dissertation, students should appraise their achievements in relation to the stated aims of their investigation and the methods use to research and write up the dissertation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEQ5-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Secure Smart Cards and Tokens
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Introduction to Smart Cards; Trusted Environment; Operating systems, Interoperability and Security USIM Cards for 3G and 4G mobile communications applications.Smart Cards for:- Secure Banking, Finance, Satellite and digital TV ; Advances in Smart Chips and Tokens for Platform & Application Security. Security Attacks, Countermeasures and Testing for Smart Cards. Use of application Development Environments such as Java Card Development Toolkit (JCDT) and SIM Toolkit.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEPP-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Project Management (E-Learning)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. 1. General: the use of given mathematical formulae (including exponential and logarithmic functions), both on a calculator and in spreadsheets. This will feed into an understanding of how parametric models use linear regression theory and measures of performance on past projects.
  2. 2. Project Development Matching projects to some established procedures, usually termed system life cycle models, which include traditional, evolutionary, prototyping and DSDM.
  3. 3. Project Team The role of the project manager; typical group and team structures; qualities and skills of managers; team dynamics; leadership and management qualities.
  4. 4. Project Planning Establishing what the planning criteria are, the use of work breakdown structures (WBS), milestones, deliverables, activity planning and considerations of team size.
  5. 5. Estimating Planning requires estimates and was is in an estimate needs consistency, hence the use of effort, time and manpower, together with what are the appropriate units for these. Using data from past projects in parametric cost modelling (e.g. COCOMO, Putnam and Mk II Function Point Analysis) is an important part of estimating.
  6. 6. Organising and Controlling Projects The project management team needs tools and techniques including; activity lists, bar charts, arrow and precedence diagrams. Often, management requires aids to visibility and management of what the models indicate, such as cascade activity numbering and cascade bar charts. These can be achieved using software tools, including spreadsheets (particularly Excel), drawing packages (e.g. Visio) and project management software (e.g. MS Project). A checkable project management program for research and student use is under development.
  7. 7. Resources and Time Managers need to use activity lists and bar charts to allocate resources efficiently. Levelling resources is often necessary by taking up float on non-critical paths, or dealing with single and multiple critical paths. Calculating float from start and finish times and the critical path is necessary, as is resource productivity.
  8. 8. Project finance Finance needs to be treated as a resource to calculate the cumulative cost of a project but time has an influence, hence the use of earned value and cost-to-complete as measures of cash flow.
  9. 9. Risk An introduction to risk assessment techniques; control and contingent risks; triggers and modifications to the precedence diagram; analysis by risk zones and action plans.
  10. 10. Quality Control This is tied to risk and how to measure quality. Planning systems for quality, quality assurance reviews, design walkthroughs and inspections. Knowing the contents of a quality plan and factors that affect quality.
  11. 11. Project Administration Project documentation, reviews and configuration management with change control.
  12. 12. Report Writing Bringing together all parts of the reporting on a project plan and project review is complex. Understanding and presentation is key, including the role and contents of appendices and the links between them. The assignment is a complete project report and a critical analysis of methods and choices. The appendices are: i) an estimate ii) work breakdown structure iii) activity list iv) precedence diagram v) cascade diagram (Gantt chart) vi) resource schedule and cumulative cost curve vii) quality plan, and viii) risk analysis.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPES6-30-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Product Design Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design Methods: the design process, and the systematic approach to design problems: requirement analysis, problem identification, problem solving methods, problem solving tools, preparation of specifications, solution identification and design. Principles of embodiment design.

Engineering Drawing: sketching. principles of projection: third angle and isometric views. Basic standard conventions using British Standards. Use of simple software design tools eg 2D and 3D CAD.

Practical Skills: follow through the design, build, test cycle as part of a group project. within the practical environment of the design studios and workshop. Present the results, documenting the design process and including an analysis of the standard and accuracy of the work produced.

Professional Skills: completion of workbook to demonstrate effective use of the library. Time management, working in groups, oral and written presentation skills, basic project management. Reflection on learning achieved.

Legislation: an outline of current UK and EU environmental legislation, and the meaning of the term Design for the Environment. An understanding of the principles of sustainability.

Ergonomics: an introduction to ergonomics, with reference to the needs of inclusive design principles.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEV7-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Work-based Production 1
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Identification and recording of achievements and personal skills; use of personal development analytical tools (e.g. SWOT analysis, time management techniques, SMART objectives, 360 feedback, benchmarking); identification of structure of work-placement organization (showing lines of accountability, authority and control) and the students role and responsibilities in that organization; methods of communication in the organization; analysis of potential conflict situations and methods for dealing with conflict; techniques of constructive feedback; guidance on job application and interview techniques; completing of work-based learning period(s).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEF3-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Logistics Optimisation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The Roles of Logistics and Business Optimisation. The management science approach to problem solving. Types of logistics problems amenable to optimisation. The optimisation modelling process.

Linear Programming for logistics. The components and specification of LP models. Different approaches to solving LP problems. Underlying assumptions of linear programming. Special-purpose LP algorithms (e.g. Transportation and Assignment problems). Logistics network models (e.g., Shortest-path, Maximum flow, covering, partitioning and spanning). Integer linear programming models for logistics. Production and supply chain planning, scheduling and optimisation. Use of spreadsheet and specialist optimisation modelling languages. Practical aspects of combinatorial optimisation applied to logistics problems. Introduction to metaheuristic optimisation methods for complex logistics problems.

Inventory Control: Deterministic and stochastic models, The EOQ model, the economic production lot size model, inventory models with planned shortages, quantity discounts and the EOQ model, models for the re-order level and periodic review systems, probabilistic demand models, use of simulation in solving stochastic inventory models.

Critical Path Analysis: The Critical Path Method. Project scheduling with uncertain activity times (PERT). Gantt charts, crashing activities Planning and scheduling project costs. Optimisation of projects.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETR-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematics, Statistics and Operational Research (MSOR) Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The nature of the project will vary according to the topic which is being investigated. The aim of the project is to provide an opportunity for a significant, in-depth, individual study of a problem which arises in a mathematical, statistical or operational research context. In the project, a selection of concepts or tools from across the programme of study can be integrated and refined in order to analyse and to solve the problem at hand. The topic chosen for investigation might originate from the student's own particular interests, from the students placement year, or from a lecturers suggestion.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDH-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Mechatronics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The syllabus may include but not be limited to the followings:

MECHANICAL ELEMENTS: Acceleration, Velocity, Torque, Inertia; Mechanical transmission; Gearboxes, pulley, belt and chains; Linear and Rotary bearings; Machine screws and Splined shafts

SYSTEMS INTEGRATION: Rotary and linear electric motors, gearboxes ,shafts integration

SYSTEMS MODELLING and CONTROL: Open, close loop control; Novel controllers; System performance measures; Controllers PC and PLC and Embedded; Software for control, Languages and Platforms

Examples of mechatronic systems may include: Robots and Machine tools; Car Engine management system; Washing machine control

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEUH-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Requirements Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module examines the contribution that knowledge of requirements makes to the production of systems. It considers a variety of different approaches to requirements development process and considers their strengths and weaknesses.

  • Rationale for requirements- why bother?
  • What is a requirement?
  • Stakeholders
  • Examples of good and bad practice
  • Placing requirements within the context of Systems Engineering:
  • What is Requirements Engineering?
  • Component parts of the Requirements Engineering process
  • Characteristics of requirements
  • Types of requirements
  • Non-functional requirements
  • Prioritising requirements
  • Validating requirements
  • Managing requirements
  • Requirements Engineering tools
  • Role-playing activity
  • Case Study

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBG-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to Mechanical Principles
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to units and problem solving techniques.

Equilibrium, free body diagrams, frameworks, axial stress and strain.

Displacement velocity and acceleration, scalars and vectors, relative and absolute quantities, projectiles, Newton's laws, gravity, D'Alembert's principle, moments of inertia

Hydrostatics, Bernoulli's equation, flow measurement.

Pressure and temperature, work, heat and energy, open and closed systems, analysis of open and closed systems, simplifications for incompressible fluids.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UMEDEB-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: The Business and Economies of Fun and Games

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: USPJDR-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Issues in the Psychology of Work

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEVF-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Energy and Environment Management Tools
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Performance limitations and inefficiencies
  • Embedded software solutions
  • Vehicle behaviour modelling as a tool for algorithm development
  • Controlled power flow and intelligent drivetrains, including hybrids
  • Design for purpose, consideration of compromise solutions
  • Effective management of fuels and emissions

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEAG-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Health Informatics Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The student will have the opportunity to negotiate the content of the project with tutors at the university and with the management of an appropriate host organization, normally his or her place of current or recent employment, where this is possible. If this is not possible, the student will be supported in the search for an appropriate host.

The 'project' may be an in-depth intellectual study of a particular problem or issue of IM&T in Health Care, or it may be an analysis of the information requirements of a department and a proposed design of a system to address these requirements. In-between these polar examples, any well argued for and suitably negotiated mix of library study, empirical analysis and requirements definition through to design can be acceptable, provided this is so to the candidate, the supervisor and the host organization.

The project must have well defined process and outcome objectives which can be measured effectively at the end; these measures will contribute the major part of the student's final mark in the module.

The nature of the research will vary according to the subject to be addressed. The core module in Research Methods requires students to develop an initial research proposal and students are expected to evaluate this proposal and determine how to take it forward in their dissertation. (This may involve writing a fresh proposal in agreement with their supervisor.) Dissertation topics will focus on some aspect(s) of information technology as it is or may be applied in particular health care contexts. Students are expected to carry out an in-depth survey of relevant literature. It is also likely that some primary research will be necessary to ensure that an investigation contributes to existing work in the field. Such primary research will involve a degree of methodological choice, to be justified in the context of the particular subject and circumstances. The written dissertation must make clear how the primary research was designed and conducted and discussion of the outcomes of primary research should be clearly related to existing literature. The body of the dissertation should be supplemented by a critical review of relevant aspects of the research process, including the design and production of the report itself.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGX-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Quantitative Methods Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The nature of the project will vary according to the subject which is being addressed. The aim of the project is to provide an in depth study of a topic applicable to a business decision making environment. It is intended to give the opportunity to integrate a number of the areas of study undertaken across the award. The topic chosen may come from a student's own particular interest, from industry or commerce during the placement period or through personal contacts.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEKM-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: DSP for Real Time Control Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Theory: DSP design flow, Texas Instrument F2812 processor architecture, F2812 peripherals (mainly, the Analog-to-Digital converter and the event manager), and an integrated hardware/software design methodology.

Practical: A series of lab-based exercises using Code Composer Studio (CCS) integrated development environment and the eZdspTM F2812 development kit. The programming languages adopted are assembly and C/C++.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEETT-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Digital Design and Instrumentation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Digital Electronic Circuits

Number systems. Logic gates. Boolean algebra. Logical minimisation. Combinational logic design. Static and dynamic hazards. Implementation using discrete gates, multiplexers, ROMs, PLAs, FPGAs. Sequential logic components. Clocking. Registers. Counters. Detect and steer method. Introduction to VHDL.

Digital System Design

State diagrams, tables and equations. State reduction. Structured state assignment. Incompletely specified state tables. Design process of synchronous sequential circuits. ASM charts and blocks. Data processor design. ASM tables and state assignment. Implementation using decoders, multiplexers and programmable devices.

Electronic interface

Monitoring and control systems, open and closed loop arrangements. Sensors including temperature, displacement and torque measurements. Basic electric circuit principles, properties of resistors, power dissipation, electric fields, simple DC circuit analysis, Kirchoffs laws. Simple AC circuit analysis, RMS, phase and frequency. Electronic components: diodes, LED, photodiode, bipolar transistor as a switch, operational amplifiers. A/D and D/A conversion.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEUC-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Group Project Challenge
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: As this is a Project Module, there is no detailed syllabus for this course. Instead, students construct their own syllabus as they carry out their project.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8K-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Data Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Overview of data management. Methods of data organisation and access. From files to databases. Database architectures. Database Management Systems (DBMS). Distributed databases and distributed DBMS.

Database design methods and methodology. Fact finding and requirements determination prior to design. Conceptual, logical, and physical design. Data analysis and design within systems analysis and design. Database design within a system development methodology.

Entity Modelling. Entities, attributes and relationships. E-R diagramming. UML notation for ER diagrams.

Relational modelling. Tables, relations, attributes, and normalisation. Relational algebra and calculus.

SQL: the Structured Query Language. Syntax and application.

Object-oriented approaches. Classes and instances; association and aggregation. Generalisation and inheritance. Object-relational DBMSs.

Data management in the organisational context. Database administration and management. Overview of database application areas. Introduction to, and uses and characteristics of: knowledge bases and knowledge management systems (KBS/KMS); online analytical processing (OLAP); data warehouses; data mining.

Developments in database systems. WWW as an emerging platform for database applications. XML and query languages for XML. Multimedia databases. Document management systems and digital libraries. Spatial and temporal databases. Active databases. Mobile databases.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8P-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Practice 2
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFIE8N-20-1 OR UFIEKD-20-1 OR UFIEQQ-20-1 OR UFMEVC-20-1)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The syllabus is generally organised into 5 main stages of work:-

  1. Preparation and planning: key concepts in IS practice are introduced, and students are prepared in a range of ways for stages 2 to 5, and briefed on the ensuing project work requirements;
  2. IS investigation: a short practical project to prepare, conduct, review and document an IS investigation in a real organisation is carried out, embracing technical and social elements from a user perspective;
  3. Project definition: opportunities for IS improvement identified in stage 2 are reviewed by students in conjunction with sponsor and supervisor, and a practical project aimed at bringing about a small IS change of some kind is negotiated and documented;
  4. IS change project: the project defined in stage 3 is executed, monitored and controlled;
  5. Review and write-up: the project is reviewed and documented from an academic perspective.

Students are given initial exposure to a wide range of topics from amongst the following:-

  • The nature of IS practice and the relationships between organisations, IS and IT
  • Understanding and interpreting IS in the workplace, including their technical and social characteristics and their relationships with business functions and objectives
  • The diversity, uncertainty and complexity involved in contemporary patterns of human usage of IT in the workplace, across a range, including end user IS and strategic approaches as well as a focus on individual corporate systems
  • Defining, planning, monitoring and controlling IS projects
  • Team-working, team roles, delegation, time management, reporting and accountability
  • Working collaboratively with peers, users and business or technical specialists orally, electronically and in writing
  • Understanding and questioning assumptions, expectations and opportunities surrounding IT in the workplace
  • Technology, its social context and the search for a good fit between the two; IS maintenance
  • The IS practitioner as methodologist: exploring, using and evaluating methods, techniques and tools from across a range; reflective practice as self-development

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETL-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Applications of Statistics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Following an introduction covering common areas of statistical testing and methodologies, students will have the opportunity to choose from two pathways. Each will explore statistical modelling drawing upon topics either from medical and industrial or from socio-economic and business application areas. Indicative contents will include:

Model selection, derivation and properties of estimators.

Violation of model assumptions.

Modelling and estimation of simultaneous equation systems.

Time series and forecasting methods.

Design and planning of experiments.

Diagnostic testing.

Survival analysis.

Statistical process control.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDR-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Project Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The module aims to review the main theories of operations management with particular reference to systems and integrating theories. This will enable those in general and project management to use these methods to achieve complex organisational and technical goals.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4A-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Data Structures and Databases
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Relational Model: revision and extension: terminology, keys, integrity. relational algebra.

SQL: table creation and maintenance, simple queries, calculations and functions, groups and group functions, joining tables, subqueries, views.

PL/SQL: blocks, cursors, stored procedures and functions, triggers.

Physical Design Issues: file organisations - heap, hash, ISAM, B+ trees, indexing, clustering, denormalisation, disk storage, security and integrity.

Transaction Management: serialisability, concurrency control, locking, granularity, 2PL, deadlock, timestamping.

Backup and recovery: problems, transaction logging, recovery techniques.

Query Processing and Optimisation: queries and query trees, transformation to equivalent expressions, comparison of rule based v. cost based strategies.

Weaknesses of relational DBMSs.

Overview of advanced database applications.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4B-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Software Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Concepts of Object-Orientation Encapsulation and information hiding (visibility control). The representation of problem space concepts through abstraction and classification. Collaboration between objects, class relationships, lifecycle models (analysis, design, implementation).

Object-Oriented Modelling UML Models e.g. use case, class, interaction, state, activity models. Techniques for use case identification, class identification (Class / Responsibility / Collaboration ), and refining object interaction scenarios. Refactoring class models to reflect inheritance and polymorphism.

Software Design Architectures The role of decomposition, components / subsystems, interfaces, separation of concerns, layers, architectural styles and patterns.

Software Design Principles The Law of Demeter, DIP Principle, Liskov Principle, and the Open/Closed Principle.

Patterns Definition, history of patterns, pattern languages, pattern communities. Design patterns both from general usage (e.g. Model-View-Controller, iterator, wrapper) and from Gamma et al. (Gang of Four) e.g. creational, structural, behavioural categories of patterns.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHL-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Integrated Case Studies
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEEHG-30-2 OR UFCE4B-20-2 OR UFPENX-20-2 OR UFPENB-10-2 OR UFEE69-20-2)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Not Applicable

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHV-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The Von Neumann Inheritance: digital logic, CPU& fetch-execute, microcode, migration of functionality, the RISC/CISC debate, the bus bottleneck, future architectures: multiprocessors, distributed data.

CPU architecture, adders/subtractors in two's complement integer format, decoders, barrel shifters.

From Hex to X: machine code, assembler routines, compiled & interpreted languages, compiler/interpreter strategies, linking, Win32 libraries, using debuggers.

How Windows Work: video subsystems, graphic primitives, graphics coprocessors, multitasking, input from mice, network communication, X protocols, Client-server applications.

The Network as a Computing Environment: network applications, WWW, ftp, telnet, email, ping address resolution, ip name, ip number, mac number, hosts file, arp/rarp networked operating systems, Unix, Windows/NT introduction to basic facilities, sockets, rpcs, rcp, NFS/mount, the tx/rx of data packets ethernet cards video/voice transmission.

Networking from Nothing: serial communications through the COM ports. Packet addressing, routing and flow control. Handling errors with a checksum.

Choosing and Using Peripherals: CD-ROM and hard-disk units, the IDE and SCSII interfaces, disc organisation and directory structures, laser printers, introduction to PostScript, graphic subsystems, document scanners.

Estimating disk access and data transmission times.

Using Unix as a software tool-bench.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEJ6-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Distributed Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Distributed System Issues, Properties & Services: location & access; security; availability; management.

Distributed Object Models & Architecture\'s: Inter Process Communication; characteristics; TLI primitives; RPC\'s; remote object invocation; Group Communication characteristics; atomic multicast; FIFO atomic multicast; causal atomic multicast; sync ordering atomic multicast; ISIS case study.

Naming: bindings & mappings; scaling & consistency; examples DNS, X500.

Global States & Time: The problem of clock distribution over an arbitrary network; clock synchronisation; event ordering; logical & vector clocks; distributed snapshots and stable property detection; global predicates.

Distributed Atomic Transactions and Objects: event ordering & serialisation; locking & timestamp techniques; failure recovery; two phase commit protocol (consensus problem) non blocking commit protocols; nested transactions; deadlock detection.

Fault Tolerance: fault classification schemes; the primary backup approach; active replication; reaching agreement in the presence of faults; the co ordinated attack problem; k agreement; fault diagnosis & reconfiguration.

Intelligent & Co operative Distributed Systems: agent architecture\'s; co ordination & negotiation in agent systems; agent communication.

Security: security policies; security mechanisms; encryption algorithms; authentication; access control; auditing.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEG4-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Numerical Analysis
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations:

Methods and analysis for the numerical solution of initial value problems; single step and linear multi-step schemes, convergence, local and global error analysis, adaptive schemes, inherent and induced stability, application of methods to first order systems. One-dimensional boundary value problems; finite difference schemes.

Numerical solution of partial differential equations:

Methods and analysis for the numerical solution of elliptic, parabolic and hyperbolic second order problems. Finite difference schemes and the method of characteristics; truncation and discretisation errors; consistency, convergence and stability; solving systems of linear algebraic equations; different types of boundary conditions; rectangular and non rectangular grids.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEUB-40-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Individual Project (Music Technology)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The Individual Project (Music Technology) is an individually executed project which enables the student to select and investigate a topic of interest beyond or even outside the normal level of treatment in the taught modules. It will allow the student to demonstrate skills, abilities and creativity within the chosen area as well as the ability to present their ideas and achievements to a wider audience.

The subject of the project will be agreed between the student, the tutor and the module leader. Suitable topics may stem from staff, the student, the student's employer or other outside organisations. It must involve research followed by software, hardware or other artefact development derived from it. Projects may, exceptionally, be research focused, however, clear solutions or recommendations must be developed from the research undertaken. A degree of creativity will be expected, dependant upon the topic chosen.

Whatever the subject, the student will be expected to treat material critically and to demonstrate their understanding of the relevance of material from their award to the project topI.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEEM-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer-Aided Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Representing Geometry

Review of requirements of design descriptions in different fields of engineering design. Parametic methods of curve and surface modelling based on Hermite and B-spline techniques. Creation of geometric models and principles of representation of wire-frame, surface and solid models.

Boundary and constructive solid geometry representations of solids. Role of the CAD solid model as basis for product description and specification and design analysis. Review of software packages for CAD; their structure and capabilities. Integration Issues:

Use of CAD as a mechanism for integrating engineering activities within an engineering organisation, such as analysis and product development. Role of CAD within concurrent and simultaneous engineering. Data exchange standards, such as DXF, IGES and STEP.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEUV-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Flight Control and Simulation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Control theory for open and closed loop control of flight manoeuvres and flight simulation
  • An overview of the construction of a flight simulator and the integration of its sub-systems
  • Knowledge of the sub-systems especially for control and flight including autopilots and motion bases
  • The basics of the typical software systems and architecture in flight simulators, real-time systems and I/O computers, control loading systems for stick and rudder forces
  • flight computer and flight models, aerodynamic considerations and approximations
  • simulation of aircraft systems including landing gear, variable thrust, CofG movement, and aircraft system failure
  • flight simulation cues for simulating aircraft movement and sounds
  • visual system software including head-up display, scenery, weather and terrain models, 3D perception projection and synthetic vision
  • the human-in-the-loop: the physiological and psychological aspects of flight simulators, flight displays and motion-based simulators, safety aspects
  • the use of flight simulators in aircraft design, stability and control studies, flight handling, pilot-training, airworthiness and certification, and research

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE6C-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Industrial Control
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Measurement & Electronics:

Parameter measurement including position, speed, strain, temperature, light intensity. Introduction to electronic components (passive & active) with particular reference to sensor systems. Laboratory-based review of manual measurement (use of oscilloscopes, meters, DVMs, etc.). Basic computer interfacing, continuous and sampled systems, brief review of electronic integrated circuits including op-amps, A-D/D-A.

Electrical machines and drives:

DC machines: characteristics :series, shunt, compound. Brushless DC motors. AC machines: basic characteristics: induction, synchronous. Stepper motors. DC motor/servo drive systems, bridge/ PWM. AC motor drives, induction, variable frequency. Stepper motor drives. Size/type for particular application, characteristics.

System Modelling:

Modelling of simple linear systems as differential equations. Using the operator \'s\' (using cross-discipline examples, ie electrical, mechanical, thermal, fluid, etc.). Use of the transfer function form for modelling. System classification. Introduction to state space techniques.

Closed and open loop:

Introduction to feedback and its effect on system performance. Use of block diagrams. Manipulation and simplification using block diagram algebra.

System performance:

Response of systems to standard inputs in the time domain (mathematically and using computer simulation packages). Correlation of system transfer function to position of poles and zeros on the \'s\' plane, consequent relationship to transient performance. Use of frequency response techniques, Bode and Nyquist plotting. Stability criteria. Determination of transfer functions from Bode plots and vice versa. Computer simulation of frequency domain performance.

Design for specific objectives:

Compensation, two and three term controllers. Use of various techniques to achieve desired performance, frequency response methods, root locus, etc. Use of simulation package(s) to design controllers.

Industrial controllers:

Introduction to Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs), ladder logic, high level schematic systems, PID modules.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDN-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Decision Making for Manufacturing
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The aim of this module is to provide a review of the latest technologies required to manufacture and assemble aircraft to international benchmark standards of weight, quality and cost.

The module will concentrate on the implications of the new and emerging technologies:

- High Performance Machining

- Novel methods of cutting, forming and joining

- LASER Interferometry and other metrological advances

- Determinate assembly

- SPF/DB

- New composite materials: their properties, applications and manufacturing techniques

- Knowledge based Expert Systems and Finite Element Analysis as tools for Optimised Production.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDP-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Manufacturing Systems Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The module aims to provide an overview of the range of functions within a manufacturing system and the inter-relationships involved.

The structure of manufacturing resources, comparative evaluations of job shops, batch production, continuous flow systems and group technology, strengths and limitations of these structures.

Selection of process systems and manufacturing methods, use of automation and robotic systems, critique of automated assembly and production systems.

Relationship between manufacturing and the business, the strategic role of manufacturing and the need for focused manufacturing.

Design life-cycles, concurrent engineering objectives, principles and approaches, evaluation of DFX tools: for example, design for manufacture/assembly methods, review of current research issues and future directions.

Organisation of manufacturing and production facilities, tools and techniques for plant layout, introduction to simulation and modelling methods.

Tools and techniques for plant layout, line balancing methods, facilities layout methods, critical review of deterministic techniques and tools, development of software-based implementations using spreadsheets.

Need for stochastic-based evaluation tools, discrete event simulation systems, rationale for these systems, operation and implementation issues, undertaking simulation studies, statistical evaluation of results/confidence intervals.

Role and contribution of IT systems, as design tools and during plant operation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEP3-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Foundation of Systems Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Issues and problems in current engineering practice: successes and failures in large engineering projects; cost and timescale overrun and quality shortfall; team structures; communities of practice in engineering; scope and use of development and management methodologies.

Organisational context: engineering socio-technical systems; strategies for process improvement; the role of standard process models; human factors in the adoption of new techniques; organisational models and architectures; managing change.

Holistic systems engineering: scope of systems from engineering artefacts to human activity systems and complex socio-technical domains; systems thinking principles; lifecycle from problem formulation through design and manufacturing to maintenance and disposal; problem domain analysis; soft systems methods; systems dynamics.

Systematic systems engineering: user requirements elicitation; requirements validation and verification, derived and system requirements; system modelling and system modelling languages; model-driven development; risk analysis; validation and verification tools; configuration management; system integration; modelling and engineering organisational work structures and flows.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMETM-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Dissertation (CPD-Aerospace)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module requires the creation of an advanced piece of research involving in-depth enquiry into an aspect of the Aerospace Sector, with respect to Engineering. The student should identify a realisable topic, which has both the potential to contribute to knowledge of the subject and to be of relevance and interest to the Aerospace sector. It would normally be expected that the topic would arise from work identified or associated with the students role in the Aerospace industry.

The student must develop a research proposal and an associated work plan to enable them to undertake the required research, practical work (if relevant) and produce the dissertation. An in-depth survey of relevant literature should be conducted and some primary research be undertaken in order to ensure that the investigation contributes to existing research in the field. The primary research may involve a wide range of activities such as: an evaluative case study or an action research study, or developing an experimental piece of software or hardware. The written dissertation should make clear how the primary research was designed and conducted, and critically appraise the outcomes of primary research in relation to the existing literature of the field and the objectives of the project. The body of the dissertation should be supplemented by a critical review of all aspects of the research process, including the design and production of the report itself.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEER-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Business Statistics and Decision Making for Marketing
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Throughout this module emphasis will be placed on marketing applications in the following areas:

1. Surveys and sampling theory. Survey methods and data sources. Sampling and data collection.

2. Measures of location and spread. Calculation and interpretation of summary measures such as quartiles, means, weighted means and standard deviations. The use of appropriate charts of business data, such as bar charts, histograms and ogives.

3. Making inferences from sample data. Probability. The normal distribution. Confidence intervals for population mean and percentage. Hypotheses tests for population mean and percentage. Chi-square test.

4. Forecasting methods. Time series decomposition. Correlation and regression. The use of spreadsheets to facilitate these techniques.

5. Measuring change. The use of RPI and other common index measures. Calculation, manipulation and interpretation of simple and weighted indices.

6. Decision making under conditions of uncertainty. Payoff tables and decision trees. Decision makers' attitude towards risk taking. The value of perfect information.

7. Management planning tools. Critical path analysis. Resource planning.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEEX-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Elements of Statistics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Probability Theory

Permutations and combinations. Combination of probabilities. Bayes\' Theorem Properties of discrete and continuous distributions (functional form, expected values, variance) and their practical application. Study of Poisson processes and Binomial procesess and thei application in practical situations.

2. Statistical Inference applied to single sample and two sample problems.

Rationale for statistical inference. Sampling distributions. The Central Limit Theorem and the practical results from the Central Limit Theorem. The mean and variance of linear combinations of random variables. Hypothesis testing, the concept of statistical significance and p-values. Estimation of parameters and the use of confidence intervals. Rationale underpinning the correct selection of appropriate tests for parametric and non-parametric methods of analysis. Example tests include single sample t-test, two sample t-tests, Mann Whitney test, Wilcoxon test and tests involving proportions from one and two samples. Power of the test. The use of the bootstrap in formulating tests of hypothesis and estimating parameters.

3. Sampling Methods

Probability based and non-probability based sampling methods and their use with sample surveys. Analysis of proportions and means for simple random samples and for stratified samples.

4. Association, correlation and relationships between variables

Assessing association in two-way contingency tables. Quantifying the strength of relationships using bivariate correlation coefficients.

5. On-Line Quality Control

Control charts in practice, short- and medium-term variation. Moving average and range charts. Cusum charts. Charts for attribute data. Comparisons of charts: The operating characteristic and average run length. Process capability.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEMU-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Cryptography and Coding Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Cryptography Review of background mathematics: modular arithmetic, probability, gcd algorithms. Historical ciphers: letter, bigram & trigram distributions, shift, substitution, vignere & permutation ciphers, rotor machines and Enigma. Security Politics Modern Key Ciphers: stream and block ciphers, Symmetric, Asymmetric (Public & Secret Key) Transformation and substitution ciphers (DES) RSA public key (one way functions) Example Ciphers (AES, triple DES, Blowfish, IDEA, Stream Ciphers in Mobile Phones) Cryptographic Hash Functions and digital signatures (SHA1, MD5) Key Management Implementation and performance within computing systems

Error Correcting Codes Principles of correcting errors introduced through transmitting and storing data in noisy environments. Introduction to coding, information theory and the systems in which codes are used. The emphasis is on the underlying concepts governing information theory and the mathematical basis for modern coding systems, but practical details of important codes like Reed-Solomon, BCH, and Turbo codes will be analysed.

Data Compression Review of basic compression techniques: simple compression, interpolation, predictive, transform and statistical. Implementation of compression techniques within Multimedia (audio, video) and communication systems. Understanding of application requirements in terms of bandwidth, latency, cost, data loss and tolerance of errors. Analysis of relevant compression standards for music, video and communications. Knowledge of the system in which the compression techniques are used.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEPM-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Object-Orientated Design and Programming
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Concepts of Object-Orientation - Encapsulation and information hiding (visibility control). The representation of problem space concepts through abstraction and classification. Collaboration between objects, class relationships, lifecycle models (analysis, design, implementation). The challenges and rewards of achieving reuse through object-orientation.

Object-Oriented Modelling - UML Models e.g. use case, class, interaction, state, activity models. Techniques for use case identification, class identification (Class / Responsibility / Collaboration ), and refining object interaction scenarios. Refactoring class models to reflect inheritance and polymorphism.

Java Programming Language - Review of java syntax. Basic object-oriented concepts including object, object reference, class, attribute, method, encapsulation/information hiding, message passing, static members. Inheritance, abstract class, interface, polymorphism. Event-driven GUI programming

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEPU-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Dissertation (Software Engineering)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Not applicable

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEPX-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: The Semantic Grid
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Aspects of Knowledge
    • Working epistemology: introduction to theories of knowledge;
    • Taxonomies
    • Declarative/procedural, explicit/tacit, individual/community knowledge;
    • Knowledge for understanding and knowledge for action;
    • Knowledge representation logic, structure and inference;
    • Knowledge discovery.
  2. Knowledge-Based and Automatic Collaboration: the Semantic Web
    • Web services and standards in W3C;
    • XML and related extensions;
    • SOAP: a transport protocol;
    • WSDL: a description language for web services;
    • UDDI: a publication/discovery context for web services;
    • Persistency, state and workflow in web and grid services;
    • Open Grid Services Architecture.
  3. Semantic and Knowledge Grids
    • Technology-side and domain-side implications of grids;
    • Three-layer model of knowledge grids;
    • Metadata-driven middleware;
    • Dynamic resource integration;
    • Implicit descriptions and annotations;
    • Patterns of collaboration and publication;
    • Issues of provenance, quality, trust and proof;
    • Knowledge and meta-knowledge interactions;
    • Stability and instability of domain knowledge.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEQ6-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Security Management in Practice
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Software Security in the real world: analysing systems and security aware applications from various domains such as mobile communications, electronic commerce, banking and finance. Trusted computing and trust in electronic commerce and the existence of a trusted computing base. Policies for managing security, policy languages and models. Trust and Reputation and the basis for authorization decisions; the notion of trust and how to express it (subjective logic, trust and uncertainty, rating systems and reputations servers); the eBay reputation server as an example; communities of trust. Security analysis; assumptions made, social basis and threat assumptions. Trade off between threats and countermeasures and the return on security investment (RoSI). Information Security Management Standards and Codes of Practice. The interrelation and interdependency of security management and other system management activities and considerations such as:- Business Continuity Management, Organizational Security, Asset Classification and Control, Personnel Security, Physical and Environmental Security, Communications and Operations Management, Systems Development and Maintenance, Business Continuity Management and Compliance.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEQA-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Games Development and Evolution
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: History of games hardware and associated peripherals since late1970s: Arcade video games, 8, 16 and 32 bit, hand held devices and mobile phones, PC gaming, DirectX technologies, middleware, propriety SDKs and dedicated game development environments. Online, distributed and cooperative gaming including MMORPGs. Market demographics within the Europe, America, Asia and other territories. Typical game elements and characteristics from initial concept to production. Scenario, graphics, animation, sound, game-play. Games development within a commercial setting. IP, NDAs, copyright and software licensing considerations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEQB-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Developing Interactive 3D Environments
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Overview of available modelling and RAD applications. Introduction to computer modelling, primitives, polygons, nurbs, etc. and the concepts required for their management within interactive environments (hierarchies, collision meshes etc.). The use and creation of texture files, texture wrapping, the lighting of virtual objects/scenes and their rendering. Importing media and 3D files into RADs and the optimisation issues arising from hardware constraints. Programming and scripting within RADs. Camera management and transition within interactive environments. The use of spatialized sound within virtual environments.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEQC-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Artificial Intelligence for Games Programming
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Consideration of the nature of creativity in humans, computers and games; notions of simulation and emergence.

Review a range of the AI paradigms available to games programmers and designers.

Consideration of the nature of machine learning and identify those methods suitable for games.

Analyse the requirements of the game, developing a sense of where artificial intelligence might reside, that is, roles for AI, such as, non-player-character learning, planning moves, or developing strategic opponents.

Understand the essential architecture and usability of some AI techniques, including fuzzy systems, artificial neural networks, and genetic algorithms; comparing AI techniques with traditional search algorithms and methods. Understand the principles behind flocking and emergent modelling and their potential use in games.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCET3-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Coding for Game Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Overview of the uses and rationale underlying C# and XNA its relationship within the .Net framework and other development environments such as C++ and DirectX.
  • An introduction to the principles of the C# programming language and the XNA framework.
  • The importing and management of assets within code based development environments.
  • An introduction to the data structures and techniques required for the manipulation of 2D progressing to 3D content within interactive environments (including vectors, matrices, quaternion math) and the ways in which XNA handles this data.
  • The principles of movement and interaction with games programming.
  • An introduction to the methods that allow game events be conceptualised and abstracted in such a way as to be able to create efficient and reusable object oriented structures rather than the creation of bespoke solutions.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCET4-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Post Production and Soundtrack Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Overview of the role of post production and its associated technologies.
  • An introduction to relevant principles of game and multimedia audio engineering.
  • Recording equipment, mic types, patterns and placement.
  • Audio post production; ADR, foley, atmospheres and sound effects.
  • Editing; narrative, filters, effects, angles, transitions and file formats.
  • Documentation; Report sheets, edit decision lists and planning.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCET5-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Group Work in Large Scale Software Development (Student LED)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Software engineering as a coherent process
  • Selection evaluation and use of CASE tools
  • Critical reflection on current software engineering practices
  • Stages of the software engineering development discipline
  • Organisation and management of a team
  • Documentation issues
  • Quality issues
  • Risk assessment
  • Project monitoring and control
  • Task allocation and resourcing
  • Computer supported collaborative work
  • Application of system/software construction techniques to a group project
  • Professional issues
  • Usability issues

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEUE-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Symbolic AI
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• This module aims to introduce and examine issues relating to intelligent systems that use symbolic representation and rule-based architectures.
  • Domain of symbolic processing and search techniques: notion of well and ill-defined problems; search techniques; conflict-resolution and control strategies.
  • Knowledge representation: knowledge and meta-knowledge; production rules; semantic networks; frames; logic systems; problems of knowledge acquisition.
  • Reasoning, planning and learning: types of reasoning; numeric reasoning using fuzzy logic and probabilistic reasoning; reasoning strategies and uncertainty management; human problem solving and reasoning; planning techniques; types of learning; examples of machine learning.
  • Natural language processing: appreciation of the probable processes involved in understanding language (syntactic, semantic and pragmatic analysis); proposed representations for the necessary knowledge.
