  • Logic and its limitations: propositions; Horn clauses; a simple logic database (statements, facts, assertions, variables and rules); inference mechanism (search strategy, backtracking).
  • Introduction to Logic Programming: Translations of simple English descriptions into specifications in logic and logic programs.
  • Standard data structures and algorithms in a logic programming language; applications to planning, search, knowledge representation and other similar domains; simple problem solving and comparison with procedural / imperative solutions.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4F-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Graphics Programming
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Graphics Primitives: Vector and raster displays; The graphics hardware; Line drawing - Bresenhem\'s algorithm; Drawing a circle from pixels; Primitives: polyline, polyfill, text, general.

Geometry: Geometry of three dimensions; Matrices: Scaling, translation and rotation in 2 and 3 dimensions; Vector equations of lines and planes; Projective geometry.

Transformations: Transformations to and from Pixel/Screen/World axes; Perspective views; Change of origin and view direction;

Data Structures: Holding geometry as points/lines/circles; Segments and paging; Data compression techniques.

Algorithms: Area fill; Inside/outside algorithm; Intersection of bounded lines; Area of triangle and polygon using determinants; Cohen Sutherland clipping algorithm; Clipping in three dimensions; Hidden lines and hidden surfaces; The depth buffer algorithm.

Animation: Animation techniques, effectiveness.

Realism: Aspects of realism; lighting models; shadows; shading; texture; reflections; transparency; Texture mapping.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE5W-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Control Systems Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Root locus method: Design of PID controllers for high order systems.

Non linear systems: Description of non-linear systems - saturation - hysteresis etc; Stability analysis and simulation of non-linear systems - numerical simulation - linearisation - Lyapunov criterion - phase plane method - describing function method.

Discrete systems: z-transfer functions - difference equations - zero order hold DAC - unit circle - aliasing - stability of z-transfer functions - frequency response of z-transfer functions - design of phase shifting z-transfer function - impulse and step invariant simulation of continuous systems - selection of sample period - z- transfer function of a PID controller Discrete controller design using: (i) direct method; (ii) phase compensation method; (iii) root locus method

State space methods: definition of continuous state variables - state equations from transfer functions control canonical, physical and diagonal state variables - eigenvectors/values - transformation of state vectors - state equation to transfer function conversion - solution of stae equations using Laplace transforms - controllabiblity - observability - continuous to discrete conversion - state feedback control design by pole placement - observer design by pole placement - Ackerman's control and observer formulae - design of combined observer/controller.

System identification: correlation using PRBN - cross-spectral method.

Kalman filter: Optimal control; LQ cost function with Lagrangian multiplier.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE63-30-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Individual Project (Electronics)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Project selection: connection with departmental research and industrial problems (placements).

Project proposal: produced by students with advice from supervisors.

Project execution: monitored by supervisors.

Project presentation: report and presentation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE66-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Power Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Representation of Power System Components

Structure of Power Systems, Source of Electrical Energy, Synchronous Machines, The One Line diagram and the Impedance or reactance diagram, Per Unit Systems, Representation of Loads and Complex Power.

Symmetrical Components

The 'a' Operator, Symmetrical Component Transformation, Sequence Impedances and sequence Networks, Construction of Sequence Networks.

Representation of Power Transmission Lines

Short, Medium and Long Transmission Lines, Interpretation of the Line Equations, Ferranti Effect, Power Flow through a Transmission Line, Equivalent circuit representation.

Fault Analysis

Symmetrical Fault, Unsymmetrical Fault, Transient on a Transmission Line, Algorithm for Short Circuit studies, Bus Impedance Matrix Method for Analysis of Unsymmetrical Fault.

Power System Stability

Dynamics of Synchronous Machines, Power Angle Curve, Steady and Transient State Stability, Equal area Criterion, Swing Equation and Multi-Machine System Stability.

Load Flow Studies

Network Model Formulation, , Ybus Matrix, Gauss-Seidel Method, Newton-Raphson Method and decoupled Load Flow Solution. Comparison of Load Flow Methods.

Power Systems Protection and VAR Control

Distance Protection, Differential Protection, Components of Protection Schemes, Methods of VAR Injection.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE68-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Music for Engineers
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Tonality - defining tones, semitones, temperament. Scales/modes, degrees of scale. Concept of dominant and subdominant, primary/secondary chords, dominant 7th and secondary 7th chords. Higher tertiary chords. Functional analysis of chords. Augmented 6th chords, diminished 7th, cadences and phraseology.

Form and Genre Types

Form - a selection from: Binary, Ternary, Da Capo Aria, Sonata-form, Fugue, variation and allied forms, Jazz, Blues, Rock and allied forms.

Genres - Suite, Symphony, Concerto, Tone Poem, Sonata, Trio-Sonata, Opera, Oratorio, Lieder.

Musical terms, rhythm and notation in different countries.

Orchestra

Instruments of, and development of, the orchestra. History of orchestration. Score reading.

Cook\'s Tour of Music History

A selection from: Renaissance, Impressionism, Baroque, Expressionism, Classical, Neo-Classism, Romantic, Nationalism, Modern (including Jazz, Rock, Pop), World Music

Aural - ear training, fault finding, stylistic awareness and score reading.

Musical endeavour - active practical involvement in a musical ensemble, internally (for example U.W. E. Centre for Performing Arts) or externally OR Musical involvement in a CPA drama production. Evaluation of aspects of individual performance and experiences.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE69-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Embedded Microprocessor Systems
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEE7A-20-1 OR UFEE5H-20-1 OR UFEEHE-30-1 OR UFEES9-20-1 OR UFEETS-20-1 OR UFEEU8-40-1 OR UFEEHP-10-0)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Hardware. Review of hardware approaches to embedded systems design, including microcontrollers vs. rack based systems vs. PC-based. Review of basic computer architecture including the fetch-decode-execute cycle. Parallel and serial bus connection systems, including asynchronous & synchronous serial I/O. Basic concepts of analog I/O. Address decoding techniques, including Programmable Logic Devices as an example. Memory devices. Counter/timer devices.

Software. Review of software approaches to embedded systems design, including high vs. low level language, polling vs. interrupt driven, cross vs. native program development. Basic syntax of an assembly language; including instruction formats, addressing modes, and good design practices. Setting up and using I/O & counter/timer peripheral devices from a high level language by direct communication with devices. Exception processing and event driven systems. Introduction to fault tolerant computer systems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPENX-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Group Project and Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Illustrative examples of topics to be presented in the module include:

Projects and stakeholders. Project life-cycle models. Customers\' requirements analysis and capture. System modelling and validation. Feasibility studies. Goal setting. Work breakdown structures and schedule control systems. Project team structures. Team-building and management. Project control techniques and management strategies.

Groups may also receive presentations of domain specific material appropriate to the project that they are undertaking.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3K-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Machine Learning
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction - Historical examples. Relationship between Machine Learning and traditional Artificial Intelligence. Overview of the different classes of learning algorithms (supervised, reinforcement, unsupervised). Learning task formulation. Learning as a search through hypothesis space.

Tree and Rule Introduction - Representation. Data mining. Training and test data. ID3. Entropy measure. Inductive bias. CN2. C4.5. Rule pruning. Bagging and boosting.

Genetic Programming - Natural and simulated evolution. Evolutionary Programming. Knowledge representation (trees, linear, Cartesian). and manipulation (recombination, mutation, inversion). Tree Schema Theory. Automatically defined functions. Tree bloat.

Reinforcement Learning - Trial and error learning. Policy evaluation. Action selection. Temporal difference learning. On-policy and off-policy algorithms. Generalization. Eligibility traces. Planning/internal models.

Learning Classifier Systems - Population-based reinforcement learning. Accuracy-based and reward-based schemes. Memory (Markov and non-Markov domains). Knowledge representation. Parameter self-adaptation.

Instance-Based Learning - K-nearest neighbour. Euclidean space. Weighted linear regression. Case-based reasoning.

Bayesian Learning - Bayes Theorem. Concept learning. Nave Bayes classifier. Bayesian belief networks.

Unsupervised Learning - Contrast to supervised learning. Instar and outstar networks. Adaptive resonance theorem. Kohonen networks. Latent learning.

Modern Approaches - Subsumption and behaviour-based systems (model free, appearance of adaptation/learning). Artificial Immune Systems. Belief Networks. And/or others at the discretion of the tutor.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3E-10-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Internet Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to WWW and Internet structures: global structures, client-server architecture; browsers as clients; protocols (http, ftp etc).

Accessing the Internet: Hardware (dialup, broadband, ISDN); Internet Explorer versus Netscape; other browsers; URLs; file transfer, email, firewalls.

Page editors and HTML: Introduction to Frontpage or Dreamweaver as a graphical page editor; modifying raw HTML using the chosen editor.

Web page design: Design overview - desirable and undesirable features; using images; critiquing websites; building simple webpages; understanding links; building a simple website.

WWW and Internet past and future: ARPANET - aims and methods, developing the Internet - SGML, Tim Berners-Lee and HTML, early browsers, XML and other recent developments.

E-commerce: methods (e.g. CGI), problems and solutions, case studies of successful and unsuccessful e-commerce implementations.

The Internet and Society: the Internet as a 'libertarian and anarchic' community; positives - facilitating communication, reducing costs, expanding choice; negatives - access issues, security issues, facilitation of crime, internet-related crime, language issues.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE47-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Systems Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Unix: file and directory management including access rights; file editing - processes - starting; stopping; pipes and filters as a system architecture; PERL - simple programs.

Data Handling: Record structures (comma delimited, fixed format, tagged); file structures (sequential, random access, hashed); domain-specific file structures for representation of text; sound; images.

The internet: URLs; HTTP and low level access with telnet; search engines and web resources; HTML coding; CGI and client-server integration.

Describing systems; Layered models; Data models; Data flow diagrams; Message trace diagrams; Regular expressions and BNF.

Building systems: Development activities and process models; team management; quality and professional issues.

Components and interfaces: Selecting components and defining appropriate interfaces.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3G-20-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Programming Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: There is no set content. The student will be encouraged to undertake a project that gives an opportunity to apply and extend their existing knowledge and skills. Students are encouraged to undertake a project in an area which interests them, e.g. programming, database, web-based, etc.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4R-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Intelligent Systems
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFCE4D-20-2 OR UFCE4E-20-2 OR UFCE4C-20-2 OR UFCEUE-20-2 OR UFCEUF-20-2)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The module will introduce students to a thematic selection of recent research articles pertaining to intelligent systems, allowing them to prcis the material sufficiently well to form the basis of a personal perspective on the issues raised.

The module will be based around selected articles from current research in intelligent systems and may be determined by staff interests. For instance, in any one year, selected articles might come from, say, three of the following:

Biological and Social Paradigms; Genetics Algorithms; Philosophy of AI; Intelligent Agents; Knowledge and Reasoning; Natural Language Processing; Neural Networks; Collective Intelligence.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHK-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced CPU Architecture
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Review of the ARM and Pentium processors,

CPU functionality, fetch-execute management,

Processor Design - data path, control path, A simple RISC computer, Register Transfer Notation modelling, Instruction sets and code maps,

Pipelined processor architecture, Handling branch instructions with pre-fetch buffers, Avoiding pipeline stalls Delayed branching, branch delay slot usage, Instruction Level Parallelism, dependency resolution issues

Super-scalar CPUs, synchronising parallelism Shelving techniques, Register renaming, Out-of-Order execution, reorder buffers, post-RISC CPUs., VLIW processors (Intel/HP Itanium & Metadata Crusoe), predicated instruction sets

Microprogrammed or discrete decoding Multi-bus architectures

Integer ALU structure and functionality Introduction to Floating Point Units

RAM structure and dynamic timing Two level memory system design, accessing SRAM cache and DRAM main memory

Input/Output subsystem, Programmed I/O and interrupt handling

VHDL libraries for CPLD implementations Using Altera Nios soft core embedded processor

Using SimpleScalar toolkit for CPU architectural simulation studies Capturing and analysing performance profiles

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEERR-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Analogue Circuit Analysis
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Circuit Analysis

- Resistive circuits: Kirchoffs laws. Thevenins and Norton's theories, mesh analysis, Millman theorem, principle of superposition. Natural and forced response of LC, RC and LCR circuits. Phasor diagrams, complex analysis and Laplace transforms. Transient analysis for circuits with sinusoidal supplies. Bode diagrams. Analysis of two port networks

Analogue Electronic Circuits

- Operational amplifier as a small signal amplifier, as an active filter, as an integrator and differentiator, as a comparator and as an oscillator

Fields

- Analyse simple examples of electric fields. Electric potential and voltage, Gauss' law. Energy stored in electric fields

- Analyse simple examples of magnetic fields. Magnetic flux linkage, magnetic circuits, self inductance, reluctance, energy stored in magnetic fields. Mutually induced emf, introduction to transformers. Coupled networks in relative motion

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3B-40-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Computing Project
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFCE4B-20-2 OR UFCE49-20-2 OR UFCEKX-20-2 OR UFCEQG-20-2)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The subject of the project will be agreed between the student, the tutor and the Module Leader. Suitable topics may stem from staff, the student, the student's employer or other outside organisations. It must involve research followed by software development derived from it.

The research component will include the identification of a suitable topic and subsequent investigation from books, papers and other sources. Software development will include the identification of suitable tools and methodologies to use.

Whatever the subject the student will be expected to treat material critically and to demonstrate their understanding of the relevance of material from their award to the project topic.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3H-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Introduction to Artificial Intelligence: What do we mean by Artificial Intelligence: the Turing/Searle debate; strong vs. weak Artificial Intelligence; Symbolic Processing vs. Computational Intelligence. Exploration of the reasons for shared interests in mind, psychology and artificial intelligence of related disciplines such as Cognitive and Computer Science. Biological and social paradigms for Computational Intelligence. Appreciation of the biological basis for neural networks, evolutionary computation and collective intelligence.

Problem types and decomposition: Pattern recognition, modelling & prediction, action selection, planning, optimisation, simulation. Hybrid systems, and the need for an appropriate choice of paradigms for different parts of a decomposed problem.

Search as an underlying metaphor: The Black-box model of computer systems and problem solving as search. Search landscapes. Deterministic search strategies (depth/ breadth-first, branch-and-bound, A*) , combinatorial explosion, and Global/local search heuristics.

2. Knowledge Representation: Knowledge and meta-knowledge; production rules; logic systems; problems of knowledge acquisition.

Logic and its limitations: logic database (statements, facts, assertions, variables and rules); inference mechanism (search strategy, backtracking); deduction and abduction.

Structure of rule-based systems. Expert systems. Domain of symbolic processing and search techniques: notion of well-defined problems; state-space graphs and trees.

3. Artificial Neural Networks Natural and artificial networks. Parallel processing in nature: neurons and structure of brain; neural models; connectionist architecture. Simulation of simple neuron-like structures; neuron as a simple computing element, pattern associator; emergent properties; perceptrons; multi-layer neural networks, backpropagation; associative memory. Networks for supervised and unsupervised learning.

Application domain of neural networks: subtle, deep and complex pattern recognition without rules or explanation. Used in classification; noise reduction; black box decision aid; real-world applications.

Pragmatics of using a neural network: network size; weights and learning parameters; representative training data; scaling; training and test; pre-processing data. Constructing neural networks using a software package.

4. Evolutionary Algorithms: Notion of natural and artificial evolution and biological inspiration of evolutionary computation, basic evolutionary metaphor for problem solving.

Hollands simple Genetic algorithm as classic exemplar of approach: origins and theory; notions of selection schemes and selection pressure; crossover and mutation operators.

Pragmatics of using Evolutionary Computation: representational issues as driver for choice of metaphor, encoding and operators; population initialisation; fitness calculation; reproduction. Genetic Programming for model building and programme induction.

5. Collective Intelligence Swarm Intelligence & Robot Societies. Notion of agents. Social networks structure (the neighbourhood principal). Particle swarm optimiser. Emergent culture. Emergent intelligence. Applications. Future research and speculations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3L-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Software Development Principles
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Categories of system - Approaches to systems development and definition of Software Engineering - Concepts: Modelling, abstraction, hierarchy, partitioning, modularisation, control. - The Software Engineering Process: Software Crisis, lifecycle models. - Development Methods: Review and overview, notations. - Human-Computer Interface issues. - Software Quality: Definition, issues, standards. - Software project issues: Metrics, cost estimation, risk. - Testing: Verification and validation. - Professional practice: Legal issues, ethics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE44-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Program Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module explores object-oriented concepts through Java. The contents include the following topics:

Review of java syntax and introduction of simple input/output Basic object-oriented concepts including object, object reference, class, attribute, method, encapsulation/information hiding, message passing, static members Inheritance, abstract class, interface, polymorphism Advanced control flow on exception handling and thread Event-driven GUI programming

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE48-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer Science Concepts
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Computer Science and Computing: what Computer Science covers; the need for formal models; practical v theoretical concerns; the contribution of Computer Science to practical problem solving.

Essential features of a Computing Machine: what counts as a computer?; input/output; \"arithmetic\", logic, memory, states and state transitions.

Some models: Finite machines; things a finite machine can and can\'t do; Turing Machines: examples, extensions, limitations, other models eg. URMs, the brain as computer.

Formal Languages: words, sentences, languages, grammars, productions, Links to computing models. The Chomsky Hierarchy, simple parsing algorithms.

Classes of algorithm: iterative; recursive; randomised, probabilistic, heuristic.

Algorithm performance: worst case, Big-O notation: ideas of polynomial time, exponential time, hardness; time v space.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE49-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Software Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to software engineering with emphasis on the engineering discipline to software development.

The Software Engineering Process: Generic process models and the Unified Process Model.

The triangle of software development: process model, modelling language, and tools (with emphasis on upper case tools).

Project Management: the initial proposal, costing, planning, scheduling, personnel selection, project monitoring and reviews.

The use of the Unified Modelling Language (UML) to develop robust analysis and design models.

Software Engineering Activities: Business Modelling, Requirements Analysis, Design, Implementation, Testing, and deployment along with supporting workflows to include configuration management, and project management.

Testing: Verification and Validation, and testing strategies.

Software Cost Estimation: cost estimation methods with emphasis on algorithmic methods (e.g. The COCOMO model)

Configuration Management: change, version, and release management.

Software Quality: Definition, Issues, Standards, Professional Practice, and Legal Issues.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE5X-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer Networks
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design principles for computer networks. Layered architectures and the ISO-OSI and TCP/IP models.

Forward and feedback error control. Error detection and correction codes. Data link protocols: idle and continuous ARQ.

Performance analysis. Protocol specification and verification: finite state machines, Petri nets, protocol description languages.

Local area networks (LANs): topologies and medium access control protocols. Performance analysis. Implementations: IEEE 802 Ethernet, Token bus, Token ring, Fast Ethernet, FDDI, DQDB. Wireless local area networks. LAN devices: repeaters, bridges, routers.

Wide area networks (WANs): circuit-switched and packet-switched networks. Switch architectures. Addressing. Routing methods and algorithms: centralised versus distributed, static versus adaptive. Congestion control methods and algorithms. Integrated Services Digital Networks (ISDNs). Frame Relay. Switched multimegabit data service (SMDS). Broadband ISDN and Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM).

Transport layer in ISO-OSI and TCP/IP. ISO-OSI session and presentation services. Application layer services.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4C-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Declarative Programming
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to declarative languages. Properties of programming languages, motivation and history of declarative languages. Criteria for assessing programming languages.

Introduction to Logic Programming: Translations of simple English descriptions into specifications in logic and logic programs; concept of \'executable specification\'; comparison with other subjects such as Rapid Application Development, prototyping.

Standard data structures and algorithms in a logic programming language; applications to planning, search, knowledge representation and other similar domains; simple problem solving and comparison with procedural/imperative \'solutions\'.

Complex predicates and standard library predicates.

Introduction to first order logic and comparison to Horn clauses.

The declarative and procedural semantics of Horn Clause logic programs. Unification and resolution. Negation as finite failure and the Closed World Assumption.

Constraint Logic Programming; use of constraints to program and optimize solutions to appropriate problems.

Extensions: Inductive LP; Disjunctive LP. Connections to other areas of the discipline.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4E-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Subsymbolic Processing
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFCE45-20-1 OR UFCE46-20-1 OR UFCE4V-20-1 OR UFEEHE-30-1 OR UFQEFY-20-1)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module aims to introduce and examine issues relating to intelligent systems that use sub-symbolic representation and connectionist architectures. It will explore the ability of such systems to sustain artificially intelligent behaviour and briefly consider their potential to provide plausible models of aspects of human cognition.

1. Introduction: historical background; paradigms relating to intelligent systems (symbolic and sub-symbolic, artificial and biological, declarative and procedural, local and distributed representations); neural computing.

2. Parallel processing in nature: neurons and structure of brain; neural models; connectionist architecture.

3. Simulation of simple neuron-like structures; pattern associator; fault tolerance; perceptrons; backpropagation; associative memory.

4. Brief consideration of other networks and paradigms.

5. Domains of sub-symbolic processing: fuzzy data; ill-defined problems; subtle or deep pattern recognition; non-linear data; chaotic data; real-world problem domain; robust to unmodelled parameters through generalisation. Uses: continuous function approximation; classification; noise reduction; black box decision aid; real-world applications.

6. Cognitive issues - aspects of human cognition that can and cannot be simulated in PDP models: content addressing memories; model of schema organisation; spontaneous generalization; prototype from exemplars; unitary model of semantic and episodic memory; graceful degradation; amnesia; deep dyslexia; natural language processing; one-trial learning; introspection.

7. Philosophical issues: connectionist models of mind; limits imposed by computation; limits imposed by architecture.

8. Pragmatics of building and using a neural network: network size; weights and learning parameters; representative training data; scaling; training and test; pre-processed data; case study -pattern learning and recognition.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4K-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Mathematical modelling of complexity: space v time.

Upper and lower bounds: techniques of analysis: correctness, efficiency; analytical strategies, order notation.

Design strategies: Brute force; Divide-and-conquer; Decrease-and-conquer; Transform-and-conquer; Dynamic programming; Greedy techniques; Iterative improvement.

Searching algorithms: linear search; worst and average case upper bound determination - probabilistic approaches; binary search; search trees; using decision trees to determine the lower bound on search - worst and average cases.

Selection algorithms: finding maximum and second maximum values; lower bound considerations; finding maximum and minimum; finding i-th largest.

Sorting algorithms: strategies for sorting; select sorts; insert sorts; merge sorts; split sorts; sorting-by-counting; analysis of lower bounds and average case.

Graph algorithms: operations on structures; queues; topological sort; depth- and breadth-first search; spanning trees; cheapest paths, travelling salesman problem, Warshalls and Floyds algorithms.

Numerical algorithms: Fibonacci and related topics, exponentials; lcd and gcm; prime numbers; Gaussian elimination; linear programming.

Hard problems: the classes P, NP and NP-complete; significance for computing.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEKR-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Media Technologies
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Text and font characteristics, HTML, XML, VRML, Image editing techniques: scaling, transforming, applying filters, optimizing, composite images, vector graphics. Various graphics file formats, e.g. JPEG, GIF, PNG, SVG,

2. Sound recording and processing: hardware, line-in, line-out, microphone, speakers, MIDI, signal processing, filters, echo, reverb, EQ, noise reduction, sampling, sequencing, mixing, loops, fade-in, fade-out, voice-over techniques,

3. Video capture and editing post- production effects, video formats, transitions, codecs setup and connectivity, video production techniques, storyboarding, scripting.

4. File formats, storage media, and device connectivity: CDROM, DVD, Blue Tooth, Firewire, USB, SCSI,

5. Deployment technologies: Perl, PHP, ASP, JSP, Java, Servlets, Shockwave Flash, Shockwave 3D, VRML,

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEKS-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Multimedia Authoring
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Animation methods & techniques: timeline & script-based control methods, key-frame animation, motion tweening, shape tweening, sprite animation, creating and importing animation from external packages.

2. Import & management of media resources, file sizes and optimisation, file format conversion. Importing vector and bitmap images, audio files, music files, sprite animation, video, realtime 3D importing and embedding fonts

3. Planning, design and implementation, storyboarding , user-interface metaphors and HCI, design and layout strategies, use of colour and design, navigation methods, GUI components selection, look and feel, cross-platform issues, software design methodologies.

4. Timeline metaphors. Mouse driven events and interaction: selection, rollover, drag and drop, Script-based control and navigation, designing and coding scripts, object-oriented programming techniques, processing keyboard data, program logic control structures. Testing, verification, and validation of data, testing and debugging, deployment emulation.

5. Database connectivity technologies perl, php, xml, asp, jsp, Java servlets, deployment issues and considerations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEKT-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: 3D Modelling and Animation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Introduction to the visualisation, creation, and editing of computer generated models in 3D. Mesh creation and generic editing principles and techniques. Use and placing of cameras in the scene to visualise objects, camera attributes and control. Lighting of objects and world environment. Using and applying texture maps to objects.

2. Animation techniques. principles of keyframe animation, animation curves, path animation, inverse kinematics, reactive animation, and rigid body dynamics. 3D characters, animating characters, motion capture principles and techniques, lip-sync animation, morphing, walk cycles, facial animation.

3. Introduction to modelling techniques, polygon modelling, NURBS curves, NURBS surfaces, boolean object creation, joining surfaces, UV coordinates, construction history, patch modelling. Exporting scenes and objects to media formats: VRML(.wrl), Shockwave3D (.W3D), DirectX (.x).

4. Surface materials and shading algorithms, flat, gourad, and phong shading, texture mapping

5. Rendering scenes, control and optimisation of rendering output.

6. Planning, teamworking, storyboarding, file management, version control

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEKU-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Web Games Programming
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Introduction to computer games programming. Gaming history, technologies, and genres. Game development environments and target devices; DirectX technologies, Shockwave Flash, Shockwave 3D, middleware component libraries, open source projects. Game consoles, mobile devices.

2. 2D graphics and animation, sprite animation, device issues and user interface control. Parallax scrolling techniques, collision detection, object transformations.

3. Input devices. Keyboard and mouse control. Joystick and force feedback devices.

4. Sound and music, sound formats and conversion, loading and playing sound, 3Dsound.

5. 3D graphics, creating and importing game content, texture mapping and lighting, multi-player games, 3D transformations,

6. A. I. tracking and evasion algorithms, path following, patterns, finite state machines, probability machines, fuzzy logic, pathfinding algorithms.

7. Game scripting, persistence - saving game state, optimisation techniques, creating game art and sounds - supporting technologies and applications. Copyright and legal issues.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEKW-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Application Development Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The subject of the project will be agreed between the student, the tutor and the Module Leader. Suitable topics may stem from staff, the student, the student\'s employer or other outside organisations. The aim of the project is to develop a product which shows evidence of the breadth and depth of the student's understanding and skills in the area of their degree programme.

Whatever the subject the student will be expected to treat material critically and to demonstrate their understanding of the relevance of material from their award to the project topic. It is expected that for a high mark a student should go beyond the level and/or scope of material taught on their degree or attempt a task of considerably greater complexity than would be covered in a taught module.

A second or subsequent attempt should not, in general, be based on a topic previously attempted.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEKX-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Java for Sound and Music
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Key Java concepts not covered in pre-requisite modules: Exceptions and exception handling; Nested classes; Interfaces; Multiple Threads; Simple GUIs;

2. Digital Audio: Pulse code modulated audio data; Bit streams; big-endian and little-endian formats; Simple synthesis techniques.

3. The javax.sound.sampled API: Basic components: Line, Clip, Mixer, Format, AudioSystem; Advanced components: Controls; Capturing audio data from devices (microphones) and files; Converting between byte streams and data frames; Reading, saving and converting between file formats; Limitations ;

4. The javax.sound.midi API: Basic concepts: wire protocol, file protocol; Streaming MIDI commands; time stamping of Midi commands; API classes: MidiSystem, Transmitters, Sequencers, Synthesizer; Creating and editing MIDI data; Direct control of a musical instrument; Limitations and extensions;

5. Integrating audio and MIDI.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEMQ-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer Crime and Digital Evidence
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Legal matters Categories of computer crime: offences against confidentiality and integrity; computer-related offences (e.g. fraud, forgery, copyright etc.); content-related offences (e.g. child pornography).

Law pertaining to computer crime: Computer Misuse Act 1990; EU CyberCrime Convention 2003; applicable international law may also be presented.

Law relating to evidence: Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984; Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000; challenges in applying existing legislation to forensic computing.

Responsibilities of Forensic Computing practitioner: securing evidence; ensuring continuity of evidence; use of auditable procedures when investigating evidence; admissibility of evidence; the need for impartiality; regulation and licensing.

Computer Crime Investigation and incident response Forms of digital evidence: emails, documents, images, residual information.

Low-level information structures: hard disk formats: Windows: DOS, FAT, NTFS; Unix; Apple/Mac. partitions and free space. File structures and formats, file compression.

Investigative strategies for digital evidence and computer crime scenes.

Introduction to investigative tools: Generic: hex editors, search tools etc.; Professional: EnCase. To include practical experimentation and preliminary investigation with these tools.

Creating a criminal profile from digital evidence - statistical analysis of probabilities.

Introduction to legally-admissible report writing: style, content, impartiality, correct use of terminology.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4W-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Databases
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module will be an opportunity to address the most recent topics in database technology and to compare the models from an application point of view in order to assess their relative values. The teaching is based on using a seminar format. At the moment, the topics might be taken from any of the list below. In future years, as topics are developed beyond the research stage, some of these topics might become new modules. Similarly, as new areas of research into databases are developed, the topics would be included in this list.

Semantic Data Models: Aggregation, Association, Generalisation and Classification. The Extended ER Model, SDM, and RM/T. The power, representation and effectiveness of the above four concepts. Relationship to the RDBMS approach.

Object Oriented Databases: Basic Concepts of message passing and inheritance. Query languages and access. Bulk classes such as Sets, Bags, Lists and Dictionaries. Special applications for OODBMSs. Three different approaches: IRIS, ONTOS and GEMSTONE. Comparison to RDBMSs.

Temporal Databases: The inability of RDBMSs to handle time efficiently. Valid and Transaction Time, Temporal Projection, the Time Slice Operator. Tuple stamping vs attribute stamping. Append only databases, Schema Evolution. Review of models and query languages based on extending the Relational Algebra. Review of models and language based on the Object Oriented Databases. Comparison of approaches.

Real Time Databases: Managing transactions with real-time requirements. Scheduling with deadlines, constraints on concurrency control, handling overloads, scheduling I/O requests.

Knowledge Bases: Rules, Intrinsic knowledge, Extrinsic Knowledge and DATALOG. The ways that DATALOG is translated into Relational Database queries. Limits to recursion, Naive and Semi-Naive Evaluation, the flavours of DATALOG. The Closed World Assumptmachines, extending existing databases to cope with parallelism.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4Q-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Distributed and Parallel Databases
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The architecture of distributed systems and related concepts that impact the design of database systems.

The architecture of distributed database systems including the client-server model and multi-database systems.

Distributed database design including fragmentation and allocation of database fragments over distributed database system nodes.

Distributed Semantic Data Control: view management, data security, and semantic integrity control.

Distributed query optimization: characterization of query processing including, query optimization, and the generic architecture of distributed query processor.

Distributed transaction processing: distributed transaction and the ACIDity properties, classification of transaction models including the workflow model, concurrency control, and the generic architecture of a distributed execution monitor.

Parallel Databases and Systems: why parallel database systems? Parallel system architectures, and parallel DBMS techniques.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEPL-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Software Engineering Concepts
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module examines the contribution that Software Engineering makes to the production of software systems. It considers a variety of different approaches to Software Engineering and considers their strengths and weaknesses.

Topics Covered:

  • Definitions of Software Engineering
  • The Software Engineering Process: Software Crisis, lifecycle models
  • Kinds of System
  • Models and concepts
  • Software Engineering Methods: Review and overview
  • Software Quality: Definition, issues, standards, metrics, usability and effectiveness
  • Testing: Verification and validation
  • Professional practice: Legal issues, ethics
  • Future Directions

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEPN-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Requirements Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Introduction to requirements engineering with emphasis on the engineering dimension
  2. Requirements engineering and the software development process
  3. Requirements engineering processes
  4. Requirements elicitation methods
  5. Software requirements specification (SRS) document
  6. Modelling techniques including selected UML notations, goal-oriented approaches, and business process modelling
  7. Formal requirements specification
  8. Identification, modelling, and specification of non-functional requirements
  9. Requirements validation, and
  10. Requirements management.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEPQ-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Databases
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module will be an opportunity for masters-level students to address some recent topics in database technology and to compare models and approaches from both applications and computer science points of view in order to assess their relative merits. The topics listed below are typical of the syllabus. However, in future, as issues and technologies emerge from the database research community, some of these may be replaced by more recent research topics.

  • Fundamental issues in database management systems (for example, integrity, concurrency, transaction handling, recovery, security, definition and query languages).
  • Fundamental paradigms: relational vs object-oriented databases; the 'object-relational' approach.
  • Extended ER Models and knowledge representation; semantic data models (aggregation, association, generalisation and classification); conceptual models.
  • Object-Oriented Databases: basic concepts (message passing, inheritance), query languages, OODBMS applications, comparison of recent commercial products.
  • Schema Evolution, versioning, federation.
  • Meta-data and self-describing data models.
  • XML data representation, native XML databases and related query languages.
  • Multimedia data management.
  • Deductive and Active Databases; Real-Time Databases.
  • Distributed and parallel database developments.
  • Spatial and Temporal Databases; Geographic Information Systems.
  • Logic, Rules and Knowledge Bases.
  • Data Warehousing and OLAP.
  • Data cubes and multi-dimensional databases.
  • Data Mining and other knowledge extraction methods.
  • WWW and Semantic Web.
  • Grid databases
  • Genomic and proteomic databases arising in bioinformatics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEPR-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Component-Based Software
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Components: Definitions, current directions in component development, Components v Objects;
  • Reuse concept, realisation, problems, issues, design for reuse;
  • Design by Contract;
  • Architecture, Frameworks, Patterns;
  • Development, documentation and cataloguing of components
  • Program-level Component Technology:
  • Fundamental concepts encapsulation, information hiding, high cohesion, loose coupling;
  • Component Technologies (e.g. Java Beans);
  • Fundamental design patterns faade, listener, and delegation;
  • Component use in small-scale server side applications (e.g. JSP, Servlets)
  • Distributed components:
  • Designing distributed systems;
  • Developments in Middleware;
  • Distributed Objects Technologies (e.g. RMI);
  • Distributed component models (EJB, CORBA, .Net) and comparison of provision;
  • Web Services

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEPW-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Grid: Virtual Organizations
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Aspects of Organizations
    • brief overview of literature: Charles Handy on Understanding Organizations;
    • diagrammatic methods for organizational descriptions;
    • roles (individuals, groups, departments);
    • resources (human, material, abstract);
    • flows (material, information, control);
    • inter-organizational flows, dependencies and problems;
    • the context of Virtual Organizations.
  2. Organizations, Processes and Workflows
    • workflow management;
    • case process, case management process, case strategy process [OULD].
  3. Web and Grid Services
    • examples how a VO may form around a Web Services Open Architecture (e.g. MammoGrid);
    • stateless and stateful, persistent and transient services;
    • languages for registration and invocation of Web Services;
    • Open Grid Services Architecture and beyond.
  4. Grid and Workflow Services
    • Workflow Management Coalition (WfMC) Workflow Standard;
    • Business Process Modelling Language (BPML);
    • Business Process Execution Language for Web Processes (BPEL4WS);
    • -calculus inspired languages.
  5. Governance: Provenance, Security, Trust
    • audit trail for information
    • problems of authorization, authentication and certification;
    • domain-specific issues: confidentiality, privacy, consent; anonymization, pseudonymization; negotiation and policy-bridging.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3C-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Dissertation (Software Engineering)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Not applicable

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3F-20-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Program Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Problem Solving - Polya\'s approach to problem solving; Consideration of algorithmic and strategy problems such as river crossing and NIM.

Program Design - Constructs: sequence, selection and iteration; Step-wise refinement using an associated PDL; Modularization: coupling and cohesion, structure charts.

Data Structures - Concrete data structures: records, arrays, files; Operations: searching and sorting.

Verification and Validation - Trace tables; Test case design; Walkthroughs and inspections.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3U-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Algorithms
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Introduction and summary of mathematical techniques for algorithmic analysis sufficient to ensure all students being able to study the four major algorithmic topics presented in the balance of the module. String algorithms: Knuth-Morris-Pratt and Boyer-Moore algorithms. Parallel algorithms: PRAM algorithms used to solve common computer science problems. NP-complete: problems, approximation algorithms and DNA algorithms. Polynomials and matrices: evaluating polynomial functions, fast Fourier transform.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEQE-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Commercial Games Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Input devices, display devices, camera control, collision detection, implementing AI, integrating existing model resources, character animation, audio and music, network protocols, deployment testing, optimisation techniques, file formats and game persistence. Licensing, copyright, distribution mechanisms and royalties.

For a given development framework:

Students will work in groups, and will be allocated a game genre in which they must design and implement a prototype of a game. The whole group will be involved in the formulation of the game scenario and storyboarding out the gameplay and objectives. Then subgroups are to be identified to cover the following: Project Management Team (Project Manager, Artwork Director, Technical Director, Quality Director, Marketing and Legal Director), Digital Artists, Coders, Testers.

Deliverables to include one level of the game scenario implemented on the chosen platform with supporting documentation. Together with personal progress reports where students critically evaluate their own progress within the context of the group activities. To fulfil these criteria, both management and development practices will need to be utilised. In addition, use of associated supporting technology and tools will be expected.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3D-10-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Database Fundamentals
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Database concepts: The use and application of relational databases: investigate various manual and computerised systems.

Database context: Main stages of the database application lifecycle, requirements collection and analysis, fact finding techniques.

Logical Data modelling: understand and be able to apply correctly the data modelling terms: entity, attribute, relationship. ER modelling. Translate the ER model into a set of tables, use normalisation to check tables are well designed: understand methods used to implement 1NF, 2NF and 3NF. Determine multiplicity constraints of relationships: refine logical model to remove many to many relationships. Define integrity constraints.

Physical database design: design base tables, for implementation in the target DBMS. Design physical representation: analyse transactions, choose file organisations and indexes, security mechanisms, user interface design: consider guidelines for form/report design

Implementation and testing: Use relational database software e.g. Access, to build a database to meet the needs of the normalised data model: data entry, reports, queries (using QBE).Testing to ensure the database meets the original specification.

Documentation: document the development of the database and create user and technical documentation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEUF-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Sub-symbolic AI
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module examines issues relating to intelligent systems that use connectionist architectures and evolutionary computation. It will explore the ability of such systems to sustain artificially intelligent behaviour and briefly consider the potential of neural computation to provide plausible models of aspects of human cognition.

  1. Review of paradigms and intelligent systems.
  2. Simulation of simple neuron-like structures; pattern associator; fault tolerance; perceptrons; back-propagation; associative memory. Brief consideration of other networks.
  3. Domains of sub-symbolic processing: fuzzy data; ill-defined problems; subtle or deep pattern recognition; non-linear data; chaotic data; real-world problem domain; robust to un-modelled parameters through generalisation. Uses: continuous function approximation; classification; noise reduction; black box decision aid; real-world applications.
  4. Pragmatics of building and using a neural network: network size; weights and learning parameters; representative training data; scaling; training and test; pre-processed data; case study -pattern learning and recognition.
  5. Using evolutionary computation to evolve a neural network.
  6. Explore the general applicability of evolutionary computation.
  7. Cognitive issues - aspects of human cognition that can and cannot be simulated in connectionist models: content addressing memories; model of schema organisation; spontaneous generalization; prototype from exemplars; unitary model of semantic and episodic memory; graceful degradation; amnesia; natural language; one-trial learning.
  8. Philosophical issues: connectionist models of mind; limits imposed by computation; limits imposed by architecture.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEUP-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Program Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Basic programming concepts: An introduction to computer operating systems and software. The software development process. Learning to use the text editor and compiler within Visual Studio. Creating a simple GUI based program using Visual Studio. The Visual Studio debugger.
  2. C# syntax: Scalar data types. Using primitives: Declarations, Assignments, Constants, Arithmetic operations and expressions. Console based input and output. Simple GUI based input, output and event handling. Standard GUI widgets.
  3. Program Control: Defining and using sequence, selection and iteration techniques in programming languages generally and C# specifically. Considering input data validation routines.
  4. Lists and Arrays. Simple collections and array handling. The relationship between loops and arrays. Using arrays of scalars and objects. Processing arrays and using the array attribute length. Studying and implementing lists, stacks and queues.
  5. Object Orientation: An introduction to thinking about and using the OO paradigm. Considering basic OO concepts such as encapsulation. Identifying and using the constituents of OO - classes, objects, methods, fields, properties. Using UML to design classes.
  6. Implementing classes: Introducing more OO concepts e.g. polymorphism. Using class members (the keyword static). Method definition and invocation - formal and actual parameters. Using simple GUI components.
  7. Inheritance: Understanding inheritance. Using inheritance and representing it in UML class diagrams. Learning to override methods.
  8. Software Development and Maintenance: The importance of using sound software development techniques. Coding conventions. Distinguishing between compile-time, run-time, and logical program errors. Testing methods and methodologies. A brief look at exception handling.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFU-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Fluid Dynamics
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFQEFT-20-2 AND (UFQEFV-20-1 OR UFQELG-20-1 OR (UFQETH-10-1 AND (UFQETG-10-1 OR UFQETJ-10-1))))
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Vector Calculus: Vectors, scalar and vector fields. Grad, Div and Curl, appropriate vector identities. Summation convention and manipulation of formulae. Conservative fields. Cylindrical and spherical co-ordinates, general curvilinear co-ordinate systems. Line integrals, surface integrals and volume integrals. Divergence, Stokes' and Green's theorems.

These methods will be used to model and solve problems in fluid mechanics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEL5-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Research Review
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The student will: Develop a research hypothesis; Plan and structure a programme of research to test the hypothesis; Undertake a literature review and build a reference base; Undertake initial stages of the research programme; The area of research will be negotiated and agreed between the student and the supervisor.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEMP-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Academic and Professional Perspectives on Technology
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Culture - theories and classification, academic and workplace cultures, globalisation. multiculturalism, common cultures, views of knowledge The internet and digital cultures, impact of technological change Language - genre analysis, discourse analysis, academic and professional literacies, critical language awareness, intercultural communication, computer mediated communication

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEEU-20-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Foundation Mathematics for Computing
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
NUMBER BASES

The Positional Nature of Decimal Numbers, Other Number Bases [in particular bases 2 and 16], Changing the Base of a Number [including numbers between 1 and 0], Arithmetic Operations with Binary Numbers, Two\'s Complement Representation of Negative Numbers.

SET THEORY

Sets and Elements, Universal Set and Empty Set, Subsets, Set Operations including Union, Intersection and Subtraction, Complements, Venn Diagrams, Algebra of Sets and Duality, Power Sets.

TRIGONOMETRY

Graphs of Sine and Cosine, Solution of Simple Trig Equations, Sine Rule, Cosine Rule, Arc Length and Sector Area, Radians, Amplitude, Phase, Frequency, Combinations of Waveforms.

RELATIONS and FUNCTIONS

Domain, Range, Relational diagrams, Relational Image, Relational Override, Inverse Relations, Relational Composition.

Function - defined as a type of relation. Applications of Functions [Solution of Linear and Quadratic Equations, Transposition of Formulae, Remainder Function, Modular Arithmetic, Exponential Functions, Logarithmic Functions].

Sequence - defined as a type of function. Common Sequence Operations [Head, Tail, Reverse, Join].

MATRICES

Addition, Subtraction and Multiplication of Matrices. - Transformation [Rotation, Reflection, Enlargement] of 2-d shapes using matrices. - Solution of Systems of Linear Equations [Maximum of 3 Unknowns] using matrices.

LOGIC and PROPOSITIONAL CALCULUS

Propositions and Compound Propositions, Connectives [AND, OR, NOT], Truth Tables, Switches, Tautologies and Contradictions, Logical Equivalence, Algebra of Propositions, Conditional and Biconditional Statements, Arguments, Logical Implication, Algebra of Propositions, Propositions and their Predicates, Quantifiers [Universal and Existential], Negation of Quantified Statements.

BOOLEAN ALGEBRA

Basic Laws, Duality, Basic Theorems [including DeMorgan's Laws] Sum-of-Products Forms, Logic Gates [NOT, AND, OR] and Logic Circuits, NAND and NOR Gates, Karnaugh Maps [Maximum of Four Variables].

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGA-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistics and Experimental Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Basic maths: algebraic functions and formulae, logarithms and exponential functions, transformation of non-linear relationships and linear forms;

The concepts of bias, precision and accuracy;

Sources of error: technical errors, systematic errors, biological variability, the means of measuring variation and minimising errors, the need for replication, when statistics is and is not needed;

Probability: basic concepts of random variables, Binomial, Poisson and Normal distributions;

Introduction to hypothesis testing: point and interval estimation tests of hypotheses about means and proportions, chi-squared tests for contingency tables and goodness of fit (e.g. genetic ratios);

Non-parametric methods: how they are used and when they are useful.

Experiments with more than two treatments: analysis of variance and the design of experiments, including factorial experiments with interaction, least significant differences;

Regression analysis, including curve-fitting;

Presentation of data: use of computer packages for production of high quality tables and figures;

The scientific method: asking the right questions, testing hypotheses, experimental planning, experimental design, data collection, analysis and interpretation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGF-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Business Research Methods
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The research process. The research proposal. Design strategies and measurement.

Sampling theory and methodologies random sampling. systematic sampling. stratification techniques. cluster sampling. multi-stage sampling. longitudinal studies. quota sampling.

Survey methods and instruments personal interviewing. telephone interviewing. postal surveys. Internet based surveys. question construction and evaluation. assessment of reliability and validity. the coding of questionnaire data. the analysis of questionnaire data.

Multivariate analysis - to include some of the following techniques principal components analysis. factor analysis. cluster analysis. correspondence analysis. correspondence analysis. binary logistic regression. Classification and Regression Trees (CART). Chi-square Automatic Interaction Detection (CHAID)

Presentation of results The written research report.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEL9-20-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistics for Research C
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Units:

1. Statistical Inference (Parametric Tests)

Syllabus

(a) The logic and theory underpinning statistical hypothesis tests.

(b) The practical application and logic underpinning tests of significance for mean differences including the one-sample t-test, paired t-test, two-sample t-tests, one-way ANOVA, one-way ANOVA with blocking, two-way factorial designs and using the result of the Central Limit Theorem. Checking the assumptions underpinning parametric tests of significance.

(c) Reporting of statistical tests, their interpretation and the graphical display of differences.

(d) Power of the test.

Indicative sources

Kvanli, A.H., Pavur, R.J. Keeling, K.B., (2003) An Introduction to Business Statistics (A Microsoft Excel Integrated Approach) 6th ed., West Publishing Company

Daly, F. Hand, D.J. Jones M.C., Lunn, A.D. and McConway ,K.J, (1995) Elements of Statistics, Addison-Wesley

2. Statistical Inference (Nonparametric Tests)

Syllabus

(a) The logic and theory underpinning statistical hypothesis tests including permutation tests and randomization tests.

(b) The practical application and logic underpinning tests of significance for nonparametric tests including the Wilcoxon Signed Rank Sum test, Sign test, Mann Whitney test, Kruskall-Wallis test, Friedman's test and using the result of the Central Limit Theorem.

(c) Using the bootstrap to test for significance.

Indicative sources

Kvanli, A.H., Pavur, R.J. Keeling, K.B., (2003) An Introduction to Business Statistics (A Microsoft Excel Integrated Approach) 6th ed., West Publishing Company

Daly, F. Hand, D.J. Jones M.C., Lunn, A.D. and McConway ,K.J, (1995) Elements of Statistics, Addison-Wesley

3. Regression Modelling 1

Syllabus

(a) The uses of linear regression. Ideas relating to best fit and the use of linear models and their interpretation. Validity and reliability of the fitted equation, the assessment of residuals (tests of normality, randomness, constant variance, effect of outliers) and predictive ability (prediction intervals and confidence intervals).

(b) Extending the linear model to include multiple predictors. Model building using computer aided selection techniques (backward elimination, forward selection, stepwise, best subsets).

(c) Correlation Analysis. Zero order correlations (Pearson, Kendall, Spearman) and partial correlations and part correlations. Confidence intervals and tests of hypothesis relating to correlations (e.g. Fisher's test).

Indicative sources

Draper, N.R. and Smith, H (1997), Applied Regression Analysis, 3rd Edition, Wiley

4. Regression Modelling 2

(a) Extending and improving multiple regression models.

Development of models to include factors through coding schemes (e.g. dummy variables). Development of models to include higher order effects (interactions). Development of models by transforming variables (e.g. Box-Cox transformation). Model improvement by the identification of influential observations (Cook's distance, leverage and studentized residuals) and lack-of-fit.

(b) Assessing assumptions underpinning models though an analysis of residuals e.g. analysis of residuals for normality using standard tests of normality (Anderson-Darling, Shapiro-Wilk, Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests), for homogeneity of variance (e.g. Goldfeld-Quant test, Glejser test), and for independence (e.g. Durbin-Watson test, residual plots and partial plots).

Problem associated with near multicollinearity and the use of orthogonalisation techniques in model building (e.g. Gramm-Schmidt orthogonalisation).

The use of holdout samples and cross cross-fold validation in the validation of models.

(c) An introduction to time series regression modelling

Indicative sources

Draper, N.R. and Smith, H (1997), Applied Regression Analysis, 3rd Edition, Wiley Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

5. Logistic Regression Models

Syllabus

(a) Motivation and uses of binary logistic regression. Assessing significance (log-likelihood and t-ratios). Interpretation of models through the odds ratio. Assessing goodness-of-fit and lack of fit using standard diagnostic techniques (e.g. Hosmer-Lemeshow test, Pearson residuals, deviance residuals, Brown's test, pseudo R-squares, measures of concordance, roc analysis, the identification of influential observations).

(b) Extending the binary model to include either nominal outcomes or ordinal outcomes.

(c) An introduction to other link functions in the generalised linear model.

Indicative sources

Agresti, A (1996) An Introduction to Categorical Data Analysis, 1996, Wiley

Hosmer, D and Lemeshow, S (2000), Applied Logistic Regression, Wiley

6. Design and Analysis of Experiments

Syllabus:

(a) Advantages of designed experiments in engineering and science.

(b) The \"one-factor-at-a-time\" approach to experimentation. Randomisation, replication, blocking and balancing.

(c) Full and fractional factorial experiments and their analysis. 2n-k designs. Main effects and interaction effects. Use of normal and half-normal plots. Aliasing and confounding. Techniques for removing the ambiguities in aliased effects.

(d) Composite and sequential designs. Response surface designs and their analysis.

(e) Taguchi\'s contribution to designed experiments. Robust parameter design and analysis.

Indicative sources

Box G.E.P., Hunter W.G. & Hunter J.S. (1978). Statistics for Experimenters, Wiley , New York.

Montgomery D.C. (2001). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Wiley, New York.

Wu C.F. Jeff & Hamada (2000). Experiments. Planning, Analysis and Parameter Design Optimisation. Wiley, New York.

7. Designing and Analysing Questionnaire Surveys

Syllabus

(a) Methodology of sampling including sampling theory and limitations on inference from non-probabilistic methods. Sampling plans will include probabilistic and non-probabilistic sampling and include random sampling, systematic sampling, stratification techniques, cluster sampling, multi-stage sampling, quota sampling, convenience sampling and snowball sampling amongst others.

(b) Survey methods including, for example, personal interviewing, telephone interviewing, postal surveys.

(c) Question construction and measuring validity and reliability of questions and sub-scales.

(d) Storage and coding of data and the use of technology in the survey process.

(e) Identifying and applying appropriate multivariate methods of analysis for questionnaire data including regression models, the analysis of categorical data and multivariate exploratory data analysis. Indicative sources: Emory, W C and Cooper, D R, (1991) Business Research Methods, 4th Edition

Lattin, J, Carroll, J D and Green P E (2003), Analysing Multivariate Data, Thompson

8. Multivariate Exploratory Data Analysis

Syllabus

(a) Cluster Analysis. Measures of similarity and distance (e.g. Euclidean distance, Mahalanobis distance). Hierarchical methods (e.g. single linkage, complete linkage, Wards method) and non-hierarchical methods (e.g. k-means clustering) and their application to multivariate data.

(b) Applications of correspondence analysis.

(c) Factor Analysis and Principal Component Analysis. An introduction to principal components analysis as a method of extracting maximum orthogonal variance in a set of data.

Concepts involved in exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis. Using eigenvalues and eigenvectors to understand the process of extracting factors. Orthogonal and oblique rotations to aid factor interpretation. The use of scores derived from factor analysis.

(d) Discriminant Analysis. Motivation behind discriminant analysis. Deriving linear classification rules and evaluating their significance (e.g. Wilks' Lambda), interpreting rules (e.g. standardised coefficients, structure matrix, profile plots), evaluating the accuracy of classification rules (e.g. leave-one-out, Cohen's Kappa) and model building (e.g. stepwise selection).

Indicative sources

Everitt B and Dunn, G (2001), Applied Multivariate Data Analysis, Arnold

Hair, J.E., Anderson, R.E, Tatham, R.L and Black, W.C. (1998), Multivariate Data Analysis, 5th Edition, Prentice-Hall International.

Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

9. Multivariate Analyses of Variance

Syllabus

(a) A brief review of independent measures (between subjects) analysis of variance and post hoc analyses.

(b) Multiple Analysis of Variance for between subjects designs and relationship with Discriminant Analysis (including Wilks Lambda, Roys Largest Root, Pillai's Trace and Hotelling's Trace).

(c) The one-way blocked design (repeated measures). Analysis of one-way repeated measures designs including analysis of variance, checking models assumptions, graphical representation of results, post hoc tests and reporting tests. Mauchly's test of sphericity and adjusted F-tests including Greenhouse-Geisser, Hyundt-Feldt and Lower Bound.

(d) The results from 9(b) and 9(c) will be combined to analyse mixed designs.

(e) The multivariate approach to the analysis of repeated measures designs (Profile Analysis)

(f) Different approaches to the analysis of doubly-multivariate designs.

Indicative sources

Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

10. Forecasting

Syllabus

(a) Introduction to Forecasting. Assessing forecast accuracy, the role of forecasting in planning and decision making. Types of forecasting models. Monitoring forecasts.

(b) Exponential Smoothing Models. Simple and adaptive exponential smoothing. Double exponential smoothing, Holt\'s method and Holt-Winter\'s method. Damped exponential smoothing.

(c) The Box-Jenkins Approach. Autocorrelation and Partial Autocorrelation Functions. Types of Time Series model. Model Identification. Parameter Estimation.

Indicative sources

Box, G.E.P., Jenkins, G.M., and Reinsel G.C. (1994), Time Series Analysis, 3rd Edition, Prentice-Hall

Chatfield, C. (1996), The Analysis of Time Series, 5th Ed, Chapman Hall.

11. Data Mining

Syllabus

(a) Introduction to Data Mining: The role of data mining, components of data mining algorithms, assessing performance of data mining techniques, nearest neighbour methods.

(b) Classification and regression trees. Growing trees, pruning trees, use of trees for regression, use of trees for classification.

(c) Neural Nets. Perceptrons, feed forward neural nets, deciding on network structure, issues in training neural nets.

(d) Kernel estimation. Density estimation, nonparametric regression

Indicative sources

Hand, D. Mannila, H. and Smyth, P (2001), Principles of Data Mining, The MIT Press.

Hastie, T., Tibishrani, R and Friedman, J (2001), The Elements of Statistical Learning: Data Mining, Inference and Prediction, Springer-Verlag.

12. Survival Analysis

Syllabus

(a) Survival analysis and reliability. The analysis of censored and truncated data. Comparison of survival curves using tests such as Mantel-Haenszel test, Peto's test and the logrank test. Nonparametric, semi-parametric and parametric survival techniques such as Kaplan-Meier, Cox's Proportional Hazards and Weibull models and related techniques.

Indicative sources

Hosmer D and Lemeshow, S (2001) Applied Survival Analysis. Regression modelling of time to event data. Wiley

13. Time Series Regression Modelling with Non-stationary Data

Syllabus

(a) Definitions of stationarity. Non-stationarity of variables and its implications for regression modelling. Unit roots and the Dickey-Fuller tests for stationarity.

(b) Differencing as a solution to non-stationarity. Short-run and long-run equilibrium models.

(c) Cointegration and error-correction models. Testing for cointegration.

(d) Engle-Granger two stage and Johansen methodologies. Applications of ECM in bivariate models.

Indicative sources

Dougherty, C., (2002) Introduction to Econometrics, 2nd ed. Oxford

Kennedy, P., (2003) A Guide to Econometrics, 5th ed., Blackwell Oxley, L., (1999) Practical Issues in Cointegration Analysis, Blackwell Thomas, R.L., (1997) Modern Econometrics: An Introduction, Addison-Wesley

14. Independent Study in Advanced Quantitative Topics

The above units cover the most frequently used statistical techniques in applied quantitative research. The above units do not provide an exhaustive list of quantitative techniques likely to be needed in applied research. This unit (ISAQT) permits independent investigative research into the concepts, theory and practical applications of a specific technique (or techniques) with supervisory guidance. It is not possible to give a comprehensive list of topics that may be needed by an individual researcher but by way of examples, appropriate topics for this unit would include issues relating to specific experimental designs (e.g. clinical trials, cross-over trials), structural equation modelling (SEM), Bayesian Statistics, multilevel modelling.

15. Problem Solving: Case study 1 Analysis of an attitudinal survey.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques often used in the analysis of data from an attitudinal survey will be studied. These are likely to be:

  • Sampling methods
  • The analysis of two-way tables
  • The analysis of 2x2 tables
  • The analysis of two independent samples
  • The analysis of three or more related samples
  • Binary logistic regression analysis

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

16. Problem Solving: Case study 2 Analysis of an employment satisfaction survey.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques often used in the analysis of data from a satisfaction survey will be studied. These include:

  • Summarising Data
  • Descriptive statistics
  • Graphical displays
  • Analysis of two-way tables
  • Analysis of 2x2 tables
  • Non-parametric tests

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

17. Problem Solving: Case study 3 Analysis of data from the World Health Organisation.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques that are often used to build a statistical model will be studied. These include:

  • Graphical Displays
  • Summarising Data
  • Correlation Analysis
  • Comparison of three or more independent samples
  • Linear regression with one independent variable
  • Checking regression assumptions
  • Multiple regression analysis

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

By negotiation with the module leader, in units 15, 16 and 17, and if appropriate to the case study, any of the following web-based learning topics from Data Skills for Business may be included in the unit.

  • Graphical displays
  • Questionnaire design
  • Sampling methods
  • Sampling error and variation
  • Statistical inference the fundamentals
  • The analysis of two-way tables
  • The analysis of 2x2 tables
  • The normal distribution
  • Comparison of two independent samples
  • Comparison of two related samples
  • Comparison of three or more independent samples
  • Comparison of three or more related samples
  • Tests following an ANOVA
  • Correlation analysis
  • Linear regression with one independent variable
  • Checking regression assumptions
  • Multiple regression analysis an introduction
  • More multiple regression analysis
  • Binary logistic regression analysis

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEMD-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Symmetry
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction What is symmetry? Notions of symmetry in Mathematics. Symmetry in other areas of human endeavour such as Physics, Biology, Architecture and Art. The importance of symmetry principles. Describing symmetry.

Group Actions Motivational examples of groups: group structure in number systems; modular arithmetic; matrix groups; groups of bijections. Basic definitions and results in group theory. Subgroups, cosets and Lagrange's theorem. Generation. Centre. Homomorphisms and associated subgroups. Cyclic and dihedral groups. Symmetric and alternating groups. Cycle notation. Conjugacy and normal subgroups. Quotient groups and the First Isomorphism Theorem. Automorphisms of groups. Products. Groups of small order. Basic definitions and results concerning group actions. The idea of group action as a means of encoding symmetry. Orbits and Stabilizers. Cayley's Theorem. (Not Burnside)'s Theorem and its applications to enumeration. Introduction to groupoids as a generalized means of encoding symmetry.

Symmetry This section will explore some important applications of group theory and of group actions to symmetry problems in Mathematics. Topics will be selected from the following. Metric spaces and their isometry groups. Euclidean 2-space: structure of the isometry group; frieze groups; wallpaper groups; tessellations. Euclidean 3-space: structure of the isometry group; finite rotation groups; symmetries of the platonic solids. A comparison of the two-dimensional geometries: models of the geometries (euclidean, spherical, elliptical, hyperbolic); classical theorems; isometries; tessellations.
