Symmetry in linear algebra: the general linear group and its subgroups; canonical forms; accidental isomorphisms; applications of matrix groups over . Symmetry and dynamics: using group theory to find or to classify solutions of differential equations; symmetry in discrete dynamical systems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEQ7-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematics for Research C
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
UNITS

1. Basic concepts of Linear Algebra

The theory and application of linear algebra are fundamental to many branches of mathematics, both in abstract and concrete terms. This unit concentrates on the theory and practical applications of Numerical Linear Algebra. This unit will start with a system of linear equations as motivation for the study of matrices, linear transformations and, ultimately, vector and sub-spaces which are the basic building blocks of linear algebra.

As a result of studying this module, students will understand:

(i) representation of a linear algebraic system (LAS) as a matrix equation

(ii) representation of the solution of a LAS as a vector

- as a vector space

- linear transformations from to

- the properties of linear algebraic systems

The content is as follows:

(i) Linear Algebraic Systems (LAS):

- Introduction to Matrix Algebra

- Representation of a linear system of equations as a matrix equation

- motivating the definition of matrix multiplication

(ii) The vector space properties of . Definition of a subspace of .

(iii) Linear transformations from to and their representation by a matrix.

(iv) Solution of linear systems of equations by Gaussian Elimination.

- This includes consideration of:

- a) the null space and nullity of the system matrix

- b) the column space and rank of the system matrix

2. Linear Algebra (Solving Linear Algebraic Systems)

This unit covers the mathematical background behind and the implementation of methods for solving large systems of algebraic equations. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, either because a linear algebraic model is being used to describe a particular problem or as a consequence of applying a numerical scheme to the governing equation.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand

- the difference between the use of direct methods and iterative methods of solution

- how to implement these methods efficiently

- the importance of being able to identify ill-conditioning in a linear algebraic system and what techniques can be used to improve the accuracy of a numerical method of solution, when ill-conditioning is present

The content is as follows

(i) Direct methods: - Implementation of Gaussian elimination, using an LU factorisation routine

(ii) Iterative methods: Implementation of Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and Successive Over Relaxtion (SOR) schemes

(iii) Error control: Use of condition number to identifying ill-conditioned systems. In the case of direct methods, implementing pivoting strategies to control the propogation of rounding error

3: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

This unit covers what eigenvalues are and how useful they can be in the analysis of problems which arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics.

As a result the student will understand

- the nature of eigenvalues with respect to different types of matrices

- how eigenvalues can be computed

- the extension of the concepts of eigenvalues to include singular values of non-square matrices

The content is as follows:

(i) Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Revision of eigenvalues and eigenvectors to include definition and diagonalisation of matrices, and extend work to cover complex matrices and other similarity transformations

(ii) Computation of Eigenvalues: The power method, tridiagonal and upper Hessenberg forms of matrices and the QR algorithm for finding eigenvalues

(iii) Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) of matrices: The SVD for any rectangular matrix is defined and constructed. We look at an applications such as the least squares problem, numerical conditioning and the pseudoinverse

4. Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Introduction)

This unit introduces the initial value problem together with simple numerical techniques for producing a numerical solution. It contains material that must be understood prior to looking at the more advanced numerical techniques that form the basis of commercially available software packages that are used to solve this problem. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, whenever modelling of continuous time dynamical systems is a requirement of the research.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand:

- how an initial value problem arises from the modelling of a dynamical system

- the logic that lies behind the derivation of a numerical method for solving an intitial problem

- the nature and magnitude of errors that are incurred when using numerical methods to solve an initial value problem

The content is as follows:

(i) Initial Value Problems: Modelling dynamical systems, initial conditions, analytical solution (for simple problems)

(ii) Numerical schemes: Eulers method, the modified Euler method, Runge-Kutta schemes (including the classical 4th order scheme)

(iii) Error analysis: Discretisation error and stability of numerical schemes. In this unit, the analysis will be restricted to simple 2nd order numerical schemes

5. Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Error control and analysis)

Prior to taking this unit, student must have knowledge that is equivalent to that contained in unit 4 Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Introduction). Unit 5 considers the implementation of advanced numerical methods consideration of the efficient implementation of these schemes and methods for dealing with stiff equations. It contains material that lies behind the advanced numerical techniques that form the basis of commercially available software packages that are used to solve initial value problems. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, whenever modelling of continuous time dynamical systems is a requirement of the research.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand:

- the logic that lies behind the derivation of high order accuracy numerical methods for solving an initial problem

- which methods are appropriate for the solution of stiff equations

- how to control the error incurred when implementing these schemes

The content is as follows:

(i) High order numerical schemes: Linear multistep schemes, embedded Runge-Kutta schemes. Comparing the implentation of explicit and implicit numerical schemes.

(ii) Error estimation and control: Use of predictor-corrector schemes, embedded Runge-Kutta schemes. Introducing adaptive discretisation step size.

(iii) Stiff Equations: -Linear stability analysis of high order numerical schemes. Gear style schemes.

6. Nonlinear Dynamics

The main aim of this unit is to introduce the concepts of stability and bifurcation in nonlinear ordinary differential equations with a view to their application in other disciplines e.g. engineering, economics, biology, etc.

1. Solution concept and phase space

2. Linearisation and stability (via eigenvalue test)

3. Simple bifurcation of fixed points (saddle-node, transcritical and pitchfork)

4. Periodic solutions and Hopf bifurcation

Students will also be made aware of more complicated (chaotic) solution behaviour in higher dimensions, though this will not be assessed

7. Analytical methods for pricing financial derivative contracts

The aim of this unit is to introduce and apply stochastic models that occur in finance to the derivation of analytical expressions that are available for pricing derivative contracts such as forwards, futures and options. The unit covers the key theoretical concepts of risk neutral valuation and no arbitrage that are central to the derivation of pricing models. The use of Itos lemma in determining the probability distribution of a function of a random variable will be investigated as a prelude to deriving the Black-Scholes pricing model for financial derivatives where the underlying asset follows a geometric Brownian motion. Assets that follow a mean reverting process such as oil and electricity prices will be considered as an extension to the Black-Scholes framework.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand the main theoretical concepts involved in modelling financial derivative contracts and will have an appreciation of the limitations of the theory. In particular a student will be able to interpret the pricing formula as a description of the market view of risk that is inherent in a financial derivative contract.

8. Numerical methods for pricing financial derivative contracts

Before studying this unit, students will require a working knowledge of the material covered in Unit 7 together with experience of using a programming language that is suitable for implementing algorithms for the solution of mathematical problems. (for example Maple, Matlab, Visual Basic, Fortran, R or C).

The aim of this unit is to cover computational techniques that are used in the pricing of financial derivative contracts. These techniques may be based on:

  • Monte Carlo simulations
  • Binomial probability trees
  • Numerical integration techniques
  • Finite difference schemes

Students will be expected to apply one of the above approaches to the pricing of a derivative contract that they have chosen as relevant to their research. Students will be required to demonstrate understanding of how to the computational scheme is derived, its efficient implementation and the performance of the schemes in terms of its speed of convergence and stability.

9. Independent Study in Advanced Mathematical Topics

The taking of this unit is subject to negotiation and the identification of a suitable supervisor.

The above units cover techniques commonly used in research that involves applied mathematics. The above units do not provide an exhaustive list of mathematical techniques likely to be needed in applied research. The unit (ISAMT) permits independent investigative research into the concepts, theory and practical applications for a specific technique (or techniques) with supervisory guidance. It is not possible to give a comprehensive list of topics that may be needed by an individual researcher but by way of examples, appropriate topics for this unit would including issues relating to the application of a scientific programming language, mathematical modelling, discrete mathematics, optimisation problems, solution of partial differential equations, signal processing and analysis.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE6S-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Principles A
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Fundamental Units, Vectors and Scalars, Behaviour of Static Bodies:

Newton's 1st and 3rd Laws, force, weight, resultant component. Moments, equilibrium, centre of gravity, centre of area. Stress and strain - shear, direct stress, basic definitions.

Rigid Body Motion:

Linear motion, displacement, velocity, acceleration, falling bodies, projectile, relative velocity, application of Newton's 2nd Law.

Angular Motion:

Radians, angular velocity and accelerations. Analogous linear and angular laws and quantities.

Energy:

Types of energy transfer - work, heat. Possessed energy - potential, kinetic, internal, electrical. Conservation of energy.

DC Electrical Circuit:

Electrical current/voltage. Mechanical analogies. Resistors in series and parallel. Heating effect of current, variation of resistance with temperature. Voltage divider and current divider. Simple circuit calculations,

Signals:

DC, sinusoid, square wave. Period and frequency. Use of oscilloscope. Peak, mean and rms. Power dissipation. EM waves and modulation.

AC circuits:

Capacitors and inductors. Rate of change of current and voltage, C-R and L-R behaviour to sine and step voltages. Phasors and phase lead/lag.

Analogue Processing Devices:

Operational amplifiers (as ideal devices only), negative feedback; non-inverting gain, inverting gain circuits. Differential amplifier. Comparator (without hysteresis). Sensors

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE6X-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Professional Studio Practice
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Personal skills: time management, study skills, listening skills, negotiation.

Communication skills: oral presentation, writing technical reports.

Research skills: including completion of the library workbook.

Project planning and keeping to deadlines.

Working in groups: interpersonal relationships, effective teamwork.

Conformity to recognised standards in a variety of areas.

IT use and knowledge: word processing, spreadsheets, Internet.

Studio induction, booking system, logging, health and safety issues.

Studio technology: microphones and headphones, mixers, tapes and recording

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHJ-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Operating Systems and Systems Administration
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEEHE-30-1 OR UFEEHF-30-1 OR UFEETS-20-1 OR UFEEHV-20-1)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Operating Systems

Operating System Organisation models and structures

Process & Object Management kernel services, interrupt handlers, scheduling.

Interprocess Communication event handling, message passing, synchronous-asynchronous, shared memory

Concurrency and Synchronisation semaphores, critical regions, monitors, message passing, multi-threaded processes

Memory Management Organisation algorithms and policies, Virtual Memory Management

I/O Management Device driver design, Buffering and interrupt handling.

File & Persistent Object Management File organisation, directories and naming, index nodes, disk block management. Network & distributed file systems Protection and Security Models for secure computing, access control, capability based systems, access control lists

Networked Systems

Computer network architecture\'s and models Layered models, peer protocols, the ISO OSI model

Protocol Specification and Design Specfication techniques -FSM, layered protocols, error correction Connection vs connectionless protocols

Medium Access Control Protocols MAC techniques

Subnetworks and Internetworks network layer design, routing and switching, addressing and naming network topology

Transport Services TLIs

Network & Distributed Systems Management Security issues, fault, monitoring and accounting issues.

TCP/IP protocols IP layer, ICMP, ARP TCP socket programming Applications IPV4 and IPng Administering a TCP IP network

System Administration Specifying and installing an OS and network Initialise the system for user and applications Install devices, software packages and communication links Making the system secure, investigation of security strategies Instigation of system maintenance - backup, user control Document system and system modifications

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7A-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to Software Development in C
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Programming: Students are introduced to the fundamentals of programming in a high-level language through the medium of simple control activities.

Flow chart design methods; Top-down, stepwise-refinement design strategies; Variables, operators and control flow; Writing expressions using logical, relational, bitwise and arithmetic operators; Decision making; Functions and program structure; Files; Arrays as a simple data structure; Basic elements of graphics programming; Pointers. Hardware:

Students will be given a brief (1 or 2 lectures) introduction to the functional division within a microprocessor/microcomputer and introduced to the concepts of a CU, IAS, ALU, computer instruction, fetch execute cycle, machine code and assembly language; Accessing I/O devices in order to transfer information using address, data and control buses; Digital I/O. Concepts of parallel and serial I/O; Analog I/O. Use, accuracy and speed considerations in the design of D/A and A/D interfaces; Sensing - digital bumpers, opto-reflectors, analogue optical input, digital & analogue joysticks; Actions - stepping motor, dc motor (analogue & digital) and at the system level the robot (plant) is controlled in an appropriate manner; Introduction to the control cycle - sense, process, action - open loop and closed loop arrangements. The control cycle will be used by the students in the context of controlling a mobile robot; Process - programming skills employed to process the sensed information and control actions, emphasis on polling but the notion of interrupts will be introduced.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7D-20-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Electronic Fundamentals
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Energy:

Work, energy and power in electrical systems. Conservation of energy.

DC Electrical Circuit:

Electrical current/voltage. Resistors in series and parallel. Heating effect of current, variation of resistance with temperature. Voltage divider and current divider. Simple circuit calculations, use of Ohm, Kirchoff laws, electric and magnetic fields. Example: electronics in motor vehicles

Analogue Electronic Components:

Diodes,. Bridge rectifiers. Transistor Amplifiers/Switches, design of simple amplifiers Power transfer. Operational Amplifiers, design of simple inverting and non-inverting The op.amp as a switch, design of a level detector and an oscillator. Use of these circuits. Opto-electronics, LEDs, photodiodes/transistors. Example: robotics

Digital Circuits:

Representation of digital information, basic gates, AND, OR, NAND, NOR, NOT, XOR. Simple combinational logic problems. Structure of a simple microcomputer. Example: Aircraft systems

AC signals:

Analysis of sine waves, RMS value, phase, frequency, electromagnetic spectrum, signal transmitters and receivers, modulation techniques. Example: communication systems, mobile communications

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7F-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Control & Dynamics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Control mathematics, such as matrix algebra, Laplace transform, z-transformer, differential equations, and difference equations, for control system modelling, analysis, and design.

Use of computational packages, such as Matlab and Maple, to analyse and design control systems.

Advanced control concepts such state-space representations, solution of state equations, controllability and observability; state-feedback, (pole placement) control design.

Modelling and analysis of multivariable control systems, to convert from the transfer function model to state space representation, and vice versa. Evaluation of dynamic plant performance in aspect of controllability and observability.

Modelling and analysis of multivariable control systems, to convert from the transfer function model to state space representation, and vice versa. Evaluation of dynamic plant performance in aspect of controllability and observability.

Design of multivariable state-feedback controllers, decoupling control systems, state observers.

Digital control system analysis and design and practical application

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7L-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Mobile Communications
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
INFORMATION THEORY: Information contents of signals, Transmission of information, and Hartley and Shannon's Law and its applications.

CELLULAR PRINCIPLES: The cellular concept, Typical cell operation, System capacity, Frequency re-use distance, Determination of cell radius, Sectoring, Properties of the radio channel, Space wave propagation, Short-term fading (fast fading).

MOBILE COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS:

First generation analogue systems: Total Access Communication System (TACS), TACS radio parameters, TACS mobile network control, Call management in TACS, Alternative analogue systems.

Second Generation Communications Systems: Global System Mobile Communication (GSM), GSM radio interface, Mapping of logical channels in GSM, GSM modulation, coding and error protection, Handoff in GSM, GSM handoff measurements, Features of the GSM system, Operation of the GSM system, Security in GSM, Others Cordless Communications systems.

3G Mobile Communications Systems: Universal Mobile Telecommunications System (UMTS), Comparison with GSM and others second generation systems, CDMA principle, WCDMA air interface-physical layer, Modulation techniques and spread spectrum, UMTS networks and network management.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEUA-40-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Audio Processing
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Foundation topics: Introduction to analysis, modification, synthesis and control of audio signals; Mathematical techniques and forms used in audio processing; Programming technologies and software packages used in the module
  • Analysis and representation of sonic form: Understanding time and frequency domain representations of sounds
  • Relationships between acoustical sound sources/modifiers and audio processing techniques
  • Sound modification: Musical and studio effects; Perceptual response, time and frequency domain effects
  • Synthesised sound: Sampling; Classical and advanced digital synthesis techniques
  • Musical control in audio systems

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEN6-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Linux in Commerce
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The history and philosophy of open source software provision Open source software as a new commercial paradigm The GNU project Third party suppliers for Open Source code Linux as a corporate, social endeavour Open Source licence agreements

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHF-30-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer Systems Architecture
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The Von Neumann Inheritance: digital logic, CPU& fetch-execute, microcode, migration of functionality, the RISC/CISC debate, the bus bottleneck, future architectures: multiprocessors, distributed data.

CPU architecture, adders/subtractors in two's complement integer format, decoders, barrel shifters.

IEEE 754 floating point data format and arithmetic operations

From Hex to X: machine code, assembler routines, compiled & interpreted languages, compiler/interpreter strategies, linking, Win32 libraries, using debuggers.

How Windows Work: video subsystems, graphic primitives, graphics coprocessors, multitasking, input from mice, network communication, X protocols, Client-server applications.

The Network as a Computing Environment: network applications, WWW, ftp, telnet, email, ping address resolution, ip name, ip number, mac number, hosts file, arp/rarp networked operating systems, Unix, Windows/NT introduction to basic facilities, sockets, rpcs, rcp, NFS/mount, the tx/rx of data packets ethernet cards video/voice transmission.

Networking from Nothing: serial communications through the COM ports. Packet addressing, routing and flow control. Handling errors with a checksum

Choosing and Using Peripherals: CD-ROM and hard-disk units, the IDE and SCSII interfaces, disc organisation and directory structures, laser printers, introduction to PostScript, graphic subsystems, document scanners.

Estimating disk access and data transmission times

Using Unix as a software tool-bench.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHG-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Software Design & C++
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEEHE-30-1 OR UFEE5H-20-1 OR UFEE7A-20-1 OR UFEETS-20-1)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
UML and Case Tools: An Introduction to the Concept and use of Rational Rose Classes, derived classes and objects, members, attributes and operations, Data hiding, private, public, private and protected

Constructors and destructors

Classification hierarchies. Inheritance, Polymorphism, virtual functions and overloading

Input / output using streams

Template and container classes.

Introduction to Microsoft Foundation Class library.

C++ development environments. DevStudio IDE, GNU G++ .

Using C++ for embedded and stand alone applications. Problems with memory allocation, virtual functions and run-time environments.

Interfacing C++ to assembler level programs, dealing with tasking and interrupts.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEEL-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Operations & Quality Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The relationship between manufacturing and the rest of the business, manufacturing as a strategic weapon, focused factories, flexible manufacturing systems. Product and process lifecycles, concurrent and simultaneous engineering, design for manufacture and assembly.

The structure of manufacturing resources, approaches to organising manufacturing facilities, job shops, batch production, flow systems, cellular systems and group technology, calculation of batch sizes and order quantities, ABC parts classification.

The selection of production equipment and systems, an introduction to automation and robotics, methods for analysing and modelling production, line balancing, plant layout, linear programming and simple optimisation problems, use of discrete event simulation.

The control of production systems, an overview of MRP, MRP II, OPT and JIT, the control of projects.

Introduction to Quality control, Quality Assurance, Total Quality Management and improvement techniques: need for management commitment and leadership; management strategies for quality; quality policy and planning; creation, operation and maintenance of quality systems; quality auditing. Concept of internal/external customer care. Quality system standards (ISO 9000): role and requirements. Quality awards and self-assessment. Quality costs collection and use. Computer aided quality systems. Quality of design (QFD & FMEA); Supply chain management, handling of customer complaints.

Quality in manufacturing and service industries: inspection activities; statistical techniques; department and process analysis and performance improvement; quality circles; improvement teams.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHM-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Embedded and Microprocessor Systems
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEEHE-30-1 OR UFEEHF-30-1 OR UFEE7A-20-1 OR UFEETS-20-1 OR UFEEHV-20-1)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to C: Basic types, control structures, operators; Data structures in C; Pointers; Scope and functions; Preprocessor; ANSI, POSIX and K&R standards.

Linking C and an assembler: Writing environment initialisation files; Mixed language programming; Passing parameters between HLLs and ALPs; Writing interrupt service routines.

Software tools for cross development: Understanding how compilers work; Using linkers and linker options; Assemblers and compilers; S-record and Intel Hex downloaders;

Compilation control programmes; Writing support code for compilers; How to select tools for cross-development; Make and debuggers.

Interfacing in C: Writing portable code for low level operations; Programming serial ports; Programming parallel ports; Programming serial ports; Programming timers; Introduction to writing device drivers; Writing small schedulers.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHN-10-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer Architecture
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Von Neumann system architecture. - Digital logic as a basis for building computers. - CPU, memory, peripheral I/O, and bus. - Adders/subtractors in two's complement integer format, decoders. - Example machine instructions and the fetch-execute cycle. - Peripherals: keyboard, mouse, video subsystems, printers, network ports, USB, disks. -

Choosing and using peripherals: CD-ROM and hard-disk units, the IDE and SCSI interfaces, disc organisation and directory structures, laser printers, introduction to PostScript, graphic subsystems, document scanners.

Assembling PC s from component parts. Booting computers and installing the operating system

The role of the operating system from user and programmer's viewpoints. - Common operating system functions. - Command line and GUI user interfaces. -

Data storage formats: ASCII, Unicode, two's-complement integer, IEEE floating point, boolean, string.

Compilers, assemblers and linkers.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEEN-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Design Embodiment & Materials Selection
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The key aim of the course is to establish design practices through lectures, coursework and self-learning. It emphasises practical hands-on design approach with 'real' components. The course include:

  • Using standard mechanical components (fasteners, seals, bearings, etc.) and features (location, limits and fits, welds, stress raisers, etc.)
  • Selection or specification of bought-out equipment (making use of catalogue library and Technical Index).
  • Use of I-DEAS solid modelling software.
  • Integration of analytical areas, especially stress analysis, into the design process.
  • Selection of materials. For example, heat treatment of metals, structure behaviour and manufacturing process of ceramics.
  • Composite structures, anisotropic conditions, high performance composites, metal matrix and ceramic matrix composites.
  • Failure mechanisms in components and materials: fatigue, creep, corrosion and fracture toughness. Mechanisms involved in these failures.
  • Design and material selection to overcome likely failure modes. NDT and non-destructive evaluation, techniques. Case studies of failure.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHQ-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Web Technology
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: HTML tags, tables, image maps, forms and frames; HTTP protocols; Cascading style sheets; Using client-side Javascript with browsers; Review of browser applets and plugins; Perl for CGI scripting; Web site design and specification issues: HCI, performance, security, integrity, availability, maintenance; XML; PHP server-side scripting; Introduction to Servlets; Applet and Servelet security; Usage monitoring; LAMP (Linux, Apache, MySQL and PHP); Introduction to SQL; Java database connectivity (JDBC); Java Beans and JSP; Setting up Apache on Linux; Embedded web servers.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMERB-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Flight Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Essential aircraft systems on modern aircraft, e.g. including: propulsion, flight control, hydraulic, landing gear, fuel, cabin air / pressurisation, ice / rain protection, electrical power generation / distribution, avionic ( communication /navigation/ radar ), duplicated and emergency systems. System fault diagnosis. Introduction to aircraft system maintenance manuals and documentation

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEJ5-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Real-time and Embedded Systems Design
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEEHG-30-2 OR UFCE4B-20-2 OR UFEEHM-30-2 OR UFEE69-20-2)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Concurrent Systems: Intellectual simplicity or system responsiveness; The interleaving problem; Centralized I/O management; Concurrent processes; varying priorities; pre emption; time slicing; Examples of commercial systems.

Commercial Executive Systems: Functionality; selection criteria; Scheduling strategies; Using Linux as a target executive; Processes; events; signals; pipes; Installing device drivers; Networking support facilities.

Languages for Real time Systems implementations: The requirements for real time systems; Choosing a compiler.

Using a data flow method for design, eg Ward Mellor/Yourdon: Diagrams; pseudo code text; hierarchical design capture; Transformation to code modules; Run time support facilities; Process communication/synchronization methods.

Review of Design Methodologies for Real time Systems: OOD; FSM; Yourdon; DARTS; Planning for Cross Development; Choosing and configuring cross compiler tool kits; Microcontroller target environments.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE88-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Application Domains of Information Technology
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Information. Data, information, and knowledge; information and communication; representation, expression and interpretation. Information as grounded in human action and interaction. Types and general uses of information. Conveying meaning and coordinating action. Information as resource or process. Information technology and the digitization of information. Information/communication structured and mediated through IT systems.

Information in organization and society. Information and action in social settings. Uses of information in organizations: communication, control, decision making, planning, operations, invention. Information levels and channels in organizations. Moral and political dimensions of information use. Growing scope, volume, and salience of information. Information overload and anxiety: responses.

Information Systems. Systems perspectives as a way of thinking about, modelling, and intervening in complex sociotechnical environments. The range and variety of information systems. Typologies and evolutionary frameworks. Evolution of computer/network-based information systems. Interrelations between technical systems and contexts of use. Complexity, creativity and variety in the interface. Diversity of systems, contexts and users. Models and methods for developing information systems (overview). Emergence of applications ahead of theory and methodology.

Application Domains. Exploration of a range of domains, e.g.: commercial, industrial, educational, medical, library, financial, governmental, scientific, professional, domestic, artistic, personal, entertainment, information services. Regular characteristics of selected domains; the role of information systems in supporting and extending activities in these domains; typical applications. Assimilation of new applications into working practices and impact on working life. Trends in the development of technologies, organizational and social contexts, and applications. Information appliances. Emerging application domains.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEJB-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Systems Administration
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEEHE-30-1 OR UFEEHX-20-2 OR UFEEHJ-30-2 OR UQC155S2)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Computer network architectures and models: layered models; service access points; peer to peer protocols.

Data transmission basics: data encoding, multiplexing, modulation; error correcting techniques; characteristics of transmission media; synchronous and asynchronous transmission.

Protocol Specification and Design: Connection oriented and connectionless protocols; error and flow control protocols; link-level protocols, transport protocols, application protocols.

Medium Access Control Protocols: Mutual exclusion problem; token solutions; distributed queues.

Subnetworks and Internetworks: Network layer design issues; topology and connectivity analysis; addressing and naming; routing algorithms; congestion control algorithms; packet and circuit switching.

Transport Services: Protocol design issues; transport level interface.

Network and Distributed Systems Management: Monitoring and event handling; policies and obligations; fault, security, configuration, performance management services; SNMP and CMlP protocols.

Operating System Organisation: Models - monolithic, layered, process, object, virtual machines; client-server; network and distributed operating systems, middle ware, component; technology.

Process & Object Management: Kernel services; interrupt handlers, process-object descriptors, state tables, state transmissions; scheduling algorithms and load balancing; object invocation.

Interprocess Communication: Event handling, message passing; synchronous-synchronous; shared memory.

Concurrency and Synchronisation: Safety and liveness properties; semaphores; critical regions; monitors; message passing; multi-threaded processes.

I/O Management: The Posix system call interface and I/O descriptors; device driver design; buffering and interrupt handling.

File and Persistent Object Management: File organisation block management.

Network and File Distributed Systems: Protection and security; models for secure computing; access control; capability based systems; access control lists; authentication; cryptography; auditing; the Kerberos project.

System Administration: Specify and install an OS and network; initialise the system for user and applications; install devices, software packages and communication links; make the system secure; investigate various security strategies; instigate system maintenance - backup; user control; document system and system modifications.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEJX-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Recording Technology
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Music sequencing systems and application. Transducers, mics and loudspeakers. Analogue and digital recording technology, formats, sample rates, noise, distortion. Mixing, effects and processes. Listening formats - mono, stereo surround etc. and mixing for these formats.

Room acoustics, spatial hearing. Sound design for broadcast and post production. Critical listening and appreciation of music and recording techniques.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEK7-30-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to Robotics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: What is a robot? History: three landmark robots (Elsie, Shakey, Genghis). Components of mobile robots (sensors, actuators, control architectures, power source). Locomotion and navigation. Computer vision. Applications of robots (manufacturing, medicine, space, entertainment). Collective robotics. Future of robots in society.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFN-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Foundation Maths 1
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Basic Skills and Notation. Inequalities, Modulus, Algebraic and arithmetic properties. Percentages, Significant figures and decimal places, Sigma notation.

Linear Equations. Graphic representation, Quadratic solutions, Revenue, cost and profit. Indices, Exponentials and logarithms. Mathematics of Finance. Compound interest, Calculating total investment using geometric series. Linear Programming. Sketching feasible regions, Problem formulation.

Differentiation. Finding slopes, Basic rules of differentiation, Chain rule, Product rule. Quotient rule, Finding and classifying maxima and minima.

Integration. Anti-differentiation, Integral as an area, Evaluation of elementary functions.

Matrices. Basic matrix operations, Inverse of a matrix. Solution of simultaneous equations by row reduction.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEMY-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Embedded Co-design (VHDL & C)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Review of VHDL & C languages and constructs. Review of Logic elements in the context of programmable devices including timing, drive strength, use of component libraries etc. CPU selection issues Creating the co-design environment and design management. Use of modelling guidelines. Design verification and formal verification of testing. Simulation and testing, test pattern generation. Controlling the synthesis and compilation processes, optimisation. Timing. Constraints imposed by target hardware. Vendor specific issues. Hardware testing and debugging, faults, fault simulation, problems. Software testing and debugging. Use of Intellectual Property (IP) in a co-design context and design for reuse.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE9M-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Technical Writing and Editing
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• "Technical" is used in its broader sense to mean "relating to a specialised subject", rather than necessarily information and communication technology.
  • Technical writing and technical editing, contrasted - skills common to writers, skills common to editors.
  • The editor's role: editorial skills; editor's responsibilities - to the writer, to the customer, for accuracy, for time management, for understanding. Editing as a form of project management.
  • The editor within the team - quality, objectivity, cost, efficiency, economy of scale; the editor's job. Working with other people - writers, managers, production staff and clients.
  • Purpose and process of editorial reviews, editing stages and product development schedule; developmental editing - objectives, inconsistencies, content issues, style issues, potential problem areas.
  • Writing style, accuracy (factual and technical), the audience, usability. House and document style guides.
  • Production edits: scheduling, text, page layout, figures and tables, table of contents, index, final details.
  • Writing and editing for specific audiences - readability, terminology, layout suited to purpose, allowing for possible disabilities.
  • Writing and editing for an international audience: language considerations, cultural considerations, technical differences.
  • Copymarking and proofreading.
  • Editing computer manuals.
  • Editing in electronic format.
  • Editing issues specific to online documents.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEP4-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Microsoft Windows Administration & Security
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction - What\'s wrong with windows? surviving the first day. Microsoft services - Overview, issues, configuring, deploying and troubleshooting security templates. Active Directory - Overview, Structures, Domains & Trusts, Secure Replication, Authentication, Delegation & ACL\'s The .NET framework - Overview, Evidence based, code access & role based security. The role of cryptography Securing IIS, relationship with active directory services, Domain issues, Configuration DHCP & DNS security issues in a Microsoft

environment Auditing & Logging. - Configuration, analysis, issues for Sarbanes-Oxley Act compliance within a UK context. IPSec, VPN & Remote Access -Implementation, configuration, management and policies SMB/CIFS security issues. Security issues in an heterogeneous environment - issues, integrating windows & unix networks, specific issues relating to distributed file systems, authentication & ACL\'s Incident response

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEUX-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Operations Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The relationship between operations such as manufacturing and the rest of the business, operations design as a strategic weapon, focused factories, flexible manufacturing systems. Product and process lifecycles, concurrent and simultaneous engineering, design for manufacture and assembly.

The structure of technical operations resources, approaches to organising manufacturing facilities, job shops, batch production, flow systems, cellular systems and group technology, calculation of batch sizes and order quantities and other concepts related to operations management.

The selection of technical equipment and systems to support operations, methods for analysing and modelling production, line balancing, plant layout, linear programming and simple optimisation problems.

The control of production systems, and overview of MRP, MRP II, OPT and JIT, the control of projects.

Introduction to Quality Control, Quality Assurance and Total Quality Management. Improvement techniques: need for management commitment and leadership; management strategies and planning; creation, operation and maintenance of management systems. Introduction to Quality Management Systems (ISO 9000). Collection and use of data and information to support and aid management decision making. Computer aided quality systems. Quality of design (QFD & FMEA). Supply chain management.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEPF-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Recording Projects
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Initially the students will be familiarised with the available facilities, equipment and resources. They will receive guidance on relevant techniques and suitable practice to develop their skills.

2. In the major part of the module students will work on a number of different recording projects. The projects span a range of musical/sonic contexts, requiring the use of different techniques and creative approaches to the tasks. In particular, students will spend time:

- experimenting with different equipment and techniques

- developing listening skills

- reflecting and improving on their methods

- critically evaluating results relative to musical/artistic and technological aims

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEPK-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Music Dissertation (Advanced)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The intention of this module is for students to investigate a chosen musical instrument thoroughly from a wide range of viewpoints. The investigation is to be made largely independently and would include, for example, the instrument's structure, sound production, its history, physics, context of use.

The student will be given guidelines on what is expected in the final dissertation. This will include an indication of the subject matter to be researched, such as the history, cultural context, physical structure, sound reproduction, coupling and amplification within the instrument, resonances, waveforms, synthesis of the instrument and problems with recording from the instrument. Material on relevant aspects of project management, suitable for a small project, will be provided, and students are expected to apply it to the planning and management of their activities in the module.

Students will be expected to create, using modern synthesis techniques, a synthetic version of their chosen instrument. The most important aspect of this will be the control of the sound of the instrument using a range of different parameters to attempt to recreate the levels and intricacies of control found in a classical wind instrument.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEND-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Transferable Management Skills
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Overview of essential personal skills for library and information managers. Learning styles and effective learning behaviour. Information literacy concepts and skills. Learning and study skills. Investigation and analysis skills. Communication, report writing and presentation skills.
  • Theory and practice of continuing professional development. Professional qualifications and chartership. Role of relevant professional body (CILIP). Assessing and meeting development needs.
  • Concepts and key skills in management of self and others. Working with other people. Leadership, motivation and team building. Time and stress management. Planning and coordinating work. Running meetings, negotiating and influencing. Change management.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE76-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to Communications Systems and Signals
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- AC circuit analysis, phasor diagrams, complex number terminology. Laplace transfom.

- Frequency spectra. Harmonics. Fourier series. Fourier transform. Bandwidth. Discrete and continuous signals. Sampling.

- Review of operation of operational amplifiers, gain and phase shift. Bode plots. Filters. Tuned amplifiers. Oscillators. Use of simulation software (eg. MATLAB).

- PCM, encoding and decoding techniques, commercially available subsystems. Use of simulation software (eg CommSim)

Transmission of Data:

- Parallel & Serial; concepts, limitations of parallel transmission

- Parallel; computer address & data busses, IEE488, SCSI, HIPPI

- Serial transmission modes; simplex, half duple, full duplex; Asynchronous; separate clocks, character framing, timing problems

- Synchronous; Rx clock recovery, clock encoding for bit synchronization, byte synchronization, message framing

Serial Data Transmission Standards:

- Physical layer standards; electrical (or optical), timing and mechanical; Standards organizations; V, X and I standards;

Data Link Layer Protocols:

- Typical data link topology; point to point, multidrop, shared bus, and connections to packet or circuit switched networks

- Error control concepts; full or partial link control, end to end control; little or no low level error control

- Flow control; hardware, XON-XOFF, sliding window

- Character oriented protocol; bisync

- Bit oriented protocol; HDLC, frame structure, operational modes NRM, ARM & ABM

- User services; unacknowledged connectionless service, connection oriented services

- Data Link layer management; medium access control (MAC), logical link control (LLC); LAPM, LAPB, LAPD;

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPERM-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Industrial & Operational Case Studies
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Critical analysis of problems and proposed solutions

- General introduction to the research process

- Research aims and objectives

- Research approaches

- Project management

- Writing and presenting technical reports

- Students will also be required to complete two subject specific industrial case studies

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEERV-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Sonic Design: Music, Art and Technology
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is designed to develop student understanding of artistic practice in the area of sound and music, particularly with reference to technique, technology, aesthetics, culture and creative methods. A wide range of contemporary styles will be considered. The following topic areas will be considered:

  • Compositional techniques and working methods for different contexts.
  • Development from individual sounds to complete pieces.
  • The psychology of creator and consumer; creativity, inspiration, emotion, and engagement.
  • Structure and implementation; writing, recording, production, and performance.
  • Composition through performance, and as separate activities.
  • The interaction between humans and technology, as creator and consumer.
  • Relationships between sound and other media.
  • Effective use of different technologies for the generation and transformation of sound.
  • Analytical listening and the appreciation and interpretation of different sonic arts.
  • Developing an awareness and understanding of artistic forms beyond immediate personal tastes.
  • Expressing and representing musical/sonic form.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEES3-40-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Music Composition and Performance
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is designed to allow the student to develop their musical abilities in both composition and performance. These two aspects are seen as closely interlinked and students will be expected to write and perform their own compositions. There will also be an expectation to promote their own compositions and performances at concerts and events, which will be arranged with staff support.

Composition:

  • A study of the development of contemporary compositional techniques leading to the creation of a portfolio of new and original music in a range of idioms
  • Musical styles and genres in relation to the historical development of Western music - key historical influences on composing practice through the centuries from Renaissance to Contemporary
  • Harmonic concepts and tonality
  • Traditional and contemporary forms and structures
  • Non Western rhythmic influences e.g. African, Indian
  • Instrumentation - technical guidelines, exploration of ranges and timbres, writing for ensemble
  • Arrangement and creative transcription - transferring instrumental sources effectively to a different context
  • Electronic and experimental composition, fusion
  • Media composition - TV, film, corporate, theatre

Performance:

  • Development of technique, stylistic awareness and musical interpretation on own instrument/voice
  • Understanding of appropriate historical concepts and genres in relation to performance practice
  • Exploration of orchestral, chamber music and ensemble repertoire through the study of scores, recordings and practical workshops
  • Opportunities to perform a wide range of music in a variety of contexts including student ensembles and UWE Centre for Performing Arts activities e.g. Orchestra, Singers, Chamber Choir, Big Band, Musical Shows at venues and events throughout the South West
  • Ensemble rehearsal and direction

Composition and Performance:

  • Integrated workshops of ongoing composition projects
  • Practical knowledge of instrumental capabilities through student exchange and interaction
  • Practical approach and critical reflection through a variety of resources such as recordings and self-evaluation

Language of Music:

  • Musical literacy and terminology
  • Development of aural perception - ear training, fault finding, stylistic awareness and score reading
  • Effective written and verbal communication of musical thoughts

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEETB-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Machine Vision
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Basic Concepts:

  • Machine vision, in the context of computer and human vision.
  • Machine vision applications: robot guidance, object recognition and tracking, image understanding, inspection and quality control, metrology, security (biometrics), medical applications.
  • The five stages of the machine vision process.
  • Hardware elements: lighting, camera, optical configuration, frames-store, resolution v field of view, monochrome v colour. Image acquisition and display: photosensitive devices, digitisation.
  • 2D Image analysis

- Binary images:

  • Feature extraction: segmentation (connectivity), region mensuration.
  • Erosion and dilation.
  • Skeletonization.

- Grey level images:

  • Histogram analysis.
  • Image pre-processing: brightness/contrast enhancement, standard mappings: negation, thresholding, sharpening, smoothing.
  • Thresholding
  • Convolution (edge detection).
  • Hough space domain transformations
  • Feature extraction: area, perimeter, shape descriptions.

- 3D Image analysis:

  • Applications.
  • Projected patterns.
  • Stereo triangulation.
  • Photometric stereo.

- Interfacing and data collection.

- Management appraisal: why vision, safety and reliability, quality, flexibility, economic justification

- Generating machine vision code.

- Current research (e.g. surface inspection, 3D metrology, face recognition, etc).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEETU-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Digital Systems Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Review of basic functional parts of one small and one medium scale microcontroller, including internal architecture, programming model, op-codes, addressing modes, memory mapping and address decoding.
  • Use of digital electronics CAD tools, and simple system simulations
  • Design and implementation of single-chip microcontroller-based embedded computer hardware
  • Simple assembly language and high-level language software design and implementation
  • Digital and analogue electrical interfacing of simple state machines with simple electrical actuators and sensors, including an introductory understanding of the sensor and actuator characteristics
  • Signals and their Types; Simple AC Signals, Electromagnetic Radiation, Baseband Signals, Frequency Spectrum, Relationship between Frequency and Wavelength ''
  • LC Circuit Response; Behaviour of Inductor, Capacitor and Resistor in a Circuit; Resonance, Q factor and Selectivity, Parallel and Series Tuned Circuit, Practical Tuned Circuits
  • Basic Transistor Amplifier; BJT circuits, Common emitter transistor amplifier
  • Oscillators; Oscillator Principles, Basic Types of Oscillators, Transistor Oscillator, Crystal Oscillator
  • Binary Counter; Basic understanding and circuit analysis, LED
  • Principles of Aerials: radiation from an aerial, isotropic radiator, effective length, monopole aerial, gain of an aerial, effective aperture and the power received.
  • Pulse Modulation and Types: Sampling Theorem, PCM, PAM

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEETV-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Foundation Skills for Software Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The Nature of Software & Design (3 hours)

  • Systems Life-Cycle
  • The common sources of technical information
  • Why software fails
  • Reliability, flexibility, reusability, & maintainability

Designing for Software (10 hours)

  • Introducing UML
  • Problem analysis and specification
  • Functional decomposition (Structure Charts)
  • Introduction to event-driven systems (Finite State Diagrams)
  • Introduction to data-driven systems (JSP).

Software Tools in Unix (12 hours)

  • Compilers, assemblers and linkers
  • Common Unix tools: grep, find, make etc
  • Process piping and redirection
  • Using X-Windows

Problems, paradigms and algorithms (10 hours)

  • Analysing problems
  • Algorithm selection and evaluation
  • Search, sorting and backtracking methods
  • Iteration and recursion
  • Planning for parallel processing and multithreading

Source code protection (2 hours)

  • SourceSafe, CVS, Subversion
  • Documentation support systems, doxygen

Debugging Software (5 hours)

  • Using dbx and gvd for debugging programs
  • Approaches to testing: black-box, white-box
  • Top-down and bottom-up strategies
  • Testing multi-modular programs

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEAV-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Aerofluid Systems
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFQEFH-20-1 AND (UFMEBF-40-1 OR UEM001H1 OR (UFMEQT-20-1 AND UFMEQU-20-1)))
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The atmosphere: variation of pressure, temperature and density with height; the ISA and its variants; non-standard, idealised atmosphere models; pressure and density altitudes.

Dimensional analysis: dimensional statements; homogeneity; non-dimensional groups; Buckingham\'s -theorem; similarity

Aeronautical terminology: axes systems and degrees of freedom; classification of aircraft components and configurations; visual representations of body shapes and flow behaviour.

Viscous flow: Reynolds' experiments; laminar and turbulent flows; the boundary layer concept; velocity profiles; transition and separation.

Boundary layers: Reynolds number(s) and its/their effects; layer characteristics; numerical modelling for laminar, turbulent and mixed layers; skin friction and layer thickness estimation.

Low-speed aerodynamics: flow over an aerofoil; effects of angle of attack; vorticity.

Forces on an aerofoil: force and moment coefficients; variation of lift, drag and pitching moment with angle of attack; effects of lift on drag and pitching moment; aerodynamic centre and centre of pressure.

Performance: straight and level flight; performance envelope estimation; climbing and descent performance; gliding flight; limiting cases.

Compressible flows: pressure waves; their presence and effects; sub-, trans- and supersonic speed regimes.

Transonic flow: effects of Mach number on lift and drag coefficients and on drag; wing sweep; area rule; supercritical aerofoils; high-lift devices.

Supersonic flow: finite strength wave formation; wave patterns; shock-expansion theory; supersonic coefficient definitions.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBA-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Finite Element Modelling with Elastomers and Similar Materials
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The engineering application of elastomers.

Types of elastomeric material classified by manufacturing method (of end product) and by mechanical, chemical and other properties.

Mathematical foundations of large deformations.

Mechanical behaviour of elastomers: extensibility; hyperelasticity; \"incompressibility\" and stress calculations (neo-Hooken, Rivlin, Odgen and other laws); anelastic behaviour.

Elements of FE modelling.

Time domain modelling and frequency-domain modelling in FE.

Advantages and limitations of FE modelling for elastomeric components.

Practical FE modelling of example elastomeric components.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEU8-40-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introductory Programming for Audio
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is designed to enable students to develop their skills in programming with a high level language, with the application of audio and music systems as the basis for the practical examples and assignments. There are five principal areas which will be covered:

  • The techniques by which programming problems are tackled, and how to design suitable solutions
  • The use of a particular programming language to implement those solutions
  • The development tools used in producing a working solution
  • The application of programming to audio and music systems
  • The relationships between the core processing function, the libraries which it uses, the operating system that supports it, and the underlying hardware

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEU9-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Music for Engineers B
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Tonality - defining tones, semitones, temperament. Scales/modes, degrees of scale. Concept of dominant and subdominant, primary/secondary chords, dominant 7th and secondary 7th chords. Higher tertiary chords. Functional analysis of chords. Augmented 6th chords, diminished 7th, cadences and phraseology

Form and Genre Types

Form - a selection from: Binary, Ternary, Da Capo Aria, Sonata-form, Fugue, variation and allied forms, Jazz, Blues, Rock and allied forms.

Genres - Suite, Symphony, Concerto, Tone Poem, Sonata, Trio-Sonata, Opera, Oratorio, Lieder.

Musical terms, rhythm and notation in different countries.

Orchestra

Instruments of, and development of, the orchestra. History of orchestration. Score reading.

Cook's Tour of Music History

A selection from: Renaissance, Impressionism, Baroque, Expressionism, Classical, Neo-Classism, Romantic, Nationalism, Modern (including Jazz, Rock, Pop), World Music

Aural - ear training, fault finding, stylistic awareness and score reading.

Musical endeavour - active practical involvement in a musical ensemble, internally (for example U.W. E. Centre for Performing Arts) or externally OR Musical involvement in a CPA drama production. Evaluation of aspects of individual performance and experiences.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBS-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Stress Analysis
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Stress analysis, Strain analysis, Mohr's Circle for stress, strain and section propert, Rosette analysis, Section properties, Un-symmetric bending, Buckling of struts, Pressure vessels (thin & thick), Failure criteria and FOS, Elastic plastic analysis.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMECE-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Materials
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFPED8-30-1 OR UEP039S1 OR UFMEDB-20-1 OR (UFPECD-10-2 AND UEP016H1))
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Energy basis of microstructure and microstructural changes. Diffusion and diffusion sensitive processes.

Amorphous and crystalline structures, including use of Miller Indeces.

Principles behind the manipulation of mechanical properties in metals, including study of dislocation theory and phase diagrams. Study of specific systems, such as aluminium alloys and titanium alloys

Properties and behaviour related to specific processing routes, such as superplastic forming and diffusion bonding, and single crystal growth.

High performance polymers: molecular structure and behaviour with respect to temperature and stress, including use of spring/dashpot modelling.

Composite systems. Principle of fibre composites. Theoretical and practical choice of fibres and manufacturing processes to optimise behaviour.

Comparison of polymer matrix composites, metal matrix composites and ceramic matrix composites

Fracture toughness, critical defect size and toughening techniques in brittle materials

Engineering ceramics: characteristic behaviour and applications, molecular origin of behaviour. Forming of ceramics, critical defect size.

Surface engineering. Effects of surface modification and typical treatments, including PVD and CVD processes.

Nanotechnology and the materials aspects of miniaturisation.

Smart materials, including memory metals.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEV4-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Work-based Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is completely work-based. The student will be required, through negotiation with the academic tutor and the industrial (workplace) supervisor to identify a suitable area for work. The student will work on the project in the workplace and will be visited on a regular basis by the academic tutor. The student will have bi-weekly timetabled peer group meetings in college in order to reflect on and further plan for the project. These times may also be used to introduce appropriately requested information by the academic tutor.

The student will be expected to maintain a logbook of all relevant information, ideas, designs, tests, results and analysis arising from the project. The work will culminate in a presentation, production of a fully documented report and working component/module. Students will be given written guidelines on the required structure of the project report.

Interim progress will be assessed by the supervisor based on a short interim report, with reference to the agreed project brief and project plan. This report will be submitted at a point approximately half-way through the project.

Continuous assessment, of all aspects of the student's work on the project, will be the made by the supervisor based on regular discussions with the student and using the logbook as a reference. Assessment of the content, quality of the final report and the working component/module will be made by the academic tutor with reference to the workplace supervisor. This assessment will specifically concentrate on the report as a piece of technical communication. The report may include supplementary information such as drawings, sketches or photographs.

Assessment of the student's final oral presentation will be made by the academic tutor and by another member of staff acting independently. It will be assessed for its effectiveness as a means of communication rather than for its technical content.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE7U-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: eBusiness
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• eBusiness context and cases.
  • Internet technology infrastructure for eBusiness.
  • eBusiness Marketing and Retail (B2C).
  • eBusiness Marketing and EDI (B2B, B4B).
  • eBusiness Security.
  • eBusiness Payment Systems.
  • eBusiness Supply Chain Management.
  • Intranet and Extranet technologies and applications.
  • Software Tools and Techniques for eBusiness.
  • Designing and Building eBusiness Systems.
  • Implementing and Supporting eBusiness Systems.
  • Cultural, ethical, political, social and legal issues surrounding eBusiness

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE85-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Internet Systems Group Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Students work in teams on a website development project with a real client. The website may be destined for the Internet or an intranet. Teams report to an academic supervisor and to the client.

Client needs are assessed and a disciplined approach to design and implementation is followed. Additional technical material can be brought in by team members or by tutors to suit the needs of the projects, but in general this module applies and integrates knowledge and techniques from other modules rather than introducing much new material.

Additional taught material may be needed:

  • to help teams establish their design, user liaison, and project management practices
  • to link in and exploit new knowledge coming in from other modules (e.g. multimedia/hypermedia, e-commerce)
  • to support teams wishing to extend their technical development beyond the immediate scope of the general authoring tools (e.g. by adding some programming)
  • in relation to testing and posting a website and in considering its future use and development.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEE4-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Quality Assurance & Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to Quality Assurance and Management: definition of terms relating to quality; comparison of quality control, quality assurance and quality management. Concept of processes as applied across organisational activities.

Organisation and management of quality: management responsibilities; management and staff responsibilities; need for management commitment and leadership; management strategies for quality; quality policy and planning; creation, operation and maintenance of quality systems; quality auditing; vendor rating and surveillance; supplier-customer partnership; documentation requirements; necessity for and achievement of good internal communications. Quality system standards (ISO 9000): role and requirements.

Quality in design, manufacturing and service industries. Quality control, assurance and improvement techniques: inspection activities; statistical techniques for problem analysis; department and process analysis and performance improvement; process capability studies and process control (SPC); quality circles; improvement teams; problem solving and identification of root causes and corrective action control. Quality of design: specifications; tolerances and conformance; Failure modes and effects analysis (FMEA); handling of customer complaints.

Legal and consumer protection requirements.

Quality costs in organisations; categorisation, collection and use of quality costs.

Computer aided quality systems: including quality assurance records; calibration control; supplier rating; reliability predictions; automatic quality data acquisition; the integrated quality information system concept.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFE-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistics & Research Methods (Hartpury) A
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Types of data (counts and measurements), scales of measurement, concept of sampling, frequency distribution, normality and non-normality, presentation of data.

2. Descriptive statistics: central tendency, (mean, median, mode), variation (standard deviation, variance), probability distribution, inferential statistics: standard error, confidence limits.

3. Statistical tests and association between categories and variables, measuring differences (Independent Samples and Matched Pairs t tests, Wilcoxon test for Matched Pairs, Mann Whitney U test, Kruskal Wallace, Pearsons Product Moment and Spearman Rank correlations, Chi Squared tests, F test, Analysis of Variance.

4. Forming a research proposal: identification of the research topic, formation of a research question/hypothesis, literature review, statement of objectives, research strategy, data collection methods, timetable.

5. Reviewing the literature: a critical review of the literature, conducting a literature search, recording references, quoting from the literature, references in text, reference list.

6. Surveys: collecting information, observation, interviews, focussed interviews, questionnaires, sample design, and quantification of data, scientific approach.

7. Research methods: experimental and investigative designs, pros and cons, sampling procedures, bias, statistical analysis of quantitative data, computer software.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEEA-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Electromechanical Systems Integration
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The syllabus may include but not be limited to the followings:

MECHANICAL ELEMENTS:

Acceleration, Velocity, Torque, Inertia; Mechanical transmission; Gearboxes, pulley, belt and chains; Linear and Rotary bearings; Machine screws and Splined shafts;

SYSTEMS INTEGRATION:

Rotary and linear electric motors, gearboxes ,shafts integration;

SYSTEMS MODELLING and CONTROL:

Open, close loop control; Novel controllers; System performance measures; Controllers PC and PLC and Embedded ; Software for control, Languages and Platforms;

Examples of mechatronic systems may include:

Robots and Machine tools; Car Engine management system; Aircraft actuators from fly by wire.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE89-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Policy and Practice in ICT in Education
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The nature of ICT policy in education: scope of ICT policy, eg the impact of policy on the curriculum, the lifelong learning agenda and the teacher's role; why and how ICT policy is created; legislation, statuary policy and guidance; power, control and influence in ICT policy creation; policy to practice models, eg 'top-down' and 'bottom-up'.

Implementation of ICT policy: discourse and reinterpretation of policy; implementation strategies; ICT and professional practice in education; the changing role of the teacher; professional development in ICT; the role of the ICT co-ordinator and the relationship between ICT and the curriculum; the role of ICT in educational management and administration.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8A-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Integrative Case Studies
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is aimed at providing the students with a combination of generic teamwork and self-management skills and knowledge and specific IT focused skills and knowledge. The emphasis is on groups working together to apprehend the impact and potential of IT systems in organizational settings, and thereby learn how to contribute to an effective change process. It integrates and applies materials from the other core modules in IT infrastructure, system development, and applications. Students work in teams on a small number of case studies from different parts of the IT spectrum, in order to produce system designs for a range of typical small-scale applications. In suitable instances, the designs may be taken through to implementation.

The case studies are generally chosen to include examples from business, manufacturing, and public or voluntary sector areas such as health, education or community action. Student groups need to address issues in requirements determination, analysis and design, and project management in finding appropriate sociotechnical solutions for the case study domain. On the technical side, specific studies may include consideration, for instance, of intranet or Internet systems provision, database development, or network security. On the social side, work structures and flows, improved information provision, and ethical and deskilling/reskilling issues may be among the matters of interest.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEEH-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Total Quality Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
An Introduction to Quality and Total Quality Management including an overview of the history and development of the concepts involved and the recognised 'Gurus' in the field.

A review of the themes, concepts & principles of TQM including: Customer orientation, Continuous quality improvement, \'Right first time\' culture. Motivation of the entire organisation, Top management commitment and leadership, Concept of the internal customer; external customer care.

Management of Change and Improvement, including: Creating a TQ culture in practice, Teamwork for problem solving and improvement, Managing people and teams for continuous improvement, Supporting the improvement process.

TQM Tools & Techniques, including: Department Analysis & Improvement, Statistics & SPC and Six Sigma, Quality Tools (7 new tools) and Design, Quality Systems (ISO 9000/BS 5750), Guidelines for Total Quality (BS 7850).

Total Quality models for excellence - the Baldridge Quality Award, European and British Quality Award models and their use in self assessment.

Quality assurance, quality management systems, quality system standards, regulatory standards and their relationship to TQM.

Quality economics, assessment of quality performance and real costs in design, manufacturing, logistics, customer support and projects.

Quality Policy & Mission Deployment, Hoshin and associated terms and approaches.

Automating the collection and analysis of data for purposes of quality systems and improvement through the use of computers and an integrated quality database.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGB-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Quantitative Modelling
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFQEEP-20-1 OR UFQEEQ-20-1 OR UFQEER-20-1 OR UFQEES-20-1)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
INTRODUCTION. Types of quantitative model. The modelling process. Strengths and limitations of models

SPECIFIC PROBLEM-SOLVING TECHNIQUES. Linear and integer programming. Transportation, transhipment and allocation problems. PERT. Bayes' theorem and the use of imperfect information. Inventory control. Monte Carlo simulation

STATISTICAL METHODS. Experimental design models. 1 & 2 way ANOVA. Non-parametric tests. Multiple comparison (post hoc) tests. Factorial design

Quality control: Cost of quality, UK and US differences, Control charts, Process capability

Multiple regression analysis: Backwards & forwards, Dummy variables, Transformations

Using statistical packages although the emphasis throughout will be on the use of Minitab, students will also be introduced to SPSS.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8F-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Dissertation (Information Technology)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
For this module the nature of the research will vary according to the subject which is being addressed. The Dissertation topic should focus on some agreed aspect(s) of the student\'s programme as applied in a particular context.

Students are expected to carry out an in-depth survey on relevant literature to identify a focus for their study. The primary research may involve a wide range of activities such as: carrying out a quantitative survey, and evaluative case study or action research study, or developing an experimental piece of software. The written dissertation should make clear how the primary research was designed and conducted. Discussion of the outcomes of primary research should be clearly related to existing literature. The body of the dissertation should be supplemented by a critical review of all aspects of the research process.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8H-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: E-Business
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module combines taught material with teamwork and independent research to give students the opportunity to understand the key business, economic, social, and technical implications of e-business, and to investigate and report on a particular topic within the general area of e-business by working in Special Interest Groups (SIGs). 'Business' is understood broadly, to include not-for-profit enterprises. The emphasis is on bringing together technical developments in this area with organisational responses and initiatives, both through the course content and in the students' collaborative investigations.

The taught component of the module focuses on emerging areas of interest and development in e-business technologies, application, uptake and innovation in organisations. Some treatment of online learning and SIG working methods is included.

Students are invited to suggest SIG topics at the beginning of the module, and through a process of on-line negotiation the module leader agrees and publishes a list of topics and allocates students to the appropriate SIGs according to their choices. Topics can come from a broad area, but must be approachable from an e-business angle. They might be in such areas as: e-retailing, e-advertising, Internet security, XML, education, supply chain management, auctions, mobile commerce

Students explore their chosen topic area together, but within the group choose and agree specific individual assignment titles within the topic area, and then submit separate individual pieces of work for assessment. The exploration of the topic and subject areas should focus on how organisations might discover and apply e-business models and technologies for particular business purposes.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8L-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Health Informatics Independent Study
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
