This module provides an opportunity for independent study to enable students on the MSc Health Informatics to complete 120 credits of study prior to undertaking a project. In combination with UFQEH4-10-M (UQQ803HM) Research Methods (Health Informatics) and UFIEAG-60-M (UQI829TM) Health Informatics Dissertation it provides the necessary element of self-directed work envisaged in the NHS Information Authority's Advanced Professional Diploma in IM&T

Selection of subject matter

  • In conjunction with tutor, select a subject for independent study.

Literature

  • Agree an initial bibliography
  • Conduct a deeper literature search
  • Document the results with an assessment of the sources

Selection of topic(s) within the subject

  • Agree on one or two topics for deeper study
  • Agree on one or two essay topics for assessment.

Defend the essay in a short presentation and viva voce examination

  • Agree on a short presentation topic

Discuss with examiners

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQK-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Aerospace Manufacturing Technology
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The module aims to give attendees a detailed understanding of the way aircraft are manufactured and assembled and the importance of designing for ease of manufacture, maintenance and minimum cost while meeting functional ie aerodynamic / structural and other customer requirements.

Material covered will include :

1. Aerospace manufacturing materials metallics and composite technologies.

2. Aerospace metallic manufacturing technology primary processes casting and forming, secondary processes forging, tertiary processes machining, grinding.

3. Aerospace composite manufacturing technology material production / manufacture, primary structural processes tape lay, thermo-form, autoclave processes.

4. Aerospace assembly manual and automated current technologies and challenges.

5. Design for manufacturing and assembly metallics and composites. Design for maintenance and repair.

6. Manufacturing planning and control, manufacturing and supply chain logistics planning, lean manufacturing.

7. Manufacturing cost control and modelling.

8. Process validation and certification, COSHH and Environmental management.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8Q-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Application Contexts
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Information Systems as discipline and profession: IS as technical systems in social contexts; IS discipline and its relations to other disciplines; IS profession - scope and development; introduction to information systems contexts: human, organizational, social, political, ethical; approaches to study in the area of IS contexts.

Nature and uses of information: types of information; representation, expression, interpretation, and reference; uses of information - operational, creative, decision making, controlling; relationship between IS and operational systems and between IS and organizational processes and levels.

Range and variety of information systems: typologies and evolutionary frameworks; computer/network-based information systems and their evolution; reasons for diversity; emergence of new application areas ahead of theory and methodology.

Exploration of a range of application domains: commercial, industrial, artistic, professional, personal examples; inquiry into the regular processes characteristic of such domains and the role played by information systems in supporting or extending them; could include, for example, order processing, production planning, product design, authoring, time management, personnel, stock control.

Systems perspectives as a way of organizing thinking about, and intervention in, complex sociotechnical environments.

During the module we will consider the wide range of uses or applications of information and the extent to which information might be considered a resource. The materials presented are intended to draw together apparently diverse subject matter in order to enable students to understand the spread and diversity of information systems applications in different domains, establish an initial understanding of the nature and uses of information in information systems, and grasp and use systems frameworks in approaching the study of information systems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8T-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Development 1
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Overview of objectives and activities in information systems development: establishing requirements; specification; systems analysis, design and implementation.

Models of the system development process: development lifecycle; the waterfall model, prototyping, the spiral model.

The importance of description and modelling to the development process. Languages of description: a range of modelling techniques, including functional descriptions (data flow diagrams), data descriptions (entity relationship models), event descriptions (entity life histories).

System development tools: use and evaluation of a suitable software package to support the construction of a simple system.

Evaluation, critique and applicability of strategies for design: design by hierarchical decomposition; design by composing descriptions of abstractions of the whole.

Introduction to methodology: role of method both technical and managerial, benefits and drawbacks of method utilisation; method seen as comprising representation, process and heuristics; complexity in the development process and method as a means of dealing with complexity.

The social and technical organisation of the development process. Development activities: design; construction; implementation; testing and maintenance. Integration and control of these activities; role of the client.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8V-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Development 3
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
A review of contemporary approaches to systems development, its methods, tools and practices.

A theoretical framework for design: form, context, ensemble, multiple form-context boundaries, fitness and misfit, measuring fitness and trade-offs, complexity management, representations, specifications and requirements

Alternative perspectives on design: design as learning; as decision making; as adaptation; as social process; as pre-structured by recurrent frames and patterns

Critical evaluation of the forces which shape the development process: organisational structure, technological possibilities, designer knowledge and presumptions, development under constraints.

The components, tools and architectures of web-based and workflow systems; business process modelling and enactment; business process management.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEMK-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematics Education Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Identify in consultation with the placement institution those topics to be taught during the 10 weeks placements. Identify the appropriate level of explanation of each of the main concepts. Establish what the most common misconceptions are for each topic under study. Consider how these misconceptions arise. Identify contrasting aspects either conceptually or methodologically between school based mathematics and university mathematics. Develop appropriate teaching methods to facilitate effective learning of mathematics

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE98-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Development and Practice 3
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This will include a review of currently recommended system development practices and the models they are based on. Selection of an appropriate methodology can depend on a variety of factors and various frameworks have been proposed to facilitate such decisions. Context, experience and current constraints and project characteristics are considered when choosing the system development methodologies.

System development is heavily dependent on building functionality and usability. Alternative perspectives on design need to be considered: design as learning; as decision making; as adaptation; as social process, as classification. User participation in the design process is always advocated but needs serious consideration, such as: organisation and dynamics of participatory design teams; barriers to participation; development and the place of end-user computing; importance of user-system interface and interaction; addressing user concerns and moving towards user-led development; prototyping as cooperative systems development. Object-oriented approaches can inform all styles of system development and need investigation: principles of object orientation; structure of object-oriented software; object-oriented analysis and design. OO needs to be considered in the context of further data modelling: data definition, keys and constraints; controlling integrity in a database and the extension of all these approaches from stand-alone systems to web-based databases which are key in modern business.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE9B-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Project Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Project management is closely associated with systems or other kinds of development in that some life cycle model needs to be applied and used in the management of the project. These models may include traditional waterfall models, evolutionary or prototyping models. Generically, life cycle models can be described for project management as 4Ds: Define, Design, Do and Develop where the last D is essentially a review of the project i.e. how it has all gone and what could be improved upon.

Defining a project is often referred to as requirements analysis but also takes in assumptions, standards and experience. Design of a project is one of the key roles of the project manager and is essentially the planning given the project definition. Plans are predictive so will have estimates and these need to take account of risks and likely or probably changes. Project plans must be able to adapt to changing assumptions and requirements during a project and the project manager must be able to manage the plan and changes to it. Techniques and tools available to a project manager will be described and investigated, such as planning criteria, work breakdown structures (WBS), activity lists, activity planning, bar charts, arrow and precedence diagrams, milestones, deliverables and appropriate team size. Monitoring often needs aids to visualise the project plans and project management techniques such as cascade activity numbering and cascade bar charts will be demonstrated. The issue of overlapping activities will be considered as well as software tools including: spreadsheets, drawing packages or project management software (e.g. MS Project).

Project management makes little sense is there is only one person involved so project inevitably involve teams. The rle of the project manager; typical group and team structures; qualities and skills of managers; team dynamics; leadership and management qualities will be investigated. This will include delegation and how to give project instructions.

In planning a project, estimates of effort, time, manpower and their appropriate units need to be considered. These can be done for any project de novo but with experience data from past projects can be most helpful in making such estimates more accurate or used in parametric cost modelling. Three such systems (COCOMO, Putnam and Mk II Function Point Analysis) will be mentioned and at least one described in detail.

Plans are constrained by resources and time. Refinement and documentation of these constraints will be investigated using activity lists and bar charts for allocating resources efficiently. Levelling resources by taking up float on non-critical paths and resource productivity will be demonstrated, as well as calculating float from start and finish times of activities and the critical path (the determination of which will be described).

Risk is a key issue in project management so there will be an introduction to risk assessment techniques, control and contingent risks, triggers and modifications to plans. Quality is affected by risk so quality control will be addressed through ideas of what measuring quality and planning for quality really means. This will allow quality assurance reviews, design walkthroughs and inspections.

Projects all require some finance, even if you are providing it yourself. Therefore, finance needs to be treated as a resource, which is also the responsibility of the project manager. Various ways of dealing with financial accountability will be investigated: cumulative cost, earned value and cost-to-complete as well as other issues of cash flow.

The Project Manager is usually the chief administrator of a project so needs to deal with project administration: project documentation, reviews, configuration and change management. This is going to entail lots of report writing, which will be introduced by identifying appropriate styles and content of reports as well as the use of appropriate appendices in a project plan and project review, and the links between them.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE9K-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Professional, Legal and Commercial Issues
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
An introduction to ethics including utilityarianism, duty theories, normative theories of business ethics and codes of practice from relevant professional organisation such as the BCS, ACM, IDPM.

The nature of expertise and professionalism with particular reference to ICTs in the 21st century.

Issues of concern to ICT professionals such as privacy, ownership of information, accessibility, regulation, and the digital divide.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPED7-30-M
rdf:Description.p:title: M. Eng Group Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Outline of the selected problem by lecturer and industrial representative, development of specification by students (with lecturer\'s comments), work of students on solution (work in groups, planning, teamwork), presentation, feedback discussion.

Areas covered by a short taught section (6 hours) include:

Design of research programmes. Design of experiments; use of controls. Pilot experiments. Logging and recording data. The need to record decisions and the basis for them.

Design and development programmes. Revision of design process. Client requirements. Specifications. Analysis and Modelling. Design for manufacture as well as purpose. Prototypes.

Information search and retrieval. Use of libraries as research tools. Databases of publications. Use of Internet in research.

The need for effective project management and the use of project management tools.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE9S-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Multimedia Systems: Contexts & Applications
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Basic principles in multimedia. Data Compression for text, audio, image and video. Coding standards. Text as essential multimedia content. Digital audio. Musical synthesis. Image media compression and standards. Digital video. 2D and 3D Graphics, animation and Virtual Reality. HTML, XML, Javascript and other WWW technologies such as Internet film. Multimedia applications such as video-conferencing, mobile phones (WAP, GPRS, G3 etc), palmtops, games machines, medical VR applications, flight simulators, DVD/CD-ROMs will be considered from theoretical and practical standpoints. Consideration of the contexts in which multimedia systems are specified, developed, implemented, and used. Unpredictable outcomes of multimedia technology (e.g. SMS boom and smart mobs). Film making on the net from a technological point of view and how to construct traditional film using these tools with traditional Hollywood approaches. How traditional roles are changing. What are the relationships between technicians and director/artists? Who is leading the technology.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEAE-20-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Health Care Information Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This is one of five modules derived from the NHS Executive's Professional Diploma in IM&T (Health), in which it carries the title Module D: Information Systems. Some of the text below is copied or paraphrased from that document

Business Case and Feasibility. Business analysis; internal and external factors; finance, human factors, IM&T strategy, current and planned systems. Health care information systems in context; characterization and appropriate methodologies. Cost benefit analysis; tangible and intangible costs and benefits.

Requirements Definition. Review of data / information / knowledge issues. Information requirements elicitation; validation and verification. Users and experts in the elicitation process; health care case studies.

Design Appraisal. Identification and documentation of the design of an existing system; hard and soft elements. Analysis of process: choice of methodology, user involvement. Relevance of design to IM&T strategy. Analysis of security and confidentiality.

Implementation and System Administration. From design to implementation: variety of approaches and appropriate contexts. Project planning the implementation of a system; analysis of case or shadow studies. Roles in implementation; analysis of a particular role from a personal point of view. Policies and practices in relation to version control, disaster management, journaling, audit, documentation, security; legal requirements. Process management, including maintaining the integrity of the system and management of failure.

Health Care Systems. Types of systems; e.g. hospital, community, commissioning, primary care, GP. Features of systems; e.g. registration, inpatient, outpatient, waiting list, Patient Administration.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPENB-10-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Music Business
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The students will be given an overview of business with a bias to viewing it from a small business viewpoint. This is because the premise is that they will be in the creative industries when employed. Students will be encouraged to consider the implications and disciplines involved in creating the small business venture in a creative industry.

This module is designed to be student-centred with an emphasis on the practical, commercial and conceptual issues related to enterprise and entrepreneurial activity within the area broadly defined as the creative industries. The emphasis of the module is on the development and application of creative thinking through problem-solving and research.

The first part of the module is taught and will introduce students to the extant literature and concepts of enterprise and entrepreneurship. Examples of the issues covered include:

Analysis of contemporary entrepreneurial practice: history, characteristics, cultural importance, public policy, examples, range of practice; Analysis of creativity and creative ideas development: theories of enterprise, organisational creativity; Entrepreneurship: characteristics, sources and processes of innovation, examples; Impact of external environment on enterprise, including ethical issues;

These are linked to the practical applications of this knowledge through seminars and workshops that introduce and explore specific skills and ideas, with the overall focus upon how a good idea could be turned into a commercial prospect. Examples include:

Links between creativity / new product development / innovation Industry analysis Marketing methods Business planning Funding methods and sources - support networks Legal issues - copyright, intellectual property rights, liability etc.

This knowledge is applied in the module to conducting primary and secondary research to address a key question or set of questions related to the development of a specific opportunity identified by the students. Research will include one or more of the following:

Market or customer research Evaluation of industry conditions and competition Evaluation of technological opportunities Evaluation of financial opportunities

The final section of the module will provide taught input on writing a business plan.

Students are assessed through the submission of a written evaluation of their business idea as a group assignment.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPENW-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Professional Studies for Electrical/Electronics Engineers
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design Methods: The design process, and the systematic approach to design problems: requirement analysis, problem identification, problem solving methods, problem solving tools, preparation of specifications, solution identification and design.

Completion of workbook and associated on-line test to demonstrate effective use of the library.

Groupwork project using library and internet research to produce a written report to Faculty standards. Findings to be presented to the rest of the class in an oral presentation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEK4-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Computing, Audio & Music
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The syllabus will include:-

  • History of computing audio & music.
  • Analogue/digital conversion of audio sounds
  • Analogue and digital rendition of music.
  • Hardware devices for audio and music
  • Software functionality
  • MIDI protocols, MIDI dialogue. and limitations of MIDI.
  • Issues of inter-conversion between different file formats.
  • Exploration of the impacts of digital technologies on the practices of composition, publication and rendition of music.
  • Digital Rights Management
  • Exploration of issues in creativity and control.
  • Practical use of software and hardware to create, edit and present MIDI only, audio-only and integrated sequences
  • Critical reflection on effects of technologies on audio and music

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPER4-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Work-Based Learning
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- SWOT analysis

- Personal Development Profile

- Action planning

- Link/visit host organisation

- Problem solving techniques

- Presentation & Communication skills

- Work environment roles and responsibilities as appropriate to the student

- Reflective analysis of work based learning

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPERY-30-M
rdf:Description.p:title: MEng Individual Project part B
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The main content of the module will depend of the subject agreed by the supervisor.

Project selection: an extension of the work presented in UFPERX-30-3.

Project proposal: derived from the concluding chapters of UFPERX-30-3.

Project execution: monitored by supervisor.

Project presentation: written report and viva examination.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPES8-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Professional Practice
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Organisational analysis. Workplace culture. Business strategy and operations. Industry-specific trends and developments.

Contemporary technological changes and opportunities. Contemporary developments in business practices, emerging technologies and methodological trends.

Industry codes of practice and professional standards. Professional ethics. Company-specific standards.

Relate at least three taught modules (generally at level 2) to professional practices experienced in the workplace, and vice-versa.

Relationships between academe and practice. Knowledge exchange. Communities of practice. Experiential and organisational learning.

Reflective practice and professional development. The practitioner as methodologist lifelong learning in choosing, using, evaluating methods, techniques and tools.

Comparative analysis of organisations and technologies in different workplaces.

Critical analysis and evaluation of online and other information sources to support comparison of practices in different contexts and identification of emerging issues.

Identification of career and personal goals. Action planning for level 3 studies and beyond.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEV8-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Work-based Production 2
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Participation in a simulated project with an identified client, users, and a development team. Discussions with the client will be recorded and prioritized to form project-briefing instructions. User needs will be defined through enquiry, observation or research.

Selection of team roles together with a production schedule relating resources to the critical production path. Co-operative team working initially produces concepts and identifies areas and skills for development.

Presentation to the client and negotiation for development is supported team management techniques. Project requirements are recorded periodically to provide a shared evidence source and provide material for reflection and review. Maintaining an open dialogue within the team is essential for co-operative success and to avoid wasted effort.

A professional standard of presentation is required to simulate working practice and forms a focus for achievement and evaluation.

Ownership of intellectual property rights is researched and considered in parallel to production, supported by an enquiry into forms of protection.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEVB-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Working and Professional Practice 2
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Each student will individually conduct a real-life development project within an organisation or as a Sole trader for a customer. Each student will carry out an initial systems investigation by interviewing their customer about the existing system and user requirements. Students will present this information to the module tutor along with a planned project methodology to be used, project management tools, an indication of cost, time and resources. From this students will develop a feasibility study and offer business systems options to the customer. The students will develop the systems according to agreed timescales and costs with the customer to an agreed specification. The module tutor will provide support. The student will compile a project log file containing all the phases of the software development lifecycle chosen. If the customer decides not to accept any of the options following the feasibility the project can be completed for educational purposes as the feasibility has been conducted as work based learning.

Subjects included in this project:

Project management techniques: methodologies ( e.g.PRINCE2, APM, PMBOK, ISO) Project initiation, documentation; scope; viability; change control, configuration management; termination; contingency planning; risk; work breakdown structure.

Project management tools: analysis of various tools (Microsoft Project, Excel Spreadsheets)

Systems development life cycle: feasibility analysis (Investigating system requirements, user requirements, resources required); design; build; implementation; testing; review.

Designing and implementing a solution; feasibility of a project with reference to cost, time and resources using an appropriate project management software tool to plan the project.

Critically evaluate project: self-evaluation (e.g. SWOT); success or failure of the project (aims, objectives, outcomes, techniques used, improvements required, cost, time, resources, compliance with procedures); problems encountered and resolved.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFA-20-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Foundation Mathematics: Calculus
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Functions including composite functions

Trigonometric Waveforms

Trigonometric waveforms of the form Rcos(t+) and Rsin(t+). Definition of amplitude, phase, period and frequency. trigonometric identities, compound angle formulae.

Properties of functions and introduction to composite functions

Introduction to Differential Calculus

The gradient of a function, use of tables to differentiate standard functions, standard rules of differentiation, product rule, quotient rule and chain rule, turning points, rate of change and acceleration

Introduction to Integration Introduction as reversal of differentiation, use of tables to integrate standard functions, definite and indefinite integrals, calculation of the area under a curve

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGK-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Modelling Data and Systems Over Time
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to forecasting. Approaches to forecasting. The role of forecasting in planning and decision making. Problems of applying statistical forecasting methods e.g. data collection, definition of variable to be forecast, etc.

Decomposition methods for time series forecasting. Measuring the trend, seasonal, cyclical and random components of a time series. Preparing a forecast based on the decomposition method.

Smoothing Methods - simple exponential smoothing. Adaptive methods e.g. Chow and Trigg and Leach. Brown\'s single parameter, double exponential smoothing method. Holt\'s two parameter method. The Holt-Winter\'s method. Damping the trend. The Box-Jenkins Method. Autocorrelation and partial autocorrelation functions. Types of time-series model. The Box-Jenkins methodology. Transfer functions.

Monitoring Methods. Tracking signals. Cusum charts.

Use of Computer Packages. Comparison of univariate, judgemental and explanatory forecasting methods

Models and modelling. The modelling cycle. Deterministic and stochastic models. Queuing models and solution using queuing theory. Types of simulation models, including discrete-event simulation, Monte-Carlo simulation, and continuous simulation. Advantages and disadvantages of simulation, pitfalls in simulation modelling, terminating and non-terminating systems.

Monte-Carlo simulation. Use of spreadsheets, in financial modelling.

Construction of discrete-event simulation models. Activity cycle diagrams. Data collection and analysis. Practical problems with data collection, interpreting stochastic data, choice of sampling distribution, testing for goodness of fit. Validation of simulation models. Face validity, testing assumptions, statistical comparisons, method of independent replications, initial bias, batch means method.

Interpretation of simulation experiments. Absolute measures for a single model, comparison of two alternatives, comparisons of several alternatives, variance reduction techniques.

Simulation software. A practical understanding of one commercial simulation package.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIENR-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Academic Libraries
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Current trends in higher and further education and in their library and information services. The role of the library and its integration into the academic life of the institution. Convergence of academic libraries with computing and other support services. Visions of the future of the higher and further education environment and the academic library. Co-operation between academic libraries.
  • The library environment and the role of the professional academic librarian. Skills necessary to work effectively in academic libraries. The role of the subject librarian/ information specialist. Managing printed and electronic resources to support teaching, learning and research. Information skills and information literacy issues. Promoting the library within the institution.
  • The electronic library. Academic library websites. Electronic resources and licensing issues. Subject and institutional portals. Institutional repositories.
  • Key management issues affecting academic libraries. Management structures, academic liaison, collection management and user support, Collection management issues and the 'hybrid library'. Budget distribution models. Performance measurement and surveys of user satisfaction.
  • Service provision. Services for different types of user (students, researchers and academic staff). The physical library as a learning space. Support for distance learners. Services for users with disabilities.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIENT-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Government and Legal Information Services
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The module will cover accessing and managing the key types of government and legal information, including UK legislation, European information, case law and business information. Key challenges within the area will be considered, such as knowledge management for government and legal information services and the skills required and roles undertaken by information professional in these environments.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEP6-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Internet Application Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The internet application in its organisational and social context; types of internet applications, their user bases and dominant metaphor; the differing needs of business, government, collaborative and social systems; the internet application as an extended human/computer activity system; alignment of development approach and technology to the user and client needs.

Development and project management processes for web site development: requirements driven versus agile methods; user involvement; specialist skill and the management of a project team; user involvement; use cases and user stories.

Choice of technical platform for an internet-based application: Enterprise-level systems such as Microsoft's .Net and Sun's J2EE; the LAMP approach with PHP and MySQL and the open source movement; customisable environments such as Content Management Systems; the role of IDEs and CASE in web development.

Choice of systems architecture: layered architectures; service-oriented architecture with SOAP and REST; design issues in systems architecture such as allocation of functionality to layers; multimedia and multi-modal integration; XML-based architectures;

Web site setup: researching and choosing a hosting service; domains and the domain registration process; backup and security of the site; server demand prediction and scaling; site testing; site positioning and search engine optimisation; site activity monitoring and analysis; payment schemes; revenue generation

Choices in interface design, navigational design and the dominant site metaphor; patterns in internet site design; advances in interface design - DHTML, DOM and AJAX.

Application evaluation and on-going site evolution.

Careers and career development in the internet world; on-going professional development.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEQD-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Play and Games
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to play and games: concepts, types, principles and categories of play and games; competition and cooperation; chance, simulation, vertigo; improvisation and discipline; relation to stories and drama.

Sociocultural background: play and games in the cultural context; psychological and social aspects; play and games in development, learning and socialisation; gender aspects and issues.

A range of examples of games.

Analysis of games in terms of rules, structures and roles.

Introduction to games as systems: emergence and uncertainty; conflict and game theory; simulation and system dynamics.

Play aspects: experience, pleasure, meaning, engagement, narrative, simulation, social interaction.

Story-based games and role play: characters, character development, and encounters; story themes, motifs and scenarios, story development; aesthetic and moral qualities of games.

Games design: designer and user perspectives; conceptualisation and refinement; assembling the elements; prototyping, evaluation and playtesting.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEQP-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Business Applications
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The role of IS in business, the range and variety of information systems: typologies and evolutionary frameworks; monolithic, client-server and computer/network and web-service-based information systems and their evolution; reasons for diversity; emergence of new application areas ahead of theory and methodology; the impacts of the web, multi-media and technological convergence.

The relationship between IS and operational systems and between IS and organizational processes and levels; the effects of IS on the individual, groups, organizations, and markets and the relationships and influences between them.

Exploration of a range of application domains: commercial, industrial and professional examples; inquiry into the regular processes characteristic of such domains and the role played by information systems in supporting, extending or changing them; could include, for example, supply chain management, financial accounting, office automation, computer integrated manufacturing, e-learning, product design, virtual reality, Business Process Management.

The systems lifecycle as a way of organizing thinking about and intervention in, complex sociotechnical environments; systems as whole-life, multi-dimensional, constructs; establishing user requirements within the business context, system specification; systems analysis, systems design, and systems implementation; project management and its relationship to the systems lifecycle including an understanding of the social and technical organisation of the development process and a need for integration and control of development activities through project management.

The importance, applicability and relevance of abstractions, models, diagrams, notations and descriptions in the development process; examples commonly used in information systems development e.g. functional descriptions (data flow diagrams), data descriptions (entity relationship models), and relational data analysis (normalisation).

During the module we will consider the wide range of uses, applications and effects of information systems. The materials presented are intended to enable students to understand the spread and diversity of information systems applications in different domains, establish an initial understanding of the nature and uses of information systems and grasp and use appropriate systems models and frameworks in approaching the study of information systems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEQQ-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Informing & Communicating in Practice
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Fundamental concepts of information and communication. Linguistic and non-linguistic information: language, sound and pictures. Graphical representations and visual language. Meaning and interpretation in different social contexts. Experiencing information and communication.

Information literacy. Search and retrieval. Classification. Ordering and sorting. Evaluating information sources.

Foundations of information systems practice. Relationships between people, organisations, information systems and information technology. Investigating, analysing and modelling organisations, information systems and IT from multiple perspectives. People and IT: changing roles, expectations and activities.

Practical communications skills. Writing for different audiences. Report-writing. Oral communications in information systems practice, negotiation and assertion. Introduction to interviewing. Presentation skills.

Working with people. Planning and managing teamwork. Communicating, record-keeping and documentation. IT support for team projects. Examples of contemporary information systems projects.

Learning styles, action learning and reflective practice. Lifelong learning in information systems as a response to social, organisational and technological change.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETH-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Mathematics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Complex Algebra: Basic algebraic operations, rectangular, polar and exponential forms.

Matrix and Vector Algebra: Properties of matrices and determinants, the inverse matrix, Gaussian elimination, properties of vector quantities, vector addition, unit vectors, position vectors, scalar product, vector product.

Calculus: Partial differentiation with applications. Applications of the definite integral to problems such as mean values, root mean square values, volumes of revolution, moments of inertia, curved length.

Solution of Differential Equations: Modelling of simple dynamical systems, solution of first and second order linear constant coefficient ordinary differential equations, natural and forced response.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIERH-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Health Care Information Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The management of quality information is a critical asset. Information is central to the process of decision-making within the delivery and management of health care. The provision of quality information is a complex management process underpinned with requisite knowledge and skills. To this end, information should be relevant, timely, accurate, complete, verifiable and clear.

Information management is not an arbitrary process and requires the IM&T specialist to be logical and analytical, to use methods and techniques, to understand coding classifications and data definitions, to act as an interpreter of information and to bridge functions.

Information management requires effective intelligence and data administration services to organize, store, validate and maintain access to soft and hard information.

- Information and Information Quality

  • Organizational levels operational, tactical and strategic; information needs at different levels.
  • Interpretation of the six qualities (relevance, timeliness, accuracy, completeness, verifiability and clarity) at the different levels.

- Data and Information

  • Information gathering, organization, interpretation and presentation.
  • Methodologies for information gathering.
  • Methods and techniques for organizing information.
  • Factors affecting interpretation of information.
  • Methods and techniques of presentation.

- Sources of Information

  • Library services; classification and technology.
  • Literature search and literature review; healthcare case studies.
  • Accredited sources of information and knowledge.

- Health Records and Registers

  • Reasons why health records and registers are kept legal, communication, record of management plans, identification of specific diseases; the role and function of record keeping.
  • Examples of health records, their use and maintenance, including hospital records, community care records and primary care records.
  • Examples of registers, including GP age/sex, cancer, at-risk, mental health, learning difficulties and transplant registers.

- Data Validity and Data Security

  • Standardized coding and data validation; examples of codes (OPCS4; ICD9; ICD10; READ).
  • The problem of data validation; the coding process, languages and standards.
  • Ethical issues around sharing of data.
  • Data protection, confidentiality and security; official guidance and compliance.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIERK-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Independent Study in Information Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module provides an opportunity for independent study. This may be undertaken on a topic which is not offered as a taught module or to deepen a students knowledge of a specialist area prior to his or her undertaking a project.

Tutorial support is provided in the selection of topic and material, in the conduct of the literature review and in writing an essay or report on the chosen subject.

- Selection of subject matter

  • In conjunction with tutor, select a subject for independent study

- Literature

  • Agree an initial bibliography
  • Conduct a deeper literature search
  • Document the results with an assessment of the sources

- Selection of topic(s) within the subject

  • Agree on one or two topics for deeper study
  • Agree on one or two essay topics for assessment

- Defend the essay in a short presentation and viva voce examination

  • Agree on a short presentation topic
  • Discuss with examiners

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIET7-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems and Services
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Publishing and the future of libraries. Structure and distribution of printed materials. Academic journal publishing and production methods. Electronic information publishing. Developments in publishing and in library information provision.
  • Digital libraries and Internet-based information services. Types, processes and components and key technical underpinnings and standards. Digital information resources. Internet standards, searching and metadata (eg, Dublin Core). Intranets. Databases and metadata schemas. Usability and functionality in digital libraries. Preservation of digital library materials.
  • Wider societal impact of digital libraries and Internet-based information services, considered through a series of case studies drawn from academic, government, commercial and other relevant sectors. Role of digital libraries and allied information systems in society. Access to information. The Information Society.
  • Managerial and technological issues relating to digital libraries and information services. Future trends and developments in digital libraries and Internet systems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIET8-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Corporate Information Services
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Current trends in corporate information services and examples of different types of information service in different corporate organisations. The range of roles for information professionals in the corporate environment and the skills required.
  • Delivering a corporate information service to meet the divergent needs of users: - identifying user needs; business information sources and research analysis; synthesising content and competitive intelligence; delivering content.
  • Challenges faced by corporate information professionals: - demonstrating value to management; promoting awareness of information services and skills; the importance of branding; new technologies.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEUT-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Consultancy Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Students are given the opportunity to tackle a complete consultancy project in a live client situation, in groups acting as consultancy teams, working in a self-managed fashion.

Projects across a wide range of types are typically involved, including business information analysis, requirements engineering, feasibility studies, web design, system development, multimedia deployment, creative media, infrastructure development, strategic planning, information systems evaluation, user training and support, process redesign, etc.

Projects usually involve external organisations, and students are matched with project opportunities in accordance with a range of factors including their specific programme of study and preferences.

Consultancy teams are typically expected to

  • prepare project plans and a team-working methodology
  • negotiate, agree and document project terms of reference that reflect the business case for the project related explicitly to context and are manageable yet involve sufficient depth and challenge
  • undertake the agreed consultancy activities and produce the agreed deliverables, including forward planning recommendations for the client
  • operate in a substantially self-managed fashion, working within their own project management framework
  • delegate tasks and roles to individual team members in accordance with specialisms, interests and needs, and manage individual contributions and quality effectively
  • utilise relevant literature and resources effectively including tutor and others expertise
  • make explicit choices of methods, tools and techniques from across a range, deploy them and evaluate their effectiveness in context
  • demonstrate a professional, engaged approach to the client organisation, managing expectations and delivering sustainably
  • document all aspects of their work appropriately for their client
  • review and write up all aspects of their project critically and self-critically for an academic audience
  • refer back to any known interventions in the same client organisation preceding theirs, and facilitate follow-on interventions as appropriate, demonstrating a responsible approach to sustainability, continuity and the client's long-term strategic interests.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEF9-20-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Foundation Mathematics: Algebra and Manipulation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Fundamental Skills:

Estimation, accuracy, fractions, percentages, indices, standard form, substitution in formulae, transposition of formulae, manipulation of exponential and log expressions.

Trigonometry:

Right angled triangles; Pythagoras's Theorem, definition of sine, cosine and tangent. Sine rule and cosine rule, resolution of hypotenuse in horizontal and vertical components.

Introduction to Mathematical Functions:

Equation of a straight line, intersection of straight lines, quadratic equations, factorisation, roots of quadratic functions using linear factors or the quadratic formula, intersection of straight lines and quadratics, plotting standard mathematical functions including sin(x), cos(x), tan(x), ax and ln(x).

Standard Mathematical Functions and techniques:

Definition of a function, the inverse function, polynomials up to cubic functions, completing the square, partial fractions, trigonometric functions, use of radian, exponential and log functions, solving equations that involve standard mathematical functions.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQELJ-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematical Problem Solving
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Computer Algebra Arithmetic, expressions, statements, functions, plotting functions, manipulating plots, data types, solving equations, differentiation and integration .

Computer Programming Control statements, use of arrays, writing Procedures, reading files and saving results, programming workshops to illustrate use of arrays, loops and conditional statements.

Differential Equations Solution of first and second order differential equations, initial conditions and boundary conditions, systems of first order differential equations, separation of variables, integrating factors, complementary function and particular integral.

Mathematical Modelling Problem formulation, assumptions, choice of appropriate solution methods, interpretation of results, validation of results .

Report writing Structure, layout and formatting of reports containing substantial mathematics. Effective use and presentation of mathematical graphs and tables. Methods of avoiding plagiarism through quoting and referencing.

Making presentations Oral presentations: planning, timing, using visual aids. Poster presentations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBM-20-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to Mechanics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Fundamental Units, Vectors and Scalars

Behaviour of Static Bodies: Newton's 1st and 3rd Laws, force, weight, resultant component. Moments, equilibrium, centre of gravity, centre of area. Stress and strain - shear, direct stress, basic definitions. Basic stress analysis

Rigid Body Motion: Linear motion, displacement, velocity, acceleration, falling bodies, projectiles, relative velocity, application of Newton's 2nd Law. Work done, power, Conservation of Energy Effect of friction

Angular Motion: Radians, angular velocity and accelerations. Analogous linear and angular laws and quantities.

Behaviour of Fluids Fluid properties - pressure, temperature, density . Compressibility. Solids, liquid and vapour phases, energy changes during phase change .Ideal gas law.

Hydrostatics: pressure, density, static force balance, Archimedes' principle. Descriptive approach to fluid flow. Flow patterns Conservation of energy for fluids. Comparison of solid,. liquid and gas systems

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBN-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Solid Systems Modelling and Simulation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design simulation techniques and tools

Experimental Mechanics

Application of ANN in engineering

Numerical approximation.

Inverse problem analysis.

Photo stress

Theoretical and experimental Strain Analysis

Composite material simulation and laminate theory.

FEA

Analytical simulations and tools

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBR-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Power Conversion
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Power production processes: Entropy, its meaning and effect on thermodynamic work and heat transfer processes The thermodynamic cycle in power production. Steam based electricity generation. Internal combustion engines. Gas turbine power and thrust production.

Combustion: The chemistry of combustion - reactants, products and pollutants. Heat release and the prediction of temperatures generated.

Compressible flows: Frictionless compressible flow and its application to nozzle design. Compressible flows with friction.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBV-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Fundamental Aeronautics
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFQEFH-20-1 OR (UFQETH-10-1 AND (UFQETG-10-1 OR UFQETJ-10-1) AND UFQETJ-10-1))
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Aerodynamics:

Introduction: Some Fundamental Variables, Aerodynamic Forces and Moments, Centre of Pressure and Aerodynamic Centre.

Incompressible Flow over a Finite Wing: Downwash and Induced Drag, the Vortex Filament, the Biot-Savart Law, Helmotzs vortex theorems and Prandtls Lifting Line Theory.

Viscous Flow: Reynolds Experiments, Laminar and Turbulent Flows, the Boundary Layer Concepts, Velocity profiles, Transition and Separation.

Subsonic Flow over Airfoils: Characteristics of Flow Field around an Airfoil (Lift slope, profile Drag, zero-lift angle of attack, stall, aerodynamic centre, zero-lift moment), Influence of the Profile Geometry, Influence of the Reynolds number, Laminar Profiles, Influence of the Mach number, Stall and Separation (stall due to leading edge separation, stall due to trailing edge separation) and Influence of the Leading Edge.

Transonic and Supersonic Flows over Airfoils: Introduction of Compressible flows, Transonic Flows (Description of the Transonic Regime, Cp distribution, Aerodynamic characteristics, Profiles for Transonic Regime) and Supersonic Flow (Description of the Supersonic Regime, Cp distribution, Aerodynamic characteristics).

2. Mechanics of Flight:

Performance: straight and level flight; performance envelope estimation; climbing and descent performance; gliding flight; limiting cases; range and endurance estimation; flight profiles for maximum range.

Stability and control: static and dynamic stability; longitudinal static stability determination; stick-fixed and stick-free cases.

3. Computational Fluid Dynamics:

Introduction to CFD: relevant equations, principles of discretisation, turbulence models, mesh generation, boundary conditions, consistency, convergence, stability, obtaining flow solutions, post-processing, validation and assessment of results.

4. Laboratory work and design project(s):

Wind tunnel design and operation: types of tunnel; tunnel components and their functions; data acquisition and processing; standard representations; flow visualisation techniques; similarities and differences between low-speed and high-speed facilities.

Component and/or aircraft design: design to meet a specific requirement; the design loop and iteration; effects of construction methods on the finished product; documentation; testing and evaluation of a prototype.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBW-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Applied Aeronautics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Aerodynamics:

Boundary layers: Reynolds number(s) and its/their effects; layer characteristics; numerical modelling for laminar, turbulent and mixed layers; skin friction and layer thickness estimation. Incompressible Flow over a Flat plate (Blasius Solution), Compressible flows: pressure waves; their presence and effects; sub-, trans- and supersonic speed regimes.

Transonic flow: effects of Mach number on lift and drag coefficients and on drag; wing sweep; area rule; supercritical aerofoils; high-lift devices.

Supersonic flow: finite strength wave formation; wave patterns; shock-expansion theory; supersonic coefficient definitions.

Hypersonic Flow: Qualitative Aspects, Newtonian Theory

Space: Atmospheric Drag, Satellite Orbit Transfers: Circular (Hohmann), Elliptic, Hyperbolic and Parabolic

UAV: Requirements, Design

2. Mechanics of Flight:

Equations of motion of an aircraft: vector and scalar forms; linearised and non-dimensional forms; force and moment derivatives; solutions in longitudinal and lateral degrees of freedom.

Longitudinal dynamic stability: phugoid and short period oscillation; mathematical description of each mode; magnitude and effects of damping; contribution(s) of aircraft layout.

Lateral dynamic stability: spiral dive, Dutch roll, Roll subsidence; mathematical description of each mode; magnitude and effects of damping; contribution(s) of aircraft layout.

Response Transfer Functions, Flight Control System.

Gusts: Impacts on Aerodynamics and Flight Mechanics.

3. Computational Fluid Dynamics:

Producing flow simulations for aerofoil, wing and full aircraft configurations in subsonic, transonic and supersonic regimes. Parameterisation studies for wing design including mathematical descriptions and optimisation. Cad-repair, mesh generation, finite volume, finite element & finite difference algorithms, design of experiments & verification of results, flux models, turbulence models.

4. Flight Experience and Experimentation:

Weight and balance; in-flight measurements; post-flight calculations; comparison with theory; trends from multiple flights and tests.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBX-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Lightweight Structures
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design requirements and airworthiness. Aircraft Construction: Structural elements, jointing, manufacturing and costing.

Design Analysis:

Buckling of compression and shear members, principles of stressed skin construction. Bending and torsion of thin-walled box beam structures to meet required stress and stiffness limitations. Fatigue and fracture mechanics analysis

Fatigue and Safe Life Design:

Effects of manufacturing processes on fatigue life.

Modern Developments

Materials selection for strength and stiffness, stress analysis of fibrous composites.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEC8-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Automated Manufacture
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction:- The need for automation in manufacturing industry for the production of components and in both high and low volumes. The financial implications incurred in the automating of a manufacturing system. Appreciation of the different types of automation equipment available, including robots, automatic guided vehicles, flexible manufacturing systems and transfer line systems.

Robotics:- Definitions of industrial robots. The different methods of classifying robots, for example by means of function and capability. Consideration of the specification of robotic devices in terms of workspace, load capacity, environment and speed of operation. The configurations of industrial robots, the four main basic configurations and `new\' robot configurations. The construction of robots. Robot programming, including off-line programming. Use of simulation systems to define robot workspaces. Robot sensory devices. Applications of industrial robots including parts handling applications and processing use applications. Consideration of the place of the robot in the automation of assembly operations. Reviews current research into automated assembly. Recognition of the need and importance of effective safety measures when robots are operating alongside personnel.

Automatic Guided Vehicles:- The need and application of automatic guided vehicles in the factory. Vehicle types. Vehicle control systems. Automatic load and unload systems.

High Volume Production Systems and Flexible Manufacturing Systems:- onsideration of the automated techniques used for the processing of discrete piece parts in high volumes, such as those employed for manufacture in the volume automotive industry. Evaluation of the different types of transfer machine. The use and operation of high volume machine tools. The construction, operation and use of flexible manufacturing systems. Line and cell type assembly systems, balancing of the assembly task. The place of the automated assembly machine.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMED9-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Integrated Manufacturing Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Practical application of scheduling, work planning and control, priority rules for scheduling and dispatching.

Comparisons and analysing of production control philosophies, ie MRP, MRP II, JIT and OPT, logistics and supplier chain relationships.

Evaluating manufacturing systems, approaches techniques and issues, use of discrete event (DE) models analysing manufacturing systems, the structure and workings of DE simulators, undertaking simulation studies, evaluation of experiments and experimental results, determination of confidence intervals.

Costing of engineering components based on a logistics model to incorporate inventory costing and activity based costing.

Integration of discrete-event models with other systems such as CAD/CAM, MRP and optimisers.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDB-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Materials & Manufacturing Processes
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Materials: Mechanical properties of materials and their measurement; e.g. tensile, hardness, impact. Introduction to primary and secondary bonding and the structure of materials.

Metals: Crystal structures and crystal defects (point defects, dislocations, grain boundaries); strengthening processes: alloying, work hardening, grain refinement and heat treatment processes; phase diagrams, simple phase transformations and microstructures; basic heat treatment; the heat treatment of steels.

Non-metals: Structure, properties, and strengthening mechanisms in polymers; introduction to ceramics and composite materials. Manufacturing Processes

Primary Processes: Rolling, casting, extrusion and forging of metals.

Presswork and Associated Processes: Sheet metal blanking, piercing, shearing and forming. Press tools, CNC presswork, drawing and extrusion. Ultrasonic, laser and water jet cutting.

Material Removal Processes: Conventional metal cutting processes. Turning, milling and grinding.

Assembly of Electronic Components: Printed circuit board layouts and assembly. Etching, dip soldering, strip board techniques, wire wrapping, surface mount.

Computer Numerical Control: CNC application, economic benefits of CNC, features of NC machine tools, machine tool control, structure of part-programs, manual part-programming, computer-aided part-programming.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDF-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Design, Materials and Processes
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Structure of Solids Bonding between atoms / molecules. Crystalline and amorphous structures. Relationship between bonding, structure and properties. Typical properties of materials with different structure and bonding.

Properties of Materials Definition of terms. Physical properties: thermal; optical; electrical; density. Mechanical properties: ductile and brittle behaviour; dislocations and crystalline materials; viscous flow and amorphous materials.

Polycrystalline Materials Origins of metallic and ceramic materials, economic and environmental considerations. Microstructure: single and multiphase systems. Principles of alloying in metallic and ceramic systems.

Metals Strengthening processes and heat treatment. Resources and recycling.

Metal Processes Primary processes: casting; rolling; extrusion; forging; powder technology. Sheet metal processes: blanking; piercing; shearing; forming; drawing. Cutting processes: turning; milling; grinding. Ultrasonic, laser and water jet cutting. Joining processes: welding; brazing; soldering; mechanical.

Polymers Thermoplastics, thermosets and elastomers: relationship between molecular structure and properties. Thermal and mechanical behaviour, environmental stability, recycling. Formulation and curing. Typical applications.

Polymer Processes Melt processes: extrusion; injection moulding; film blowing. Thermoforming. Dipping and slush moulding. RIM. Foam blowing.

Ceramics Structure and properties of ceramics: glass; clay products; building materials; engineering ceramics. Toughening methods.

Ceramic Processes Shaping processes; sintering; HIPping.

Composite materials Composite systems: reinforcing materials; matrix materials; interactions between the phases. Laminate design. Wood. Typical properties and applications.

Composite Processes Filament and tape winding. Laminating and consolidation. Spray and hand lay-up methods. Dough and sheet moulding processes.

Failure of Materials Materials failure resulting from operational / environmental degradation: fatigue; creep; corrosion; wear. Avoidance of such failures.

Surface Finishes Functional and aesthetic finishing processes: paints; lacquers; metallic coatings, ceramic coatings.

Materials Selection Use of a computer database to assist the selection of appropriate materials.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDG-40-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Design Studio 1 & 2
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The topics addressed will be organised under three main headings:\" Contexts\", \"Methodologies\" and \"Issues\".

Contexts will address a range of perspectives and students will be asked to consider the production and consumption of visual culture with the aid of a variety of theoretical models which they will be introduced to (e.g. marxism, structuralism, post-structuralism, feminism, critical theory, semiology ... etc.) as a means of understanding better the issues and debates which have emerged within this field and the influences these factors have on consumers and consumer products.

Methodologies will address approaches to design, methods of visualisation and representation : modelling, drawing, computer based graphics and related practical skills that can be used to realise a design. Methodologies will also address business and commercial perspectives, market evaluation, break even analysis, marketing approaches and product promotion.

Issues will address current and future soci-economic, environmental and legal issues surrounding product design and manufacture. Recycling legislation and pressure group activities, environmental marketing, producers / manufacturers liability, CE marking, British Standards approval, type testing issues. Environmental Protection Act (1990) and the H&SW Act (1974) with emphasis on their impact on engineering companies.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDJ-40-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Design Studio 3 & 4
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Review of the design process. Definition of fundamental concepts of design space, functional mapping objective trees. Customer requirements analysis. Idea generation and Brainstorming techniques. Use of binary weighting matrix to analyze requirements Mapping of requirements to functions, systems and components. Introduction to design optimization. Alternative design space search algorithms. Introduction to Taguchi and robust design. Functional analysis, Value engineering and value analysis, Constraints analysis. Theory of inventive problem solving (TRIZ).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDL-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Design Studio 5
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Through referral to industrial partners, coupled with their own primary research of a self defined market-place, the students work in groups to produce a functional plan for a small business. The exercise will require students to develop a design solution a specific brief that will address a range of product, market, legal and economic and other task dependant aspects which will be introduced to the whole group through a series of lectures and workshops throughout the module.

Individual tasking means that each student has a role within the proposed venture which he/she is required to carry out to ensure the success of the production of a viable business for the product plan.

Students will be awarded individual marks at the final assessment. Individual contributions will be assessed through the submission of a personal evaluative statement which will be written to correspond to a pro-forma with stated requirements and criteria.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE6B-10-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Music Dissertation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The intention of this module is for students to investigate a chosen musical instrument (including the human voice and electronic instruments) thoroughly from a wide range of viewpoints. The investigation is to be made largely independently and would include, for example, the instrument\'s structure, sound production, its history, physics, context of use. An 'engineering approach' is expected.

The student will be given guidelines on what is expected in the final dissertation. This will include an indication of the subject matter to be researched, such as the history, cultural context, physical structure, sound reproduction, coupling and amplification within the instrument, resonances, waveforms, synthesis of the instrument and problems with recording from the instrument. The main emphasis will be on the Engineering aspects. Material on relevant aspects of project management, suitable for a small project, will be provided, and students are expected to apply it to the planning and management of their activities in the module.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDY-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Materials and Manufacture
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Materials

- Selection of engineering materials and use of materials databases.

- Thermomechanical treatment in metallic systems, and its relationship to structure and properties.

- Structure and behaviour of engineering ceramics in relation to end use and manufacture. - Analysis of composites, anisotropic behaviour, behaviour of specific high performance composite materials, including metal matrix and ceramic matrix composites.

- Failure mechanisms in materials and components: fatigue; creep; corrosion; ductile failure and fast fracture. Mechanisms involved in these failures. Design and material selection to overcome likely failure modes.

- Non-destructive testing - techniques and applications.

- Case studies of failures.

Manufacturing Processes

- Role of manufacturing processes in the productivity of a manufacturing enterprise and in the efficient design and operation of a manufacturing system.

- Near Net Shape Forming: Material and energy conservation, near net shape forming processes, powder metallurgy, cold isostatic pressing, HIPping, superplastic forming, hot die and isothermal forging, diffusion bonding.

- Polymer Processing: Thermoplastic and thermosetting plastics, processing of plastics by injection, compression, blow moulding, extrusion and vacuum forming techniques.

- Joining Processes: Mechanical joining methods. Solid state and liquid state welding processes, weld quality, defects. Adhesive bonding.

- Low Stress Machining: Electro-chemical machining, electrochemistry of EM process, surface finish, tool design, electrolytes. Electro discharge machining, surface finish and machining accuracy, tool electrode and dielectric fluids, effect on metal surfaces.

- Competitive Aspects and Economics of Manufacturing: Materials and processing costs, selection of manufacturing processes, process capabilities, different elements of manufacturing costs, value engineering.

Laboratory Programme

- The students, working in small groups, will participate actively in the detailed specification of problems and the development of a work plan. Real life constraints, such as available time and other resources, must be taken into account, and the students will be expected to perform practical activities involving the collection plus analysis of experimental data.

- Examples: Use of noise analysis as an inspection tool. Assessment of robot performance.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEE3-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Illustrative examples of topics to be presented in the module include:

Review of the design process; Customer requirements analysis; Use of binary weighting matrix to analyse requirements; Introduction to design optimisation; Functional analysis, Value engineering and value analysis, Constraints analysis; An appreciation of the hardware and software requirements of typical CAD/CAM systems; Systems evaluation and selection methods (Benchmarking); Investigation of the design and manufacture of an engineering artefact using CAD/CAM programmes.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGP-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistical Modelling
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Basic Principles of Estimation and Inference. Theory underpinning non-parametric tests and applications to factors with more than two levels including the Kruskal-Wallis Test, Friedmans test and appropriate Bonferroni corrected post hoc analyses (Mann-Whitney tests and Wilcoxon tests as appropriate). Robust tests of dispersion (e.g. Levenes test) and tests of non-parametric correlation (e.g., Spearmans rank correlation, Kendalls tau).

2. Design of Experiments. The need for experimental design. Random selection, randomisation and blocking. Complete factorial designs. The need of replication. One-way analysis of variance. Blocked designs, factorial designs. Theoretical rationale for the use of the F-distribution in experimental designs. An introduction to multiple comparison tests and their development and theory. Limitations of inference from observational designs. Power of the test.

3. Linear Regression. Linear regression - revision of basic ideas, calculation of residuals and use of residuals as diagnostics for assessing model adequacy. Model diagnostics such as leverage, Cook's distance, standardised residuals, Studentized residuals and delta-beta measures of influence. Hypothesis testing for model parameters. Assessment of homoscedasticity (e.g. Goldfeld-Quandt test, Glejser test); independence and normality of residuals.

Multiple regression including the above on linear regression along with model formulation, selection of variables using backward elimination, forward selection and stepwise methods. Model interpretation and assessing adequacy of model. The use of dummy variables (referential coding) and interactions. Limitations of model inference e.g., problems arising from near multicollinearity. Theoretical rationale for the use of the t-distribution and the F-distribution under the linear regression model.

Partial correlations and their interpretation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEE9-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer Vision and Virtual Environments
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Illustrative examples of topics to be presented in the module include:

Imaging; Image formation;

Computer graphics, image processing, and computer vision and how do they relate to one another; Image capture; Image display; Human vision; Resolution and quantisation; Colour and colour spaces; Storage and compression of images; Capture and display devices; 3D to 2D projection;

Image processing and analysis

Operations on images: filtering, point processing, histogram techniques, thresholding, edge detection, segmentation; Encoding and compression: difference encoding, run length, transform encoding Applications of machine vision using Vision Builder in terms of data acquisition and process control.

Virtual engineering

3D Computer graphics; 3D modelling techniques; 3D transforms and matrices; Projection: orthographic and perspective; Ray tracing; Lighting: theory, flat shading, Gouraud, Phong; Texture mapping;

Virtual instrumentation

Vision Builder and LabVIEW as a virtual prototyping tool; Machine vision applications.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEEC-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Concurrent Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Rationale of Concurrent Engineering Issues related to the corporate culture and the organisational structures in the context of successful implementation of concurrent engineering Technologies for communication & collaboration Product development methodologies including capturing customer needs for defining conceptual specifications Issues related to cost factors in a CE environment Design for Manufacturability, Maintainability etc Rapid prototyping techniques for fast product development Life-Cycle Management vis--vis concurrent engineering

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEEE-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Theoretical Concepts in Applied Computer Vision
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Illustrative examples of topics to be presented in the module include:

- Basic Concepts: Machine vision, in the context of computer and human vision; Machine vision applications: component identification, inspection and quality control, metrology, security, medical applications, robot guidance; The five stages of machine vision; Hardware elements: lighting, camera, optical configuration, frames-store, resolution v field of view, monochrome v colour. Image acquisition and display: photosensitive devices, digitisation.

- 2D Image analysis: Binary images: Feature extraction: segmentation (connectivity), region mensuration; Erosion and dilation; Skeletonization; Grey level images: Histogram analysis; Image preprocessing: brightness/contrast enhancement, standard mappings: negation, thresholding, sharpening, smoothing; Thresholding; Convolution (edge detection); Hough space domain transformations; Feature extraction: area, perimeter, shape descriptions.

- 3D Image analysis: Applications; Projected patterns; Stereo triangulation; Photometric stereo;

- Interfacing and data collection.

- Management appraisal: why vision, safety and reliability, quality, flexibility, economic justification.

- Generating machine vision code.

- Current research (e.g. surface inspection, 3D metrology,etc).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEJR-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Surface CAD Modelling
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
To create, edit, analyze, and translate NURBS curves, surfaces, and solids in Windows with some limits on complexity, degree, or size. Creation of polygon meshes and point clouds.

To create geometric models and principles of representation of wire-frame, surface and solid models.

The development of physical and virtual prototype models using a commercial CAD system.

Undertaking design of an engineering product using CAD programs i.e. Rhinoceroses ready to export to an analyzing software i.e. ALGOR.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEJS-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Computational Mechanics
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEE6S-20-1 OR UFMES5-20-1 OR UFMEBF-40-1 OR (UFMEQT-20-1 AND UFMEQU-20-1))
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Course is based on computer simulation of selective components from the following: Trusses Pressure vessel Slope deflection of beams, Shear force bending moment diagram Complex stress analysis Complex strain analysis Buckling of struts. Symmetric and Unsymmetrical bending, Torsion of circular and non circular sections, Pin-jointed frames, Shear flow analysis

Additional Options Plastic hinges Bolt grouping Indeterminate problems Experimental Mechanics/ Electrical Resistance Strain Gauges (ERSG), PhotoStress

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMELF-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Product Design Technology Case Studies
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Outline of the selected problem by lecturer and/or industrial representative, development of specification by students (with lecturer\'s comments), work of students on solution, planning, presentation, feedback discussion.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEN9-20-3
