rdf:Description.p:title: Design in Business
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Design's contribution to business success. Why businesses use design. Where design fits into a business. Definitions of design disciplines. Design management. Product planning. Product design constraints - time, cost and resources. Relating design strategy to corporate and functional strategies. Design and branding. Innovation in business. Costs in business. Cost and value in products. Value analysis. Platform strategies. Intellectual property management.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQM-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: CAD Solid and Surface Modelling
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module provides an introduction to surface and solid modeling and aspects of Computer Aided Design (CAD) as they relate to the practice of product design. The module explores issues around the construction and presentation of surface models and the relevant computer software used by product designers in the expression of their ideas.

This may include creating, editing and analyzing NURBS curves and surfaces and the creation of polygon meshes and point clouds and surface rendering. Editing and analyzing solid models ready to be export to simulation software such as Algor or MSC VisualNastran.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQR-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Flight Simulation & Control
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The workings of the various types of flight simulators including:

- the construction of a flight simulator and the integration of its sub-systems

- the required structure for the flight computer and flight models, aerodynamic considerations and approximations, leading flight simulation software

- simulation of aircraft systems including landing gear, variable thrust, CofG movement, and aircraft system failure

- flight control systems, autopilot and navigation aids

- software systems and architecture, real-time systems, I/O computer

- electrical networks, control loading systems for stick and rudder forces

- motion bases

- simulating aircraft sounds (engines, propellers, warnings for stall, fire, gear, configuration), navigation markers and runway rumble

- visual system software including head-up display, scenery, weather and terrain models, 3D perception projection and synthetic vision.

- Overview of the current state-of-the-art of computer visualisation simulation and its uses for flight simulation

The human-in-the-loop: the physiological and psychological aspects of flight simulators, flight displays and motion-based simulators, safety aspects.

The use of flight simulators in aircraft design, stability and control studies, flight handling, pilot-training, airworthiness and certification, and research

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQS-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Aircraft Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Aircraft systems including: flight controls, flight instruments, landing gear, hydraulics, pneumatics, fuel, pressurisation, air conditioning, ice and rain protection, APUs, automatic flight, flight management computers, communications, navigation, emergency equipment, fire protection and warning systems.

The working of the gas turbine engine and engine power plants.

Interpretation of cut-aways, schematics and circuit diagrams for aircraft systems.

Applicable regulations for certification and flight including FAA, JAR, CAA, and ATA.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQU-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Thermodynamics and Fluids
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to units and problem solving techniques.

Hydrostatics, Bernoullis equation, flow measurement, dimensional analysis, laminar and turbulent flow, fluid flow with friction, fluid machines, pump and pipeline systems, introductory aerodynamics.

Pressure and temperature, work, heat and energy, open and closed systems, analysis of open and closed systems, simplifications for incompressible fluids, gas laws, fluid properties, problems involving gases and vapours.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQW-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Science 1
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Bending; Shear force and bending moments in simply supported beams; torsion, shear stress, shear strain, shear modulus, torsion in solid and hollow sections.

Laws of motion; linear and angular motion, moment of inertia and radius of gyration of rotating components. Linear and angular kinetic energy, effects of friction. simple harmonic motion; linear and transverse systems, effects of damping and forcing frequency.

Heat transfer; thermal conductivity, natural and forced convection, black and grey body radiation, Stephan's constant

Fluid flow; laminar and turbulent flow, viscous flow, boundary layer formation, pressure losses in pipes, effect of temperature, friction coefficient, Darcy's formula

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEJN-30-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Structural Integrity & Safety
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Dynamics component: Inertial and viscoelastic effects and nonlinearity. Elements of biomechanics. Structural behaviour under impact. Materials component: Materials response to stress: elastic and plastic behaviour; ductile and brittle behaviour; strain rate sensitive and strain rate insensitive materials. Energy absorption mechanisms in materials: single phase and multiphase systems; composite systems; fibre and laminate constructions Materials selection for safety: design for elastic and plastic deformation; design for specific problem areas e.g. fuel, electrical, clothing. Effect of degradation of materials and components on safety: downgrading due to, e.g. 'wear and tear', natural ageing, environmental factors, fatigue, prior damage. Materials testing: NDE and NDT; testing processes, e.g. for certification.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESK-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Strength of Materials
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Complex loading systems

Complex stress: analysis of two-dimensional stress systems, combined torsion and thrust, and combined torsion and bending.

Complex strain: Mohrs strain circle; strain analysis using strain gauges.

Theories of elastic failure: maximum principal stress and maximum shear stress theories; strain energy and maximum principal strain theories.

2. Loading on beams, columns and struts

Simply supported beams: Macaulays method, slope and deflection due to bending.

Reinforced concrete beams: theoretical assumptions; distribution of stresses.

Columns: stress due to asymmetrical bending; middle third rule; middle quarter rule.

Struts: end fixings; effective length; least radius of gyration of section; slenderness ratio; Euler and Rankine-Gordon formulae.

3. Behaviour of loaded structural members

Strain energy: strain energy, shear loading, bending and torsion.

Elastic deflections: elastic deflection of struts and ties; Castiglianos theorem, elastic deflection of torsion bars and transmission shafts.

Shock loading: elastic deflection and stress in struts and ties.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESL-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Dynamics of Machines
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Characteristics of power transmission systems elements

Gears: geometry; velocity ratios; acceleration of geared systems.

Screw drives: motion on an inclined plane; efficiency.

Flywheels: turning moment diagrams for reciprocating engines and presses; moment of inertia; specification.

Universal couplings: Hookes joint; constant velocity joint; conditions for a constant velocity ratio.

Characteristics of mechanisms

Cams: radial plate and cylindrical cams; follower types; misc. profiles; output characteristics.

Plane mechanisms: instantaneous output velocity; velocity vector diagrams; use of instantaneous centre of rotation.

Resultant acceleration: acceleration in plane linkage mechanisms; resultant acceleration and inertia force.

Gyroscopic motion: angular velocities of rotation and precession; reaction torque; applications.

Mechanical vibrations

Natural vibrations: mass-spring systems; transverse and torsional vibrations of systems; natural frequency of vibration; whirling of shafts.

Vibrations: mathematical analysis of damped and forced vibrations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESM-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Material Science for Engineers
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Material Properties

Introduction to materials, design, manufacturing and materials selection. Mechanical, physical, chemical and process characteristics. Metal structures: solidification, cooling rates and grains. Stress/strain curve, Youngs Modulus, plastic deformation, work hardening, residual stress. Plastic materials: structure, thermosets and thermoplastics, mechanical and physical properties. Composite materials: basic theory and rule of mixtures. Ceramic materials. Material selection.

2. Material Testing

Testing in the laboratory to establish the mechanical, physical and chemical properties of a range of material types including metals, plastics, composites and ceramics.

3. Materials Manufacture

Casting: sand, shell moulding, investment casting, gravity die and pressure die. Plastics: extrusion, injection moulding, blow, rotational, compression/transfer and vacuum forming. Forming: rolling, forging, extrusion, wire/bar drawing, sheet shearing,/blanking and deep drawing. Machining: mechanics, chip formation, cutting tools/fluids, turning, milling, drilling and grinding. Joining: joint preparation, welding, brazing and soldering, adhesive bonding and mechanical fastening. Design considerations for manufacturing and consideration of manufacturing costs.

4. Failure Criteria

Causes of material failure including corrosion, creep, fatigue, impact, overstressing, temperature, thermal cycling, stress relaxation, degradation. Consideration of service life, preventive and remediation methods.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESP-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Mechatronic Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Mechatronic systems

Discipline integration: integrated design; constraints on size and cost of components, compatibility of connection systems, required reduction in process delays etc.

System and sub-systems diagrams: as an aid to understanding function and measuring performance.

Mechatronic systems: industrial robot, CNC machines, vending machines etc.

2. Control concepts

Systems: open and closed-loop systems and system diagram representation

Feedback: negative feedback and benefits of negative feedback, feedback fraction, feedback block, mixing point and transfer function.

Types of control: on/off, proportional, derivative and integral control methods. Examples of systems using the range of control types.

System response: open-loop and closed-loop system responses to a step input and continuous input change in terms of response time and stability. Use of software simulation packages to demonstrate system response to input changes.

3. Specification for a mechatronic system

British Standards: reference to appropriate British Standards

Sensor attributes: phenomena being sensed, interaction of variables and removal of undesired changes, proximity of sensor to measureand, invasiveness of the measurement and measurand, signal form, ergonomic and economic factors.

Sensor technologies: resistive, inductive, capacitive, optical/fiber optic, ultrasonic, piezoelectric etc.

Software: appropriate software control for mechatronic systems e.g. microprocessor, PLC, PC based, basic programs.

4. Fault Location

Information: component data sheets, systems diagrams, flow charts, trouble shooting charts, wiring and schematic diagrams, operation and maintenance manuals, performance data, use of Internet etc.

Inspection and testing: system characteristics, on-line/off-line testing, test equipment, self diagnostic techniques, expert systems, safety issues

Fault location techniques: identification and selection of appropriate sources of information, analysis of evidence, fault evaluation and verification.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESR-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Project Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Project management principles

Project management: definition of projects; project management and the role of the project manager;

Success/failure criteria: operational, time and cost criteria, the project scope, product breakdown structure (PBS), work breakdown structure (WBS), project execution strategy and the role of the project team; investment appraisal (e.g. use of discount cash flow (DCF) and net present value (NPV), benefit analysis and viability of projects);

Project management systems: procedures and processes; knowledge of project information support (IS) systems; integration of human and material resources;

Terminating the project: audit trails; punch lists; close-out reports and post-project appraisals; comparison of project outcome with business objectives.

2. Organisation and Human Resources

Organisational structure: functional, project and matrix organisational structures; job descriptions and key roles; other stakeholders.

Control and coordination: project plans, planning, scheduling and resourcing techniques, use of work breakdown structure, monitoring performance and progress measurement, project reporting, change control procedures.

Leadership requirements: stages of team development (e.g. Belbins team roles), project leadership styles and attributes; delegation of work and responsibility; techniques for dealing with conflict; negotiation skills.

Human resources and requirements: calculation, specification and optimisation of human resource requirements.

3. Processes and procedures

Project management plans: contract terms, document distribution schedules, procurement, establishing the baseline for the project.

Project organisation: organisation charts, task responsibility matrix, statement of work (SOW) for project tasks.

Scheduling techniques: relationship between schedules, bar charts; milestone schedules; network techniques; resourcing techniques; computer-based scheduling and resourcing packages; project progress measurement and reporting techniques; staff-hours earned value and progress S curves; critical path analysis and reporting.

Cost control: project estimates, resource needs, estimating techniques, estimating accuracy, contingency and estimation, bid estimates, whole-life cost estimates, sources of information, cost information sensitivity, computer-based estimating.

Techniques: allocation of budgets; committed costs; actual costs; cash flow; contingency management.

Performance: budgeted cost for work scheduled (BCWS) budgeted cost for work performed (BCWP)); earned value; cost of work performed (ACWP); cost performance indicators.

Change control: impact of changes, principles of change control , changes to scope, specification, cost or schedule; change reviews and authorisation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEST-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Quality Assurance and Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Total Quality Management (TQM)

Quality strategy, management of change, customer and supplier focus, motivation, training. Behavioural, cultural and leadership issues. Organisational structures and responsibilities, quality improvement terms, quality circles.

2. Quality Assurance (QA) systems

Procedures, quality manuals, parameters fitness for purpose, customer satisfaction, cost effectiveness, compliance with standards, standards organisation and documentation charts, communication, feedback, legislation. Quality systems - ISO 9000, QS 9000 and ISO 14001 Environmental Systems. Control methods: internal and external quality audits, statistical methods, planned maintenance, condition monitoring. Cost issues.

3. Quality Control (QC) techniques

Statistical quality control techniques: frequency distribution, mean range, standard deviation, control charts. Process capability. Use of Software packages for quality audit procedures, cause and effect analysis, Failure Mode and Effect Criticality Analysis (FMECA).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESU-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Design for Manufacture
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Although lectures will be used as a means of imparting information much of the syllabus will be delivered through a combination of case studies, site visits and learning that will take place in the students workplace. The following areas will be covered:

1. Manufacture

Manufacturing methods: Different manufacturing methods. Influence of factors such as design form, material type and properties, quality requirements, available equipment, processing capability, costs, skills of labour force. Advantage and disadvantage of standardisation. Application of British Standards, ISO standards and industry-specific standards.

Cost issues: material, labour and overheads; fixed and variable costs; relationship between manufacturing method, complexity of design, required surface finish, chosen materials, standardisation of parts and processes, value engineering etc.

Factors affecting material requirements and specifications: form, size, weight, quality, processing method, quantity, availability, service life, and physical characteristics.

2. Assembly processes

Selection of appropriate assembly methods. Standardisation, sequencing, rationalising of numbers of parts, ease of assembly, ease of handling and positioning. Links with good design awareness of assembly processes at the design stage.

3. Tolerances and dimensions

Introduction to tolerances, limits and fits. Geometric tolerancing. Dimensioning of assemblies. Use of datums. Jig & tool design. Sub-assemblies and assemblies. Using relevant BS and ISO standards.

4. Computer-aided manufacturing

Review of Computer Aided Manufacture (CAM). Current technologies for manufacture and context of manufacturing in the Supply Chain. Introduction to Numerical Control (NC) and Computer Numerical Control (CNC). Demonstration of CAM equipment. Software: for numerical control of manufacturing, assembly and material selection.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEUW-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Control Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
System Analysis

Introduction to Signals; Instrumentation; Actuation; Systems of differing order.

Frequency response: Frequency response from Laplace transfer function; bandwidth in relation to time constant; definition of dB; Bode plots with straight line approximation; Nyquist plots, resonance.

Laplace transforms: Definition; transforms of common signals; use of tables; solution of ordinary differential equations; pole/zero diagrams; network time response; forced and natural modes; time constant; stability; second order response; use of standard second order response chart.

Systems Electronics: Operational amplifiers: Network analysis: RLC network analysis using Laplace transforms; step and sinusoidal response.

System representation in a computer simulation environment.

Control Systems

Introduction: Need for automatic control; Examples such as amplifiers, machine tools, aircraft, the eye, the economy; open and closed loop; servo and regulator control; plant, actuator, sensor, controller.

System modelling: Definition of linear and non-linear systems; linear modelling of systems of differing orders and complexities; approaches to non-linear control; systems representation, analysis and control in simulation packages; introduction to Stochastic Optimal Control.

System performance: Static servo and regulator gain; overshoot and rise time applied to various domains.

Feedback control design: Dominant poles; design of P, PI, PID, IP and IPD controller using pole placement regulator control.

System identification: Identification of transfer functions from system time and frequency responses.

Frequency domain controller design: Nyquist stability criterion; gain and phase margin: design of a phase shift controller.

Routh - Hurwitz stability criterion and Final Value theorem.

Robust Control of Systems

Critical system control strategies; Failure mode mitigation; Robust digital control systems for aircraft and plant; Integrity, redundancy and diversity.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEH4-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Research Methods (Health Informatics)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Scientific and ethnographic models for research The Research Process; theory and practical implications Selection and Identification of the Research Topic, Definition of Research Objectives, Formulation of Research Questions and Hypotheses Review of Relevant Literature and Existing Research: Literature Searches; Effective Use of the Internet and library materials, and organisation of material. Deciding the Research Strategy and Design The Research Proposal and Plan Ethical considerations for researchers Issues of reliability, validity and generalisability for researchers Features of Qualitative and Quantitative Data Collection of Primary Data: Experimental Design, Survey Methods, Sampling Design and Procedure. Use of secondary data in the research process Collection and Analysis of Qualitative Data; Interviewing and Observation Methods. Communicating your Results Effectively: Dissertation Structure and Presentation

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE97-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Development and Practice 2
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Models of the system development process: development lifecycle; the waterfall model, prototyping, the spiral model.

The role of design in systems development. Introduction of the constraints and objectives of design: functionality, usability, cost-benefit analysis, performance objectives, matching problems to solutions, evaluating available technology. The use of method in the systems development lifecycle: integration of particular modelling techniques into design methods; comparative strengths and weaknesses of different methods and the evolution of methods, eg structured to object-oriented.

Prototyping in projects: approaches, methods, the role of prototyping in design; use of techniques (eg, Rapid Application Development) to produce prototypes; involving users in prototype development (eg, Joint Application Development); walkthroughs.

Introduction to databases: database architectures and DBMS; data modelling, normalisation, logical database design; the structure, syntax and use of query languages, eg SQL.

Building software applications: transforming models and diagrams into software realisations; using CASE tools; using 4GLs and packages; using programming languages.

Working in teams on a group project: project planning and control; investigations to establish requirements; developing prototypes; keeping individual and team activity logs; implementation and report; review of work done, results, and process.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7H-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Communication Networks and Protocols
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Layered architectures for communication systems. Reference models and standards.

The data link layer: framing, error detection and correction, error control protocols. Performance analysis. Protocol specification and verification.

Local area networks: MAC protocols and relative performance. Ethernet variants. Wireless LANs. Bridged LANs.

The network layer: packet and circuit switching. Routing algorithms. Congestion Control algorithms. The Internet protocol.

The transport layer: transport protocols. TCP and UDP. Performance issues.

The application layer: application protocols. Network Security.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEF5-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistical Models
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Additional aspects of multiple regression

Model diagnostics, transformations, interactions, lack-of-fit, Durbin-Watson statistic. Application of multiple regression for designed experiments including central composite designs and effect coding models (one-way anova, blocked designs, latin square designs, factorial designs, nested designs, nested factorial designs).

2. The Generalised Linear Model.

Model specification, parameter estimation and model diagnostics for logistic regresssion (binary outcome, ordinal outcome and nominal outcome), Poisson, Binomial (logit, probit and complementary log-log) and Gamma models. Tests of goodness-of-fit, tests of significance, examination of residuals. Issues surrounding model fitting.

Log-linear models and their application to analysing contingency tables and their interpretation.

3. Survival analysis and reliability.

The analysis of censored and truncated data. Comparison of survival curves using tests such as Mantel Haenszel test, Peto's test and the logrank test. Non-parametric, semi-parametric and parametric survival techniques such as Kaplan-Meier, Cox's Proportional Hazards and Weibull models and related techniques.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEF6-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Applied Multivariate Techniques
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Multivariate data collection, missing values and bias. Methods of preliminary analysis and visualization of data Principal component analysis Factor analysis Correspondence analysis Procrustes analysis Canonical correlation analysis Discriminant analysis Cluster analysis using a variety of metrics and clustering algorithms Multi-dimensional scaling (classical and ordinal methods) Multivariate multiple regression Multilevel modelling Structural equation modelling

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFH-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Mathematics 1
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Algebra -

Revision of basic algebraic techniques such as transposition of formulae, factorization, completing the square, partial fractions and manipulation of exponential and log expressions.

Extension to:

Complex Algebra: Basic algebraic operations, rectangular, polar and exponential forms, Argand diagram, Eulers formula, De Moivre's theorem. Applications to circuit analysis and use of phasors.

Matrix and Vector Algebra: Properties of matrices and determinants, the inverse matrix, Gaussian elimination, properties of vector quantities, vector addition, unit vectors, position vectors, scalar product, vector product. Vector equation of a straight line, vector equation of a plane. Linear independence. Applications (e.g. circuit analysis and use of Kirchoffs Laws).

Functions and Calculus -

Revision of the properties of standard engineering functions, basic concepts and rules of differentiation; linear properties, product rule, quotient rule and chain rule, and basic concepts and rules of integration.

Extension to:

Solving trigonometric equation (e.g. A sin(wt) = p). Combining sinusoidal waveforms of different angular frequencies.

Interpretation of exponential and power relationships in terms of log-linear and log-log transformation and determination model parameters.

Parametric and implicit differentiation. 1st and 2nd order partial derivatives, error estimation, Maclaurin and Taylor series expansions. Newtons method for solving non-linear equations. Optimisation problems.

Integration by parts, integration by substitution. Applications of the definite integral such as average values, root mean square calculations, energy storage and dissipation, centres of mass, moments of inertia, volumes and surface area. Trapezium and Simpsons rules for numerical integration.

Solution of Differential Equations: Modelling of simple linear dynamical systems, solution of first and second order linear constant co-efficient ordinary differential equations, natural and forced response, resonance. Eulers method for the numerical solution of a non-linear differential equation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFQ-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Nonlinear Mathematics
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFQEFT-20-2 AND UFQEFP-20-2 AND UFQELH-20-1 AND (UFQELG-20-1 OR (UFQETH-10-1 AND (UFQETG-10-1 OR UFQETJ-10-1))))
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
One-dimensional maps: Discrete dynamical systems, fixed points, cycles, stability, bifurcation, period doubling, chaos.

Scalar ordinary differential equations (ODEs): Existence and uniqueness, fixed points, stability, bifurcation.

Coupled ODEs: Existence and uniqueness, fixed points, stability, phase portraits, Hopf bifurcation, limit cycles, Poincare-Bendixson Theorem.

Applications. Mechanical buckling, population dynamics, electrical/mechanical oscillators, chemical reaction kinetics, numerical convergence.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFW-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Discrete Mathematics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Logic and Methods of Proof

Propositional and predicate logic: logical equivalences, transformational proofs, validity of arguments and proof by inference, models and countermodels, minimisation of well formed formula.

Induction and Recursion with proof by induction (mathematical and structural). Includes introduction to set theory. Combinatorial Proof.

Combinatorics. Functions and Counting. Selections (ordered/unordered; with/without repetition). Partitions and Equivalence Relations. Recurrence Relations.

Graph Theory. Introduction to graph theory. Simple graphs and representation by matrices. Isomorphic graphs. Problems involving cycles and circuits. Matching problems and bipartite graphs.

Group Theory. Introduction to Group Theory, including its applications to combinatorial problems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGG-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Decision Analysis and Modelling
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The role of quantitative modelling in business

Decision models when certainty is assumed: Formulating simple linear programming models and solving them using the graphical method. Elementary sensitivity analysis. Stock Control decisions: Determining how much to order: the elementary economic order quantity model. Production level decisions: break-even analysis

Decisions models when uncertainty applies: Decision tables and trees. Decision criteria: maximin, maximax, minimax and expected value. Conditional profit tables. Influence diagrams and decision trees. Stock Control: determining when to order to meet a given customer service level or to minimise costs: the re-order level model. Investment appraisal decisions: net present value, internal rates of return

Models of Processes: Modelling queuing problems. The nature of queuing problems. The (M/M/1) model. Using queue models to minimise costs. Limitations of queue models. Introduction to simulation.

Planning and forecasting models: Project planning problems. Activity-on-node networks, types of activity dependency relationship, activity times and float, Gantt charts, PERT. Short-term Forecasting Methods: Moving averages, weighted moving averages, simple exponential smoothing.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8B-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Web Based Information Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. The background and development of the World Wide Web from a sociotechnical perspective; its significance from an operational perspective.
  2. The development of client-server computing architectures and the parallel developments in wide area networking. Current and ongoing developments; e.g. the 'Wireless Web', MBone (Multicast Backbone)
  3. Protocols and languages including tcp/ip, http, https, html, xml, xhtml.
  4. Appreciation of the role of Open DataBase Connect and Java DataBase Connect drivers; Common Object Request Broker Architecture.
  5. The variety of processing styles available: Common Gateway Interface, Active Server Pages, Client- and Server-side processing.
  6. The three-tier paradigm: Data, Business and User services.
  7. Mapping Information System requirements onto WBIS. Appropriate object oriented development methodologies. Web-page and Web-site development tools.
  8. Third party enhancements to WBIS: e-commerce, cybercarts.
  9. Web based IS in organisations: implications for working practices and the organisation of work.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQELH-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Structures of Mathematics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Notation, logic and language. Definitions and theorems. Methods of proof. Sets and functions. Cardinality: finite sets, countable sets and uncountable sets. Number Systems. Complex numbers. Further topic: application/extension to other areas in mathematics, e.g. algebra, geometry, set theory, logic.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEQ4-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Biomedical and Industrial Statistics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design and Planning of Experiments

In the medical Sciences:- Basic principles in designs: Randomisation, Replication, Blindness, Control, Use of placebos; Repeated measures designs; Hierarchical designs. Designs in Clinical Trials; Prospective Cohort Studies; Case-control Studies; Cross-sectional Studies; The Protocol; Study size.

In Industrial Studies:- Role of process and product design in quality improvement; two-level factorial designs, aliasing, design generators; augmented designs, central composite and rotatable designs; optimisation of a process using these designs and steepest ascent methods; Taguchi methods; controllable noise factors; parameter design; inner and outer arrays. Modern approaches to the analysis of experiments containing controllable and noise factors. Comparison of the similarities and differences in the approach to the design of experiments in medicine and industry.

Diagnostic Testing in Medicine and Health

-Uses of diagnostic tests in screening for disease, new compounds and new biological strains. -Description of test accuracy: specificity and sensitivity; probabilistic modelling. -Evaluation of predictive value of a test; use of Bayes theorem

Survival Analysis and Reliability

Life tables. Types of life tables: Clinical/Cohort and demographic; time interval data, endpoints, censorship, estimation of survival probabilities, Kaplan-Meier survival curves. Comparison of survival curves: odds ratio, Mantel-Haenszel test and logrank test. Applications in medicine, health studies and industry.

Statistical Process Control

Process monitoring using control charts for variables (x-bar and range) and attributes (np, p, c and u); cusum charts, the operating characteristic and average run length.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEKJ-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Professional, Ethical and Policy Issues
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Overall focus is on the emergence of a so-called information society and the role of ICTs in sustaining or reconfiguring social institutions and relations.

- Social informatics and the information society:

  • introduction to analytical frameworks;
  • theories of the information society;
  • evidence and issue-based approaches;
  • technological and social determinism.

Ethical and policy issues

  • ethical codes and theories
  • privacy and surveillance
  • e-democracy and the public sphere.

Political economy of digital media:

  • ownership of information, intellectual property and copyright;
  • community and commodity models, and the information commons concept.

The rise of the networked society:

  • information, knowledge and learning;
  • trust and authority;
  • access, inclusion and the digital divide;
  • reworking of time-space relations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQERF-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematical Techniques (Distance)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Algebra -

Algebraic Manipulation: Revision of basic algebraic techniques such as transposition of formulae, factorization, completing the square, partial fractions and manipulation of exponential and log expressions

Complex Algebra: Basic algebraic operations, rectangular, polar and exponential forms, Argand diagram, De Moivre\'s theorem

Matrix and Vector Algebra: Properties of matrices and determinants, the inverse matrix, Gaussian elimination, properties of vector quantities, vector addition, unit vectors, position vectors, scalar product, vector product.

Calculus -

Functions: Revision of the properties of standard engineering functions such as polynomials, rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions and trigonometric functions; the inverse function, solving non-linear equations

Differential Calculus: Revision of standard derivatives, linear properties, product rule, quotient rule and chain rule. Higher order derivatives, classification of turning points, parametric and implicit differentiation. 1st and 2nd order partial derivatives, Taylor series expansions. Newton's method for solving non-linear equations

Integral Calculus: Revision of standard integrals, indefinite and definite integration, integration by parts, numerical integration, applications of the definite integral

Solution of Differential Equations: Modelling of simple systems, solution of first and second order linear constant co-efficient ordinary differential equations, natural and forced response

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQERN-5-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematics for Research A
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
UNITS

1. Basic concepts of Linear Algebra

The theory and application of linear algebra are fundamental to many branches of mathematics, both in abstract and concrete terms. This unit concentrates on the theory and practical applications of Numerical Linear Algebra. This unit will start with a system of linear equations as motivation for the study of matrices, linear transformations and, ultimately, vector and sub-spaces which are the basic building blocks of linear algebra.

As a result of studying this module, students will understand:

- (i) representation of a linear algebraic system (LAS) as a matrix equation

(ii) representation of the solution of an LAS as a vector

- as a vector space

- linear transformations from to

- the properties of linear algebraic systems

The content is as follows

(i) Linear Algebraic Systems (LAS):

- Introduction to Matrix Algebra

- Representation of a linear system of equations as a matrix equation

- motivating the definition of matrix multiplication

(ii) The vector space properties of . Definition of a subspace of .

(iii) Linear transformations from to and their representation by a matrix.

(iv) Solution of linear systems of equations by Gaussian Elimination.

- This includes consideration of:

- a) the null space and nullity of the system matrix

- b) the column space and rank of the system matrix

2. Linear Algebra (Solving Linear Algebraic Systems)

This unit covers the mathematical background behind, and the implementation of methods for, solving large systems of algebraic equations. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, either because a linear algebraic model is being used to describe a particular problem or as a consequence of applying a numerical scheme to the governing equation.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand

- the difference between the use of direct methods and iterative methods of solution

- how to implement these methods efficiently

- the importance of being able to identify ill-conditioning in a linear algebraic system and what techniques can be used to improve the accuracy of a numerical method of solution, when ill-conditioning is present

The content is as follows

(i) Direct methods: - Implementation of Gaussian elimination, using an LU factorisation routine

(ii) Iterative methods: Implementation of Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and Successive Over Relaxtion (SOR) schemes

(iii) Error control: Use of condition number to identifying ill-conditioned systems. In the case of direct methods, implementing pivoting strategies to control the propogation of rounding error

3: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

This unit covers what eigenvalues are and how useful they can be in the analysis of problems which arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics.

As a result the student will understand

- the nature of eigenvalues with respect to different types of matrices

- how eigenvalues can be computed

- the extension of the concepts of eigenvalues to include singular values of non-square matrices

The content is as follows:

(i) Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Revision of eigenvalues and eigenvectors to include definition and diagonalisation of matrices, and extend work to cover complex matrices and other similarity transformations

(ii) Computation of Eigenvalues: The power method, tridiagonal and upper Hessenberg forms of matrices and the QR algorithm for finding eigenvalues

(iii) Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) of matrices: The SVD for any rectangular matrix is defined and constructed. We look at an applications such as the least squares problem, numerical conditioning and the pseudoinverse

4. Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Introduction)

This unit introduces the initial value problem together with simple numerical techniques for producing a numerical solution. It contains material that must be understood prior to looking at the more advanced numerical techniques that form the basis of commercially available software packages that are used to solve this problem. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, whenever modelling of continuous time dynamical systems is a requirement of the research

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand:

- how an initial value problem arises from the modelling of a dynamical system

- the logic that lies behind the derivation of a numerical method for solving an initial problem

- the nature and magnitude of errors that are incurred when using numerical methods to solve an initial value problem

The content is as follows

(i) Initial Value Problems: Modelling dynamical systems, initial conditions, analytical solution (for simple problems)

(ii) Numerical schemes: Eulers method, the modified Euler method, Runge-Kutta schemes (including the classical 4th order scheme)

(iii) Error analysis: Discretisation error and stability of numerical schemes. In this unit, the analysis will be restricted to simple 2nd order numerical schemes

5. Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Error control and analysis)

Prior to taking this unit, student must have knowledge that is equivalent to that contained in unit 4 Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Introduction). Unit 5 considers the implementation of advanced numerical methods consideration of the efficient implementation of these schemes and methods for dealing with stiff equations. It contains material that lies behind the advanced numerical techniques that form the basis of commercially available software packages that are used to solve initial value problems. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, whenever modelling of continuous time dynamical systems is a requirement of the research.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand

- the logic that lies behind the derivation of high order accuracy numerical methods for solving an initial problem

- which methods are appropriate for the solution of stiff equations

- how to control the error incurred when implementing these schemes

The content is as follows

(i) High order numerical schemes: Linear multistep schemes, embedded Runge-Kutta schemes. Comparing the implentation of explicit and implicit numerical schemes

(ii) Error estimation and control: Use of predictor-corrector schemes, embedded Runge-Kutta schemes. Introducing adaptive discretisation step size

(iii) Stiff Equations: Linear stability analysis of high order numerical schemes. Gear style schemes

6. Nonlinear Dynamics

The main aim of this unit is to introduce the concepts of stability and bifurcation in nonlinear ordinary differential equations with a view to their application in other disciplines e.g. engineering, economics, biology, etc

1. Solution concept and phase space

2. Linearisation and stability (via eigenvalue test)

3. Simple bifurcation of fixed points (saddle-node, transcritical and pitchfork).

4. Periodic solutions and Hopf bifurcation

Students will also be made aware of more complicated (chaotic) solution behaviour in higher dimensions, though this will not be assessed

7. Analytical methods for pricing financial derivative contracts

The aim of this unit is to introduce and apply stochastic models that occur in finance to the derivation of analytical expressions that are available for pricing derivative contracts such as forwards, futures and options. The unit covers the key theoretical concepts of risk neutral valuation and no arbitrage that are central to the derivation of pricing models. The use of Itos lemma in determining the probability distribution of a function of a random variable will be investigated as a prelude to deriving the Black-Scholes pricing model for financial derivatives where the underlying asset follows a geometric Brownian motion. Assets that follow a mean reverting process such as oil and electricity prices will be considered as an extension to the Black-Scholes framework.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand the main theoretical concepts involved in modelling financial derivative contracts and will have an appreciation of the limitations of the theory. In particular a student will be able to interpret the pricing formula as a description of the market view of risk that is inherent in a financial derivative contract.

8. Numerical methods for pricing financial derivative contracts

Before studying this unit, students will require a working knowledge of the material covered in Unit 7 together with experience of using a programming language that is suitable for implementing algorithms for the solution of mathematical problems. (for example Maple, Matlab, Visual Basic, Fortran, R or C).

The aim of this unit is to cover computational techniques that are used in the pricing of financial derivative contracts. These techniques may be based on

  • Monte-Carlo simulations
  • Binomial probability trees
  • Numerical integration techniques
  • Finite difference schemes

Students will be expected to apply one of the above approaches to the pricing of a derivative contract that they have chosen as relevant to their research. Students will be required to demonstrate understanding of how to the computational scheme is derived, its efficient implementation and the performance of the schemes in terms of its speed of convergence and stability.

9. Independent Study in Advanced Mathematical Topics

The taking of this unit is subject to negotiation and the identification of a suitable supervisor

The above units cover techniques commonly used in research that involves applied mathematics. The above units do not provide an exhaustive list of mathematical techniques likely to be needed in applied research. The unit (ISAMT) permits independent investigative research into the concepts, theory and practical applications for a specific technique (or techniques) with supervisory guidance. It is not possible to give a comprehensive list of topics that may be needed by an individual researcher but by way of examples, appropriate topics for this unit would including issues relating to the application of a scientific programming language, mathematical modelling, discrete mathematics, optimisation problems, solution of partial differential equations, signal processing and analysis.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQESJ-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Further Analytical Methods
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Number Systems

Error arithmetic: significant figures and estimation techniques; error arithmetic operations; systematic and random errors

Number systems: natural, integer, rational, reals, dinary, binary, octal and hexadecimal number systems; conversion between bases; two-state logic systems, binary numbers; logic gates and logic circuits

Complex numbers: real and imaginary parts, notation; Cartesian and polar forms; modulus, argument and complex conjugate; addition, subtraction, multiplication and division ; Argand diagrams; de Moivres theorem

Engineering applications:

Graphical and numerical methods

Graphical techniques: Cartesian and polar co-ordinate systems; vector representation; standard curves; asymptotes; irregular areas and mean values of wave forms; phasor and Argand diagrams

Numerical integral: mid-ordinate; trapezoidal and Simpsons rules

Numerical estimation methods: method of bisection; Newton-Raphson

Vector geometry and matrix methods

Vector notation and operations: vector representation; addition, subtraction and scalar, dot and vector products; graphical methods

Matrix operations and vectors: matrix operations, square and rectangular matrices, row and column vectors, determinant and inverse of a 2x2 matrix; Gaussian elimination

Ordinary differential equations

First order differential equations: separation of variables; integrating factor method, complementary function and particular integral

Numerical methods for first order differential equations: Euler, improved Euler and Taylor series methods

Second order differential equations: homogeneous and non-homogeneous linear second order equations

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQT-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Stress & Dynamics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to units and problem solving techniques.

Equilibrium, free body diagrams, frameworks, axial stress and strain, engineers bending theory, properties of sections, engineers torsion theory, combined bending and direct stress, plane stress and strain, thin pressure vessels.

Displacement velocity and acceleration, scalars and vectors, relative and absolute quantities, projectiles, Newtons laws, gravity, DAlemberts principle, moments of inertia. Introduction to free and forced vibration, energy, work, power and efficiency, circular motion, rigid body motion, vector methods, mechanisms.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETG-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introductory Mathematics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Algebra: Transposition of formulae, factorization, completing the square, partial fractions.

Functions: Properties of functions such as polynomials, rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions and trigonometric functions; the inverse function, solving non-linear equations.

Differentiation: Limits, standard derivatives, product, quotient and chain rules. Higher order derivatives, classification of turning points, series expansions.

Integration: Standard integrals, indefinite and definite integration, integration by parts, integration by substitution.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEF7-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Prediction: Forecasting and Data Mining
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Introduction to Forecasting: Assessing forecast accuracy, the role of forecasting in planning and decision making. Types of forecasting models. Monitoring Forecasts.

2. Exponential Smoothing Models : Simple and adaptive exponential smoothing. Double exponential smoothing, Holt\'s method and Holt-Winter\'s method. Damped exponential smoothing.

3. The Box-Jenkins Approach: Autocorrelation and Partial Autocorrelation Functions. Types of Time Series model. Model Identification. Parameter Estimation.

4. State Space Models: Structural models. Estimation using the Kalman filter. Connections between the three types of models.

5. Introduction to Data Mining: The role of data mining, Components of data mining algorithms, assessing performance of data mining techniques, nearest neighbour methods.

6. Classification and regression trees: Growing trees, pruning trees, use of trees for regression, use of trees for classification.

7. Neural Nets: Perceptrons, feed forward neural nets, deciding on network structure, issues in training neural networks.

8. Kernel Estimation: Density Estimation, Nonparametric regression.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEVE-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Chassis
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• tyre behaviour and racing performance limitations
  • applying dynamics modelling techniques to vehicle chassis performance (Matlab)
  • road surface characterisation and modelling
  • suspension geometries and their analysis
  • design for purpose, consideration of compromise solutions
  • handling dynamics, understeer and oversteer, roll etc.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEL6-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Research Writing
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Different kinds of academic writing. Writing genres. Essays, journal papers, conference papers, posters, book chapters, research proposals and bids. Formulating a subject. Research areas and topics. Research questions and problems. Documenting research in progress. Notes, logs, diaries. Indexing contacts and sources. Recording. Managing research information. Mapping the research territory. Formulating an argument. Elements of a good argument. Making claims and providing supporting evidence. Warrants and challenges to warrants. Writing style. Achieving clear communication. Writing for an audience. Grammar, punctuation and composition. Styles of academic writing. Styles and formatting in word processing. Using sources. Reading styles and strategies. Comprehension, prcis, notetaking. Citing, referencing and quoting. Paraphrasing. Bibliographies. Authority and attribution. Designing and presenting research information. Communicating evidence verbally and visually. Information design for research writing. Report structure and layout. Summarising. Introductions, rehearsal, recapitulation, conclusions. Titles and subtitles. Abstracts. Keywords and search terms. Drafting and revising. Preparing and organising a draft paper. Tracking revisions and version control. The editing process. Writing with others. Dividing and coordinating the work. Keeping focus. Achieving consistency of style. Agreeing the final version. Reviewing. Submission and refereeing process and cycle. Writing and reading reviews. Software tools for academic writing. Word and text processors and electronic publishing. Bibliographic tools. Tools for managing research data. Markup and markup languages. Online publication. Writing for e-journals and web dissemination.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFB-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematics for Mechanical Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Further Vectors and Matrices: Vector geometry of lines and planes. Vector geometry of curves and differentiation of vectors. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Solution of discrete linear systems x(n+1)=Ax(n) and continuous systems x' = Ax

Laplace Transforms: Definition and manipulation of standard transforms. Inverse transform. Solution of linear differential equations.

Fourier Series: Periodic functions and fundamental period. Computation of Fourier Series. Convergence of Fourier Series.

Partial Differential Equations: Derive a PDE in context of either the Heat equation or Laplace's equation. Use Fourier series and separation of variable techniques to solve the PDE. Use appropriate software to display results and aid interpretation. Use a numerical solution which uses a finite-difference scheme to solve the PDE, with appropriate software to implement and display the numerical solution.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPER3-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Design Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Design specification; Customer requirements: compliance, function, performance, cost, production parameters are identified and listed.

- Design Parameters: implications of specification parameters and resource requirements are identified and matched;

- Design information: information required in the design process is researched and extracted from appropriate reference sources, an examination of techniques and technology used in similar products, relevant standards and legislation are identified and applied.

- Design report: Application of creative thinking techniques, Analysis of possible design solutions, evaluation of costs, compliance check-lists, future development potential, value engineering concepts, final design solution, conclusion.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPER8-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Industrial Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Project selection: connection with departmental research and industrial placement

- Project proposal: produced by student with advice from supervisor

- Project execution: monitored by supervisor

- Project presentation: report, and viva

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: USPJDX-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Learning Disability: Issues, Debates and Psychological Perspectives

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFY-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Analytical Modelling
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Logic: Propositional and Predicate logic. Logical equivalence and inference. Validity of arguments. Methods of proof.

Set Theory: Numbers. Sets. Functions. Relations.

Combinatorics and Probability Theory: Enumeration. Probability Theory. Probability Theory of Random Variables.

Real-valued Functions: Measurement and Error. Rules and manipulation of logarithms and indices. Properties of standard functions. Big-O notation. Rate of change of functions.

Graph Theory. Introduction to Graph Theory and its applications as a modelling tool.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDQ-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Management of Aerospace Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The module comprises the following:

- Introduction, history and rationale of CE

- Organisational issues: corporate culture, overcoming barriers, multi-disciplinary teams, creation and empowerment of product development teams

- Communication infrastructure

- Product development in CE

- Cost considerations in CE

- Design for Manufacturability and maintainability

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDW-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Aircraft Manufacture and Assembly
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The module aims to give design personnel a detailed understanding of the way aircraft are manufactured and assembled and the importance of designing for ease of manufacture, maintenance and minimum cost while meeting customer requirements.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEJJ-20-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Mechanics of Materials and Lightweight Structures
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Statics and equilibrium; framework structures; shear and moment analysis; loading actions; direct stress and strain; stresses in beams; combined bending and direct stress; 2D and 3D stress and strain analysis; thin pressure vessels and optimisation; complex stress; principal stresses and yield criteria; beam deflections; strain energy; unsymmetrical bending; buckling; torsion theory; shear stress due to bending; shear centre; torsion of open and closed section beams; aircraft loads, structural components and materials; compression panels, tension field shear panels, idealisation of sections, box beam shear flows; fatigue, fracture mechanics; finite element analysis; composites; practical strain analysis; bolting groups.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEJM-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: The Aerospace Design Process, Concept to Compliance
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Ability to assess relative importance of aerospace customer requirements and priorities.

- Understanding of certification requirements.

- An understanding of how to create an objective hierarchy showing relative importance of requirements and constraints.

- Generation of abstract aerospace design configurations.

- Creation of general arrangement sketches of alternative design solutions and major systems (powerplant, landing gear, control system etc).

- Analytical assessment of alternative designs.

- The need to exercise engineering judgement in the face of uncertain knowledge.

- Sensitivity analysis and the use of stochastic design variables.

- Use of optimisation tools and statistical analysis to refine and produce a robust design solution.

- Presentation of case studies and critical review of the design process.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDM-60-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Individual Project (Product Design)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The issues addressed will reflect the specific focus of each project selected by the student.

Taught sessions will be given on research methods, how to source information and formal requirements for references and bibliographies.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE77-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Telecommunication Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
INFORMATION THEORY: Information content of signals, Transmission of information, and Hartley and Shannon's Law and its applications.

CW TRANSMISSION SYSTEMS: Analogue CW modulation techniques: DSB, AM, SSB, VSB, Angle Modulation, generation, demodulation and applications, FDM, Comparison including SNR performance, Superhet principle for reception.

DIGITAL TRANSMISSION SYSTEMS: PCM: A/D conversion, sampling (anti-aliasing filter) and encoding, quantisation noise, linear and non-linear noise, TDM, digital hierarchy for telephony, D/A conversion.

Baseband data signals: bit rate/bandwidth relationship, ISI and I diagram, error probability estimation, source, error and line coding, regeneration.

Digital CW modulation: forms, spectra and bandwidth in terms of bit rate, modems, applications

TELEPHONY SYSTEMS: Handset operation. Characteristics of the local loop. The telephone network: numbering systems, switching and routing. Digital transmission hierarchy. Framing and synchronization. Signalling methods. ISDN. Introduction to voice transmission over packet networks.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: USPJF7-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: The Psychology of Sport and Exercise

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFC-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistics & Experimental Design (Hartpury)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Types of data (counts and measurements), scales of measurement, concept of sampling, frequency distribution, normality and non-normality, presentation of data.

2. Descriptive statistics: central tendency (mean, median and mode), variation (standard deviation, variance), probability distribution, inferential statistics: standard error, confidence limits.

3. The basis of statistical testing, probability and statistical significance, parametric and non-parametric tests.

4. Statistical tests and association between categories and variables, measuring differences, analysis of variance.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPED8-30-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design Methods: The design process, and the systematic approach to design problems: requirement analysis, problem identification, problem solving methods, problem solving tools, preparation of specifications, solution identification and design. Principles of embodiment design.

Engineering Drawing: sketching. principles of projection: third angle and isometric views. Basic standard conventions using British Standards. Use of simple software design tools e.g. 2D CAD.

Practical Skills: follow through the design, build, test cycle within the practical environment of a the aerospace engineering workshop. Present the results, including an analysis of the standard and accuracy of the work produced.

Professional Skills: completion of workbook to demonstrate effective use of the library. Time management, working in groups, oral and written presentation skills, basic project management.

Software Skills: introduction to the range of engineering software tools. Writing of simple programmes, including the incorporation of data from other sources, especially Excel.

Legislation: an outline of the Environmental Protection Act (1990) and the Health and Safety at Work Act (1974) with emphasis on their impact on engineering companies

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEKH-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Services
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction. Expansion of information delivery and exchange within and between organizations. Convergence of library/reference services and web services. Infrastructure, impacts and consequences.

Digital libraries. Organizing and converting source material. Document representation. Presentation for searching and browsing. Markup and metadata. Building document collections. The Dublin Core Metadata Initiative.

Web services. Component technologies for web services: XML, SOAP, WSDL, UDDI. Planning, developing, deploying and managing web services. Customer-centric approach. Potential and impact of web services.

Information infrastructure. Emerging standards and protocols for national and global information infrastructures.

Developing information services in organizations. Establishing scope and customer requirements. Aspects of organizational knowledge management. From information audit to information policy and strategy. Organizing and delivering the information service.

Public information services. Information services in the public sector, eg: government information services and e-government; information services in healthcare.

E-services in the Information Society. Diffusion of information and communication technologies. User communities; access, inclusion and exclusion, virtual communities. Transforming infrastructures and services to meet social needs. Digital libraries in developing countries. Community networks. Social issues in the expansion of information services, eg multilingualism, access, cultural homogenization, negative implications of controlled vocabularies.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEAY-30-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Individual Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Project selection: connection with departmental research and industrial placement

Project proposal: produced by student with advice from supervisor

Project execution: monitored by supervisor

Project presentation: report, viva and poster

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEJU-40-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Motorsport Performance
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: ((UFMEBF-40-1 OR (UFMEQT-20-1 AND UFMEQU-20-1)) AND UFMEQU-20-1 AND UFMEQU-20-1)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Aerodynamic Lift - Ground effect; Tyre-road friction variation; Spoilers and negative lift devices.

Effect of Aerodynamic force on Performance - Aerodynamic force and maximum speed; Drag effect on fuel consumption and acceleration.

Fundamental analysis of forces affecting car stability - Position of the centre of aerodynamic pressure; Side force; Aerodynamic moments about centre of gravity.

Effect of Aerodynamic forces on steady stability - Equations of equilibrium; The static margin; Turning characteristics

Engine Cooling system Requirements; Design; Evaluation

Wind tunnels and Measurement techniques.

Introduction to computational fluid dynamics and its uses for internal and external aerodynamics, including basic combustion modelling.

Powertrain - C.I. engines; Forced induction; Powertrain systems gearboxes / clutches / transmission; matching to engine.

Further work to expand on level 2 intro in: Charge exchange; mechanical/fluids design to allow increased engine speeds; Combustion chemistry and pollutants; Fuelling and ignition strategy and engine management systems

Stress - Complex section properties and section idealisation; Thick cylinders and interference fits; Introduction to panel Buckling; Shear stresses due to bending; shear stress due to torsion; Intro to failure criteria; Intro to experimental mechanics; Intro to Composite; Intro to Linear elastic fracture mechanics; Shear panels and tension fields.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEN4-30-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Communication Networks and Operating Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Operating System Organisation

  • Models: monolithic, layered, process, object, virtual machines, client-server, network & distributed operating systems, middle ware, component technology
  • Process & Object Management
  • Kernel services - interrupt handlers, process-object descriptors, tables, state transitions.
  • Scheduling algorithms and load balancing, object invocation.
  • Interprocess Communication - event handling, message passing, synchronous-asynchronous, shared memory
  • I/O Management - The Posix system call interface and I/O descriptors, File organisation, directories and naming, index nodes, disk block management, network & distributed file systems

Computer network architecture\'s and models

  • Layered models
  • Service access points
  • Peer to peer protocols

Protocol Specification and Design

  • Specification techniques(state machines, Petri nets, SDL)
  • Connection oriented & connectionless protocols
  • Error & flow control protocols
  • Link-level protocols, transport protocols, application protocols

Medium Access Control Protocols

  • The mutual exclusion problem
  • Token solutions
  • Distributed queues

Subnetworks and Internetworks

  • Network layer design issues
  • Topology and connectivity analysis
  • Addressing & naming
  • Routing algorithms
  • Congestion control algorithms
  • Packet & circuit switching

Windows access permissions and export controls
Group Policies
Active directories
Operating Unix & Windows together on a diverse network

Transport Services

  • Protocol design issues
  • Transport level interface

Network & Distributed Systems Management

  • Monitoring and event handling
  • Policies and obligations
  • Fault, security, configuration, performance management services
  • SNMP & CMIP protocols

TCP/IP protocol suite

  • The IP layer
  • Address resolution
  • TCP and UDP
  • Routing
  • Higher level protocols
  • Socket programming

Secure data handling

  • Secure sockets & Shell
  • Protocol tunnelling
  • Host and Network intrusion detection & prevention
  • Defences against and types of malware
  • Authentication and Authorisation protocols
  • Certification management
  • Using Kerberos and PKI

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFP-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Numerical Methods
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFQEFS-20-1 OR UFQELG-20-1 OR (UFQETK-10-1 AND (UFQETJ-10-1 OR UFQETG-10-1)))
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Solving Non-Linear Equations. Finding roots of non-linear equations; Bisection method, Newton-Raphson and fixed point iteration.

Numerical Integration. Evaluation of definite integrals: Trapezium and Simpson's rule, Romberg integration. Improper integrals. Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations: Euler. Runge-Kutta methods, predictor-corrector methods.

Numerical Linear Algebra. Numerical solution of linear algebraic systems. Direct methods such as Gaussian elimination and LU factorisation. Iterative methods such as Jacobi and Gauss-Seidel iteration. Iterative methods for the evaluation of eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

Function Approximation and Interpolation: Taylor series, Lagrangian polynomials, least squares and approximations, cubic splines.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGT-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Operational Research
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Introduction to Operational Research and the modelling process.

2. Linear Programming: Introduction, Formulation. Use of computer software, Interpretation of solutions, Sensitivity of analysis.

3. Linear and Integer Programming Modelling: The range of applications and accompanying formulations in Finance, Operations, Supply Chain, Manufacturing, Retailing, Commerce, and other areas.

4. The Transportation, Assignment, Transhipment and other network models. Use of computer software.

5. Critical Path Analysis for Project Management and Resource Planning. Revision of manual solution. Linear Programming formulations with variants for crashing and resource smoothing. Use of computer software.

6. Inventory Models based on stationary demand: EOQ model, quantity discounts, production lot size model, planned shortage model, determining safety stock levels.

7. Inventory Models based on non-stationary demand: Single period inventory model, MRP, Inventory Models with time varying demand; current trends in inventory management.

8. Markov processes: Transition Matrices, Absorbing States, Steady States. Application to business.

9. Queuing Models: Elements of a model, measures of performance, single/multiple server models, priority rules.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEG5-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Financial Mathematics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Option Trading: The stock market, forward and futures contracts, European and American style options, interpreting information from the financial press, hedging, arbitrage, risk neutral valuation.

Dynamics of Option Pricing: Random walks, risk free interest rate, volatility, time to expiry, dividend payments, pay-off and profit diagrams, put-call parity.

Option Pricing Models: Underlying assumptions behind the Black-Scholes model, Ito's lemma, derivation of the Black-Scholes partial differential equation, Binomial model.

Numerical Methods: Binomial model, Monte-Carlo simulations, control variate method, determining implied volatility. Implementation of Models: Algorithms for implementing numerical solutions to the above models using both test and real financial data.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETJ-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Calculus Investigations
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Functions : Properties of basic continuous functions, parametric functions, vector functions Concepts of limits and continuity Calculus: Differentiation from first principles and the fundamental theorem of calculus Differentiation and integration techniques. Applications. Power Series: Radius of convergence of power series, Taylor's theorem and Taylor's series. Parametric and vector equations of curves.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE6U-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Electrical Interface
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction: monitoring and control systems: Electronic systems: sensor inputs, processing and output to actuators and indicators. Open loop & closed loop arrangements (introduction to basic concepts only).

Principles: Properties of resistors, capacitors & inductors. Power dissipation in electrical systems. Electrical charge and field. Magnetic field and coupling. Faraday's Law. Simple DC circuit analysis. Kirchhoff's Laws. Simple AC circuit analysis: Magnitude, RMS, phase and frequency. Signal conditioning techniques using simple RC, RL circuits.

Sensors: Electric strain gauge. Temperature: platinum resistance, thermistor and thermocouple. Movement (rotary): potentiometer, absolute and incremental shaft encoders.

Actuation and Energy Conversion: Electromechanical actuators: Plungers, solenoids. Motors: DC motor/generator, synchronous generator, brushless motors (particularly stepping motors).

Semiconductor Components: Diodes: standard/zener, LED and photodiode. Bipolar transistor as a switch. Introduction to power switching devices.

Analogue Processing Devices: Operational amplifiers (as ideal devices only), negative feedback; non-inverting gain, inverting gain circuits. Differential amplifier. Comparator (without hysteresis). D/A & A/D conversion process (not internal operation).

Digital Electronics: Representation of information by logic levels. Basic digital functions: AND, OR, NOT, XOR. Simple combinational logic. Latches, flip-flops. Logic families: TTL, CMOS. PLC vs. microprocessor.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEQV-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Mathematics 1 (CBC)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Algebra

Algebraic manipulation, to include factorisation, transposition, partial fractions, exponential and logarithmic functions. Arithmetic, geometric and power series.

Trigonometry

Trigonometric and sinusoidal functions. Solution of trigonometric equations by use of appropriate Trig. identities. Complex numbers: Argand diagrams, algebra of complex numbers, complex numbers in polar and exponential form, de Moivre's theorem.Matrix and vector algebra: properties of matrices and determinants, the inverse matrix, matrix algebra, solution of linear equations, Gaussian elimination.

Calculus

Differentiation of algebraic and trigonometric functions, to include the use of chain, product and quotient rules. Classification of turning points. Higher derivatives Integration of indefinite and definite integrals. Integration by substitution, partial fractions and parts. Solution of First Order differential equations. Applications of integral calculus to engineering theory.

Statistics

Representation of data. Measurement of central tendency and dispersion. Probability. Linear regression and correlation. Reliability estimation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE74-30-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Digital Systems Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Review of basic functional parts of one small and one medium scale microcontroller, including internal architecture, programming model, op-codes, addressing modes, memory mapping and address decoding.

Use of digital electronics CAD tools, and simple system simulations using a tool such as MATLAB.

Design and implementation of single-chip microcontroller-based embedded computer hardware.

Simple assembly language and high-level language software design and implementation

Comparison between a simple state-machine implemented in software or in digital PLD-based hardware.

Digital and analogue electrical interfacing of simple state machines with simple electrical actuators and sensors, including an introductory understanding of the sensor and actuator characteristics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7K-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Intelligent & Adaptive Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction: Review of the links with other disciplines, e.g. classical AI, psychology, robotics, ethology, neuroscience and classical control. Scope and limitations of this module, especially with respect to classical control and AI.

Learning and adaptive systems: Working definitions of intelligence, adaptive systems and learning. Adaptation through learning versus design.

Basic Architectures: Neural networks. Fuzzy systems. Evolutionary computation. Supervised, unsupervised and reinforcement learning.

Compound Architectures: Classifier Systems. Behaviour-based systems. Agent-based systems. Multi-agent systems.

Example applications: Review of work carried out in this Faculty, and at other establishments, in order to demonstrate the major strengths and weaknesses of the techniques. For example; intelligent multiple agents for fault diagnosis in electrical power distribution systems, fuzzy control of an automated underground transportation system, co-operative behaviour in multi-agent mobile robotics, neurocontrol of an industrial robot manipulator, fuzzy classifier systems for telecommunications network routing, evolutionary computation as an aid to engineering design, human face and handwriting recognition using neural networks.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7R-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Signals and Circuits
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Signal Analysis

Signals: Definition; deterministic (periodic and aperiodic) random; signal sources; information; entropy; mathematical representation of basic deterministic signals.

Phasors: Graphical addition of sinusoids; definition of a phasor; phasor impedance and transfer functions of R,L,C networks.

Power: dc and rms values; power factor; real, reactive and apparent power in R,L,C networks.

Laplace transforms: Definition; transforms of common signals; use of tables; solution of ordinary differential equations; partial fractions; generalised impedance and transfer functions of R, L, C networks; pole/zero diagrams; network time response; forced and natural modes; time constant; stability; second order response; use of standard second order response chart.

Frequency response: Frequency response from Laplace transfer function; bandwidth in relation to time constant; definition of dB; Bode plots with straight line approximation; Nyquist plots, resonance.

Fourier series: Trigonometric and phasor form; power spectrum.
