Fourier transform: Derivation from Fourier series; Fourier transform of common signals; inverse spreading principle; relation to Laplace transforms; Parseval's theorem; energy spectral density.

Convolution: The convolution integral; graphical convolution; discrete convolution.

Discrete signals: Sampling; aliasing; Shannon's sampling theorem; z-transforms; z-transfer functions; difference equations and their software implementation; causality; stability; gain and phase shift; frequency response; transfer function of zero order hold DAC; first order hold DAC; impulse and step invariant simulation of continuous systems; selection of sampling period; definition of 'real time'; block diagrams.

Random signals: Definition of a random variable; PDF and CDF; Gaussian PDF; independent and conditional probability; signal mean, rms and variance; mean of a function of a random variable.

Systems Electronics

Operational amplifiers: Non-ideal operational amplifiers; current sources; current mirrors; offset; bias; drift; noise; gain-bandwidth; rise time.

Network analysis: RLC network analysis using Laplace transforms; step and sinusoidal response.

Filters: Filter classification LP, HP, BP; 2nd and higher order; transfer functions; Butterwoth and Chebychev approximations; normalised prototypes; scaling; passive and active realisations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7T-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Electrical Technology
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Electromagnetic fields and devices

Faraday\'s Law, flux, mmf, energy stored in magnetic field. The magnetic circuit. BH characteristics including hysteresis. Harmonic distortion.

Circuit Analysis

Revision of d.c, a.c. and transient circuit analysis. Three phase circuit analysis - star and delta configurations. Real and reactive power. Power requirement in single phase and three phase systems.

Transformers

Operation of single phase transformers. Equivalent circuit. Referred values. Saturation.

Power Generation

Characteristics and equivalent circuit of synchronous generator. Introduction to operation of synchronous machines in power systems. Operation of synchronous machine connected to infinite busbars.

Industrial Loads

Power and energy utilisation, efficiency, power factor. Switching - relays, solid state relays, contactors.Introduction to transmission systems. Static VAR compensation.

Electric motors - d.c. machines as motors and generators - induction machines as motors and generators. - introduction to control of electrical machines with power electronic drives.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHE-30-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Programming in C
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Basic syntax to support a structured approach to program development using procedural abstractions - program and control structures - basic data types - reuse of basic functions for I/O, string and mathematical manipulation.

Structured types - arrays, vectors and classes as records. Algorithm design. Simple file processing.

The use of functions and parameters. Global and local variables.

Bit-wise and logical operators

Using pointers for accessing data and evoking functions.

Problem analysis and design using a structured, step-wise refinement approach.

Structure charts as effective documentary aids for HLL programs.

Simple input/output to a parallel port, involving timing for multiple simultaneous activities

Introduction to the use of FSDs for event-driven applications, and the implementation of FSMs as FSTs.

Using ADCs and DACs as input and output devices, understanding relevant parameters: bandwidth, conversion rate, precision, slew rate, stability.

Elementary introduction to the problems of multi-tasking.

Speed control for a small DC motor. Driving a stepper motor from a processor.

Synthesising simple square, triangle and sine waves

Use of make files and project configuration specs.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGL-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Econometric Analysis
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UQQ101S2 OR UFQEGP-20-2 OR UFQEGR-20-2 OR UFQEGB-20-2)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Model Selection and \'Data Mining\':

Criteria for the selection of regressors; , , and its derivatives. Specification bias and multicollinearity. Choice of functional form and rationale. \'Data mining\' and its implications.

Derivation and Poperties of Estimators:

Desirable properties of estimators. Derivation and properties of the OLS estimators using a covariance approach. The Gauss-Markov theorem.

Violation of Model Assumptions:

Specification bias revisited. Serial correlation and its causes and consequences. The Durbin-Watson test and its applicability. First Differences and the Cochrane-Orcutt method as possible means of dealing with serial correlation.

The nature, causes and consequences of heteroscedasticity. Ways of detecting heteroscedasticity. The Goldfeld-Quandt test and alternatives. Correcting for this phenomenon using Weighted Least Squares.

The \'F\' Distribution and Econometric Analysis:

The \'F\' distribution and its role in testing the validity of OLS assumptions. Chow\'s test for stability of parameter values. The use of dummy variables as a variant of the Chow test.

Modelling and Estimation of Simultaneous Equation Systems:

The identification problem; rank and order conditions. The role of \'exogenous\' variables. Single equation methods of estimation; merits and demerits of using OLS, IV, 2SLS. Recursive systems and their estimation.

Time Series and Forecasting Methods:

Distributed lag models. Forecasting and prediction. Time-series methods and econometric forecasting. Stationarity and cointegration. Error correction models. AR, MA and ARIMA models. Evaluation of forecasts.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHT-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Embedded Real-Time Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction: Brief review of basic computer architecture, including interrupt generation and handling. Review of approaches to embedded systems design, including microcontrollers, rack based systems, PC-based solutions. The borderlines of viability between standalone interrupt-driven systems and operating system supported solutions. For larger problems, the trade-off between general purpose languages plus a real-time operating system and real-time languages.

System supported real-time systems: Concurrent programming models. The virtual \"communicating sequential processes\" machine. Multi-process management. Message-based vs. shared memory-based models for interprocess communication. Reliability, fault tolerance, operating in safety-critical environments, and support for error recovery. Low-level programming. A detailed study of one multitasking real-time operating system (e.g. MINOS, OS-9).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHX-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer Networks & O/S
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Computer network architectures and models: layered models; service access points; peer to peer protocols. Protocol Specification and Design: specification technique state machines. connection oriented & connectionless protocols; error & flow control protocols; transport protocols, application protocols. Medium Access Control Protocols: the mutual exclusion problem; token solutions; Subnetworks and Internetworks: network layer design issues; addressing & naming; routing algorithms; congestion control algorithms; packet & circuit switching. Transport Services: protocol design issues; transport level interface. Network Systems Management: monitoring and event handling; policies and obligations; fault, security, configuration. Operating System Organisation: Models - monolithic, layered, process, object, virtual machines; client server; Process & Object Management: kernel services; interrupt handlers, process object descriptors, tables, state transitions; scheduling algorithms. Interprocess Communication: event handling, message passing; synchronous synchronous; shared memory. Concurrency and Synchronisation: safety & liveness properties; semaphores; critical regions; monitors; message passing; multi threaded processes. Memory Management: Real Memory Management; Organisation algorithms and policies; Virtual Memory Management; Organisation of paged and segmented systems; algorithms & strategies for page placement and replacement; Memory Management Units; garbage collection. I/O Management: The Posix system call interface and I/O descriptors; Buffering and interrupt handling. File & Persistent Object Management: File organisation; directories and naming; index nodes; disk block management. System Administration: Specify and install an OS and network; initialise the system for user and applications; install devices, software packages and communication links; make the system secure; investigate various security strategies; instigate system maintenance backup; user control; document system and system modifications.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPENV-60-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Short Research Placement
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Not applicable, dependent on workplace.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEK8-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Robotics Group Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: As this is a Project Module, there is no detailed syllabus for this course. Instead, students construct their own syllabus as they carry out their project.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEN3-30-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Administering Real Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to the role of the System Administrator

  • A tour of the file system Commands to understand the file system

Overview of the LINUX system

  • Understanding and selecting the correct hardware
  • Overview of the various UNIXes and LINUXes
  • Installing the system

Taking the system up and down

  • What happens on boot up and power down
  • Creating environments with .profile, .login and .logout
  • Commands for managing disk space
  • File system repair with fsck
  • RPM and you

Users and homes on UNIX

  • Creating and deleting new users
  • /etc/passwd and /etc/group files
  • Informing user /etc/motd
  • File modes - chmod, chown and chgrp
  • Simple shell scripts to create and delete users

Device under UNIX - /dev in detail

  • Dealing with peripherals - different types
  • Spoolers and spool queues
  • The lp and lpstat commands
  • Creating and starting a system spooler

System security

  • The password system. Controlling users
  • Common security hazards more on modes
  • The super user/root
  • Authentication systems

Backing up and restoring the system

  • CPIO command
  • Full system recovery

Dealing with terminal under LINUX

  • tty, stty terminal handling commands
  • Ethenet, PC-NFS
  • Novell netware

Upgrading LINUX

  • Finding the latest kernels
  • Installing and upgrading
  • Dealing with problems
  • Installing large packages GNU

Connecting to a diverse network

  • TCP/IP on LINUX
  • Installing the correct module
  • Configuring your devices
  • Diagostic checking
  • Simple network commands and files
  • Setting up a SMB service for Windows hosts

DHCP server for mobile users

System Housekeeping and Management

  • Doing periodic tasks - crontab
  • Monitoring error messages
  • System recovery and repair
  • Using fsck, ncheck, icheck and clri
  • Using multiple file systems

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEN5-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Computing Project & Dissertation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: There can be no fixed form for such a project because of the link to the work-place or a commissioning organization. However, it will generally follow the software lifecycle to a greater or lesser extent: research phase, design work, system implementation, testing activities, demonstration and final hand-over. Because this activity underpins a Masters\' dissertation, emphasis is placed on critical analysis and the novel synthesis of ideas. The subject of the dissertation will be contracted between the student and his/her supervisor at the start of the session and the student will be expected to treat material critically and to demonstrate the relevant level of understanding, in addition to achieving a successful implementation where ever possible.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEN8-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Security in Networks
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Security as a process. Access control systems. Cryptography and its role in secure distributed systems. Forensic analysis of computer systems. Hackers, their approaches and techniques; monitoring access. Hardware protection mechanisms. Security in embedded devices. The UK legal context. Organisational and social issue with particular reference to social engineering and security policies. The Economics of security. Disaster & Compromise recovery.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEPE-30-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Contemporary Research in Advanced Robotics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Novel sensors in robots

2. Novel actuators in robots

3. Machine vision and image analysis in robots

4. Energy sources and power transmission in mobile robots

5. New materials in robotics

6. Locomotion in mobile robots

7. VLSI, FPGAs, and other control hardware in mobile robots

8. Architectures and operating systems in mobile robots

9. Machine learning in mobile robots

10. Neural networks in mobile robots

11. Evolutionary algorithms in mobile robotics

12. Robot navigation

13. Collective robotics and swarm intelligence

14. Robots in industry

15. Robots in medicine

16. Robots in space and other extreme environments

17. Military applications for mobile robots

18. Household and entertainment robots

19. Humanoid robots

20. Philosophical and theoretical aspects of robotics

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEPJ-30-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Music Technology Group Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Initially the students will learn about the nature of research, design and development for products in small commercial organisations. They will also learn about techniques suitable for the subsequent phase of the module.

2. The major part of the module will be concerned with working as a team to develop an existing product as a virtual commercial organisation. This involves a combination of creativity, response to commercial pressures, and practical considerations imposed by the structure of the organisation. The group is presented with tasks to be completed and restrictions imposed by management and previous product history. These tasks include:

  • planning and adding features
  • verifying, tracking and fixing problems
  • negotiating with customers and the executive
  • dealing with a competitor's new product, and changing priorities
  • writing user and technical documentation
  • marketing
  • dealing with deadlines, meetings, progress reports
  • keeping the executive informed
  • quality assurance and maintaining formal processes

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEE8-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Lean Engineering and Decision Support Tools for Continuous Improvement
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The syllabus may include but not be limited to the followings: Lean Manufacturing and Lean Engineering; Characteristics of Lean Engineering enterprise; Identification of Lean Engineering opportunities; Risk and uncertainty; Introductory probability theory; Multi-objective decision making; Decision trees and decision tables; Analytic hierarchy process; Data Envelop Analysis; Expected Utility Theory; Expected Monetary Value Theory; Sensitivity analysis; Simulation and Modelling.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETE-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Understanding Statistics in Public Health Research
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Study Design: Types of study. Experiments and surveys. Randomised trials. Prospective and retrospective studies. Paired and unpaired designs, repeated measures.

Review of Statistical Concepts: Hypothesis testing, type I and II errors, the p-value, standard errors and confidence intervals. Common statistical tests: t-tests, chi-squared test and McNemar's test. Underlying assumptions. Non parametric tests. Power of a test and determination of sample size. One-way ANOVA, Multiple Comparisons, Correlation.

Survival Analysis: Life tables, survival curves, the log-rank test, Cox regression.

Regression Analysis: Simple linear and multiple regression. Binary, ordinal and nominal logistic regression.

Statistical Software: Use of at least one statistical computer package (such as Minitab or SPSS) and interpretation of output from these.

Illustrations of techniques will, as far as possible, use examples based on their use in public health and related disciplines and include examples of good and bad practice from appropriate journals.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEERU-30-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Audio Processing: Systems and Practice
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is designed to provide the foundation for developing and using processing systems at M level in Music Technology. It enables students to develop an understanding of analysis, modification, synthesis and control of sound. There are five principal areas which will be considered:

  • The theory and practice of analysing, creating, modifying and controlling sonic data
  • The development and use of systems to meet human and artistic requirements
  • The relationship between creative tools and musical/artistic expression, and optimising human-technology interaction
  • Researching and developing new systems which provide capabilities beyond standard tools
  • Software development

The five areas above will be developed within the following topics:

  • Real-time and non-real-time systems
  • Acoustical and numerical representations of audio data
  • Time and frequency domain analysis
  • Basic amplitude-based modifications
  • Standard modification processes: distortion, filtering, acoustic environment effects, adaptive processes
  • Development of hybrid and novel modification systems for particular creative contexts
  • Basic synthesis forms
  • Oscillators and wavetables
  • Sampling
  • Standard synthesis forms: additive, subtractive, AM, FM, physical modelling, vocal synthesis, waveshaping, granular synthesis
  • Conventional and experimental control techniques

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEERW-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Music Technology Project and Dissertation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is designed to allow the student to develop deeper understanding in a particular area of music technology, but also to gain experience of the processes and techniques appropriate to postgraduate research and project work in general. The project might be proposed by an external commissioning organisation, or be a development of an existing Faculty research project, or be a personal project. The subject and aims of the project will be agreed with the project supervisor. Projects will generally involve:

  • research
  • design
  • experimentation and implementation
  • testing
  • documentation
  • demonstration

Importantly, a music technology dissertation project involves consideration of both the artistic and technological elements of the subject. Emphasis is placed on critical analysis and the novel synthesis of ideas. The student will be expected to treat material critically and to demonstrate the relevant level of understanding, in addition to achieving a successful implementation wherever possible. It is assumed that the project will develop ideas considered in the modules which precede it, which means that it is most likely that the focus will be on software and digital systems. Other proposed areas of focus will be allowed if they are compatible with the module and programme learning outcomes.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEES9-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introductory Programming for Audio
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is designed to enable students to develop their skills in programming with a high level language, with the application of audio and music systems as the basis for the practical examples, tests and assignments. There are five principal areas which will be covered:

  • The techniques by which programming problems are tackled, and how to design suitable solutions.
  • The use of a particular programming language to implement those solutions.
  • The development tools used in producing a working solution.
  • The application of programming to audio and music systems.
  • The relationships between the core processing function, the libraries which it uses, the operating system that supports it, and the underlying hardware.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEESA-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Robotics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Basic principles of computer vision
  • Segmentation, imaging and recognition
  • Mapping using a variety of simple techniques such as occupancy grids
  • Use of sensors and data fusion for localization
  • Path planning and motor control
  • Use of visual cues (landmarks) in localization
  • Learning and evolution for the automatic generation of robot controllers
  • Architectures; reactive (subsumption and braitenburg), deliberative and hybrid

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIERJ-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Health Care Informatics Strategy and the Management of Change
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
All organisations experience change. Changes in the environment influence an organisations control over its activities and the nature of its relationship with other organisations. To remain successful, an organisation in such a changing environment therefore has constantly to review its own modus operandi to ensure it can be responsive and flexible as required. Consequently, over a period of time an organisation will evolve the way it manages its people, finances, operations and information to remain in control.

The relationship between IM&T and the business is symbiotic. On the one hand, IM&T needs to be reactive to deliver the information needs of the business which are constantly evolving and changing. On the other hand, advances in technology mean that IM&T can be proactive and innovative, initiating change and enhancing clinical and organisational effectiveness.

To ensure that an organisation maximises the potential of IM&T, it needs constantly to review its IM&T strategy to ensure that the appropriate information, systems and technology are available to meet its objectives. To facilitate the implementation of the IM&T strategy and other aspects of organisational change, a number of methodologies and standards may be employed related to project management, procurement and investment appraisal.

IM&T professionals need to be aware of their role within the organisation in terms of being part of the change management process and, through the IM&T strategy, actively contribute to managing change within the organisation.

- IM&T Strategy

  • From policy to strategy; the case of the NHS.
  • Elements of IM&T strategy; methodologies for strategy development.
  • IM&T strategy and business objectives.

- Business Plans and IM&T Strategy

  • Identification of key objectives; the business planning cycle and business plan development.
  • From business plan to IM&T strategy; defining links from objectives to elements of IM&T strategy.

- Information Strategy

  • From business requirements to associated information requirements.
  • Description and evaluation of existing information systems; the information users need and the information systems provide.
  • Development of alternative proposals; evaluation, justification and recommendation of preferred options.
  • Techniques for the analysis of internal factors: SWOT; resources and priorities; monitoring and review.
  • Techniques for the analysis of external factors: PEST; other organizations and initiatives, both local and national.

- Project Plan and Project Management

  • Implementation of a selected option: the project plan; key issues and constraints.
  • Organizational factors: IM&T projects as team projects; management of change; organizational development.
  • Project management: products; organization; activities, timescales and resources; control.
  • Analysis of resource implications, including human, finance, accommodation and technological.

- Management of Change

  • Why change occurs, internal and external forces for change.
  • Differentiation between and arguments for and against hard and soft methods of change management.
  • Systems intervention and organizational development through change; hybrid approaches.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEETS-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Programming in C
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Basic syntax to support a structured approach to program development using procedural abstractions - program and control structures - basic data types - reuse of basic functions for I/O, string and mathematical manipulation.

Structured types - arrays, vectors and classes as records. Algorithm design. Simple file processing.

The use of functions and parameters. Global and local variables.

Bit-wise and logical operators

Using pointers for accessing data and invoking functions.

Simple input/output to a parallel port, involving timing for multiple simultaneous activities

Using ADCs and DACs as input and output devices, understanding relevant parameters: bandwidth, conversion rate, precision, slew rate, stability.

Elementary introduction to the problems of multi-tasking

Speed control for a small DC motor. Driving a stepper motor from a processor.

Synthesizing simple square, triangle and sine waves

Use of make files and project configuration specs

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGQ-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Decision Analysis
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction. The underlying rationale of decision analysis: axioms, rationality, requisite models.

Decision Problems involving Multiple Objectives under conditions of certainty. The Simple Multi-Attribute Rating Technique: value trees, direct rating and value functions, swing and importance weights, mutually preference independence, efficient frontiers, sensitivity analysis, the axioms of SMART, rank-order centroid weights, SMARTER. The Analytic Hierarchy Process.

Decision Problems under Conditions of Uncertainty. Single attribute utility functions, first and second order stochastic dominance, multi-attribute utility independence, axioms of utility, utility elicitation. Risk analysis using simulation. Use of the @RISK package. Simulating independent and dependent events.

Structuring decision problems. Decision trees. The Extended Pearson-Tukey approximation, Influence diagrams, Assessment of decision structure. Assessing Probabilities. Heuristics and biases: the availability and representativeness heuristics, anchoring and adjustment. Criticisms of the psychological research, Gigerenzer\'s frequentist view. Elicitation methods: Assessment probabilities for rare events: fault and event trees. Measurement of judgmental skill: calibration, Brier scores.

Revision of Opinion. Bayes theorem, the expected value of perfect and imperfect information.

Group Decision Making. Mathematical, behavioural and mixed aggregation methods. Groupthink, the Delphi Method, decision conferencing, negotiation problems, the Commons dilemma. Modelling resource allocation problems. Introduction to game theory.

Descriptive Decision Models. Lexicographic and semi-lexicographic ordering, elimination by aspects, satisficing prospect theory. Janis and Mann\'s conflict theory, Payne et al\'s cost-benefit theory, prospect theory. Frame blindness.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEU3-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: VHDL for Synthesis
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
VHDL modelling concepts, overview

The Behavioural, Register Transfer Language and Structural models

VHDL State machines and State machine synthesis

VHDL Subsets for synthesis

State machine design using ASM notation and Sequence Enumeration

Test patterns, Simulation, Verification and Testing

Datapath-Controller models, hardwired and micro-sequencer implementations

Fundamentals of microprocessor design

  • basic components and functionality
  • adders/subtracters/multipliers
  • I/O and interrupt hardware

Introduction to 'System on Chip' design

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEU5-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Designing and Writing Device Drivers
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Operating Systems and device drivers

OS modelsHALsTypes of OS monolithic, microkernel, distributedDevice drivers and file systemsDevices and buses

Device driver internals

Device driver modelsInterfacing to the OSInterrupt and polled devicesDMAAccessing and managing kernel memory

Device driver development

Finding information on devicesCreating a device driver from data sheetsPartitioning the driverTesting, debugging and documentingOptimisation and performance

Device driver examples

Device drivers and system initialisationI2C device driverCodec device driversGraphics drivers

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEU7-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Building, Porting and Configuring Embedded Operating Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Embedded and real-time systems

The role and function of embedded OS

Variety of Embedded OSs

The embedded systems market

Cross development tool chains

Linker and linking

Object control and conversion tools

Cross debuggers

Configuration options and systems

System boot code

File system creation

Networking embedded OSs

Technologies in embedded OS

Boot loaders

Serial communications

MMU and memory protection

Flash memory

JTAG

Timing considerations

Using patches

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPED4-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Dissertation (Masters)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This is a generic module that is used for a variety of programmes, the programme director (or delegated person) will advise students on appropriate projects to ensure that they relate to the relevant programme.

The nature of the research will vary according to the subject which is being addressed. Dissertation topics should focus on some aspect(s) of technology as it is or may be applied in particular contexts, both academic and industrial. Students are encouraged to carry out research that extends their interests in the role of technology in the context of their MSc award route. The core module in Research Methods requires students to develop an initial research proposal and students are expected to evaluate this proposal and determine how to take it forward in their dissertation. This may involve writing a fresh proposal in agreement with their supervisor.

Students are expected to carry out an in-depth survey of relevant literature and to undertake some primary research to ensure that their investigation contributes to existing research in the field. The primary research may involve a wide range of activities such as: carrying out a quantitative survey, an evaluative case study or action research study, or developing an experimental piece of software or hardware. The written dissertation should make clear how the primary research was designed and conducted and discussion of the outcomes of primary research should be clearly related to existing literature. The body of the dissertation should be supplemented by a critical review of all aspects of the research process, including the design and production of the report itself.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEEV-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Research Methods
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Scientific and ethnographic models for research

The Research Process; theory and practical implications

Selection and Identification of the Research Topic, Definition of Research Objectives, Formulation of Research Questions and Hypotheses

Review of Relevant Literature and Existing Research: Literature Searches; Effective Use of the Internet and library materials, and organisation of material.

Risk assessment and management, Planning and Budgeting

Deciding the Research Strategy and Design

The Research Proposal and Plan

Ethical considerations for researchers

Issues of reliability, validity and generalisability for researchers

Features of Qualitative and Quantitative Data

Collection of Primary Data: Experimental Design, Survey Methods, Sampling Design and Procedure.

Analysis of quantitative data ; an overview of statistical procedures.

Use of secondary data in the research process

Collection and Analysis of Qualitative Data; Interviewing and Observation Methods.

Communicating your Results Effectively: Dissertation Structure and Presentation

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEUL-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to Robotics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: What is a robot? History. Components of mobile robots (sensors, actuators, effectors, control architectures, power source). Locomotion, introduction to control. Applications of robots (manufacturing, medicine, space, entertainment). Introduction to advanced topics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEV5-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Health & Safety in an Industrial Context
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Permit to work, types; HSE Guidance; hot and cold entry; identification systems; Isolation types e.g. lock, multi lock, removal, blank off.

Monitoring equipment: noise, dust ,temperature, movement, radiation.Protective clothing and equipment: e.g. chemical, temperature, electrical isolation, noise protection etc.

Current health & safety legislation: The current regulations for the EU/UK (e.g. COSHH, noise at work, manual handling, PPE, pressure systems, HASW, management of H&S at work i.e. wiring regulations and EMC directive.) on typical engineering operations.

Role and authority of the HSE Inspectorate.

Safety audits: Policies, record keeping, safety surveys, training, proformas, management commitment and planning.

Codes of practice: Use of applying technology for codes and regulations. Awareness of relevant codes of practice.

Risk assessment and management: To conduct risk assessment identifying hazards, risk ratings, frequency, severity and records.

Evidence: to support the likelihood of or reoccurrence of a risk; statistical data (eg fatigue charts, working hours, temperature, lighting levels, noise, incorrect procedures, working practices, time of day, etc)

Implications: eg threat to life, injuries, property, environment, need to redesign, effect on company, effect on other companies; mandatory factory closure

Information: eg data sheets on substances, factory rules, codes of practice; safe working procedures, hazard identification (eg hard hat area); training in procedures for new staff and contractors

Minimising risk: eg control of known risks, guarding, covering, screening, encasing, designout; disaster contingence planning, etc

Implementation: eg management policy, lines of communication, responsibility, safety committees and trade union input

Compliance: knowledge of regulations and guidelines; mandatory compliance with current and relevant regulations (eg HASAWA and HSE; Deposit of Poisonous waste Act, EMC directive, etc); working towards company risk assessment findings

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDK-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Solid CAD Modelling
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: This module provides an introduction to solid modeling, and further aspects of Computer Aided Design (CAD) as they relate to the practice of product design. The module explores issues around the construction of solid models and the relevant computer software used by product designers in the expression of their ideas. This may include creating, editing and analyzing solid models, the production of rapid prototypes using a variety of techniques; wax modeling, FDM, SLA and the collection and manipulation of point cloud data as part of the reverse engineering process.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE7W-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to the Web
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The content of the module will necessarily change as the nature and technology of the World Wide Web develops. An indicative syllabus outline is based around the following structure:

The Internet: An introduction to the software and hardware technologies that underpin the Internet as a global network.

The World Wide Web: The client-server paradigm in relation to Web browsers and server side systems. The development, use, and limitations of HTML and related MLs (Mark-up Languages). The Interactive Web and methods of producing interactivity: e.g. client-side scripting, CGI.

World Wide Web Information and Communications Systems: Survey of types of applications of the World Wide Web. Architecture and design of web-sites. Evaluation of selected widely-visited websites and applications; including the development of criteria appropriate for making the evaluation.

Designing and creating Web based Information and Communications Systems Web-page authoring using HTML code, and software applications, e.g. Dreamweaver and FrontPage Express. Introduction to interactivity in websites. Requirements for creating effective web sites: design and navigability, maintenance, and security.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE7X-10-0
rdf:Description.p:title: IS Fundamentals
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introductory concepts: Data, information and information systems. Formal and informal information systems. Human activity systems.

Understanding IS in organisations: History of IS applications and associated ICT developments. Creating, storing and using information. Introduction to modelling in IS.

IS development in organisations: Main activities and methods. The changing role of IS and IT professionals.

IS practice: User negotiation and communications. Teamworking in IS. Learning in practice.

IS in society: potential impacts and opportunities for individuals and groups in society.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE84-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Web Design Principles
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction. The web environment. Clients and servers. Browsers. Displays. Web design principles. Usability, accessibility, simplicity. Human-web interaction.

Content design. Writing for the Web. Titles and headlines. Structure, layout, representation. Colour, graphics, typography. Legibility. Reading and attention. Designing for interactivity. Editing. Enriched content: multimedia and hypermedia. Making content accessible. Updating and maintaining content.

Tools. HTML basics: document structure, tags, conventions, standards, style, colour. Links. Including images. Tables, templates, frames, forms, CGI scripts. Server-side includes. WYSIWYG HTML editors/ authoring tools. Code editors. 'Save as HTML' function. Graphics design: the Web palette; GIF, JPEG, PNG. Introduction to CSS, DHTML, XML.

Page design. Screen 'real estate'. Designing information displays and interaction. Linking. Style sheets. Using frames. Cross-platform design. The Home Page. Incorporating multimedia elements. Creating and maintaining pages with an authoring tool.

Site design. Site purpose, planning, and structure. Assembling and linking pages. Response time. Presentation and navigation metaphors. Navigation. Home and interior pages. Search capabilities. User navigation control and content contribution. URL design. Internet vs Intranet design. Site maintenance.

Web design principles and guidelines. Site design guidelines. Observing and critiquing existing sites. Design sketches and prototypes. Designing for visual appeal. Inclusive design: access for users with a broad spectrum of abilities. Internationalization. Simplicity in web design. Evolution of web design. Emerging technologies, tools and standards. Increasing bandwidth and new information appliances. Separation of presentation and navigation. Rethinking the interface.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE86-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: E-Business Special Interest Groups
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This half-module gives students the opportunity to investigate and report on a particular topic within the general area of e-commerce/e-business, by working in Special Interest Groups (SIGs). 'Business' is understood broadly, to include not-for-profit enterprises.

Students are invited to suggest SIG topics at the beginning of the module, and, through a process of on-line negotiation, the module leader agrees and publishes a list of topics and allocates students to the appropriate SIGs according to their choices. Topics can come from a broad area, but must be approachable from an e-commerce angle. They might be in such areas as: e-retailing, e-advertising, e-Government, online gaming, Internet security, XML, P2P, digital divide, education, supply chain management, auctions, mobile commerce,

The taught component of the module focuses on emerging areas of interest and development in e-commerce technologies, application, and uptake and innovation in organizations. Some treatment of online learning and SIG working methods is included.

Students explore their chosen topic area together, but choose and agree, within the group, specific individual assignment titles within the topic area, and then submit separate individual pieces of work for assessment. The exploration of the topic and subject areas should focus on how organizations might discover and apply e-commerce models and technologies for particular business purposes.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE87-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Strategy and Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The module is organised in two main parts. The first part explores the concepts of data, information and knowledge in organisations and their relationship with the development and use of information systems. The strategic role of information systems in organisations is examined and the module uses a range of models and frameworks to help develop understanding of how a range of computing and telecommunication technologies are being developed for strategic advantage and strategic restructuring. The module looks at global policies and practice for managing information systems including supply chain logistic and management and electronic commerce. The module also looks at the issues facing information systems development, use and management in small enterprises.

The second parts looks at good practice in information systems planning. The various management processes by which organisations can attempt to align their information systems with their business are examined. This specifically examines and distinguishes the processes of Information Technology, Information Management and Information Systems strategy formulation as set out by Earl (1989). The human resource dimension is specifically examined including issues such as the role of the IT function, the role of the IT professional, IT leadership, business process redesign, training and management development, end-user computing, outsourcing, and organisational learning.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFT-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematical Methods
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Mathematical Modelling

Basic ideas of modelling and of the modelling cycle. Note that mathematical modelling ideas will permeate the entire schedule, and case studies will be discussed wherever appropriate.

Differential Calculus of Functions of Several Variables

Partial differentiation; Taylor series; total derivative; chain rule; error and small increment analysis; critical point analysis; local and global extrema; unconstrained optimization; constrained optimization (solving the constraints, the method of Lagrange multipliers); application of partial differentiation to the evaluation of integrals.

Linear Systems of Ordinary Differential Equations

Solutions regarded as integral curves of a vector field; explicit formula for solutions using eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

Fourier Series

Review of symmetries and of extensions of functions (odd, even, periodic); definition and evaluation of Fourier series; Dirichlet's Theorem; L2 convergence; Parseval's Theorem; relationship with inner-product space ideas; use of a software package, e.g., Maple, to explore and to plot Fourier series.

Partial Differential Equations

Origins of partial differential equations; types of partial differential equation; boundary value problems and initial value problems; a detailed study of Laplace's equation or of the heat equation; statement of existence and uniqueness theorems; statement of the Maximum Principle for harmonic functions; solution of, for example, the two-dimensional Dirichlet boundary value problem using separation of variables and Fourier series; use of different coordinate systems; use of a software package, e.g., Maple, to explore and to plot solutions of Laplace's equation or of the heat equation.

Integral Calculus of Functions of Several Variables

Definition and origins of multiple integrals; evaluation of multiple integrals using iterated single integrals; Fubini's Theorem; change of variables and the Jacobian; application of multiple integrals to computing mechanical and statistical moments, etc..

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEFX-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematical Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Material from previous or concurrent studies as necessary, as applied to the subject of the project.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8C-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Project Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. General. Manipulation of mathematical formulae on a calculator including exponential and logarithmic functions; use of the same formulae in spreadsheets. Understanding how linear regression theory is used to produce parametric models by measuring performance on past projects.
  2. Project Development. System life cycle models including traditional, evolutionary, prototyping and DSDM.
  3. Project Team. The rle of the project manager; typical group and team structures; qualities and skills of managers; team dynamics; leadership and management qualities.
  4. Project Planning. Planning criteria, work breakdown structures (WBS), milestones, deliverables, activity planning, team size.
  5. Estimating. Contents of an estimate; effort, time, manpower and appropriate units. Using data from past projects in parametric cost modelling (e.g. COCOMO, Putnam and Mk II Function Point Analysis).
  6. Organising and Controlling Projects. Tools and techniques including; activity lists, bar charts, arrow and precedence diagrams. Aids to visibility and management such as cascade activity numbering and cascade bar charts. Software tools including spreadsheets (particularly Excel), drawing packages (e.g. Visio) and project management software (e.g. MS Project). A checkable project management program for research and student use is under development.
  7. Resources and Time. Using activity lists and bar charts for allocating resources efficiently. Levelling resources by taking up float on non-critical paths. Dealing with single and multiple critical paths. Resource productivity. Calculating float from start and finish times and the critical path.
  8. Project finance. Treating finance as a resource to calculate cumulative cost; using earned value and cost-to-complete as measures of cash flow.
  9. Risk. Introduce risk assessment techniques; control and contingent risks; triggers and modifications to the precedence diagram; analysis by risk zones and action plans.
  10. Quality Control. Measuring quality, planning for quality, quality assurance reviews, design walkthroughs and inspections. Contents of a quality plan and factors that affect quality.
  11. Project Administration. Project documentation, reviews and configuration management with change control.
  12. Report Writing. The rle and contents of appendices in a project plan and project review, and the links between them. The main report and executive summary.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8D-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: ICT in Learning
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The role of ICT in Lifelong Learning: definitions of lifelong learning, new trends in learning, ICT and social inclusion, learning and identity and the impact of ICT

ICT and the individual learning experience: styles of learning and modes of delivery; computer-based learning, computer-assisted learning, distance learning, web-based learning, virtual learning environments; issues of computer-mediated communication; social and cultural considerations; the role of ICT in assessment

Evaluation and Design issues: determining criteria for evaluation of on-line material; approaches to evaluation; purposes and methods of evaluation; human-computer interaction issues, approaches to design, for example rapid prototyping

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEL7-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistics for Research A
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Units:

1. Statistical Inference (Parametric Tests)

Syllabus (a) The logic and theory underpinning statistical hypothesis tests.

(b) The practical application and logic underpinning tests of significance for mean differences including the one-sample t-test, paired t-test, two-sample t-tests, one-way ANOVA, one-way ANOVA with blocking, two-way factorial designs and using the result of the Central Limit Theorem. Checking the assumptions underpinning parametric tests of significance.

(c) Reporting of statistical tests, their interpretation and the graphical display of differences.

(d) Power of the test.

Indicative sources

Kvanli, A.H., Pavur, R.J. Keeling, K.B., (2003) An Introduction to Business Statistics (A Microsoft Excel Integrated Approach) 6th ed., West Publishing Company

Daly, F. Hand, D.J. Jones M.C., Lunn, A.D. and McConway ,K.J, (1995) Elements of Statistics, Addison-Wesley

2. Statistical Inference (Nonparametric Tests)

Syllabus

(a) The logic and theory underpinning statistical hypothesis tests including permutation tests and randomization tests.

(b) The practical application and logic underpinning tests of significance for nonparametric tests including the Wilcoxon Signed Rank Sum test, Sign test, Mann Whitney test, Kruskall-Wallis test, Friedman's test and using the result of the Central Limit Theorem.

(c) Using the bootstrap to test for significance.

Indicative sources

Kvanli, A.H., Pavur, R.J. Keeling, K.B., (2003) An Introduction to Business Statistics (A Microsoft Excel Integrated Approach) 6th ed., West Publishing Company

Daly, F. Hand, D.J. Jones M.C., Lunn, A.D. and McConway ,K.J, (1995) Elements of Statistics, Addison-Wesley

3. Regression Modelling 1

Syllabus

(a) The uses of linear regression. Ideas relating to best fit and the use of linear models and their interpretation. Validity and reliability of the fitted equation, the assessment of residuals (tests of normality, randomness, constant variance, effect of outliers) and predictive ability (prediction intervals and confidence intervals).

(b) Extending the linear model to include multiple predictors. Model building using computer aided selection techniques (backward elimination, forward selection, stepwise, best subsets).

(c) Correlation Analysis. Zero order correlations (Pearson, Kendall, Spearman) and partial correlations and part correlations. Confidence intervals and tests of hypothesis relating to correlations (e.g. Fisher's test).

Indicative sources

Draper, N.R. and Smith, H (1997), Applied Regression Analysis, 3rd Edition, Wiley

4. Regression Modelling 2

(a) Extending and improving multiple regression models.

Development of models to include factors through coding schemes (e.g. dummy variables). Development of models to include higher order effects (interactions). Development of models by transforming variables (e.g. Box-Cox transformation). Model improvement by the identification of influential observations (Cook's distance, leverage and studentized residuals) and lack-of-fit.

(b) Assessing assumptions underpinning models though an analysis of residuals e.g. analysis of residuals for normality using standard tests of normality (Anderson-Darling, Shapiro-Wilk, Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests), for homogeneity of variance (e.g. Goldfeld-Quant test, Glejser test), and for independence (e.g. Durbin-Watson test, residual plots and partial plots).

Problem associated with near multicollinearity and the use of orthogonalisation techniques in model building (e.g. Gramm-Schmidt orthogonalisation).

The use of holdout samples and cross cross-fold validation in the validation of models.

(c) An introduction to time series regression modelling

Indicative sources

Draper, N.R. and Smith, H (1997), Applied Regression Analysis, 3rd Edition, Wiley Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

5. Logistic Regression Models

Syllabus

(a) Motivation and uses of binary logistic regression. Assessing significance (log-likelihood and t-ratios). Interpretation of models through the odds ratio. Assessing goodness-of-fit and lack of fit using standard diagnostic techniques (e.g. Hosmer-Lemeshow test, Pearson residuals, deviance residuals, Brown's test, pseudo R-squares, measures of concordance, roc analysis, the identification of influential observations).

(b) Extending the binary model to include either nominal outcomes or ordinal outcomes.

(c) An introduction to other link functions in the generalised linear model.

Indicative sources

Agresti, A (1996) An Introduction to Categorical Data Analysis, 1996, Wiley

Hosmer, D and Lemeshow, S (2000), Applied Logistic Regression, Wiley

6. Design and Analysis of Experiments

Syllabus:

(a) Advantages of designed experiments in engineering and science.

(b) The \"one-factor-at-a-time\" approach to experimentation. Randomisation, replication, blocking and balancing.

(c) Full and fractional factorial experiments and their analysis. 2n-k designs. Main effects and interaction effects. Use of normal and half-normal plots. Aliasing and confounding. Techniques for removing the ambiguities in aliased effects.

(d) Composite and sequential designs. Response surface designs and their analysis.

(e) Taguchi\'s contribution to designed experiments. Robust parameter design and analysis.

Indicative sources

Box G.E.P., Hunter W.G. & Hunter J.S. (1978). Statistics for Experimenters, Wiley , New York.

Montgomery D.C. (2001). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Wiley, New York.

Wu C.F. Jeff & Hamada (2000). Experiments. Planning, Analysis and Parameter Design Optimisation. Wiley, New York.

7. Designing and Analysing Questionnaire Surveys

Syllabus

(a) Methodology of sampling including sampling theory and limitations on inference from non-probabilistic methods. Sampling plans will include probabilistic and non-probabilistic sampling and include random sampling, systematic sampling, stratification techniques, cluster sampling, multi-stage sampling, quota sampling, convenience sampling and snowball sampling amongst others.

(b) Survey methods including, for example, personal interviewing, telephone interviewing, postal surveys.

(c) Question construction and measuring validity and reliability of questions and sub-scales.

(d) Storage and coding of data and the use of technology in the survey process.

(e) Identifying and applying appropriate multivariate methods of analysis for questionnaire data including regression models, the analysis of categorical data and multivariate exploratory data analysis. Indicative sources: Emory, W C and Cooper, D R, (1991) Business Research Methods, 4th Edition

Lattin, J, Carroll, J D and Green P E (2003), Analysing Multivariate Data, Thompson

8. Multivariate Exploratory Data Analysis

Syllabus

(a) Cluster Analysis. Measures of similarity and distance (e.g. Euclidean distance, Mahalanobis distance). Hierarchical methods (e.g. single linkage, complete linkage, Wards method) and non-hierarchical methods (e.g. k-means clustering) and their application to multivariate data.

(b) Applications of correspondence analysis.

(c) Factor Analysis and Principal Component Analysis. An introduction to principal components analysis as a method of extracting maximum orthogonal variance in a set of data.

Concepts involved in exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis. Using eigenvalues and eigenvectors to understand the process of extracting factors. Orthogonal and oblique rotations to aid factor interpretation. The use of scores derived from factor analysis.

(d) Discriminant Analysis. Motivation behind discriminant analysis. Deriving linear classification rules and evaluating their significance (e.g. Wilks' Lambda), interpreting rules (e.g. standardised coefficients, structure matrix, profile plots), evaluating the accuracy of classification rules (e.g. leave-one-out, Cohen's Kappa) and model building (e.g. stepwise selection).

Indicative sources

Everitt B and Dunn, G (2001), Applied Multivariate Data Analysis, Arnold

Hair, J.E., Anderson, R.E, Tatham, R.L and Black, W.C. (1998), Multivariate Data Analysis, 5th Edition, Prentice-Hall International.

Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

9. Multivariate Analyses of Variance

Syllabus

(a) A brief review of independent measures (between subjects) analysis of variance and post hoc analyses.

(b) Multiple Analysis of Variance for between subjects designs and relationship with Discriminant Analysis (including Wilks Lambda, Roys Largest Root, Pillai's Trace and Hotelling's Trace).

(c) The one-way blocked design (repeated measures). Analysis of one-way repeated measures designs including analysis of variance, checking models assumptions, graphical representation of results, post hoc tests and reporting tests. Mauchly's test of sphericity and adjusted F-tests including Greenhouse-Geisser, Hyundt-Feldt and Lower Bound.

(d) The results from (b) and (c) will be combined to analyse mixed designs.

(e) The multivariate approach to the analysis of repeated measures designs (Profile Analysis)

(f) Different approaches to the analysis of doubly-multivariate designs.

Indicative sources

Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

10. Forecasting

Syllabus

(a) Introduction to Forecasting. Assessing forecast accuracy, the role of forecasting in planning and decision making. Types of forecasting models. Monitoring forecasts.

(b) Exponential Smoothing Models. Simple and adaptive exponential smoothing. Double exponential smoothing, Holt\'s method and Holt-Winter\'s method. Damped exponential smoothing.

(c) The Box-Jenkins Approach. Autocorrelation and Partial Autocorrelation Functions. Types of Time Series model. Model Identification. Parameter Estimation.

Indicative sources

Box, G.E.P., Jenkins, G.M., and Reinsel G.C. (1994), Time Series Analysis, 3rd Edition, Prentice-Hall

Chatfield, C. (1996), The Analysis of Time Series, 5th Ed, Chapman Hall.

11. Data Mining

Syllabus

(a) Introduction to Data Mining: The role of data mining, components of data mining algorithms, assessing performance of data mining techniques, nearest neighbour methods.

(b) Classification and regression trees. Growing trees, pruning trees, use of trees for regression, use of trees for classification.

(c) Neural Nets. Perceptrons, feed forward neural nets, deciding on network structure, issues in training neural nets.

(d) Kernel estimation. Density estimation, nonparametric regression

Indicative sources

Hand, D. Mannila, H. and Smyth, P (2001), Principles of Data Mining, The MIT Press.

Hastie, T., Tibishrani, R and Friedman, J (2001), The Elements of Statistical Learning: Data Mining, Inference and Prediction, Springer-Verlag.

12. Survival Analysis

Syllabus

(a) Survival analysis and reliability. The analysis of censored and truncated data. Comparison of survival curves using tests such as Mantel-Haenszel test, Peto's test and the logrank test. Nonparametric, semi-parametric and parametric survival techniques such as Kaplan-Meier, Cox's Proportional Hazards and Weibull models and related techniques.

Indicative sources

Hosmer D and Lemeshow, S (2001) Applied Survival Analysis. Regression modelling of time to event data. Wiley

13. Time Series Regression Modelling with Non-stationary Data

Syllabus

(a) Definitions of stationarity. Non-stationarity of variables and its implications for regression modelling. Unit roots and the Dickey-Fuller tests for stationarity. (b) Differencing as a solution to non-stationarity. Short-run and long-run equilibrium models.

(c) Cointegration and error-correction models. Testing for cointegration.

(d) Engle-Granger two stage and Johansen methodologies. Applications of ECM in bivariate models.

Indicative sources

Dougherty, C., (2002) Introduction to Econometrics, 2nd ed. Oxford

Kennedy, P., (2003) A Guide to Econometrics, 5th ed., Blackwell Oxley, L., (1999) Practical Issues in Cointegration Analysis, Blackwell Thomas, R.L., (1997) Modern Econometrics: An Introduction, Addison-Wesley

14. Independent Study in Advanced Quantitative Topics

The above units cover the most frequently used statistical techniques in applied quantitative research. The above units do not provide an exhaustive list of quantitative techniques likely to be needed in applied research. This unit (ISAQT) permits independent investigative research into the concepts, theory and practical applications of a specific technique (or techniques) with supervisory guidance. It is not possible to give a comprehensive list of topics that may be needed by an individual researcher but by way of examples, appropriate topics for this unit would include issues relating to specific experimental designs (e.g. clinical trials, cross-over trials), structural equation modelling (SEM), Bayesian Statistics, multilevel modelling.

15. Problem Solving: Case study 1 Analysis of an attitudinal survey.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques often used in the analysis of data from an attitudinal survey will be studied. These are likely to be:

  • Sampling methods
  • The analysis of two-way tables
  • The analysis of 2x2 tables
  • The analysis of two independent samples
  • The analysis of three or more related samples
  • Binary logistic regression analysis

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

16. Problem Solving: Case study 2 Analysis of an employment satisfaction survey.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques often used in the analysis of data from a satisfaction survey will be studied. These include:

  • Summarising Data
  • Descriptive statistics
  • Graphical displays
  • Analysis of two-way tables
  • Analysis of 2x2 tables
  • Non-parametric tests

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

17. Problem Solving: Case study 3 Analysis of data from the World Health Organisation.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques that are often used to build a statistical model will be studied. These include:

  • Graphical Displays
  • Summarising Data
  • Correlation Analysis
  • Comparison of three or more independent samples
  • Linear regression with one independent variable
  • Checking regression assumptions
  • Multiple regression analysis

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

By negotiation with the module leader, in units 15, 16 and 17, and if appropriate to the case study, any of the following web-based learning topics from Data Skills for Business may be included in the unit.

  • Graphical displays
  • Questionnaire design
  • Sampling methods
  • Sampling error and variation
  • Statistical inference the fundamentals
  • The analysis of two-way tables
  • The analysis of 2x2 tables
  • The normal distribution
  • Comparison of two independent samples
  • Comparison of two related samples
  • Comparison of three or more independent samples
  • Comparison of three or more related samples
  • Tests following an ANOVA
  • Correlation analysis
  • Linear regression with one independent variable
  • Checking regression assumptions
  • Multiple regression analysis an introduction
  • More multiple regression analysis
  • Binary logistic regression analysis

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8J-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Human-Computer Interaction
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Nature of Human Computer Interaction: Human Centred Perspective, HCI for Communication, Tool Paradigm, Supervisory Control, Virtual Reality, Ubiquitous Computing

Human Characteristics - Physiological and Psychological Attributes: Sensory and Motor Systems, Ergonomics, Memory, Thinking - Problem Solving and Reasoning, Skills Acquisition, Implications of limitations for interface design and development, Human Diversity

Usability: Principles and Concepts, Guidelines and Standards

Input and Output devices: Traditional and Emerging Technologies

Interaction Methods and Concepts: Conceptual Models, Metaphors, Dialogue type and techniques, Navigation, Adaptive Interfaces, Multimedia and Non-graphical Dialogues, Virtual Reality

Design Process, Methodologies and Cognitive Engineering: User Centred Lifecycle models, Usability engineering, Iterative prototyping, Task Analysis, Cognitive Models, Socio-technical Models, Participatory Design

Implementation support: User Interface Management/Development Systems, Toolkits

Evaluation: Goals and Methods of Evaluation, Evaluation Framework, Data Interpretation

Application Areas and Related Social Issues: Medical/Health Care, Business, Critical Systems, Mobile Technology, Groupware, Entertainment, Web Interfaces, Accessibility, Education, Social and Ethical Issues of technological change.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETQ-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Operations Simulations & Forecasting
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to Simulation in Operations.

Queuing Theory: Single and multiple-channel systems, deterministic and stochastic models, simulation of complex queuing systems, economic analysis of queuing systems.

Design and Analysis of Simulation Models: Activity cycle diagrams. Data collection and analysis. Distribution fitting. Model validation and verification. Variance reduction techniques. Experimental design and analysis.

Introduction to Forecasting. Assessing forecast accuracy, the role of forecasting in planning and decision making. Types of forecasting models. Monitoring Forecasts.

Exponential Smoothing Models. Simple and adaptive exponential smoothing. Double exponential smoothing, Holt's method and Holt-Winter's method. Damped exponential smoothing.

The Box-Jenkins Approach. Autocorrelation and Partial Autocorrelation Functions. Types of Time Series model. Model Identification. Parameter Estimation.

State Space Models.Structural models. Estimation using the Kalman filter. Connections between the three types of models.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8R-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems in the Human Context
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Systems and fundamentals

Perspectives on organisations: Systems concepts and perspectives. Models (including socio-technical) and metaphors of organisation. Approaches to human-centred IS development: paradigms and generations of IS development. Socio-technical systems design. Soft systems methodology.

Organisations and change

Information systems in organisations: The spread, assimilation and impact of information systems. The social and political character of information systems. Relationships between users, managers and developers. Human-centred systems development. Understanding work, and acknowledging tacit knowledge and skill. Requirements determination and negotiation. Forms and nature pf participation.

ICT and the workplace

Impacts of information systems on work and organisational structure. Organisational learning. Human use of information systems: Recognition of human diversity. Automation and its impact on skills and work, and the consequences of 'textualising' and 'informating'. User resistance and empowerment.

Information, organisations and the future

Knowledge, information and knowledge work. Organisational learning. Impact of Web 2.0 technologies in the workplace.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8U-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Development 2
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. The role of design in system development:
    • Introduction of the constraints and objectives of design: functionality, usability, performance objectives, matching problems to solutions, evaluating available technology.
    • The use of method in systems development: integration of particular modelling techniques to design methods; comparative strengths and weaknesses of different methods and the selection of methods for specific application types
    • Developing a physical specification from a logical design: Use of prototyping in projects: approaches, methods, the role of prototyping in design; management of risk in the development lifecycle; RAD, V model, Object Oriented and traditional development lifecycles.
  2. Turning models into designs and mapping technology onto solutions:
    • Development of data structures: Advanced data modelling, normalisation; data definition, keys and constraints; controlling integrity in a database.
    • The structure, syntax and use of SQL: Tools and techniques for web front-ended applications.
    • Transforming process models into applications: building systems to access data in databases; issues of interface design

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE8W-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Technology
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Information Technology in context - Important individuals, organisations and projects in the evolution of digital technologies. The context and application of desktop systems, mobile technologies, business servers, games consoles, multimedia, scientific systems.

Principles of computer science - An introduction to the basic principles of computer science. Representation from analogue to digital. ASCII, image formats, multimedia and stored programs.

Computer systems architecture - Microprocessor architecture, data storage, input-output devices, peripheral devices, communications standards and devices. Classification, benchmarks, purpose, characteristics and capacities of devices.

Software - The concept of stored programs. Features and functions of operating systems and utility software. Legacy and current programming languages. Mark-up and scripting languages.

Networks - An introduction to the role of networks in computer-based information systems. Standards and protocols, e.g. TCP/IP, Ethernet, OSI. WANs and LANs. Client-Server systems. Wireless networks. Classification and capabilities of different networks, with particular attention to the Internet infrastructure and applications from web and email to IM, VoIP etc. Security issues. Firewalls. Virus detection. Converging and emerging communications technologies, e.g. Grid, Web 2, Semantic web.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESG-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Energy and Fluid Flow
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to units and problem solving techniques

Hydrostatics, Bernoullis equation, flow measurement, dimensional analysis, laminar and turbulent flow, fluid flow with friction, fluid machines, pump and pipeline systems, introductory aerodynamics.

Pressure and temperature, work, heat and energy, open and closed systems, analysis of open and closed systems, simplifications for incompressible fluids, gas laws, fluid properties, problems involving gases and vapours.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE99-40-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems Practice 3
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Students are given the opportunity to tackle a substantial and complete IS engagement with a real client organisation as a team of IS practitioners, working in a self-managed fashion within a limited time frame. The precise terms of reference vary widely: some involve the analysis, design and implementation of bespoke computer-based information systems; others involve the formulation of information systems strategy. Still others concentrate on improving organisational effectiveness or efficiency by optimising existing systems or changing non-computer-based IS.

Students are exposed to a range of topics and challenges which broaden and deepen the treatment given by the pre-requisite module. In tackling them they are expected, at minimum, to:-

  • form their own consultancy teams with tutor support, and prepare for the projects, including team-working methods;
  • meet prospective clients offering live IS consultancy opportunities, and express their preferences for projects according to their own evaluation of best fit between team and client;
  • investigate, understand, analyse, and document the IS problem situation, and explore opportunities for IS improvement in the light of organisational objectives, stakeholder needs and expectations;
  • negotiate and agree project terms of reference with the client organisation and project supervisor;
  • undertake the agreed activities as a team, and produce the agreed deliverables, operating substantially in a self-managed fashion, working within their own project management framework;
  • draw upon individual task- and role-based specialisms in delegating work, and utilise relevant academic or professional literature and the expertise and advice of tutors;
  • make explicit choices of IS methods, tools and techniques from across a wide range, and reflect on their effectiveness, having practised their customisation to suit the problem situation;
  • take part in inter-team collaboration, comparison and peer review activities;
  • demonstrate a holistic view of technology, its social context, the search for good fit between the two, and the need for sustainability of client interventions;
  • experience complexity and uncertainty, and demonstrate a critical appreciation of the multiple perspectives and interests of different clients, peers, tutors and other stakeholders;
  • practise quality management in a project situation for which one has sole or major responsibility;
  • review and evaluate their practice critically in depth, demonstrating awareness of a range of professional and methodological issues in IS practice.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE9A-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Human-Computer Interaction
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Nature and Scope of Interaction Design: Review of the field of Human-Computer Interaction and an overview of the range and nature of activities interaction design encompasses. An introduction to the human-centred systems perspective.

Human Characteristics: Physiological and Psychological Attributes. Ergonomics. Memory. Cognition, to include problem solving, reasoning and skills acquisition. Implications of limitations for interface design and development. Human Diversity

Usability: Principles and Concepts. Guidelines and Standards

Interaction Methods and Concepts: Conceptual Models. Metaphors. Dialogue types and techniques. Interfaces to support Navigation.

Input and Output devices: Traditional and Emerging Technologies

User-Centred Design Process and Methodologies: User-Centred Lifecycle Models. Methods for identifying user needs and requirements. Socio-technical Models. Task Analysis. Participatory Design. Iterative prototyping.

Usability Evaluation: Goals of Evaluation. Evaluation Techniques and Frameworks. Data Interpretation.

New and Emerging Interaction Paradigms: Ubiquitous and Pervasive Computing. Wearable Computing. Virtual and Augmented Reality. Attentive Environments. Tangible bits.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE9G-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Systems in Complex Organisations
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Models and theories of organisation: bureaucracy, Fordist, modern vs. post-modern; institutional perspectives on organisations; globalisation, dis-organisation; emergent organisational forms; information and information systems in organisations.

Evolution of IT/IS within and between organisations: generational, organisation stages, and labour process perspectives; Friedman's integrated constraints model.

Innovation in the technology process: models of innovation; interaction between organisation and technology; learning organisations and organisational learning.

Computerisation of work: automation, deskilling, flexible labour; the informated organisation; computer-mediated work, shift from action-centred to intellective work; participation and resistance; implications of IS for managerial and professional roles.

IS strategy: traditional top-down model of strategy formation, and critique; alignment of IS/IT strategy with corporate strategy; strategic issues in IS; strategy as a process including and implicit in operations, and extending beyond organisational boundaries.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE9H-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Computing and Law
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction: The legal system; differences between public/private, criminal/civil, legislation/common law. The Courts.

Contractual Liability: formation, breach, limiting liability, legislative controls and remedies. Focussing on an examination of the application of these legal principles to the supply of information technology products/services.

Non-contractual Liability: principles of the tort of negligence and the Consumer Protection Act 1987. An examination of these legal principles in relation to those involved in the supply of information technology products/services.

Criminal Liability: application of general criminal law and the Computer Misuse Act 1990 to conduct involving information technology.

Data Protection: controls over the acquisition and use of personal data; main principles of the Data Protection Act 1998.

Intellectual Property: the application of intellectual property to information technology focussing on copyright, patent and breach of confidence.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE9R-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Knowledge in Organisations
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction: Data information and knowledge; knowledge elicitation, analysis and representation; background to recent interest in knowledge management in organisations.
