Understanding Knowledge in Organisations: Different categories of knowledge, e.g. tacit and explicit; embodied, embedded, embrained, encultured, encoded; propositional, practical, experiential; knowledge in action; knowing as culturally situated, artefact mediated, socially distributed, personal and provisional; communities of practice; organisational knowledge and learning: individual, social and critical perspectives.

Managing Knowledge in Organisations: Assessing, organising and creating knowledge in organisations; the process of knowledge management as generation, codification and transfer; techniques and technologies for knowledge management; epistemological, ontological and temporal dimensions of knowledge creation; Nonaka and Takeuchi's knowledge spiral.

Issues for the Future: Potential and pitfalls of knowledge management projects; trust, intellectual property; implications for research and practice.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEDA-30-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Aerospace and Engineering Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design Methods: the design process, and the systematic approach to design problems: requirement analysis, problem identification, problem solving methods, problem solving tools, preparation of specifications, solution identification and design. Principles of embodiment design.

Engineering Drawing: sketching. principles of projection: third angle and isometric views. Basic standard conventions using British Standards. Use of simple software design tools eg 2D CAD.

Practical Skills: follow through the design, build, test cycle within the practical environment of a the aerospace engineering workshop. Present the results, including an analysis of the standard and accuracy of the work produced.

Professional Skills: completion of workbook to demonstrate effective use of the library. Time management, working in groups, oral and written presentation skills, basic project management.

Software Skills: introduction to the range of engineering software tools. Writing of simple programmes, including the incorporation of data from other sources, especially Excel.

Legislation: an outline of the Environmental Protection Act (1990) and the Health and Safety at Work Act (1974) with emphasis on their impact on engineering companies

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIE9T-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Creativity and Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Critical Thinking and Reasoning
  • Language and critical thinking precision, evidence, objectiveness
  • Inductive and deductive reasoning, Scientific method
  • Constructing an argument. Gathering evidence finding and evaluating evidence
Reflective Practice
  • The role of reflection (for, in and on) design processes and artefacts
  • The learning process and techniques for developing reflective practice
Creativity
  • What is creativity? Theory, practical techniques and applicability
  • Application of a broad range of creativity techniques for individuals, small groups and whole groups
The Creative Design Process
  • Understanding and defining design problems/opportunities/briefs
  • Methods for understanding people, activities and contexts. The importance of considering multiple viewpoints
  • The role of constraints in fostering creativity
  • Realising a user-centred design process. The importance of alternating phases of convergent and divergent thinking
  • Evaluating the process and outcomes
Information Presentation and Visualisation
  • Types of representations
  • Understanding audience and objectives in selecting suitable representations
  • Visual Communication
Collaboration
  • Group dynamics
  • Collective Intelligence
  • Managing relationships and conflict management
Ethics
  • The ethics of creativity and design. Sustainability and inclusive design
  • Issues and definitions of practice and professionalism

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7S-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Signal Processing and Control
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Signal Analysis

Signals: Definition; deterministic (periodic and aperiodic) random; signal sources; information; entropy; sources; information; entropy; mathematical representation of basic deterministic signals.

Phasors: Graphical addition of sinusoids; definition of a phasor; phasor impedance and transfer transfer functions of R,L,C networks.

Power: dc and rms values; power factor; real, reactive and apparent power in R,L,C networks.

Laplace transforms: Definition; transforms of common signals; use of tables; solution of ordinary differential equations; partial fractions; generalised impedance and transfer functions of R, L, C networks; pole/zero diagrams; network time response; forced and natural modes; time constant; stability; second order response; use of standard second order response chart.

Frequency response: Frequency response from Laplace transfer function; bandwidth in relation to time constant; definition of dB; Bode plots with straight line approximation; Nyquist plots, resonance.

Fourier series: Trigonometric and phasor form; power spectrum.

Fourier transform: Derivation from Fourier series; Fourier transform of common signals; inverse spreading principle; relation to Laplace transforms; Parseval's theorem; energy spectral density.

Convolution: The convolution integral; graphical convolution; discrete convolution

Discrete signals: Sampling; aliasing; Shannon's sampling theorem; z-transforms; z-transfer functions; difference equations and their software implementation; causality; stability; gain and phase shift; frequency response; transfer function of zero order hold DAC; first order hold DAC; impulse and step invariant simulation of continuous systems; selection of sampling period; definition of 'real time'; block diagrams.

Random signals: Definition of a random variable; PDF and CDF; Gaussian PDF; independent and conditional probability; signal mean, rms and variance; mean of a function of a random variable.

Systems Electronics: Operational amplifiers: Non-ideal operational amplifiers; current sources; current mirrors; offset; bias; drift; noise; gain-bandwidth; rise time.

Network analysis: RLC network analysis using Laplace transforms; step and sinusoidal response.

Filters: Filter classification LP, HP, BP; 2nd and higher order; transfer functions; Butterwoth and Chebychev approximations; normalised prototypes; scaling; passive and active realisations.

Control systems

Introduction: Need for automatic control; Examples such as amplifiers, water cisterns, machine tools, aircraft, furnaces, the eye, the economy; open and closed loop; servo and regulator control; plant, actuator, sensor, controller.

System modelling: Definition of linear and non-linear systems; linear modelling of translational and rotational mass, spring and damper, potentiometer, dc motor, pressure sensor, furnace; block diagrams.

System performance: Static servo and regulator gain; overshoot and rise time.

Feedback control design: Dominant poles; design of P, PI, PID, IP and IPD controller using pole placement for serve and regulator control.

System identification: Identification of transfer functions from system time and frequency responses.

Frequency domain controller design: Nyquist stability criterion; gain and phase margin: design of a phase shift controller.

Routh - Hurwitz stability criterion and Final Value theorem.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEL4-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Generic Skills for Research Students
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Students will be expected to engage with a variety of learning experiences and develop a set of competencies, transferable and reflective skills, which typically include the ability to

demonstrate the awareness of ethical issues and research governance,

understand the issues of working with industry and community,

identify research funding opportunities

understand the process of academic or commercial exploitation of research results

apply effective project management

develop and maintain co-operative and working relationship with supervisors, colleagues and peers

effectively support the learning of other when involved in teaching

take ownership for and manage one's career progression

present one's skills, personal attributes and experiences to potential employers.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEK3-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Moving Image Technology
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Moving image technology - development and context

Overview of the development of film, analogue video and digital video introducing the different technologies involved in moving image production and dissemination. The relationship between technical constraints/freedoms/innovations will be considered in terms of how they shape or were shaped by content choices and production and dissemination and reception.

Understanding moving image production

Students would be taken through basic concepts in moving image production and the related methods and production roles. This would include:

  • film grammar basics
  • storyboarding
  • lighting and image construction
  • sound
  • the relationship between image and sound
  • editing
  • dubbing & post-production
  • modes of distribution and implications for production

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEPT-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Research Methods for Software Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Scientific and ethnographic models for research

- The Research Process; theory and practical implications

- Selection and Identification of the Research Topic, Definition of Research Objectives, Formulation of Research Questions and Hypotheses

- Review of Relevant Literature and Existing Research: Literature Searches; Effective Use of the Internet and library materials, and organisation of material.

- Risk assessment and management, Planning and Budgeting

- Deciding the Research Strategy and Design

- The Research Proposal and Plan

- Ethical considerations for researchers

- Issues of reliability, validity and generalisability for researchers

- Features of Qualitative and Quantitative Data

- Collection of Primary Data: Experimental Design, Survey Methods, Sampling Design and Procedure.

- Analysis of quantitative data ; an overview of statistical procedures.

- Use of secondary data in the research process

- Collection and Analysis of Qualitative Data; Interviewing and Observation Methods.

- Communicating your Results Effectively: Dissertation Structure and Presentation

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEKF-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Architecture
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Introduction

Concept and principles of information architecture. Making connections between ideas of information architecture in web design, content management, information science and enterprise systems. Role of the information architect.

- Organising and structuring information

Schemes and structures for organising information: indexes; linear, hierarchical, and network structures; data and content models; interaction of content, context and users. Role and importance of metadata and markup. Markup languages, especially XML. Labelling and classification systems. Controlled vocabularies; taxonomies, thesauri, and ontologies. Support for query, browsing, searching, navigation and retrieval. Methods for determining information needs and user models, and for discovering and monitoring information usage.

- Process modelling

Relating information to business processes. Introduction to business process and workflow modelling, and to Business Process Management (BPM) notations and languages. Using tools for diagramming business processes, eg. role-activity diagrams, UML activity diagrams, BPMN. Elements in a process architecture.

- Enterprise architecture

Idea and key concepts of enterprise architecture: layered system from enterprise to applications, supported by distributed computing platform. Role of content management systems. Introduction to Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems. Document engineering with XML technologies. Developing a unified information or content strategy: content audit and lifecycle; designing information, metadata and workflow systems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEKG-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Data, Schemas and Applications
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Background. The need to store, transform, locate and present data of many forms (numeric, textual, relational, graphical, visual and auditory). Unstructured text through semi-structured networks to homogeneous relational structures. Data, information and knowledge. Application areas such as personal, corporate, public and collaborative data bases.

Data structures and operations. Elemental and composite data structures of data: atoms, propositions, sets, sequences, relations, networks, objects. Relationships: links, pointers, shared values, adjacency, nesting, spatial. Operations: restricting, projecting, combining, navigating, transforming.

Data Schemas. Separation/Composition of data, schema (including constraints) and meta data. Languages for describing schemas - UML models and SQL DDL for tables, Data structure diagrams, BNF and XSchema for hierarchical structures. Composition, types and sub-types and inheritance. Data schemas for typical problems.

Technologies. Relational database management systems (DBMS) such as MySQL, using SQL for definition and manipulation of data. Object Relational DBMS such as Oracle 9i, XML native databases. Client-server and N-tier architectures. Concurrency, recovery, access control.

Implementation. Mapping information objects - documents, indexes, guides, maps, sound and videos and their relationships to data structures in the appropriate technology. Mapping ER models to relational database, hierarchies to XML. Implementing indexing and search capabilities.

Presentation schemas: XML and CSS for text and tables, GIF, JPG and SVG for charts, graphs and diagrams, multi-media formats for video and sound. Transforming Data to information: Virtual and materialised views, dynamic server-side processing with a procedural language e.g. PHP, declarative language e.g. XSLT

Design process: Re-engineering existing data sets, normalisation, functional dependencies, ORM and Entity models. multiple perspectives, views and view integration, information architecture for Web sites.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEKV-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Digital Stories
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction. Focusing on stories as a particular kind of information and communication. Creating digital stories. Emergent forms of story.

Story and narrative. Structures, types and purposes of narrative. Stories and storytelling. Composition. Functions and kinds of stories: personal, family, and community stories; stories in organizations and society.

Resources for creating digital narratives. Document formats. Hypertext: concept, structure, and navigation. Incorporation of images and other types of media. Examples of e-publishing, hypermedia and web software tools.

Digital narratives and stories. Making stories on the computer and WWW. The process of creating a digital story: composition, construction, editing, publishing; methods, environment and support. Some types and examples of digital stories: online journals and weblogs; hypertext fiction; narrative structures in games/VR.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEMW-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Dissertation with Placement Experience
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
For this module students draw on placement experience for their primary research. The nature of the research will vary according to the subject which is being addressed. Dissertation topics should focus on some agreed aspect(s) of the programme as applied in the placement context.

As a guide for the length of a suitable placement a minimum of 200 hours would be appropriate. Placement venues may vary from voluntary organisations, educational establishments to small, medium or multi-national enterprises.

Students are expected to carry out an in-depth survey of relevant literature to identify a focus for their study that contributes to existing research in the field. The primary research may involve a wide range of activities such as: carrying out a quantitative survey, an evaluative case study or action research study, or developing an experimental piece of software. The written dissertation should make clear how the primary research was designed and conducted. Discussion of the outcomes of primary research should be clearly related to existing literature. The body of the dissertation should be supplemented by a critical review of all aspects of the research process.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIENE-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Management of Information & Library Services
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Management theories and techniques and their application in library and information services
  • Organisational culture and communication
  • Strategic management in library and information services
  • Operational and process management in library and information services
  • Customer service and quality management in relation to library and information services
  • Marketing library services
  • Managing change
  • Staff management
  • Staff development and staff appraisal

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIENG-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Research Methods in Information & Library Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Overview of theoretical tools and practical skills necessary for the design and execution of a research project, particularly in relation to research in the domain of library and information management. Underlying questions about the nature of social science and information science research and related conceptions of reality and knowledge.
  • Search and critical use of research literature.
  • Topic definition and formulation of research questions. Writing a research proposal.
  • Research methodology. Evaluation and selection of relevant methods for data collection and analysis. Interviews and questionnaires. Research design. Techniques for planning and managing the research process
  • Issues of ethics, validity, trustworthiness and reliability in research.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIENH-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Dissertation in Information & Library Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The student, working under personal supervision, will write a dissertation of approximately 15,000 words on a topic within the field of information and library management

The dissertation must contain a clear indication, at appropriate stages, of the original and creative elements of the work. It should demonstrate some originality by, for example, continuing or updating previous work, applying existing techniques to new environments, investigating new areas in information and library management or using comparative approaches to the provision of information and library services.

Expected contents also include:

  • a discussion of the dissertation's scope and aims, and its theoretical and professional significance, including a discussion of the context in which the problem to be addressed is seen as important.
  • a critical review of literature relating to the topic.
  • a justification for and account of the methods used to gather and analyse data, including consideration of their suitability, reliability and validity. This must include appropriate consideration of ethical issues.
  • presentation and analysis of research findings, to include a discussion of their significance, their relationship to other research covered in the literature review and any methodological or theoretical implications.
  • a concluding chapter which follows logically from the findings and demonstrates how the research aims have been met. The relationship of the findings to existing professional understanding should also be considered and there should be a critical review of the research, identifying both strengths and limitations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIENJ-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Public Libraries with Services for Young People
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Public libraries purpose and policy
  • Research into public libraries
  • The library service offer: reading, information and learning
  • Social Inclusion
  • Resources to meet needs
  • Visit to a public library
  • Children are people
  • Literature for young people
  • Information literacy for young people
  • Libraries serving education and schools
  • Libraries working with other partners
  • Measuring performance and impact

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGC-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Data Analysis
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Data and Data Collection: Types of data. Primary and secondary sources of data. Data collection methods. Convenience and random sampling.

Data Summary and Presentation: Presentation and summary of data using tables and graphs, including critical evaluation of these. Summarising data numerically.

Probability: The concept of random events and their probability. Independent and mutually exclusive events. Use of tree and Venn diagrams and contingency tables to assist with the calculation of the probabilities, including conditional probability. Bayes\' Theorem.

Probability Distributions: Discrete and continuous random variables and associated probability distributions, including uniform, binomial, Poisson and normal distributions. Use of statistical tables and Minitab to calculate probabilities associated with these distributions. Expected values. Mean and variance of distributions.

Statistical Inference: Estimation: Sampling error. Estimation of a population mean and proportion. Sampling distributions of means and proportions. The central limit theorem. Confidence intervals for means and proportions. Hypothesis testing: The concepts of significance, significance level and the p-value. The sign test. One and two sample t-tests for means (paired and unpaired) and z-tests for proportions and assumptions required. Chi-square tests for goodness-of-fit and contingency tables.

Correlation and Regression: Pearson\'s correlation coefficient as a measure of the linear association of two variables. Use of linear regression to quantify the relationship between two variables. Underlying assumptions, and use of residuals to check these.

Statistical Software: Use of Minitab, and occasionally Excel, to perform statistical calculations and produce graphs.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGS-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Decision Modelling & Optimisation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The course will aim to look at a wide range of mathematical programming techniques. These will include:

Linear Programming and applications of Linear Programming such as Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) and Goal Programming - both pre-emptive and non pre-emptive. Integer Programming: including Branch and Bound method, knapsack problems, set covering problems and the use of integer programming in modelling a variety of real life constraints which linear programming cannot deal with - including set up costs, either/or constraints, if then constraints etc.

Dynamic Programming: including decision trees, Stagecoach problems, inventory and production problems, replacement and maintenance problems.

Heuristics: including when heuristics are appropriate, local optima versus global optima, diversification versus intensification, tabu search, simulated annealing and genetic algorithms, other approaches inspired by nature, dealing with constraints, recent developments in heuristics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGV-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematical Statistics
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFQEGE-20-1 AND (UFQEFS-20-1 OR UFQEG6-20-1 OR UFQELG-20-1 OR (UFQETH-10-1 AND (UFQETG-10-1 OR UFQETJ-10-1))))
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Approaches to probability. Properties and application of discrete probability distributions including the geometric, negative binomial and hypergeomeric distribution. Properties of discrete bivariate distributions including marginal and conditional distributions. Properties and application of continuous distributions. Introduction of the gamma integral and distributions which rely upon this. Addition and transformations of random variables.

2. Regression Analysis and Analysis of Variance. Derivation of least squares line for simple linear regression. An introduction to bivariate regression and the bivariate normal distributions. Derivation of formulae for prediction intervals and confidence intervals for predictions under simple linear regression. Matrix formulation for multiple linear regression. Derivation of additivity in one-way analysis of variance.

3. Non-parametrics. Development of combinatoric ideas under null hypothesis. Derivation of means and variance of non-parametric statistics.

4. Frequentist inference. Estimation. Estimators as statistics, bias, consistency, variance, mean square error, Cramer-Rao lower bound. Good estimators. Methods of maximum likelihood and moments. Sufficiency, information. MLE large sample properties; asymptotically normal. Interval estimation. Hypothesis testing. Rationale, size, power, one- and two-sided tests, Neyman-Pearson lemma; likelihood ratios; asymptotic properties of LRT.

5. Bayesian Inference. Prior knowledge, prior ignorance. Conjugate priors. Estimation and hypothesis testing. Empirical Bayes' methods. Decision theory. Loss functions, admissible decision criteria, minimax, maximin and Bayes' decision rules.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQELG-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Linear Algebra and Calculus
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Functions : Properties of basic continuous functions, parametric functions, vector functions Concepts of limits and continuity Calculus: Differentiation from first principles and the fundamental theorem of calculus Differentiation and integration techniques. Applications. Power Series: Radius of convergence of power series, Taylor's theorem and Taylor's series. Vectors: Vector algebra. Vector geometry in 2D and 3D. Matrices: Matrix algebra. Operations on matrices including determinant, transpose, inverse. Linear Algebraic Systems: Representation by matrices. Existence and uniqueness of solutions. Solving linear systems using direct methods. Vector Space: Definition of vector space and subspace. Linear combination, linear independence, span, basis and dimension. Linear Transformations: Definition of general linear transformation. Matrix transformations. Properties of linear transformations. Null space, range, rank, nullity. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Eigenvalues, eigenvectors and eigenspaces of a linear transformation. Diagonalisable matrices

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQESD-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Analytical Methods
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Algebraic methods

Functions: Review of concepts including composite functions, inverses, domain and range.

Algebraic methods: polynomial division; factor and remainder theorem; rules of order; reduction of algebraic fractions

Exponential, trigonometric and hyperbolic functions: nature and relationships; solution of equations;

Arithmetic and geometric series: notation; arithmetic and geometric progressions and series; Pascals triangle and the binomial theorem; Power series

Trigonometric methods

Sinusoidal functions: trigonometric ratios; co-ordinate systems; radian measure; sinusoidal functions, applications

Trigonometric identities: trigonometric and hyperbolic identities; double angle and compound angle formulae; trigonometric equations

The calculus

The calculus: concepts and definitions of the derivative; standard derivatives; product, quotient and function of a function rules; indefinite integrals; standard integrals and applications; the definite integral and area under curves

Further differentiation: second order and higher derivatives; logarithmic differentiation; differentiation of inverse trigonometric and hyperbolic functions;

Further integration: integration by parts and by substitution; integration using partial fractions

Applications of the calculus and Engineering problems

Statistics and probability

data collection and graphical representation; concepts, methods and applications of:

  • Central tendency and dispersion
  • Regression, linear correlation
  • Probability and Probability distributions

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETD-5-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistics for Research (D)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Units:

1. Statistical Inference (Parametric Tests)

Syllabus

(a) The logic and theory underpinning statistical hypothesis tests.

(b) The practical application and logic underpinning tests of significance for mean differences including the one-sample t-test, paired t-test, two-sample t-tests, one-way ANOVA, one-way ANOVA with blocking, two-way factorial designs and using the result of the Central Limit Theorem. Checking the assumptions underpinning parametric tests of significance.

(c) Reporting of statistical tests, their interpretation and the graphical display of differences.

(d) Power of the test.

Indicative sources

Kvanli, A.H., Pavur, R.J. Keeling, K.B., (2003) An Introduction to Business Statistics (A Microsoft Excel Integrated Approach) 6th ed., West Publishing Company

Daly, F. Hand, D.J. Jones M.C., Lunn, A.D. and McConway ,K.J, (1995) Elements of Statistics, Addison-Wesley

2. Statistical Inference (Nonparametric Tests)

Syllabus

(a) The logic and theory underpinning statistical hypothesis tests including permutation tests and randomization tests.

(b) The practical application and logic underpinning tests of significance for nonparametric tests including the Wilcoxon Signed Rank Sum test, Sign test, Mann Whitney test, Kruskall-Wallis test, Friedman's test and using the result of the Central Limit Theorem.

(c) Using the bootstrap to test for significance.

Indicative sources

Kvanli, A.H., Pavur, R.J. Keeling, K.B., (2003) An Introduction to Business Statistics (A Microsoft Excel Integrated Approach) 6th ed., West Publishing Company

Daly, F. Hand, D.J. Jones M.C., Lunn, A.D. and McConway ,K.J, (1995) Elements of Statistics, Addison-Wesley

3. Regression Modelling 1

Syllabus

(a) The uses of linear regression. Ideas relating to best fit and the use of linear models and their interpretation. Validity and reliability of the fitted equation, the assessment of residuals (tests of normality, randomness, constant variance, effect of outliers) and predictive ability (prediction intervals and confidence intervals).

(b) Extending the linear model to include multiple predictors. Model building using computer aided selection techniques (backward elimination, forward selection, stepwise, best subsets).

(c) Correlation Analysis. Zero order correlations (Pearson, Kendall, Spearman) and partial correlations and part correlations. Confidence intervals and tests of hypothesis relating to correlations (e.g. Fisher's test).

Indicative sources

Draper, N.R. and Smith, H (1997), Applied Regression Analysis, 3rd Edition, Wiley

4. Regression Modelling 2

Syllabus

(a) Extending and improving multiple regression models.

Development of models to include factors through coding schemes (e.g. dummy variables). Development of models to include higher order effects (interactions). Development of models by transforming variables (e.g. Box-Cox transformation). Model improvement by the identification of influential observations (Cook's distance, leverage and studentized residuals) and lack-of-fit.

(b) Assessing assumptions underpinning models though an analysis of residuals e.g. analysis of residuals for normality using standard tests of normality (Anderson-Darling, Shapiro-Wilk, Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests), for homogeneity of variance (e.g. Goldfeld-Quant test, Glejser test), and for independence (e.g. Durbin-Watson test, residual plots and partial plots).

Problem associated with near multicollinearity and the use of orthogonalisation techniques in model building (e.g. Gramm-Schmidt orthogonalisation).

The use of holdout samples and cross cross-fold validation in the validation of models.

(c) An introduction to time series regression modelling

Indicative sources

Draper, N.R. and Smith, H (1997), Applied Regression Analysis, 3rd Edition, Wiley Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

5. Logistic Regression Models

Syllabus

(a) Motivation and uses of binary logistic regression. Assessing significance (log-likelihood and t-ratios). Interpretation of models through the odds ratio. Assessing goodness-of-fit and lack of fit using standard diagnostic techniques (e.g. Hosmer-Lemeshow test, Pearson residuals, deviance residuals, Brown's test, pseudo R-squares, measures of concordance, roc analysis, the identification of influential observations).

(b) Extending the binary model to include either nominal outcomes or ordinal outcomes.

(c) An introduction to other link functions in the generalised linear model.

Indicative sources

Agresti, A (1996) An Introduction to Categorical Data Analysis, 1996, Wiley

Hosmer, D and Lemeshow, S (2000), Applied Logistic Regression, Wiley

6. Design and Analysis of Experiments

Syllabus:

(a) Advantages of designed experiments in engineering and science.

(b) The \"one-factor-at-a-time\" approach to experimentation. Randomisation, replication, blocking and balancing.

(c) Full and fractional factorial experiments and their analysis. 2n-k designs. Main effects and interaction effects. Use of normal and half-normal plots. Aliasing and confounding. Techniques for removing the ambiguities in aliased effects.

(d) Composite and sequential designs. Response surface designs and their analysis.

(e) Taguchi\'s contribution to designed experiments. Robust parameter design and analysis.

Indicative sources

Box G.E.P., Hunter W.G. & Hunter J.S. (1978). Statistics for Experimenters, Wiley , New York.

Montgomery D.C. (2001). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Wiley, New York.

Wu C.F. Jeff & Hamada (2000). Experiments. Planning, Analysis and Parameter Design Optimisation. Wiley, New York.

7. Designing and Analysing Questionnaire Surveys

Syllabus

(a) Methodology of sampling including sampling theory and limitations on inference from non-probabilistic methods. Sampling plans will include probabilistic and non-probabilistic sampling and include random sampling, systematic sampling, stratification techniques, cluster sampling, multi-stage sampling, quota sampling, convenience sampling and snowball sampling amongst others.

(b) Survey methods including, for example, personal interviewing, telephone interviewing, postal surveys.

(c) Question construction and measuring validity and reliability of questions and sub-scales.

(d) Storage and coding of data and the use of technology in the survey process.

(e) Identifying and applying appropriate multivariate methods of analysis for questionnaire data including regression models, the analysis of categorical data and multivariate exploratory data analysis. Indicative sources: Emory, W C and Cooper, D R, (1991) Business Research Methods, 4th Edition

Lattin, J, Carroll, J D and Green P E (2003), Analysing Multivariate Data, Thompson

8. Multivariate Exploratory Data Analysis

Syllabus

(a) Cluster Analysis. Measures of similarity and distance (e.g. Euclidean distance, Mahalanobis distance). Hierarchical methods (e.g. single linkage, complete linkage, Wards method) and non-hierarchical methods (e.g. k-means clustering) and their application to multivariate data.

(b) Applications of correspondence analysis.

(c) Factor Analysis and Principal Component Analysis. An introduction to principal components analysis as a method of extracting maximum orthogonal variance in a set of data.

Concepts involved in exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis. Using eigenvalues and eigenvectors to understand the process of extracting factors. Orthogonal and oblique rotations to aid factor interpretation. The use of scores derived from factor analysis.

(d) Discriminant Analysis. Motivation behind discriminant analysis. Deriving linear classification rules and evaluating their significance (e.g. Wilks' Lambda), interpreting rules (e.g. standardised coefficients, structure matrix, profile plots), evaluating the accuracy of classification rules (e.g. leave-one-out, Cohen's Kappa) and model building (e.g. stepwise selection).

Indicative sources

Everitt B and Dunn, G (2001), Applied Multivariate Data Analysis, Arnold

Hair, J.E., Anderson, R.E, Tatham, R.L and Black, W.C. (1998), Multivariate Data Analysis, 5th Edition, Prentice-Hall International.

Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

9. Multivariate Analyses of Variance

Syllabus

(a) A brief review of independent measures (between subjects) analysis of variance and post hoc analyses.

(b) Multiple Analysis of Variance for between subjects designs and relationship with Discriminant Analysis (including Wilks Lambda, Roys Largest Root, Pillai's Trace and Hotelling's Trace).

(c) The one-way blocked design (repeated measures). Analysis of one-way repeated measures designs including analysis of variance, checking models assumptions, graphical representation of results, post hoc tests and reporting tests. Mauchly's test of sphericity and adjusted F-tests including Greenhouse-Geisser, Hyundt-Feldt and Lower Bound.

(d) The results from 9(b) and 9(c) will be combined to analyse mixed designs.

(e) The multivariate approach to the analysis of repeated measures designs (Profile Analysis)

(f) Different approaches to the analysis of doubly-multivariate designs.

Indicative sources

Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

10. Forecasting

Syllabus

(a) Introduction to Forecasting. Assessing forecast accuracy, the role of forecasting in planning and decision making. Types of forecasting models. Monitoring forecasts.

(b) Exponential Smoothing Models. Simple and adaptive exponential smoothing. Double exponential smoothing, Holt\'s method and Holt-Winter\'s method. Damped exponential smoothing.

(c) The Box-Jenkins Approach. Autocorrelation and Partial Autocorrelation Functions. Types of Time Series model. Model Identification. Parameter Estimation.

Indicative sources

Box, G.E.P., Jenkins, G.M., and Reinsel G.C. (1994), Time Series Analysis, 3rd Edition, Prentice-Hall

Chatfield, C. (1996), The Analysis of Time Series, 5th Ed, Chapman Hall.

11. Data Mining

Syllabus

(a) Introduction to Data Mining: The role of data mining, components of data mining algorithms, assessing performance of data mining techniques, nearest neighbour methods.

(b) Classification and regression trees. Growing trees, pruning trees, use of trees for regression, use of trees for classification.

(c) Neural Nets. Perceptrons, feed forward neural nets, deciding on network structure, issues in training neural nets.

(d) Kernel estimation. Density estimation, nonparametric regression

Indicative sources

Hand, D. Mannila, H. and Smyth, P (2001), Principles of Data Mining, The MIT Press.

Hastie, T., Tibishrani, R and Friedman, J (2001), The Elements of Statistical Learning: Data Mining, Inference and Prediction, Springer-Verlag.

12. Survival Analysis

Syllabus

(a) Survival analysis and reliability. The analysis of censored and truncated data. Comparison of survival curves using tests such as Mantel-Haenszel test, Peto's test and the logrank test. Nonparametric, semi-parametric and parametric survival techniques such as Kaplan-Meier, Cox's Proportional Hazards and Weibull models and related techniques.

Indicative sources

Hosmer D and Lemeshow, S (2001) Applied Survival Analysis. Regression modelling of time to event data. Wiley

13. Time Series Regression Modelling with Non-stationary Data

Syllabus

(a) Definitions of stationarity. Non-stationarity of variables and its implications for regression modelling. Unit roots and the Dickey-Fuller tests for stationarity.

(b) Differencing as a solution to non-stationarity. Short-run and long-run equilibrium models.

(c) Cointegration and error-correction models. Testing for cointegration.

(d) Engle-Granger two stage and Johansen methodologies. Applications of ECM in bivariate models.

Indicative sources

Dougherty, C., (2002) Introduction to Econometrics, 2nd ed. Oxford

Kennedy, P., (2003) A Guide to Econometrics, 5th ed., Blackwell Oxley, L., (1999) Practical Issues in Cointegration Analysis, Blackwell Thomas, R.L., (1997) Modern Econometrics: An Introduction, Addison-Wesley

14. Independent Study in Advanced Quantitative Topics

The above units cover the most frequently used statistical techniques in applied quantitative research. The above units do not provide an exhaustive list of quantitative techniques likely to be needed in applied research. This unit (ISAQT) permits independent investigative research into the concepts, theory and practical applications of a specific technique (or techniques) with supervisory guidance. It is not possible to give a comprehensive list of topics that may be needed by an individual researcher but by way of examples, appropriate topics for this unit would include issues relating to specific experimental designs (e.g. clinical trials, cross-over trials), structural equation modelling (SEM), Bayesian Statistics, multilevel modelling.

15. Problem Solving: Case study 1 Analysis of an attitudinal survey.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques often used in the analysis of data from an attitudinal survey will be studied. These are likely to be:

  • Sampling methods
  • The analysis of two-way tables
  • The analysis of 2x2 tables
  • The analysis of two independent samples
  • The analysis of three or more related samples
  • Binary logistic regression analysis

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

16. Problem Solving: Case study 2 Analysis of an employment satisfaction survey.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques often used in the analysis of data from a satisfaction survey will be studied. These include:

  • Summarising Data
  • Descriptive statistics
  • Graphical displays
  • Analysis of two-way tables
  • Analysis of 2x2 tables
  • Non-parametric tests

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

17. Problem Solving: Case study 3 Analysis of data from the World Health Organisation.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques that are often used to build a statistical model will be studied. These include:

  • Graphical Displays
  • Summarising Data
  • Correlation Analysis
  • Comparison of three or more independent samples
  • Linear regression with one independent variable
  • Checking regression assumptions
  • Multiple regression analysis

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

By negotiation with the module leader, in units 15, 16 and 17, and if appropriate to the case study, any of the following web-based learning topics from Data Skills for Business may be included in the unit.

  • Graphical displays
  • Questionnaire design
  • Sampling methods
  • Sampling error and variation
  • Statistical inference the fundamentals
  • The analysis of two-way tables
  • The analysis of 2x2 tables
  • The normal distribution
  • Comparison of two independent samples
  • Comparison of two related samples
  • Comparison of three or more independent samples
  • Comparison of three or more related samples
  • Tests following an ANOVA
  • Correlation analysis
  • Linear regression with one independent variable
  • Checking regression assumptions
  • Multiple regression analysis an introduction
  • More multiple regression analysis
  • Binary logistic regression analysis

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIERD-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Library & Information Services
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Overview of the structure of library and information services in the UK and worldwide. Current issues and trends affecting their development and direction. The role of information and library services in life and learning.

The structure, role and context of library and information services. Issues in collection management and development. Financial management . Principles, systems, techniques and tools used in the organisation of information within libraries and information services. The role of IT in supporting collections and users, including library management systems and associated technologies.

Assessing and supporting the needs of users of library and information services, including issues of access and inclusion. Addressing the needs of disabled users and organising information for inclusive access.

Legislative frameworks supporting and affecting library and information services, including professionalism, ethics, copyright, licensing, etc.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETK-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Linear Algebra
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Vectors: Vector algebra. Vector geometry in 2D and 3D. Matrices: Matrix algebra. Operations on matrices including determinant, transpose, inverse. Linear Algebraic Systems: Representation by matrices. Existence and uniqueness of solutions. Solving linear systems using direct methods. Vector Space: Definition of vector space and subspace. Linear combination, linear independence, span, basis and dimension. Linear Transformations: Definition of general linear transformation. Matrix transformations. Properties of linear transformations. Null space, range, rank, nullity. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Eigenvalues, eigenvectors and eigenspaces of a linear transformation. Applications of eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETP-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Investigations in Mathematics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Functions : Properties of basic continuous functions, parametric functions, vector functions.

Concepts of limits and continuity.

Calculus: Differentiation from first principles, differentiation and integration techniques.

Power Series: Radius of convergence of power series, Taylor's theorem and Taylor's series. Parametric and vector equations of curves.

Applications may be drawn from a variety of fields such as biology, ecology, physics or finance, although no specialist knowledge of these areas is required to study the module.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIERL-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Working with Information
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• The nature of information. Data, meaning, messages, and knowledge. Theories of information
  • Concepts and skills in information search and retrieval. Using search engines. Navigating information spaces.
  • Documents. Structure and organisation. Text and hypertext. Graphics. Reference sources. Bibliometrics
  • Cataloguing. Introduction to cataloguing standards. AACR2 and MARC (including MARC 21). Use with books and other media types. Internet standards. Development of in-house cataloguing standards.
  • Classification. Classification principles, schemes and systems. Subject indexing. Knowledge management. Cataloguing and classification in library management and decision making.
  • WWW and web tools for organising, creating and delivering information. Markup and metadata. Electronic documents. Digital information standards.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIET6-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Information Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction

Information design as a combination of: graphic design and technical communication. Extensions to wayfinding, experience design, and interaction design. Information design as an emerging discipline.

Information and communication

Nature of information and communication. Signal processing and semiotic models. Syntactic, semantic and pragmatic dimensions of information. Concepts of markup and metadata.

Digitisation of information

Evolution of Unicode for character representation. Overview of encoding schemes for other forms of information, including pictures, graphics, and audio. Hypertext: linked networks of online documents. Evolution and use of the portable document format (PDF).

Graphical representations of information

Types of graphical representation: icons, charts, tables, graphs, diagrams, cartoons. Depicting quantities. Graphic tools for thinking and problem solving. Visual metaphors, explanations, and languages. Elements of graphic design. Balancing text and graphics. Adding interactivity.

Content design and creation

Creating information content for print and the Web. Approaches to document and site design. Relating content to context and users; contextual design. Designing content for relevance, accessibility and usability. Designing information displays and interaction; incorporating text, graphic, and multimedia elements. Navigation and navigability linking and labelling. Devising metadata to enable retrieval.

Practical work using software design tools

Creating and sharing PDF documents. Page design and layout for print. Image editing and manipulation. Creating vector graphics. Page design and layout for the Web. Adding animation and interactivity.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIET9-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Health and Social Care Information Services
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• The range and purposes of health and social care information services, with examples.
  • The context within which health and social care information services operate in the UK, including key government policies. Implications of contextual issues for library service management in health and social care.
  • The past, present and future of health and social care library and information provision in the NHS, Higher Education and social services.
  • Evidence based health and social care. What are the implications for library and information services?
  • Exploration of key health and social care information sources and resources.
  • Collection management and development in health and social care.
  • The role and status of information professionals in health and social care. Including exploring the competencies needed in the health / social care librarian.
  • Exploration of the user participation agenda, including services and sources of information for patients / service users.
  • Policy and management issues for library and information services in both health and social care settings.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQERE-20-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Foundation Mathematics: Trigonometry and Calculus (Distance)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Algebraic Manipulation:

Basic algebraic techniques such as transposition of formulae, factorization, completing the square, partial fractions and manipulation of exponential and log expressions

Properties of Functions:

Mappings, functions, composite functions, inverse functions, linear, quadratic and cubic polynomials, exponential and logarithmic functions.

Trigonometric Waveforms:

Trigonometric waveforms of the form Rcos(t+c) and Rsin(t+c). Definition of amplitude, phase, period and frequency. trigonometric identities, compound angle formulae. Solution of simple trigonometric equations.

Introduction to Differential Calculus:

The gradient of a function, use of tables to differentiate standard functions, standard rules of differentiation, product rule, quotient rule and chain rule, turning points, rate of change and acceleration. Identification and classification of turning points.

Introduction to Integral Calculus:

Integration as reversal of differentiation, use of tables to integrate standard functions, definite and indefinite integrals, calculation of the are of regions enclosed between curves.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEV3-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Interaction Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Understanding Users

  • Cognition and cognitive frameworks

Social mechanisms in communication and collaboration

  • Mechanisms for conversation, coordination and awareness
  • Group formation

Requirements analysis and specification for design of interactive systems

  • Interaction design specific requirements modelling - Stakeholder analysis, Task analysis, Rich pictures, Requirements tools
  • Integration of requirement analysis into the iterative design cycle - Participatory design, Prototype evaluation
  • Generation of formal requirement specifications for interactive systems - Task/function mapping, Prioritisation, Criteria setting

Exploration of different types of collaborative media for work, education, social interaction - communication, conferencing and collaborative management

  • Requirements analysis and specification in the context of different collaborative media
  • Social, Cultural, Organisational Aspects of collaborative media Inclusion, Diversity

Interface Design Principles

  • Screen design concepts and patterns, Visual Information Design, Mechanisms for supporting awareness and communication

Methods for analysing and evaluating group activity drawing on theories of collaboration and communication

  • Evaluation of Interaction Design of collaborative media
  • Integration and Blending of collaborative media with traditional (face-to-face) practices

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEAK-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Finite Element Analysis
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Introduction to Finite Element Analysis: overview of FEA applications, nodes, elements, meshes, stiffness matrix, boundary conditions - loads and restraints.

2. Hardware, software and systems design: selection and use, limitations/advantages.

3. Practical FE modelling techniques: eg: techniques, planning your model, pre-processing, model solution, post processing, idealisation and discretisation, symmetry, convergence tests, boundary conditions, element types/selection, co-ordinate systems, bandwidth, mesh creation.

4. Matrix methods of structural analysis: introduction to matrix algebra, matrix displacement method, rods, pin-jointed trusses, beams, introduction to continuum structures.

5. Overview of advanced uses of FEA: Structural dynamics, non-linear analysis, fatigue and fracture mechanics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEAT-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Mechanics of Materials
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Experimental mechanics, Composites materials Fracture mechanics, Fatigue, Shear flow analysis, Torsion of non circular sections, Energy Method, Superposition method for slope and defection analysis of determinate and indeterminate beams.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEAU-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Thermofluid Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Fluid machine design - Euler's theory for constant density and compressible flow machines - pumps, turbines, fans, compressors. Other design factors. Differences from this theory.

Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Systems - Basic cycle analysis, performance assessment.

Multiphase Flows - Prediction of pressure drops in liquid/vapour systems. Condensing and Boiling heat transfer.

Transient flows - The hierachy of analysis. Quasi-steady flow, Rigid column theory,. Derivation and solution of equations for rapid events. Graphical technique, Method of Characteristics.

Introduction to computational fluid dynamics - Derivation of Navier Stokes equations. Analytical solution for simple geometry. Turbulence, discretisation, Boundaries, Geometry and meshing. Solution examples chosen from other areas of the course.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEAW-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Dynamics, Noise & Vibration
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Approaches to simplification of realistic dynamic problems.

Multi degree of freedom systems, lumped mass approach.

Solution approaches (frequency domain & time domain).

Excitation devices and measurement transducers.

Theoretical and experimental modal analysis.

Signal processing and frequency analysis (Fourier).

Random vibration.

Nonlinear behaviour.

Continuous systems and acoustics.

Practical examples and applications.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBC-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Aero-Propulsion
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Propulsion systems: energy sources; propulsors; combinations; most common examples. Momentum theory: vector equations and diagrams; scalar forms; specific examples; propulsive efficiency.

Compressible duct flow: speed of sound; isentropic flow; effects of area change at sub-, trans- and supersonic Mach numbers; convergent-divergent ducts; nozzle expansion ratios; intake mass flow requirements.

Thermodynamics: engine cycles; ideal and real gas turbine cycles; component efficiencies; cycle calculations; use of results.

Combustion: fuel and combustion chemistry; fuel-air mixtures; engine limits. Airscrew theory: Froude momentum model; blade aerodynamics.

Component design features: intakes; compressors; combustion systems; turbines; quasi-non-dimensional parameters.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBK-10-0
rdf:Description.p:title: Foundation Laboratory Programme
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Programming of robots Assembly and test of electronic circuits Investigation of mechanical systems

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBP-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Structural Integrity in Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design brief

failure assessment and structural integrity

design integrity in the industry

design solutions using embodiment, detail drawing and analytic calculations

Computer Aided Drawing using IDEAS and identifying possible areas of design weaknesses

Numerical simulations (finite element analysis) of the design solution using IDEAS software

Assessment of the structural strength in critical areas and possible failure modes

Modifying the initial designs and repeat the design cycle of the component.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBT-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Dynamics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Rigid body motion: Vector methods for velocity, acceleration and displacement assessment; Introduction to numerical methods; Application of closed and open mechanisms in 2-D and 3-D.

Vibration/Oscillation/Sound: Single degree of freedom: free and forced, undamped and damped; Two degree of freedom: free, undamped; Introduction to numerical methods; Principles of vibration measurements; Wave equation (1-D): derivation, standing waves; introduction to 3-D waves;

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBU-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Heat Transfer
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction to the basic mechanisms : conduction, forced and natural convection, radiation.

Conduction in 1-D for slabs and circular geometry.

Use and meaning of the term heat transfer coefficient (HTC). Use of dimensional analysis in the determination of forced convection HTCs. Application to steady heat transfer in the design and operation of heat exchangers.

Use of dimensional analysis in the prediction of natural convection HTCs.

2/3-D heat transfer- shape factors, numerical solution of governing differential equations. Finite difference, element techniques for heat conduction. The use of extended surface for enhanced heat transfer.

Unsteady heat flow.

Radiation heat transfer, black bodies, grey bodies, wavelength effects. Radiation parameters. Kirchoff's law. Black body radiation. View factors and their determination by various methods. Grey body radiation for case where view factors unity.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMECG-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Inspection and Test
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Destructive and Non-destructive testing. Significance and applicability of Standards. Relationship to quality assurance.

Destructive testing: for design, e.g. tensile, fracture toughness, fatigue, creep, corrosion; for quality control, e.g. hardness, impact, cupping, proof testing.

Origins of defects: production; fabrication; in-service. Significance of defects. Non-destructive evaluation (NDE). Damage tolerance methodology. Probability and inspection.

Non-destructive testing techniques, including dye penetrant, magnetic particle, eddy current, ultrasonic, radiography.

Principles of inspection using co-ordinate measuring machines; including CMM and scanning machines.

Data capture systems; including contact and non-contact methods, analogue and digital probes. Errors associated with each method. Probe compensations and the use of geometric models to correct inspection data.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMECK-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Aerospace Materials
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Analysis of the origin of mechanical and thermal properties of metals, ceramics and polymers.

The principal strengthening mechanisms in metallic alloys, particularly aluminium, titanium and nickel alloys. Properties and processing of these alloys, including single crystal technology and superplastic forming. Potential of intermetallics.

High performance polymeric systems. Molecular structure and temperature/stress limits.

Potential of ceramic systems, such as silicon nitride and silicon carbide.

The use of composite systems; fibre reinforced polymers, metal matrix composites and ceramic matrix composites. Processing and use of high performance fibres such as graphite, boron, aramid, silicon carbide. Composite manufacturing processes.

Surface engineering.

Development of smart materials and structures.

Particular requirements for space applications. Operating in high vacuum and high radiation environments.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMERC-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Aircraft Structures
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Construction methods: e.g. stressed skin, frames, formers, stringers. attachment methods of mainplanes, engines, empennage, control surfaces. Assembly techniques, rivetting, bolting, bonding. protection, chromating, anodising, painting. Airworthiness structural requirements: e.g. structural classification, zonal and station identification. stress / strain, tension / compression, bending, torsion. damage tolerance concepts, safe life, fail safe, condition monitoring

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDC-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: CAD/CAM Applications
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The syllabus aims to provide: Understanding of the power and flexibility of advanced CAD and CAM software, hardware and methodologies. An introduction to solid modelling. Illustrations of the use of CAD based geometry as the basis of complementary engineering activities (e.g. modelling of strain for load-bearing parts). A description of techniques associated with Computer Aided Manufacturing, CNC part programming, Tooling, and Inspection. The development of a 3D CAD solid model of a part, and CAM programs for machining the modelled part. Demonstrations of the integration between design and manufacture.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEE5-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Actuators and Control
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The syllabus may include but not be limited to the followings:

ELECTRIC ATUATORS including:

AC, DC and stepper motors; Commutation and electronic switching; Brushed and brushless motors; Pulse wave modulation and drives system.

PNEUMATIC and HYRAULICS ACTUATORS including:

Cylinders; single and double acting; Rotary actuators; Pressure and Flow regulators; Solenoid valves, proportional valves and circuits; Proportional control valves; NOVEL ACTUTORS.

MODELLING AND CONTROL

Introduction to matlab and application of simulink; Motor selection, response and modelling.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEEG-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Manufacturing Systems Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Overview and history of manufacturing systems.

Relationship between manufacturing and the business, the strategic role of manufacturing and the need for focused manufacturing.

The structure of manufacturing resources and plant layout, comparative evaluations of job shops, batch production, continuous flow systems and group technology, strengths and limitations of these structures.

Scheduling; infinite and finite scheduling methods.

Forecasting; simple averaging, exponential smoothing, multi-exponential smoothing.

Queuing systems and lead times. Line balancing methods.

Formal methods for manufacturing systems analysis and design including an introduction to simulation and modelling methods.

Role and contribution of IT systems in the design and operation of manufacturing systems.

Selection of process systems and manufacturing methods, use of automation and robotic systems, critique of automated assembly and production systems.

Design life-cycles, concurrent engineering objectives, principles and approaches, evaluation of DFX tools: for example, design for manufacture/assembly methods, review of current research issues and future directions.

Review of the latest industry and research developments.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPERX-30-3
rdf:Description.p:title: MEng Individual Project part A
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Project selection: connection with departmental research and industrial placement.

Project proposal: produced by student with advice from supervisor.

Project execution: monitored by supervisor.

Project presentation: written report.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEQ8-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematics for Signal Analysis and Control
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Fourier Series: periodic functions and fundamental period, definition and computation of Fourier series, convergence of Fourier series, Fourier series of odd and even functions, half-range Fourier series, translation of axes, complex notation, amplitude and phase spectra.

2. Fourier Transforms: definition of the Fourier transform, spectra, properties of the Fourier transform, inverse Fourier transform, convolution.

3. Laplace Transforms: definition, manipulation, standard transforms, inverse transform, solution of linear differential equations, transfer functions, initial and final value theorems, Laplace transform of special functions, convolution.

4. Z Transforms: definition of a z transform, sampling, properties of a z transform, inverse z transform, solving difference equations, z transfer function.

5. Systems of linear differential equations: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors, solution using eigenvalues and eigenvectors, system stability (definition and determination via eigenvalues); solution via Laplace transform, poles and system stability.

6. Control theory: state-space models, transfer-function, matrix solution via Laplace transform, poles and system stability.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEJQ-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Mechanical Design Simulation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Experimental Mechanics. Composite material simulation and laminate theory. Practical Finite Element Analysis (FEA). Working Model 2D & 3D. Application of Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) in engineering.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEVA-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Working and Professional Practice 1
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Using traditional and online information sources: primary and secondary, online research techniques; referencing systems: Harvard, literacy reviews.

Documentation conventions in business: writing for different audiences; glossary of terms; reports; user guides, project documentation.

Identifying job roles in IT: employability preparation; Job descriptions; targeted CV writing; time management; coping with change; decision-making and problem solving.

Technical and social environment of work: case studies; organisational structures; meaning of work; professionalism.

Communication and Teamwork; discussion and presentation techniques: verbal and non-verbal communication; conducting observations; team roles and group dynamics (Belbin and Tuckman); managing conflict in teams; interview techniques; negotiation and assertion; learning styles.

Personal Action planning: setting SMART targets; reviewing progress; analytical tools: SWOT, PMI, brainstorming, mind mapping; reflection and journal writing, Kolb learning cycle; British Computing Society.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEKA-10-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Design Context
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: This course is a chronological and focused study of the emergence and development of product design from 1800 to the present day. It includes investigation of products as an aspect of our culture/society/commerce/ industry and examines consumer products within the context of the changes taking place in industry and society.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEKY-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Aerospace Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Review of major aerospace systems and issues relating to performance system safety and Certification.

Engineering systems definition and development processes.

Customer requirements generation, tracking and conflict management.

Mapping of requirements to functions, systems and components.

Validation and verification in the development process.

Introduction to requirements capture and management tools.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE78-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Mobile Communications
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEE7R-20-2 OR UFEE7S-30-2 OR UFEE75-30-2 OR UFEE76-30-2 OR UFEEK6-20-2)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Wireless Transmission: Frequencies for Radio Transmission, Signals, Antennas, Signal Propagation, Multiplexing, Modulation, Spread Spectrum, Cellular Systems

Medium Access Control: SDMA, FDMA, TDMA, CDMA. Evaluation and comparison of MAC techniques.

Mobile Telecommunication Systems and Standards: GSM, DECT, TETRA, UMTS and IMT-2000: architectures, protocols and performance.

Satellite Systems: Fundamental principles of satellite communication. Routing, Localization, Handover, Application examples.

Wireless ATM: WATM Services, Reference Model, Functions, Radio Access Layer, Handover, Location Management, Addressing, Mobile Quality of Service, Access Point Protocol

Mobile Network Layer: Mobile IP, Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol, Ad Hoc Networks.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMENA-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Digital Design Skills
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: This module provides an introduction to the technology of computing and information presentation as it relates to the practice of product design. The module explores issues around graphic communication and the relevant computer software used by product designers in the expression of their ideas. This may include raster, vector based or animation programs.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMENU-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Design of Fluid Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Design hierarchy for fluid and thermal systems Finite

- Origins of the governing equations

- Analytical solutions and their shortcomings

- Difference method. Application to governing equations. Numerical stability

- Issues involved in obtaining solutions from software packages. Typical example(s)

- Critical appraisal of solutions

- Complementary experimental techniques

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQH-40-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Motorsport Applications Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Propulsion

Introduction to the basic mechanisms of Heat Transfer: conduction, forced and natural convection, radiation. Conduction in 1-D for slabs and circular geometry. Use and meaning of the term heat transfer coefficient (HTC). Use of dimensional analysis in the determination of forced convection HTCs. Application to steady heat transfer in the design and operation of heat exchangers. Cooling mechanisms (radiators; oil coolers; intercoolers).

Introduction to the use of 2/3-D heat transfer-shape factors, numerical solution of governing differential equations. Finite difference, element techniques for heat conduction. The use of extended surface for enhanced heat transfer. Power production processes-Entropy, its meaning and effect on thermodynamic work and heat transfer processes.

The thermodynamic cycle in power production. The chemistry of combustion reactants, products and pollutants. Heat release and the prediction of temperatures generated. The air standard cycle; the Otto cycle. Implementation in different engine types. Combustion and heat transfer; thermal, volumetric and mechanical efficiency. Fuelling and ignition systems. Engine design consideration. Alternative power sources and hybrids. Gas flows through engines and manifolds. Intakes and exhaust systems (steady flow approximation). Fundamentals of test and measurement, data acquisition and interpretation.

Chassis Engineering

Stress analysis, Strain analysis, Mohrs circle for stress, strain and section property, Rosette analysis, Section properties, Un-symmetric bending, Buckling of Struts. Introduction to aerodynamics of vehicles. Low-speed aerodynamics: flow over an aerofoil; effects of angle of attack; vorticity. Forces on an aerofoil: force and moment coefficients; effects of lift on drag and pitching moment; aerodynamic centre and centre of pressure. Wind tunnel design and operation; data acquisition and processing; standard representations; flow visualisation techniques; similarities and differences between low-speed and high speed facilities.

Dynamics of rigid body motion. Vector methods for velocity, acceleration and displacement assessment; Introduction to numerical methods; application of closed and open mechanisms in 2-D. Dynamics of suspension systems, roadholding. Vibration, Oscillation and Sound. Single degree of freedom: free and forced, undamped and damped; Two degree of freedom; free, undamped; introduction to numerical methods; Principles of vibration measurements; Wave equation (1-D); derivation, standing waves; introduction to 3-D waves.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQJ-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Aero-Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design requirements and airworthiness, Design Analysis

Aircraft Construction, structural elements, jointing, manufacturing and costing.

Buckling of compression and shear members, principles of stressed skin construction. Bending and torsion of thin-walled box beam structures to meet required stress and stiffness limitations.

Fatigue and fracture mechanics analysis, Fatigue and Safe Life Design, effects of manufacturing processes on fatigue life.

Materials selection for strength and stiffness, stress analysis of fibrous composites.

Linear Momentum Equation and Hydrodynamics Forces.

Engineering Applications: Force required to restrain a Convergent Nozzle, Rocket Engine Thrust, Turbojet Engine Thrust, Flow Through a Sudden Enlargement, Jet Pump/Ejector/Injector, Turbofan-Engine Thrust, Reaction Force on a Pipe Bend, Reaction Force on a Pipe Junction, Flow Through a Cascade of Guidevanes, Jet Impinging on a Flat Plate.

Turbojet/Turbofan

Shaft Power Cycles

Turbojet/Turbofan - Performance

Heat Transfer and Cooling Blade Cooling Performance

Combustion

Compressible Flows

Introduction to Helicopters

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEERT-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: WinCE Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• WinCE architecture as an example of an advanced RTX
  • A structural and functional description of the system
  • Development environment and tools
  • The WinCE device driver model
  • Support for multi-tasking and multi-threading
  • The file system
  • Choosing a target platform
  • Specifying a Board Support Package
  • Configuring and installing onto a new target, Platform Builder
  • Application development for Win32
  • Graphics and sound

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQL-10-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Avionic Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Design Concepts:

Operability, maintainability, reliability, testability, flight criticality, fail safety.

- Design Process:

Configuration management, international standards and design verification.

- Avionics - The commercial and military environment:

Operational requirements and how they emerge. Product life cycle. Logistics and life cycle costs.

- Avionics Systems Engineering:

System partitioning, hardware and software integrity. Flight criticality. Data transmission standards and methods.

- Avionic Design Process:

Hard and software configuration control.

- Avionics Systems:

Radar - airborne systems. Radio - airborne communications systems. Navigation - long range, short range and terminal area guidance systems. Flight control - autostabilisers and autopilot systems. Sensors - attitude, position, rate, air data, etc. Displays - electromechanical, solid-state and head-up.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQN-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Design and Realisation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design and realisation aims to have a positive influence on design ability by individual or group projects that promote lateral, cross-disciplinary thinking. This module develops student innovation and importantly helps to develop a relevant and appropriate mind and skills set for the 21st century design practitioner.

This module addresses important design issues such as modelling, analysis, prototyping and presentation of final design considering aesthetic, engineering and marketing aspects. This module also focuses on safety, standards, governmental and international legislations related to product design.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIEUS-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Web Programming
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design Patterns in software design (object-oriented & functional); architecture (systems design); design (component interactions); programming idioms (language-specific techniques/style).

Model-View-Controller (MVC) based systems - paradigms and architecture.

Model data representation, data validation and data state management and backup. (Application Layer).

View GUI, visualization of model (Presentation Layer).

Controller - manage business rules, change (update) model, control inputs and outputs, transaction management (Business Logic Layer).

Web 2.0 applications, web services and the model-view-controller framework.

Communication between components: Naming & Namespacing, addressing and binding; Communication protocols; Message data formats including SOAP and REST; Communication failure semantics and synchronicity.

Implementation technologies: PHP (main focus), XForms and Rails; .NET, SOAP, REST.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEBL-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Aircraft Structural Design & Stress Analysis
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The module comprises the following:-

- Design requirements for aircraft structures

- Aircraft materials and selection criteria
