- Basic design using unidirectional fibrous composites

- Stress-strain data, specific values

- Fracture toughness, crack growth, designing for fatigue failure

- Loading actions, bending, torsion and shear

- Thin walled open and closed beams, bending and torsion effects

- Buckling, Euler struts, effect of slenderness ratio

- Plate design formulae, skin stringer panels, shear webs

- Two-dimensional stress and strain, principal values, yield criteria

- Aircraft shell structures and section idealisation

- Introduction to the finite element analysis

- Experimental mechanics and Photostress analysis

- Structural loads during flight test

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQX-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Materials Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Alloying of metals, solid solutions, cooling curves, phase diagrams and non-equilibrium effects, e.g. coring

Iron carbon diagram, microstructures of plain carbon steels

Non-equilibrium transformation of austenite, TTT and CCC diagrams, mass effect, Jominy End Quench, hardenabillity

Polymer structures, crystallinity, glass transition, visco-elasticity and plasticity

Plastic deformation of metals, slip planes/directions, slip systems and dislocation movement

Effects of cold working on a metals physical/mechanical properties

Failure of metals: ductile/brittle, stress concentrations, crack propagation, critical crack length

Composite materials: definitions, matrix materials, reinforcement materials, properties, fibre orientation, methods of manufacture

Corrosion studies: corrosion cells, types of corrosion, protection and prevention: coatings, appropriate metal combinations, cathodic protection and structural design

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQY-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Mechanical Principles 1
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Stress and Strain e.g. Poissons ratio. Two and tree dimensional loading. Volumetric strain

Elastic Constants, e.g. Bulk Modulus

Stresses in thick and thin wall pressure vessels, e.g. spherical vessels subjected to internal and external pressure. Lame theory. Beam Analysis - McCaulay's Theorem

Dynamics, power transmission, e.g.analysis of energy stored in flywheels, belt drives and clutches, Dalbys method for determining out of balance force

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMER5-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Thermofluids
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Introduction to units and problem solving techniques. Hydrostatics, Bernoulli's equation, flow measurement, dimensional analysis, laminar and turbulent flow, fluid flow with friction, viscous drag, drag coefficients, introductory aerodynamics. Work, heat and energy, open and closed systems, gas laws, fluid properties. Isothermal and Adiabatic processes. Performance characteristics of Carnot, Rankine cycles. Circuit and property diagrams for steam and gas turbines

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMER7-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Mechanical Principles 2
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Stress analysis: complex stress, combined torsion and axial thrust, combined torsion and bending, analysis of 2D stress systems, Mohrs stress circle. Complex strain, Mohrs strain circle. Beam theory, Macaulays method. Struts, Buckling criteria, Euler and Rankine-Gordon formula. system dynamics: plane mechanisms, velocity diagrams. Geared systems, screw drives and jacks, flywheels; turning moment diagrams. gyroscopic motion; rigidity, precession, reaction torque, applications.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESB-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Aerospace Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Understanding the processes: from conceptual to intermediate to detailed design, design cycles, single and multidisciplinary (cross-disciplinary) aspects.

For aircraft design: Weights, loads, design of wing, fuselage, tail. Engine selection, take-off and landing, enhanced lift, structural design and material selection, performance, static stability, dynamic stability, control (direct and autonomous), cost estimation.

For spacecraft design: mission classes, atmospheric entry, attitude determination, thermal control, power and telecommunications.

Design optimisation (direct, adjoint and inverse) methods, response surface methods, trade studies.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESC-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Aeroelasticity
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFMEBS-15-2 AND UFMEBT-15-2 AND UFMEBV-30-2 AND UFQEFB-20-2)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Aeroelastic phenomena can be classified as either static or dynamics. This module will provide a description of both.

first one and most common to all flight vehicles is the effect of elastic deformation on the air loads associated with normal operating conditions. These effects can have a huge influence on the performance, handling qualities, flight stability and structural load distribution.

The second part of this module is devoted to dynamic aeroelasticity, especially to 2 phenomena the buffet and the flutter.

Unsteady interaction called buffet may appear on an airfoil in transonic flow with massive separation. In 2-D flow, this unsteady phenomena caused by the interaction between the shock on the upper surface and the separation characterized by a main frequency corresponding to the shock movement and the pulsation of the separation.

The flutter is a rapid self-exited motion starting when a lifting surface, such as a wing, bends under aerodynamic load. The elasticity of the structure means that the load is reduced the structure springs back so far that it overshoots and causes a new aerodynamic load in the opposite direction to the original. This type of instability could lead to a catastrophic structure failure of the aircraft. It is therefore obvious that any investigation of buffet and flutter require a good understanding of the systems structural dynamics and aerodynamic properties.

  1. Static Aeroelasticity - Uniform Lifting surface, equilibrium equation, torsional divergence, air-load distribution
  2. Aeroelastic buffet - Description (Floquets theory), linearization of the pitching equation, generalization of the equation, stability characteristics, resonance, analysis
  3. Aeroelastic Flutter - Stability characteristics, classical flutter analysis (one-degree of freedom flutter and 2- degree of freedom flutter), Engineering solutions for flutter based on the k method and the p-k method.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESE-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Science for Engineers
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Static engineering systems

Pin-jointed framed structures: classification of members, conditions for internal equilibrium, determination of magnitude and nature of the primary forces in the members by graphical and analytical methods.

Simply supported beams: simply supported beams and simple cantilevers with concentrated and uniformly distributed loads, determination and graphical representation of shear force and bending moment and the relationship between them.

Beams and columns: engineers bending theory, calculation of second moments of area, offset loading of columns.

Torsion in circular shafts: engineering torsion theory, polar second moment of area.

Dynamic engineering systems

Uniform acceleration: linear and angular acceleration; mass moment of inertia and radius of gyration; combined linear and angular motion; effects of friction.

Energy transfer: types of energy; conservation of energy; work-energy transfer; impact loading.

Oscillating mechanical systems: simple harmonic motion; linear and transverse systems; effects of forcing and damping.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESF-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Manufacturing Processes
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Conventional machining

Component manufacture: specify components for manufacture

Machining techniques: production of flat and cylindrical geometry

Tooling requirements: multi-tooth and single-point cutting; cutting angles; coolants and cutting fluids

Work-holding techniques: appropriate work-holding devices and their limitations; health and safety issues

Moulding and shaping

Component manufacture: specify components for moulding and shaping

Moulding processes: casting; powder metallurgy; sintering

Shaping processes: extrusion; forging; rolling; hot and cold presswork; metal spinning

Ceramic materials: range applicable to component

Material properties: potential structure/property changes due to moulding or shaping operations

Tooling requirements: required tooling and equipment; press tools, punches, dies, etc; press capacity and calculations

Non-conventional machining

Component manufacture: principle of operation of the non-conventional machining techniques; specification of components for non-conventional machining techniques

Tooling requirements: required tooling and ancillary equipment; work-holding techniques; health and safety issues

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESH-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Mechanical Principles
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Complex loading systems

definition of Poissons ratio and typical values; two and three-dimensional loading: Volumetric strain: and calculation of volume change: definition of Bulk and Shear Moduli and relationships.

2. Loaded beams and cylinders

slope and deflection for loaded beams; hoop longitudinal and radial stress in thick and thin walled cylindrical and spherical pressure vessels; Lames theory.

3. Power transmission

flat and v-section belt drives; flat single and multi-plate clutches; conical clutches; constant wear and constant pressure theories: simple, compound and epicycle gear trains; torque, speed and power relationships.

4. Dynamics of rotating systems

determination of relationships between velocity, acceleration, power and efficiency for single and multi-link mechanisms, rotating mass systems; Dalbys method; flywheels.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESN-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Business Management Techniques
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Costing: systems and techniques

Differing types of costing systems including job, process and contract costing. Costing techniques including absorption, marginal and activity-based. Application within engineering design, manufacturing and services. Costing techniques for measurement and evaluation of the effectiveness of changing business activity levels.

2. Financial planning and control

Short, medium, and long-term financial planning: strategic and operational plans, financial objectives, organisational strategy. Influential factors including working capital management, credit control, pricing, cost reduction, expansion and contraction, company valuation, capital investment. Budgetary planning: fixed, flexible and zero-based systems, cost, allocation, revenue, capital, control, incremental budgeting.

3. Project management techniques

Planning and production control - bar charts, network analysis precedence and arrow diagrams and time/chainage programming. Time and resource scheduling. Critical path analysis. Use and application of project management software.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESQ-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Students will be introduced to design process models and practice and their application in synthesising a design solution to engineering problems. They will be encouraged to think creatively and apply problem solving techniques to develop a design solution to a number of engineering problem of increasing complexity. A minimum of two problems will be addressed: the first being an individual piece of work and the second a group activity together they will form a design portfolio. Where possible the projects will be based on real examples.

The syllabus will follow the following guidelines but the emphasis will depend on the nature of the chosen project work:

1. Selection and specification of project

Consider project specification parameters such as cost, timescale, materials, standards, purpose, function. Feasibility study. For the group project - agree roles and allocate responsibilities, agree timescales, meetings and recording methods.

2. Implementation

Undertake the project using appropriate methodology, drawing on knowledge gained in previous study. Brainstorm and consider alternative solutions. Use analytical methods, utilise graphical displays, apply statistical methods, consider quality and resource requirements, fitness for purpose etc. Construct physical and computer models to narrow down choice of design alternatives. Prepare outline design specifications. Formulate and propose a design solution which could be developed to the full design stage.

3. Evaluation

Critically evaluate the proposed solution. Consider manufacturing processes and use evaluation techniques incorporating, for example, statistics, Gantt charts, critical path analysis, networking, simple application of Project Evaluation and Review Techniques using computer software packages where appropriate.

4. Presentation

The individual work will be presented in the form of a written report. Each group will present its design solution in the form of a poster presentation supported by a written technical report, drawings, models, a log book of activities and a defence of its proposals. The defence will be addressed to a team of academic staff and invited industrialists.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESS-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Work-based Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is completely work-based. The student will be required, through negotiation with the academic tutor and the industrial (workplace) supervisor to identify a suitable area for work. The student will work on the project in the workplace and will be visited on a regular basis by the academic tutor. The student will have bi-weekly timetabled peer group meetings in college in order to reflect on and further plan for the project. These times may also be used to introduce appropriately requested information by the academic tutor.

The student will be expected to maintain a logbook of all relevant information, ideas, designs, tests, results and analysis arising from the project. The work will culminate in a presentation and production of a fully documented report. Students will be given written guidelines on the required structure of the project report.

Interim progress will be assessed by the supervisor based on a short interim report, with reference to the agreed project brief and project plan. This report will be submitted at a point approximately half-way through the project.

Continuous assessment, of all aspects of the student's work on the project, will be the made by the supervisor based on regular discussions with the student and using the logbook as a reference. Assessment of the content and quality of the final report will be made by the academic tutor with reference to the workplace supervisor. This assessment will concentrate on the report as a piece of technical communication. The report may include supplementary information such as drawings.

Assessment of the student's final oral presentation will be made by the academic tutor and by another member of staff acting independently. It will be assessed for its effectiveness as a means of communication rather than for its technical content.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMESV-15-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced CAD
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Modify and update

Drawing files: load and create a drawing file from source, including IGES and DXF files, which a learner should understand and edit.

Blocks: access externally and internally referenced blocks; update and insert new blocks; use editing commands to modify existing parts.

Record modifications: update the drawing and record modifications; produce updated documentation using a word-processing package with inserted views relating to modifications.

Produce hard copy: produce hard copy of updated drawing using scaled plots, scaled views, different printer/plotters and reconfiguring CAD software to suit.

2. Surface model

Co-ordinate systems: manipulate the user co-ordinate system (UCS) and world co-ordinate system (WCS) to suit required geometry.

Correct geometry: using polylines to construct shapes for surfacing and constructing splines; using polyedit to restructure line/arcs into continuous geometry.

Surface construction: generate the bounded geometry required for any surface; using this geometry create surfaces; all methods of surface construction should be used, with reference to Bezier, Nurbs, Patch and Coons, to test best construction methods.

Facet numbers: numbers required to smooth surface; memory problems using high numbers of facets.

Viewing medium: the use of Hide, Shade and Render to visualise the product; print or plot finish drawing; the use of different textures; lighting controls.

3. Solid model

Co-ordinate systems: manipulate the user co-ordinate system (UCS) and world co-ordinate system (WCS) to suit required geometry.

Solid model: using polylines to construct shapes for extruding, using polyedit to restructure line/arcs into continuous geometry; the use of Hide, Shade and Render to visualise the product; applying various materials to generated slides; cutting the solids and sectioning; different lighting; textures.

Construction techniques: the effects of subtract, union, intersect extrude, sweep and revolve in model construction; editing the geometry using fillet, chamfer etc; using primitives to create geometry.

Properties of solids: using solid model to find the mass, radius of gyration, centre of gravity and surface area.

Printing image: generating image

Dimension a solid: dimensions are correctly added to a solid composite drawing in multiscreen mode; dimensions are correctly added to true shapes previously extracted from solid composite.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQELK-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistical Problem Solving
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The principles of tackling real-life quantitative problems The stages of an investigation, formulating the problem, types of study. Strategies for analysing data, initial examination of data, including an introduction to statistical modelling. Sources of data, methods of data collection. Using descriptive statistical methods for the initial data examination (IDA). Data screening.

Using the internet and library resources for research The use of the internet as a research tool. Evaluation of internet resources. Finding and using secondary data on the internet and in the library.

Writing effective reports Structure, layout and formatting of statistical reports. Effective use and presentation of statistical graphs and tables. Methods of avoiding plagiarism through quoting and referencing.

Making presentations Oral presentations: planning, timing, using visual aids. Poster presentations.

Using Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, Powerpoint) Making use of the full functionality of Microsoft Word, Excel and Powerpoint - use of the equation editor, tables, Excel graphics, functions and macros. The strengths and weaknesses of Excel and Minitab for statistical analysis. An introduction to Visual Basic.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEUY-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Control Systems Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
System Analysis

System modelling and behaviour.

Definition of linear and non-linear systems; linear modelling of systems of differing orders and complexities.

Laplace transforms: definition; transforms of common signals; use of tables; solution of ordinary differential equations.

System performance in the time domain, pole/zero diagrams; network time response; forced and natural modes; time constant; stability; second order response; use of second order response chart.

Frequency response: frequency response from Laplace transfer function; bandwidth in relation to time constant; definition of dB; Bode plots with straight line approximation; Nyquist plots, resonance.

System identification: identification of transfer functions from system time and frequency responses.

Routh-Hurwitz stability criterion.

Introduction to non-linearities in systems.

Introduction to Signals: instrumentation; actuation; systems of differing order.

Systems Electronics: operational amplifiers; network analysis; PLC network analysis using Laplace transforms; step and sinusoidal response.

System representation in a computer simulation environment.

Control Systems

Introduction: need for automatic control; examples such as amplifiers, machine tools, aircraft, the eye, the economy; open and closed loop; servo and regulator control; plant, actuator, sensor, controller.

Feedback control design: dominant poles; design of P, PI, PID, IP and IDP controller using pole placement regulator control.

Frequency domain controller design: Nyquist stability criterion; gai and phase margin; design of a phase shift controller.

Approaches to non-linear control; systems representation, analysis and control in simulation packages; introduction to Stochastic Optimal Control, Introduction to Fuzzy Logic Controllers and other technologies.

Robust Control of Systems

Critical system control strategies; failure mode mitigation; robust digital control systems for aircraft and plant; integrity, redundancy and diversity.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPE6D-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Project Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Projects and stakeholders: Understanding business strategies and the role of projects in implementing strategies. The role of quality control and its relationship to risk and its close association with stakeholder requirements. Knowing the contents of a quality plan and factors that affect quality. Customers requirements analysis and capture.

Project Team: The role of the project manager; typical group and team structures; qualities and skills of managers; team dynamics; leadership and management qualities. Project team structures. Team-building and motivating integrated human activity. Decision making and uncertainty.

Project Planning: Establishing what the planning criteria are, the use of work breakdown structures (WBS), milestones, deliverables, activity planning and considerations of team size. Understanding the project life-cycle. Feasibility studies. Problem and goal setting. Cost-schedule control systems. Estimating and pricing.. Multiple criteria decision methods. Critical paths and risk analysis. Computer-aided project control techniques.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEB6-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Professional and Communication Skills
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Five projects, each supporting different combinations of learning outcomes.

1. Working in groups, using creative thinking and oral presentation skills.

2. Use of information research skills, both library- and PC-based, to word process a report, including professional standards of referencing.

3. Use of spreadsheets. To develop skills from simple use of labels, values and formulae, to generation of reports, charts, summaries and use of what-if function. Use of the plan, build, test and document cycle.

4. Working in groups, with weekly project management meetings and deadlines, to produce a report.

5. Consolidation of skills acquired earlier in the course to work in groups to research and present information in a variety of contexts within the same time period (for example, a presentation, poster and handbook).

As the aims of this module are to assist students to develop skills, the specific content of each project is given as an indication only. It may be necessary to change the emphasis of the teaching to reflect the prior experience of the students.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE65-10-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Physical Principles of Music
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. The operation and fundamental limitations of the human hearing system.

2. The perception of pitch, musical notes, intervals and scales, consonance and dissonance.

3. Exciter-resonator forms.

4. The fundamental physics of instruments based on air columns, strings, membranes, bars and plates. The human voice.

5. Basic room acoustics

6. Introduction to psychoacoustics

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: USPJDL-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Issues in the Psychology of Education

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE7G-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Behavioural System Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
BASIC BUILDING BLOCKS Entity, architecture, signals, identifiers.

VHDL MENTOR TOOLS. Modelsim & Qicksim II design environment. VHDL debug and simulation.

STRUCTURAL VHDL. Component declaration, instantiation and configuration.

TESTING VHDL DESCRIPTIONS. Test bench and VHDL test bench styles.

VHDL TYPES. Types, arrays, records, file types, file conversion and IEEE Standard types.

GENERICS, DEFAULT VALUES, and OPEN PORT. Generics, Default Values and Unconnected Ports.

PACKAGES, LIBRARIES and DESIGN UNITS. Package use and visibility. Predefined packages.

DATAFLOW DESCRIPTION of VHDL. Signals, variables, attributes, expressions and operators. Modelling state machines.

BEHAVIOURAL DESCRIPTION of VHDL. Concurrent execution: procedures, functions. Sequential execution statements.

CONCURRENT EVALUATION. Delta Delays. Inter-process communication.

VHDL TIMING MODEL and TEXTIO. Transport and internal delay models.

RESOLUTION FUNCTIONS. Resolution and Null drivers.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDV-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Human Factors in Aerospace Design for Operations
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The module comprises the following:

- The status of human factors in the contemporary aerospace industry, the safety imperative

- Human performance: causes of error, the cognitive, qualitative and quantitative approaches

- Human factors in aerospace design: the design of systems, the flight deck; design for maintenance, for cabin crew, for other support; criteria for qualification and certification

- Organisational approach: safety culture, intercultural factors, crew resource management and organisational management

- Analysis of aviation accidents: case study evaluation for human factors in design for safety

Syndicate exercises applying the techniques, deriving key human factors implications.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEVC-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Design Fundamentals
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The course revolves around the student learning the generic process of design, experienced through a series of projects. The concepts of exploratory design research, co-design, sketching, iterative design, brief interpretation, inclusivity and creativity will be covered as well as project-specific material. Generic design processes and their application across different disciplines will be explored. Creative problem solving and collaborative analytical techniques will be taught. The module teaching will be grounded, experientially in the practical aspects of typical design projects: client handling, personal time management, group dynamics and project management, communication of design proposals and integration of client feedback.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEUG-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Flight Test Principles & Practices
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Measurement of airspeed, pressure errors
  • Trials planning, reporting and risk assessment
  • Flight test instrumentation
  • Avionic systems testing
  • Performance flight testing: Take-off and landing performance, level flight performance, range and endurance, climb & descent performance.
  • Stability & control flight testing: Longitudinal static, manoeuvre and dynamic stability, lateral and directional static and dynamic stability, asymmetric flight,
  • Qualitative evaluation, use of the handling qualities rating scale.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE5V-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Software Engineering Management
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Software lifecycle models. Software reliability and maintainability. Software management: management activities and structures, programmer productivity, project planning and scheduling, software cost estimation, software maintenance, configuration management, documentation, software quality assurance.

Software specification: the software requirements document, system modelling, requirements definition and specification, requirements validation and prototyping, formal specification, algebraic specification, model-based specification. Interactions between client and developer.

Software validation and verification: the testing process, top-down and bottom-up testing, test planning and scheduling, testing techniques, static program verification, testing and debugging tools.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEEP-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Business Statistics and Decision Making for Accounting
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Measures of location and spread: Calculation and interpretation of summary measures such as quartiles, means, weighted means and standard deviations. The use appropriate charts of business data, such as bar charts, histograms and ogives.

Introduction to probability: The classical (a priori), empirical and judgemental approaches to probability assessment. The use of Venn diagrams. Manipulation of probabilities. Probability trees.

Introduction to linear programming: Formulation of LPs. Graphical and spreadsheet solution methods. Sensitivity analysis.

Management planning tools: Critical path analysis. Resource planning.

Decision making under conditions of uncertainty: Payoff tables and decision trees. Decision makers' attitude towards risk taking. The expected value of imperfect information. Sensitivity analysis.

Forecasting methods: Time series decomposition. Exponential smoothing. Correlation and regression. The use of spreadsheets to facilitate these techniques.

Sampling theory and practise: How to take samples. Sampling distributions. Confidence intervals for population mean and percentage. Testing hypothesis about population mean and percentage. Chi-square tests.

Investment appraisal: Calculation and interpretation of net present value, discounted cash flow, compound interest, annuities and other common accounting tools.

Measuring change: The use of RPI and other common index measures. Calculation, manipulation and interpretation of simple and weighted indices.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEJY-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Audio Processing (pre 2008)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Foundation topics: Introduction to analysis, modification, synthesis and control of audio signals; Mathematical techniques and forms used in audio processing; Programming technologies and software packages used in the module

Analysis and representation of sonic form: Understanding time and frequency domain representations of sounds

Relationships between acoustical sound sources/modifiers and audio processing techniques

Sound modification: Musical and studio effects; perceptual response, time and frequency domain effects

Synthesised sound: Sampling; Classical and advanced digital synthesis techniques

Musical control in audio systems

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEEQ-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Business Statistics and Decision Making
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Data analysis

Use Excel to create appropriate charts of business data, such as bar charts, pie charts, line graphs and histograms and to calculate summary measures such as the mean and standard deviation.

2. Making inferences from sample data

Distribution of sample means and percentages. Confidence intervals for population mean and percentage. Hypotheses tests for population mean and percentage. Chi-square test.

3. Decision making under conditions of uncertainty

Payoff tables and decision trees. Elicitation of utility. 4. Forecasting methods

Apply time series and correlation and regression together with Excel to aid forecasting.

5. Investment appraisal

Discounted cash flow techniques.

6. Management planning tools

Critical path analysis.

7. Group Decision making

Unstructured and structured group processes. The problems of 'groupthink'. The Delphi technique and decision conferencing.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEUM-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Aerospace Inverse Problem Solving
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: This module addresses important aerospace direct and inverse problem issues such as understanding of stress/strain, modelling parts and components, foundation of Finite Element Analysis, strain gauging and Photoelasticity as reliable sources of data gathering and application of Artificial Intelligence techniques. This module focuses on solving real direct and inverse problems in filed of aerospace engineering such as utilizing surface data i.e. strains to predict the applied loads by means of Artificial Neural Networks.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEEW-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Problem Structuring Approaches
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The following approaches will be studied to varying depth:

Strategic Options Development and Analysis (SODA); - Soft Systems Methodology (SSM); - Systems Dynamics; - Strategic Assumption Surfacing and Testing (SAST); - Strategic Choice; - Hypergames.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEES-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Business Statistics and Decision Making (Part Time)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Data analysis. Use Excel to create appropriate charts of business data, such as bar charts, pie charts, line graphs and histograms and to calculate summary measures such as the mean and standard deviation.

2. Making inferences from sample data. Distribution of sample means and percentages. Confidence intervals for population mean and percentage. Hypotheses tests for population mean and percentage. Chi-square test.

3. Decision making under conditions of uncertainty. Payoff tables and decision trees. Elicitation of utility. 4. Forecasting methods. Apply time series and correlation and regression together with Excel to aid forecasting.

5. Investment appraisal. Discounted cash flow techniques.

6. Management planning tools. Critical path analysis.

7. Group Decision making. Unstructured and structured group processes. The problems of 'groupthink'. The Delphi technique and decision conferencing.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEVG-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Electrical and Electronic Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction: monitoring and control systems: Electronic systems: sensor inputs, processing and output to actuators and indicators. Open loop and closed loop arrangements (introduction to basic concepts only).

Principles: Properties of resistors, capacitors and inductors. Power dissipation in electrical systems. Electrical charge and field. Magnetic field and coupling. Faradays Law. Simple DC circuit analysis. Kirchoffs Laws. Simple AC circuit analysis: Magnitude, RMS, phase and frequency.

Sensors: Electric strain gauge. Temperature: platinum resistance, thermistor and thermocouple. Movement (rotary): potentiometer, absolute and incremental shaft encoders, Linear Variable Differential Transducers and engineering applications.

Actuation and Energy conversions: Electromechanical actuators: Plungers, solenoids. Motors: DC motor/generator, synchronous generator, brushless motors (particularly stepping motors).

Semiconductor Components: Diodes: standard/zener, LED and photodiode. Bipolar transistor as a switch. Introduction to power switching devices.

Analogue Processing Devices: Operational amplifiers (as ideal devices only), negative feedback; non-inverting gain, inverting gain circuits. Differential amplifier. Comparator (without hysterisis). D/A and A/D conversion process (not internal operation).

Digital Electronics: Representation of information by logic levels. Basic digital functions: AND, OR, NOT, XOR. Simple combinational logic. Latches, flip-flops, 555 timer. Logic families: TTL, CMOS. PLC vs. microprocessor. Optical devices.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEV9-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Games in C++
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• An introduction to the principles of the C++ programming language
  • Overview of the uses and rationale for using C++ within Games Development
  • An introduction to the structures and techniques required for efficient management of memory within C++
  • The creation of a simple 2D game
  • The use of complex particle systems within game engines

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE79-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Analogue Circuit Principles
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Analogue Electronics

Diodes, rectifiers, power supplies. BJT and FET characteristics. Transistor biasing as an amplifier and a switch. Basic transistor amplifier circuits. Opto-electronic systems: laser diode, phototransistor. Operational amplifiers gain, frequency response. Op amp as a small signal amplifier, as an active filter, as an integrator and differentiator, as a comparator and as an oscillator.

Circuit Analysis

Resistive circuits: Kirchoffs laws. Thevenins and Norton's theories, mesh analysis, Millman theorem, principle of superposition. Natural and forced response of LC, RC and LCR circuits. Phasor diagrams, complex analysis and Laplace transforms. Transient analysis for circuits with sinusoidal supplies. Bode diagrams. Analysis of two port networks.

Fields

Simple examples of electric fields. Electric potential and voltage, Gauss' law. Energy stored in electric fields

Magnetic fields and flux linkage. Magnetic circuits, self inductance, reluctance, energy stored in magnetic fields, energy balance equation. Mutually induced emf, introduction to transformers. Coupled networks in relative motion. Dynamics of solenoids and principles of electric machines e.g. stepper motor, dc machines.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDT-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Business Systems Excellence
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The module aims to introduce the principles of TQM in the context of organisational and cultural change dedicated to the continuous improvement of products and services.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3J-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Agent-Based Computing
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The concept of Agent - Agents as intelligent, goal-directed, autonomous units, solving problems through multi-agent communication and cooperation. The differences between agents and objects, and the diverse range of application domains for agent-based computing.

Categories of Agents - Intelligent agents and their environments - represented by ontology, Agents as intentional systems. The role of proactive and social agents, symbolic reasoning agents, deductive reasoning agents with examples in Agent0, Concurrent MetateM. Planning agents, for example means/end reasoning, goals/states/actions, practical reasoning algorithms, Beliefs/Decisions/Intents (BDI), deliberation, and commitment.

Agent Communication - The various forms and languages of agent communication, for example Speech acts, Agent0, KIF, KQML, and FIPA Agent Communication Language. The role of ontologies in agent communication. Mobile agent communication via TELESCRIPT, Aglets (mobile Java agents), Agnet TCL.

Multi-agent Interactions - Interactions such as encounters, negotiation, auctions, co-operative versus non-co-operative interactions, Competitive and Zero Sum interactions. The Prisoner's Dilemma

Agent-Based Development - Lifecycles, Architectures, Frameworks, Languages, Pitfalls

Application Domains for Agent-Based Computing - The Human computer Interface (HCI) and User Experience. Intelligent Information Retrieval and Management. Internet mobile agents (shopping agents, business-to-business supply chains, auctions, search engines), Distributed systems (Air Traffic Control, business process management / workflow. Power management systems and factory process control.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3R-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Software Design with Patterns and Java
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Object-Oriented Modelling - ML Models e.g. use case, class, interaction, state, activity, component and deployment models. Techniques for use case identification, class identification (Class / Responsibility / Collaboration), and refining object interaction scenarios.

Object-Oriented Life-cycles - Conceptual, analysis, design and implementation phases. Lifecycles as use case driven, architecture centric, and iterative and incremental.

Patterns - Definition, history of patterns, pattern languages, pattern communities. Analysis patterns of Fowler and Arlow et al. Architectural patterns e.g. system decomposition by separation of concerns into layers or tiers. Design patterns both from general usage (e.g. Model-View-Controller, iterator, wrapper) and from Gamma et al. (Gang of Four) (e.g. Factory Method, Bridge, Faade, Visitor).

Design by Contract - Contract of client / service invocation. Pre-conditions, post-conditions, invariants.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE3Y-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Dissertation (Computer Science)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The nature of the research carried out will vary according to the subject which is being addressed, however, that subject would normally be expected to sit squarely within the domain focussed upon by the student's chosen award route. Normally the student will be expected to carry out the research proposal developed during the Research Methods module, though this might not necessarily be the case. The student will discuss with his or her supervisor the proposal for the dissertation. Once the domain of interest has been finalised the detailed breakdown of work will vary from student to student. However, it is expected that the student will normally be largely self-directing in his or her approach to the work. Where possible, students will be encouraged to take the module in collaboration with an external organisation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE46-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to Program Development
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Note: Each syllabus section is supported by hands-on programming exercises.

1. Basic programming concepts: An introduction to computer operating systems and software. The software development process. The Java compiler compared to \"conventional\" compilers. Learning to use a text editor. Writing a first (\"Hello World\") program.

2. Java syntax: Java (scalar) data types. Using primitives: Declarations, Assignments, Constants, Arithmetic operations and expressions. Simple input and output (using a supplied class)

3. Program Control: Defining and using sequence, selection and iteration techniques in programming languages generally and Java specifically. Considering input data validation routines. 4. Object Orientation: An introduction to thinking about and using the OO paradigm. Considering basic OO concepts such as encapsulation. Identifying and using the constituents of OO - classes, objects, methods, attributes (using String objects). Using UML to design classes. Writing \"tester\" or \"main\" programs to test classes.

Studying a simple graphical program (using AWT)

5. Implementing classes: Introducing more OO concepts e.g. polymorphism. Using class members (the keyword static). Method definition and invocation - formal and actual parameters.

More simple graphics programming using AWT.

The use and role of Wrapper classes.

6. Collection classes: Using arrays of scalars. Using arrays of objects. Processing arrays and using the array attribute length. Studying and implementing lists, stacks and queues.

7. Inheritance: Understanding inheritance. Using inheritance and representing it in UML class diagrams. Learning to override methods. Using type casting to enable the development of Generic collection classes.

8. Software Development and Maintenance: The importance of using sound software development techniques. Coding conventions. Distinguishing between compile-time, run-time, and logical program errors. Testing methods and methodologies. A brief look at Java exception handling.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4D-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Symbolic Processing
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFCE45-20-1 OR UFCE46-20-1 OR UFCE4V-20-1 OR UFQEFY-20-1 OR UFEEHE-30-1)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module aims to introduce and examine issues relating to intelligent systems that use symbolic representation and rule-based architectures. It will explore the ability of such systems to sustain artificially intelligent behaviour and examine their potential to provide plausible models of aspects of human cognition.

1. Introduction: historical background; philosophical arguments and paradigms relating to intelligent systems (symbolic and sub-symbolic, artificial and biological, declarative and procedural); review of objectives in developing intelligent systems in a multi-disciplined area with varied aspirations.

2. Domain of symbolic processing and search techniques: notion of well and ill-defined problems; state-space graphs and trees; the problem solving paradigm and GPS; breadth-first, depth-first and heuristic search techniques; conflict-resolution and control strategies; use of agents.

3. Knowledge representation: knowledge and meta-knowlFdge; production rules; semantic networks; frames; logic systems; problems of knowledge acquisition; models of human memory and cognition.

4. Reasoning, planning and learning: types of reasoning (eg: deductive, inductive, abductive); numeric reasoning using fuzzy logic and probabilistic reasoning; reasoning strategies and uncertainty management; human problem solving and reasoning; planning in a toy world; the frame problem; planning techniques; types of learning (eg: random, rote, in GPS, concept, failure driven, by discovery, by analogy); examples of machine learning; analogies with human learning.

5. Natural language processing: appreciation of the probable processes involved in understanding language (syntactic, semantic and pragmatic analysis); proposed representations for the necessary knowledge.

6. Expert Systems: the architecture of expert systems (acquisition module, knowledge base, inference engine, user interface); contrasts with conventional computer systems; examples of expert systems; explanation facilities; expert-system shells; methodologies for developing knowledge-based systems; principles of knowledge engineering.

7. Logic and its limitations: propositions; Horn clauses; a simple logic database (statements, facts, assertions, variables and rules); inference mechanism (search strategy, backtracking).

8. Philosophical and cognitive issues: models of mind (production systems, connectionist models); limits imposed by computation; limits imposed by architecture; evaluation of symbolic systems as complete models of human cognition; role of consciousness.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4H-40-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Individual Project (Computing and Mathematical Sciences)
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: ((UFCE49-20-2 AND (UFQEFP-20-2 OR UFQEGV-20-2 OR UQQ102S2)) OR UQQ102S2)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The subject of the project will be agreed between the student, the tutors and the Module Leader. Suitable topics may stem from staff, the student, the student\'s employer or other outside organisations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4P-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Object Oriented Databases
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module builds on the Data Structures and Databases module as well as requiring an understanding of the object paradigm. It examines the limitations of existing relational database architectures and reviews the most recent developments in research towards Object Oriented Database structures and applications.

Definition of OODBMS: Concepts from Object Disciplines: Inheritance, Encapsulation, the Message Passing Paradigm. Concepts from Database Disciplines: Locking strategies, Access to large quantities of persistent data. Problems caused by lack of standards, three varying approaches: IRIS, ONTOS, GEMSTONE.

New applications and their requirements, eg CAD/CAM, GIS, CASE Tools and Document Handling Systems.

Schema Evolution, the consequences of inheritance, soft and hard changes - Orion

Object versioning - Orion as model

Query languages, SQL based approaches versus Graph oriented approaches. Query models and Processing. Object Identity.

Effective Storage of and Access to large quantities of objects. Storage structures, Disk and Page Layouts, Clustering, Managing large complex objects. Bulk classes such as Sets, Bags, Lists and Dictionaries.

Transaction management, Conventional and new locking strategies, handling long transactions.

Examination of Object Oriented additions to ORACLE and object-relational paradigm. Comparison to RDBMS.

Future trends and current research.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCESY-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Software Engineering Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The project will require the students to consider and practice the following:

Organisation and management of a team. Task allocation and resourcing. Communication skills. Presentation skills. Document production. Time planning. Applying appropriate software construction techniques in a project, rather than individual, context. Quality issues. Risk. Use of appropriate technology. Investigation, evaluation and selection of development techniques. Analytical reflection on the group development process. Usability issues.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4S-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Requirements Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Software requirement: Definition. Nature of the problem. Significance of requirements in the lifecycle. Deriving a software requirement. Problems in deriving a software requirement.

Software Requirements Document: Content of the document. Structure of the document. Production of a software requirements document.

System modelling: Introduction to the concept. Orthogonal views of a system.

Acquisition of requirements: Social perspectives (questionnaires, interviews, conversational analysis, ethnography).

Goal-oriented approaches: for example ORDIT, KAOS, etc.

Languages/notations for requirements specification: Examples. Types of languages/notations. Strengths and weaknesses of different types. Application of selected languages/notations.

Requirements analysis: Consistency, completeness, critiques of requirements models.

Validation of requirements: prototyping, enacting scenarios, mock-ups, etc.

Method and tool support for requirements engineering.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4X-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Software Technologies for the Web
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The syllabus will:

introduce state of the art concepts in the development of software technologies for the Web;

provide an integrated view of the Web software technology;

enable students to build working experience on various application oriented software technologies that help information creation, delivering, and management on the Web.

In detail, students will be taught:

a classification of Web services and their requirement for software technologies; managing information, transaction, and collaboration; an overview of Web software technologies; basic Web protocol suite;

Java object model; Java event model; Java exception and thread model;

JavaScript object model; JavaScript event model: Interaction between JavaScript and HTML;

VRML technology: creating 3D worlds on the web; distributed component technologies: e.g. CORBA, DCOM.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4Y-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Components and Services
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Note: Each syllabus section is supported by hands-on programming exercises.

1. Theory: Large, industrial scale software system development methodologies and processes, including opportunities for component/service acquisition and reuse, and deployment. The concept of components and services as modelling constructs for specification. The use of a variety of modelling notations, and the notion of physical components and services as industrial building blocks from which software systems are assembled. The challenges of component and service interoperability are investigated at length, including Design by Contract and abstracting away the realities of hardware, networking and operating systems by XML and other mechanisms.

2. Practice: Program-level Component Technology and class-level components; Component technologies (e.g. J2EE). Fundamental concepts such as encapsulation, information hiding, loose coupling, property export. Application of fundamental design patterns such as Model-View-Controller (MVC). Services - Event mechanisms, Introspection, Serialisation, Naming; Development of data components; Development of visual components; Component use within RAD tools; Component use in small-scale server-side applications (e.g. JSP, Servlets, Container managed systems).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEKN-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Data Modelling and Databases
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Thinking about data: Data representation: primitive types (integer, numbers, characters)

Data Modelling: entity-relationship model, use of ER diagrams in database design, relationships, keys. Conceptual and logical model. Use of UML notation for conceptual model.

Relational Model: terminology, keys, integrity.

Normalisation: functional dependency, normal forms 1NF, 2NF, 3NF, data redundancy and update anomalies.

Introduction to SQL: DDL table creation, DML loading tables, the select statement, use a server based DBMS (Oracle/MySQL) and write simple php scripts to develop dynamic web sites.

Database system development lifecycle.

Web database connectivity.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEKP-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Client-Server Programming
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Network applications paradigms, architecture and protocols, client-server paradigm and peer-to-peer paradigm

Examples of well known applications and protocols

Designing and developing new applications

Implementation technologies such as Socket, Datagram and RMI

Servers: concurrent servers, multicast servers, stateful/stateless; clients: locating and requesting services

Object-oriented paradigm and programming using Java for networking, GUI and concurrency

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEKQ-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Internet Security
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Introduction

Computer crime, scale of problem, financial costs, case studies

Security, Trust, Policy. Threats and Protection Mechanisms Systems trusted to deliver confidentiality and integrity; trust; security is policy protection is a mechanism against a threat; security life cycle; layering & distribution of security mechanisms

Threats

Interception; Interruption; Modification; Fabrication; Types of Attack; Eavesdropping; Masquerading; Message tampering; Replaying; Denial of service

Protection Mechanisms

Encryption (key cryptography): Public (RSA); Secret (DES, 3 DES ); Cryptographic hash functions (SHA1, MD5); Stream/block ciphers

Authentication

Protocols: Challenge response; Secret key; Key distribution centre (Kerberos); Needham Schroeder protocol; Public key.

Public Key Management: Certificates (X509); Certification Authorities & PKI; PKI Issues; .NET Passport

Digital Signatures (Message Integrity): Authorisation and Access Control; Access control lists; Capabilities; Protection domains; Firewalls;

Secure Internet Protocols: Secure Socket Layer SSL (RFC 2246); GSSAPI; DNSSEC; IPSec

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEMR-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Forensic Computing Practice
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: As with many project modules there is no particular syllabus content other than that covered by earlier modules, in particular prerequisites. The aim here is to apply the technical knowledge and put into practice the skills developed earlier in the programme in a realistic crime scenario. Knowledge of computer hardware and software and investigative tools together with knowledge of legal requirements will be applied to a case of computer-related crime.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEMV-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Computer & Network Security
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Brief review: Computer crime, scale of problem, financial costs, case studies.

Security, trust, policy. Threats and protection mechanisms. Systems trusted to deliver confidentiality and integrity; trust; security as policy; protection as a mechanism against a threat; security life cycle; layering & distribution of security mechanisms.

Threats: Interception; interruption; modification; fabrication; types of attack; eavesdropping; masquerading; message tampering; replaying; denial of service.

Protection Mechanisms: Encryption (key cryptography): public (RSA); secret (DES, 3 DES); cryptographic hash functions (SHA1, MD5); stream/block ciphers.

Authentication Protocols: Challenge response; secret key; key distribution centre (Kerberos); Needham- Schroeder protocol; public key. Public Key Management: Certificates (X509); Certification Authorities & PKI; PKI Issues; .NET Passport.

Digital Signatures (Message Integrity): Authorization and access control; access control lists; capabilities; protection domains; firewalls; auditing.

Secure Internet Protocols: Secure Socket Layer SSL (RFC 2246); GSSAPI; DNSSEC; IPSec.

Security and Mobility: WLAN security; GSM/GPRS/UMTS security; agents and mobile code; protecting an agent (selective revealing); sandbox approach (JAVA platform security architecture)); playground approach; code signing (MS Active X).

Security Application Programming Interfaces: Java secure socket extension (JSSE); Java Cryptography Architecture (JCA & JCAE).

Additional material will be covered through the practical group coursework. The aim here is to apply the technical knowledge and put into practice the skills developed earlier in the programme.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEPY-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Grid Application Domains
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Current state of grid computing
    • review of the state of various scientific, technical and biomedical projects;
    • review of industrial engagement with grid computing by sector and region;
    • provenance, security, trust
  2. Historical development of different grids across the world
    • North America; Europe;Asia Pacific Region.
    • FSU, CIS and Eastern Europe; South America.
  3. Computational grids
    • parallel and distributed computing;
    • high performance computing and cluster architectures;
    • the requirements of a scientific, technical, medical or health care field with intensive computational processes, such as three-dimensional reconstruction from medical images or complex engineering design;
    • examples.
  4. Data grids
    • scientific experiments and databases;
    • storage and analysis issues;
    • the requirements of a scientific, technical, medical or health care field with extensive data capture, transfer and analysis workflows, such as particle physics, astronomy or bioinformatics;
    • examples.
  5. Collaboration grids
    • patterns of collaboration in engineering and medicine;
    • audit trail for information: provenance, security, trust; law and ethics;
    • performance issues;
    • the requirements of a scientific, technical, medical or health care field which features intensive collaboration, such as second opinion in diagnosis through medical imaging applications;
    • examples.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCESW-30-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Group Work in Large Scale Software Development (Tutor Led)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The students will explore and gain practice of real software development by group work. It will be tutor led, with the tutor acting in the roles of Managing Director, Client and User to provide guidance. In particular, the following aspects will be emphasised:

Software development as a coherent process. - Selection evaluation and use of CASE tools. - Critical reflection on current software development practices. - Organisation and management of a team.

System/software techniques: Modelling - Project management - Project monitoring and control - Computer supported collaborative work.

Application of system/software construction techniques to a group project Issues related to software development:

Quality: Documentation. - Review process: walkthroughs, buddy checks, audit. - Risk: Analysis and management. - Ethical, legal, professional issues. - Usability issues. - Task allocation and resourcing

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCEV6-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Critical Awareness
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Critical evaluation of games content. Identification of visual inconsistencies. Visualisation techniques through applied mark-making techniques and digital image manipulation. Originating, developing and editing images using variety of techniques including photography, scanning and digital paint processes. Creating bitmap textures and application to vector scenes and models. Generation of original content through analytical drawing and development of spatial awareness of perspective: scale and juxtaposition. Presentation of rendered images including storyboarding and games design concepts.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEL8-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistics for Research B
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Units:

1. Statistical Inference (Parametric Tests)

Syllabus

(a) The logic and theory underpinning statistical hypothesis tests.

(b) The practical application and logic underpinning tests of significance for mean differences including the one-sample t-test, paired t-test, two-sample t-tests, one-way ANOVA, one-way ANOVA with blocking, two-way factorial designs and using the result of the Central Limit Theorem. Checking the assumptions underpinning parametric tests of significance.

(c) Reporting of statistical tests, their interpretation and the graphical display of differences.

(d) Power of the test.

Indicative sources

Kvanli, A.H., Pavur, R.J. Keeling, K.B., (2003) An Introduction to Business Statistics (A Microsoft Excel Integrated Approach) 6th ed., West Publishing Company

Daly, F. Hand, D.J. Jones M.C., Lunn, A.D. and McConway ,K.J, (1995) Elements of Statistics, Addison-Wesley

2. Statistical Inference (Nonparametric Tests)

Syllabus

(a) The logic and theory underpinning statistical hypothesis tests including permutation tests and randomization tests.

(b) The practical application and logic underpinning tests of significance for nonparametric tests including the Wilcoxon Signed Rank Sum test, Sign test, Mann Whitney test, Kruskall-Wallis test, Friedman's test and using the result of the Central Limit Theorem.

(c) Using the bootstrap to test for significance.

Indicative sources

Kvanli, A.H., Pavur, R.J. Keeling, K.B., (2003) An Introduction to Business Statistics (A Microsoft Excel Integrated Approach) 6th ed., West Publishing Company

Daly, F. Hand, D.J. Jones M.C., Lunn, A.D. and McConway ,K.J, (1995) Elements of Statistics, Addison-Wesley

3. Regression Modelling 1

Syllabus

(a) The uses of linear regression. Ideas relating to best fit and the use of linear models and their interpretation. Validity and reliability of the fitted equation, the assessment of residuals (tests of normality, randomness, constant variance, effect of outliers) and predictive ability (prediction intervals and confidence intervals).

(b) Extending the linear model to include multiple predictors. Model building using computer aided selection techniques (backward elimination, forward selection, stepwise, best subsets).

(c) Correlation Analysis. Zero order correlations (Pearson, Kendall, Spearman) and partial correlations and part correlations. Confidence intervals and tests of hypothesis relating to correlations (e.g. Fisher's test).

Indicative sources

Draper, N.R. and Smith, H (1997), Applied Regression Analysis, 3rd Edition, Wiley

4. Regression Modelling 2

(a) Extending and improving multiple regression models.

Development of models to include factors through coding schemes (e.g. dummy variables). Development of models to include higher order effects (interactions). Development of models by transforming variables (e.g. Box-Cox transformation). Model improvement by the identification of influential observations (Cook's distance, leverage and studentized residuals) and lack-of-fit.

(b) Assessing assumptions underpinning models though an analysis of residuals e.g. analysis of residuals for normality using standard tests of normality (Anderson-Darling, Shapiro-Wilk, Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests), for homogeneity of variance (e.g. Goldfeld-Quant test, Glejser test), and for independence (e.g. Durbin-Watson test, residual plots and partial plots).

Problem associated with near multicollinearity and the use of orthogonalisation techniques in model building (e.g. Gramm-Schmidt orthogonalisation).

The use of holdout samples and cross cross-fold validation in the validation of models.

(c) An introduction to time series regression modelling

Indicative sources

Draper, N.R. and Smith, H (1997), Applied Regression Analysis, 3rd Edition, Wiley Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

5. Logistic Regression Models

Syllabus

(a) Motivation and uses of binary logistic regression. Assessing significance (log-likelihood and t-ratios). Interpretation of models through the odds ratio. Assessing goodness-of-fit and lack of fit using standard diagnostic techniques (e.g. Hosmer-Lemeshow test, Pearson residuals, deviance residuals, Brown's test, pseudo R-squares, measures of concordance, roc analysis, the identification of influential observations).

(b) Extending the binary model to include either nominal outcomes or ordinal outcomes.

(c) An introduction to other link functions in the generalised linear model.

Indicative sources

Agresti, A (1996) An Introduction to Categorical Data Analysis, 1996, Wiley

Hosmer, D and Lemeshow, S (2000), Applied Logistic Regression, Wiley

6. Design and Analysis of Experiments

Syllabus:

(a) Advantages of designed experiments in engineering and science.

(b) The \"one-factor-at-a-time\" approach to experimentation. Randomisation, replication, blocking and balancing.

(c) Full and fractional factorial experiments and their analysis. 2n-k designs. Main effects and interaction effects. Use of normal and half-normal plots. Aliasing and confounding. Techniques for removing the ambiguities in aliased effects.

(d) Composite and sequential designs. Response surface designs and their analysis.

(e) Taguchi\'s contribution to designed experiments. Robust parameter design and analysis.

Indicative sources

Box G.E.P., Hunter W.G. & Hunter J.S. (1978). Statistics for Experimenters, Wiley , New York.

Montgomery D.C. (2001). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Wiley, New York.

Wu C.F. Jeff & Hamada (2000). Experiments. Planning, Analysis and Parameter Design Optimisation. Wiley, New York.

7. Designing and Analysing Questionnaire Surveys

Syllabus

(a) Methodology of sampling including sampling theory and limitations on inference from non-probabilistic methods. Sampling plans will include probabilistic and non-probabilistic sampling and include random sampling, systematic sampling, stratification techniques, cluster sampling, multi-stage sampling, quota sampling, convenience sampling and snowball sampling amongst others.

(b) Survey methods including, for example, personal interviewing, telephone interviewing, postal surveys.

(c) Question construction and measuring validity and reliability of questions and sub-scales.

(d) Storage and coding of data and the use of technology in the survey process.

(e) Identifying and applying appropriate multivariate methods of analysis for questionnaire data including regression models, the analysis of categorical data and multivariate exploratory data analysis. Indicative sources: Emory, W C and Cooper, D R, (1991) Business Research Methods, 4th Edition

Lattin, J, Carroll, J D and Green P E (2003), Analysing Multivariate Data, Thompson

8. Multivariate Exploratory Data Analysis

Syllabus

(a) Cluster Analysis. Measures of similarity and distance (e.g. Euclidean distance, Mahalanobis distance). Hierarchical methods (e.g. single linkage, complete linkage, Wards method) and non-hierarchical methods (e.g. k-means clustering) and their application to multivariate data.

(b) Applications of correspondence analysis.

(c) Factor Analysis and Principal Component Analysis. An introduction to principal components analysis as a method of extracting maximum orthogonal variance in a set of data.

Concepts involved in exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis. Using eigenvalues and eigenvectors to understand the process of extracting factors. Orthogonal and oblique rotations to aid factor interpretation. The use of scores derived from factor analysis.

(d) Discriminant Analysis. Motivation behind discriminant analysis. Deriving linear classification rules and evaluating their significance (e.g. Wilks' Lambda), interpreting rules (e.g. standardised coefficients, structure matrix, profile plots), evaluating the accuracy of classification rules (e.g. leave-one-out, Cohen's Kappa) and model building (e.g. stepwise selection).

Indicative sources

Everitt B and Dunn, G (2001), Applied Multivariate Data Analysis, Arnold

Hair, J.E., Anderson, R.E, Tatham, R.L and Black, W.C. (1998), Multivariate Data Analysis, 5th Edition, Prentice-Hall International.

Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

9. Multivariate Analyses of Variance

Syllabus

(a) A brief review of independent measures (between subjects) analysis of variance and post hoc analyses.

(b) Multiple Analysis of Variance for between subjects designs and relationship with Discriminant Analysis (including Wilks Lambda, Roys Largest Root, Pillai's Trace and Hotelling's Trace).

(c) The one-way blocked design (repeated measures). Analysis of one-way repeated measures designs including analysis of variance, checking models assumptions, graphical representation of results, post hoc tests and reporting tests. Mauchly's test of sphericity and adjusted F-tests including Greenhouse-Geisser, Hyundt-Feldt and Lower Bound.

(d) The results from 9(b) and 9(c) will be combined to analyse mixed designs.

(e) The multivariate approach to the analysis of repeated measures designs (Profile Analysis)

(f) Different approaches to the analysis of doubly-multivariate designs.

Indicative sources

Tabachnik, B.G. and Fidell, L (2001), Using Multivariate Statistics, 4th Edition

10. Forecasting

Syllabus

(a) Introduction to Forecasting. Assessing forecast accuracy, the role of forecasting in planning and decision making. Types of forecasting models. Monitoring forecasts.

(b) Exponential Smoothing Models. Simple and adaptive exponential smoothing. Double exponential smoothing, Holt\'s method and Holt-Winter\'s method. Damped exponential smoothing.

(c) The Box-Jenkins Approach. Autocorrelation and Partial Autocorrelation Functions. Types of Time Series model. Model Identification. Parameter Estimation.

Indicative sources

Box, G.E.P., Jenkins, G.M., and Reinsel G.C. (1994), Time Series Analysis, 3rd Edition, Prentice-Hall

Chatfield, C. (1996), The Analysis of Time Series, 5th Ed, Chapman Hall.

11. Data Mining

Syllabus

(a) Introduction to Data Mining: The role of data mining, components of data mining algorithms, assessing performance of data mining techniques, nearest neighbour methods.

(b) Classification and regression trees. Growing trees, pruning trees, use of trees for regression, use of trees for classification.

(c) Neural Nets. Perceptrons, feed forward neural nets, deciding on network structure, issues in training neural nets.

(d) Kernel estimation. Density estimation, nonparametric regression

Indicative sources

Hand, D. Mannila, H. and Smyth, P (2001), Principles of Data Mining, The MIT Press.

Hastie, T., Tibishrani, R and Friedman, J (2001), The Elements of Statistical Learning: Data Mining, Inference and Prediction, Springer-Verlag.

12. Survival Analysis

Syllabus

(a) Survival analysis and reliability. The analysis of censored and truncated data. Comparison of survival curves using tests such as Mantel-Haenszel test, Peto's test and the logrank test. Nonparametric, semi-parametric and parametric survival techniques such as Kaplan-Meier, Cox's Proportional Hazards and Weibull models and related techniques.

Indicative sources

Hosmer D and Lemeshow, S (2001) Applied Survival Analysis. Regression modelling of time to event data. Wiley

13. Time Series Regression Modelling with Non-stationary Data

Syllabus

(a) Definitions of stationarity. Non-stationarity of variables and its implications for regression modelling. Unit roots and the Dickey-Fuller tests for stationarity.

(b) Differencing as a solution to non-stationarity. Short-run and long-run equilibrium models.

(c) Cointegration and error-correction models. Testing for cointegration.

(d) Engle-Granger two stage and Johansen methodologies. Applications of ECM in bivariate models.

Indicative sources

Dougherty, C., (2002) Introduction to Econometrics, 2nd ed. Oxford

Kennedy, P., (2003) A Guide to Econometrics, 5th ed., Blackwell Oxley, L., (1999) Practical Issues in Cointegration Analysis, Blackwell Thomas, R.L., (1997) Modern Econometrics: An Introduction, Addison-Wesley

14. Independent Study in Advanced Quantitative Topics

The above units cover the most frequently used statistical techniques in applied quantitative research. The above units do not provide an exhaustive list of quantitative techniques likely to be needed in applied research. This unit (ISAQT) permits independent investigative research into the concepts, theory and practical applications of a specific technique (or techniques) with supervisory guidance. It is not possible to give a comprehensive list of topics that may be needed by an individual researcher but by way of examples, appropriate topics for this unit would include issues relating to specific experimental designs (e.g. clinical trials, cross-over trials), structural equation modelling (SEM), Bayesian Statistics, multilevel modelling.

15. Problem Solving: Case study 1 Analysis of an attitudinal survey.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques often used in the analysis of data from an attitudinal survey will be studied. These are likely to be:

  • Sampling methods
  • The analysis of two-way tables
  • The analysis of 2x2 tables
  • The analysis of two independent samples
  • The analysis of three or more related samples
  • Binary logistic regression analysis

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

16. Problem Solving: Case study 2 Analysis of an employment satisfaction survey.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques often used in the analysis of data from a satisfaction survey will be studied. These include:

  • Summarising Data
  • Descriptive statistics
  • Graphical displays
  • Analysis of two-way tables
  • Analysis of 2x2 tables
  • Non-parametric tests

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

17. Problem Solving: Case study 3 Analysis of data from the World Health Organisation.

By means of a case study, a range of statistical techniques will be learnt using web-based material specially written for this module. The aim is to demonstrate how statistical techniques are used in conjunction to analyse and obtain information from a large data set. It is anticipated that support from a lecturer will be via email and/or telephone; hence this unit is especially suitable for someone who wishes to study in their own time and at any time. For this unit, statistical techniques that are often used to build a statistical model will be studied. These include:

  • Graphical Displays
  • Summarising Data
  • Correlation Analysis
  • Comparison of three or more independent samples
  • Linear regression with one independent variable
  • Checking regression assumptions
  • Multiple regression analysis

Assessment will be by means of a report written on the analysis of a set of supplied data using, at least, all of the above techniques.

By negotiation with the module leader, in units 15, 16 and 17, and if appropriate to the case study, any of the following web-based learning topics from Data Skills for Business may be included in the unit.

  • Graphical displays
  • Questionnaire design
  • Sampling methods
  • Sampling error and variation
  • Statistical inference the fundamentals
  • The analysis of two-way tables
  • The analysis of 2x2 tables
  • The normal distribution
  • Comparison of two independent samples
  • Comparison of two related samples
  • Comparison of three or more independent samples
  • Comparison of three or more related samples
  • Tests following an ANOVA
  • Correlation analysis
  • Linear regression with one independent variable
  • Checking regression assumptions
  • Multiple regression analysis an introduction
  • More multiple regression analysis
  • Binary logistic regression analysis

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEP5-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Customer and Intercultural Awareness
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- Overview of theories, models and types of organisation.

- The European and global business environment in the aerospace industry.

- Organisational cultures: actual, desired, optimum. Cultural types and models. Exploring cultural perceptions and differences. Analysing cultural scenarios. Functional and dysfunctional cultures. Impact of cultures in the workplace.

- Leadership styles and teamwork structures in different cultures. Working in a different culture. Approaches to organisational learning and change.

- Customer awareness and customer focus. Imparting a customer orientation to business strategy. Customer relationship management.

- Customer awareness and Intercultural cooperation and in the aerospace industry, with particular reference to Airbus and Rolls Royce. History, product lines, organisation. Understanding the market for aircraft and forecasting world demand. Supply chain management. Airbus-RR cooperation. Airlines as customers. Understanding airlines strategies and expectations. Understanding passenger needs.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQERP-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematics for Research B
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
UNITS

1. Basic concepts of Linear Algebra

The theory and application of linear algebra are fundamental to many branches of mathematics, both in abstract and concrete terms. This unit concentrates on the theory and practical applications of Numerical Linear Algebra. This unit will start with a system of linear equations as motivation for the study of matrices, linear transformations and, ultimately, vector and sub-spaces which are the basic building blocks of linear algebra.
