As a result of studying this module, students will understand

- (i) representation of a linear algebraic system (LAS) as a matrix equation

(ii) representation of the solution of a LAS as a vector

- as a vector space

- linear transformations from to

- the properties of linear algebraic systems

The content is as follows

(i) Linear Algebraic Systems (LAS):

- Introduction to Matrix Algebra

- Representation of a linear system of equations as a matrix equation

- motivating the definition of matrix multiplication

(ii) The vector space properties of . Definition of a subspace of .

(iii) Linear transformations from to and their representation by a matrix.

(iv) Solution of linear systems of equations by Gaussian Elimination.

- This includes consideration of:

- a) the null space and nullity of the system matrix

- b) the column space and rank of the system matrix

2. Linear Algebra (Solving Linear Algebraic Systems)

This unit covers the mathematical background behind and the implementation of methods for solving large systems of algebraic equations. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, either because a linear algebraic model is being used to describe a particular problem or as a consequence of applying a numerical scheme to the governing equation.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand

- the difference between the use of direct methods and iterative methods of solution

- how to implement these methods efficiently

- the importance of being able to identify ill-conditioning in a linear algebraic system and what techniques can be used to improve the accuracy of a numerical method of solution, when ill-conditioning is present

The content is as follows

(i) Direct methods: - Implementation of Gaussian elimination, using an LU factorisation routine

(ii) Iterative methods: Implementation of Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and Successive Over Relaxtion (SOR) schemes

(iii) Error control: Use of condition number to identifying ill-conditioned systems. In the case of direct methods, implementing pivoting strategies to control the propogation of rounding error

3. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

This unit covers what eigenvalues are and how useful they can be in the analysis of problems which arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics.

As a result the student will understand

- the nature of eigenvalues with respect to different types of matrices

- how eigenvalues can be computed

- the extension of the concepts of eigenvalues to include singular values of non-square matrices

The content is as follows:

(i) Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Revision of eigenvalues and eigenvectors to include definition and diagonalisation of matrices, and extend work to cover complex matrices and other similarity transformations

(ii) Computation of Eigenvalues: The power method, tridiagonal and upper Hessenberg forms of matrices and the QR algorithm for finding eigenvalues

(iii) Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) of matrices: The SVD for any rectangular matrix is defined and constructed. We look at an applications such as the least squares problem, numerical conditioning and the pseudoinverse

4. Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Introduction)

This unit introduces the initial value problem together with simple numerical techniques for producing a numerical solution. It contains material that must be understood prior to looking at the more advanced numerical techniques that form the basis of commercially available software packages that are used to solve this problem. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, whenever modelling of continuous time dynamical systems is a requirement of the research

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand

- how an initial value problem arises from the modelling of a dynamical system

- the logic that lies behind the derivation of a numerical method for solving an initial problem

- the nature and magnitude of errors that are incurred when using numerical methods to solve an initial value problem

The content is as follows

(i) Initial Value Problems: Modelling dynamical systems, initial conditions, analytical solution (for simple problems)

(ii) Numerical schemes: Eulers method, the modified Euler method, Runge-Kutta schemes (including the classical 4th order scheme)

(iii) Error analysis: Discretisation error and stability of numerical schemes. In this unit, the analysis will be restricted to simple 2nd order numerical schemes

5. Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Error control and analysis)

Prior to taking this unit, student must have knowledge that is equivalent to that contained in unit 4 Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Introduction). Unit 5 considers the implementation of advanced numerical methods consideration of the efficient implementation of these schemes and methods for dealing with stiff equations. It contains material that lies behind the the advanced numerical techniques that form the basis of commercially available software packages that are used to solve initial value problems. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, whenever modelling of continuous time dynamical systems is a requirement of the research.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand

- the logic that lies behind the derivation of high order accuracy numerical methods for solving an initial problem

- which methods are appropriate for the solution of stiff equations

- how to control the error incurred when implementing these schemes

The content is as follows

(i) High order numerical schemes: -Linear multistep schemes, embedded Runge-Kutta schemes. Comparing the implentation of explicit and implicit numerical schemes

(ii) Error estimation and control: -Use of predictor-corrector schemes, embedded Runge-Kutta schemes. Introducing adaptive discretisation step size

(iii) Stiff Equations: -Linear stability analysis of high order numerical schemes. Gear style schemes

6. Nonlinear Dynamics

The main aim of this unit is to introduce the concepts of stability and bifurcation in nonlinear ordinary differential equations with a view to their application in other disciplines e.g. engineering, economics, biology, etc

1. Solution concept and phase space

2. Linearisation and stability (via eigenvalue test)

3. Simple bifurcation of fixed points (saddle-node, transcritical and pitchfork).

4. Periodic solutions and Hopf bifurcation

Students will also be made aware of more complicated (chaotic) solution behaviour in higher dimensions, though this will not be assessed

7. Analytical methods for pricing financial derivative contracts

The aim of this unit is to introduce and apply stochastic models that occur in finance to the derivation of analytical expressions that are available for pricing derivative contracts such as forwards, futures and options. The unit covers the key theoretical concepts of risk neutral valuation and no arbitrage that are central to the derivation of pricing models. The use of Itos lemma in determining the probability distribution of a function of a random variable will be investigated as a prelude to deriving the Black-Scholes pricing model for financial derivatives where the underlying asset follows a geometric Brownian motion. Assets that follow a mean reverting process such as oil and electricity prices will be considered as an extension to the Black-Scholes framework.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand the main theoretical concepts involved in modelling financial derivative contracts and will have an appreciation of the limitations of the theory. In particular a student will be able to interpret the pricing formula as a description of the market view of risk that is inherent in a financial derivative contract.

8. Numerical methods for pricing financial derivative contracts

Before studying this unit, students will require a working knowledge of the material covered in Unit 7 together with experience of using a programming language that is suitable for implementing algorithms for the solution of mathematical problems. (for example Maple, Matlab, Visual Basic, Fortran, R or C).

The aim of this unit is to cover computational techniques that are used in the pricing of financial derivative contracts. These techniques may be based on:

  • Monte Carlo simulations
  • Binomial probability trees
  • Numerical integration techniques
  • Finite difference schemes

Students will be expected to apply one of the above approaches to the pricing of a derivative contract that they have chosen as relevant to their research. Students will be required to demonstrate understanding of how to the computational scheme is derived, its efficient implementation and the performance of the schemes in terms of its speed of convergence and stability.

9. Independent Study in Advanced Mathematical Topics

The taking of this unit is subject to negotiation and the identification of a suitable supervisor.

The above units cover techniques commonly used in research that involves applied mathematics. The above units do not provide an exhaustive list of mathematical techniques likely to be needed in applied research. The unit (ISAMT) permits independent investigative research into the concepts, theory and practical applications for a specific technique (or techniques) with supervisory guidance. It is not possible to give a comprehensive list of topics that may be needed by an individual researcher but by way of examples, appropriate topics for this unit would including issues relating to the application of a scientific programming language, mathematical modelling, discrete mathematics, optimisation problems, solution of partial differential equations, signal processing and analysis.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEUK-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Practical Electronics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Schematic and PCB design. Familiarization with real, practical electronic components. Interpretation of design and product specifications and component data sheets. Prototyping and workshop skills. Linear power supplies. Interfacing electronic sub-systems. Environmental issues. Battery technology. Power and heat issues. Electronic Display Technology. De-bugging strategies. Energy awareness. Micro-power techniques. Safety issues.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEAX-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Group Design
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Illustrative examples of topics to be presented in the module include:

Outline of the selected problem by the lecturer, Introduction to Quality Assurance Concepts including global issues such as TQM as well as ISO9000, and current industrial practice. Design-related Quality supporting tools and techniques such as Failure Mode Effects Analysis (FMEA) and Quality Function Development (QFD). Development of specifications by students. Work of students on solutions via group work, embodiment of solutions into design schemes; details design and calculations, specifying bought out items of equipment and components, project presentation and feedback from staff during the design process.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEB4-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Alternative Energy
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Energy, power and efficiency, introduction to energy technologies and energy use in society, thermodynamic principles of heat engines, fundamentals of fluid flow, principles of electrical machines and distribution networks, structure of the UK electricity industry, conventional fossil fuelled and nuclear steam plant. Utilisation of renewable energy sources: solar, wind, water, biomass; conversion to electric power. Autonomous power systems. Comparative economics and environmental impacts.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEEB-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Virtual Instrumentation and Environments
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Illustrative examples of topics to be presented in the module include:

- Virtual instrumentation in system design.

- Wire-frame, solid and surface models;

- Theory of ray tracing and the method of radiosity in VR.

- Techniques for the handling of shadows, inter-reflections and the modelling of surface albedo and topographic textures.

- Typical applications: design, presentation, teleoperation, communication, simulation, entertainment, machine vision.

- Management appraisal: why virtual environments, economic justification.

- Future developments.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFIENP-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Introduction to Advanced Information Systems with Cataloguing & Classification
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
 Digital libraries and Internet-based information services. Types, processes and components and key technical underpinnings and standards. Digital information resources. Internet standards, searching and metadata (eg, Dublin Core). Intranets. Usability and functionality in digital libraries. Preservation of digital library materials.

 Introduction to the wider societal impact of digital libraries and Internet-based information services. Role of digital libraries and allied information systems in society.

 Managerial and technological issues relating to digital libraries.

 Cataloguing. Introduction to cataloguing standards. AACR2 and MARC (including MARC 21). Use with books and other media types. Internet standards. Development of in-house cataloguing standards.

 Classification. Classification principles, schemes and systems. Subject indexing. Knowledge management. Cataloguing and classification in library management and decision making.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMER9-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Design for Manufacture
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Alternative types of manufacturing method: taking account of design form, material type and properties, quality requirements, equipment and processing capability, costs, skill level requirements. Associated costs: material, labour and overheads, fixed and variable costs and break-even analysis. The application of standards relevant to design form, materials and interchangeability (BS/ISO). Cost benefits where designers take a value engineering approach, standard components, reduced numbers of components, the use of standard features and tooling. Material requirements including form, size, weight quality, processing method, quantity, availability, service life, mechanical, electrical, chemical characteristics. Methods of feeding and assembling components automatically, unidirectional component location, ease of handling, positioning, stacking, Features of good design including location of spigots, flanges, tenons, locating faces, accessibility, alignment, families of parts (groupings). Software: CAD/CAM/CNC, assembly, material selection and handling processes.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMES5-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering for Designers
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
• Metric and Imperial Units
  • Resultant Force and Force components and free body diagrams
  • Static Equilibrium of forces
  • Stress and strain due to bending, normal and shear forces
  • Structural analysis, trusses and second moment of area
  • Centre of gravity and area
  • Mechanism, cams, Levers, Gears, Cranks and Pulleys
  • Hydraulic and pneumatic actuators, valves and controls, DC and Stepper motors, solenoids, Sensors
  • Forms of energy and Conservation of energy, Work and Power
  • Electrical current/voltage, Batteries and dry cells, Switches, Resistors, Thermistors, Capacitors, Transistors and Basics of microelectronics
  • Engineering Design Case studies

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEUN-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Control of Engineering Systems
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Controller Design

Methodology

  • Review of transform methods e.g. Laplace
  • Simple system identification using step and frequency response
  • Physical modelling
  • Design of PI and PID controllers using pole placement
  • Root locus method for high order systems

Practice

  • Introduction to MATLAB/Simulink
  • Measurement of systems characteristics
  • Design of PI and PID controller
  • Verification of design using MATLAB

2. Modelling and Identification

Methodology

  • Basic modelling concepts
  • Data fitting techniques
  • Model structure detection
  • Parameter estimation
  • Model validation

Practice

  • Data processing using MATLAB
  • Simulation demonstration

3. Fuzzy and Neural Network Enhanced Control

Methodology

  • Fuzzy control
  • Neuro control
  • Comparison of strengths and weakness compared with traditional approaches

Practice

  • Application example case studies
  • Simulation demonstration

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEE7-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Operations Management & Improvement
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The relationship between manufacturing and the rest of the business, design for manufacture and assembly.

An Introduction to Quality and Total Quality Management including an overview of the history and development of the concepts involved and the recognised 'Gurus' in the field.

A review of the themes, concepts & principles of TQM including: Customer orientation, Continuous quality improvement, \'Right first time\' culture. Motivation of the entire organisation, Top management commitment and leadership, Concept of the internal customer; external customer care.

Management of Change and Improvement, including: Creating a TQ culture in practice, Teamwork for problem solving and improvement, Managing people and teams for continuous improvement, Supporting the improvement process.

TQM Tools & Techniques, including: Department Analysis & Improvement, Statistics & SPC and Six Sigma, Quality Tools (7 new tools) and Design, Quality Systems (ISO 9000/BS 5750), Guidelines for Total Quality (BS 7850).

Total Quality models for excellence - the Baldridge Quality Award, European and British Quality Award models and their use in self assessment.

Quality assurance, quality management systems, quality system standards, regulatory standards and their relationship to TQM.

Quality economics, assessment of quality performance and real costs in design, manufacturing, logistics, customer support and projects.

Quality Policy & Mission Deployment, Hoshin and associated terms and approaches.

Automating the collection and analysis of data for purposes of quality systems and improvement through the use of computers and an integrated quality database.

The structure of manufacturing resources, approaches to organising manufacturing facilities, job shops, batch production, flow systems, cellular systems and group technology, calculation of batch sizes and order quantities, ABC parts classification.

The selection of production equipment and systems, an introduction to automation and robotics, methods for analysing and modelling production, line balancing, plant layout, linear programming and simple optimisation problems, use of discrete event simulation.

The control of production systems, an overview of MRP, MRP II, OPT and JIT, the control of projects.

Introduction to Quality control, Quality Assurance, Total Quality Management and improvement techniques: need for management commitment and leadership; management strategies for quality; quality policy and planning; creation, operation and maintenance of quality systems; quality auditing. Concept of internal/external customer care. Quality system standards (ISO 9000): role and requirements. Quality awards and self-assessment. Quality costs collection and use. Computer aided quality systems. Quality of design (QFD & FMEA); Supply chain management, handling of customer complaints.

Quality in manufacturing and service industries: inspection activities; statistical techniques; department and process analysis and performance improvement; quality circles; improvement teams.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPE6V-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: MEng Individual Project
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The main content of the module will depend on the subject agreed by the supervisor.

Areas covered by the taught section (Research Methods) include:

1. The nature of research: a taxonomy covering pure fundamental research through to funded development work. The epistemology of research activity. Concepts of pre-competitive research, near market, etc.

2. Funding of research. Public sector sources, their rules and constraints. Government departments, research councils, EU framework research. Industrial funding, and public sector-industry collaboration.

3. Management of research. Contracts, technological risk. Project management and monitoring. Project reporting.

4. Information search and retrieval. Use of libraries as research tools. Databases of publications. Use of Internet in research.

5. Publication of work. Identification of where to publish. Research conferences. Journals. Style and content of papers, etc. Timescales for publication. Treatment of confidential information.

6. Design of research programmes. Hypotheses. Design of experiments; use of controls. Pilot experiments. Logging and recording data. The need to record decisions and the basis for them.

7. Surveys, both observational and by questionnaire/interview. Use of pilot surveys.

8. Statistics. Collection of analysis of statistical data. Tests of statistical significance. Recognition of systematic error. Data checking and improvement. Use of statistical packages.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPEL3-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Research Portfolio
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: The student will compile a portfolio of public presentations of either original research carried out by the student, or a review of relevant research work carried out by others, or a combination of both. To complete the portfolio, this material must be accompanied by commentary. The content of the portfolio will depend entirely on the chosen area of research study and on those topics selected for publication by the student and, where relevant, the supervisory team over the course of the research programme.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFPES4-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Music Event
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
This module is designed to give students theoretical knowledge and practical skills in the planning and execution of a musical event. Students will be asked to plan and execute all aspects of a concert, in particular:

  • Logistics: venue, performers, programme, staffing, health and safety
  • Business Planning: tickets, sales, publicity, finances
  • Execution: get-in/get-out, equipment setup, rehearsal, concert

Students will be responsible for the entire process and will be expected to take part in the performance as well as being part of the organising team. Staff support will be provided throughout.

Financial support will be provided to enable the students to put down deposits on venue and equipment, for publicity materials and other incidentals. It is hoped this will be recouped at the event.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEF4-60-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistics & Management Science Dissertation
rdf:Description.p:syllabus: Not applicable

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEQ3-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Civil Aircraft Maintenance Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The module comprises study of the following:

  • Introduction to the requirements for maintenance in aircraft operations
  • Requirements for aircraft maintenance legislation
  • Overview of maintenance planning
  • Quality Assurance in airline maintenance
  • Human factors
  • Aircraft maintenance production

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQER6-20-2
rdf:Description.p:title: Engineering Mathematics 2 (CBC)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Further Vectors and Matrices: Vector geometry of lines and planes. Vector geometry of curves and differentiation of vectors. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Solution of discrete linear systems x(n+1)=Ax(n) and continuous systems x1=Ax.Solution of Differential equations: modelling of simple systems, solution of 2nd order linear differential equations.Laplace Transforms:- Definition and manipulation of standard transforms. Inverse transform. Solution of linear differential equations. Transfer functions.

Fourier Series: Periodic functions and fundamental period. Computation of Fourier Series. Convergence of Fourier Series.

Partial Differentiation:

Partial Differential Equations: Derive a PDE in context of either the Heat equation or Laplace's equation. Use Fourier series and separation of variable techniques to solve the PDE. Use appropriate software to display results and aid interpretation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQERQ-20-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Mathematics for Research D
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
UNITS

1. Basic concepts of Linear Algebra

(i) representation of a linear algebraic system (LAS) as a matrix equation

- as a vector space

- linear transformations from to

- a) the null space and nullity of the system matrix

2. Linear Algebra (Solving Linear Algebraic Systems)

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand:

- the difference between the use of direct methods and iterative methods of solution

The content is as follows:

3: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

This unit covers what eigenvalues are and how useful they can be in the analysis of problems which arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics.

As a result the student will understand:

- the nature of eigenvalues with respect to different types of matrices

- how eigenvalues can be computed

- the extension of the concepts of eigenvalues to include singular values of non-square matrices

The content is as follows:

(i) Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: Revision of eigenvalues and eigenvectors to include definition and diagonalisation of matrices, and extend work to cover complex matrices and other similarity transformations

4. Numerical Solution of Initial Value Problems (Introduction)

- the logic that lies behind the derivation of a numerical method for solving an initial problem

- the nature and magnitude of errors that are incurred when using numerical methods to solve an initial value problem

Unit 5 considers the implementation of advanced numerical methods consideration of the efficient implementation of these schemes and methods for dealing with stiff equations. It contains material that lies behind the advanced numerical techniques that form the basis of commercially available software packages that are used to solve initial value problems. The need for these methods arise in many branches of engineering, science and economics, whenever modelling of continuous time dynamical systems is a requirement of the research.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand:

- the logic that lies behind the derivation of high order accuracy numerical methods for solving an initial problem

- which methods are appropriate for the solution of stiff equations

- how to control the error incurred when implementing these schemes

The content is as follows:

(i) High order numerical schemes: Linear multistep schemes, embedded Runge-Kutta schemes. Comparing the implentation of explicit and implicit numerical schemes

(ii) Error estimation and control: Use of predictor-corrector schemes, embedded Runge-Kutta schemes. Introducing adaptive discretisation step size

(iii) Stiff Equations: Linear stability analysis of high order numerical schemes. Gear style schemes

6. Nonlinear Dynamics

The main aim of this unit is to introduce the concepts of stability and bifurcation in nonlinear ordinary differential equations with a view to their application in other disciplines e.g. engineering, economics, biology, etc

1. Solution concept and phase space

2. Linearisation and stability (via eigenvalue test)

3. Simple bifurcation of fixed points (saddle-node, transcritical and pitchfork).

4. Periodic solutions and Hopf bifurcation

Students will also be made aware of more complicated (chaotic) solution behaviour in higher dimensions, though this will not be assessed

7. Analytical methods for pricing financial derivative contracts

The aim of this unit is to introduce and apply stochastic models that occur in finance to the derivation of analytical expressions that are available for pricing derivative contracts such as forwards, futures and options. The unit covers the key theoretical concepts of risk neutral valuation and no arbitrage that are central to the derivation of pricing models. The use of Itos lemma in determining the probability distribution of a function of a random variable will be investigated as a prelude to deriving the Black-Scholes pricing model for financial derivatives where the underlying asset follows a geometric Brownian motion. Assets that follow a mean reverting process such as oil and electricity prices will be considered as an extension to the Black-Scholes framework.

As a result of studying this unit, students will understand the main theoretical concepts involved in modelling financial derivative contracts and will have an appreciation of the limitations of the theory. In particular a student will be able to interpret the pricing formula as a description of the market view of risk that is inherent in a financial derivative contract.

8. Numerical methods for pricing financial derivative contracts

Before studying this unit, students will require a working knowledge of the material covered in Unit 7 together with experience of using a programming language that is suitable for implementing algorithms for the solution of mathematical problems. (for example Maple, Matlab, Visual Basic, Fortran, R or C).

The aim of this unit is to cover computational techniques that are used in the pricing of financial derivative contracts. These techniques may be based on:

  • Monte Carlo simulations
  • Binomial probability trees
  • Numerical integration techniques
  • Finite difference schemes

Students will be expected to apply one of the above approaches to the pricing of a derivative contract that they have chosen as relevant to their research. Students will be required to demonstrate understanding of how to the computational scheme is derived, its efficient implementation and the performance of the schemes in terms of its speed of convergence and stability.

9. Independent Study in Advanced Mathematical Topics

The taking of this unit is subject to negotiation and the identification of a suitable supervisor.

The above units cover techniques commonly used in research that involves applied mathematics. The above units do not provide an exhaustive list of mathematical techniques likely to be needed in applied research. The unit (ISAMT) permits independent investigative research into the concepts, theory and practical applications for a specific technique (or techniques) with supervisory guidance. It is not possible to give a comprehensive list of topics that may be needed by an individual researcher but by way of examples, appropriate topics for this unit would including issues relating to the application of a scientific programming language, mathematical modelling, discrete mathematics, optimisation problems, solution of partial differential equations, signal processing and analysis.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQES7-15-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Quantitative Methods for Business
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Types of data:

data and information; quantitative and qualitative and their typical uses in business; primary sources, e.g. interview, survey, postal questionnaire, observation; secondary sources, e.g. internet research, ONS/government and other published data.

Selection of source:.

factors determining choice, including size/nature of organisation, availability, relevance, age, timeliness, cost of collection/analysis, volume, clarity, and knowledge of source

Collection of data:

population, problem of bias, sampling frame; sampling methods, e.g. simple random, systematic, stratified, cluster, multi-stage, quota, panel methods; sample error.

Representative values:

arithmetic mean, median, mode, calculation from raw data and frequency distributions; uses in business e.g. pay negotiations, interpretation of the results to draw valid business conclusions.

Measures of dispersion:.

maximum, minimum, use of quartiles, percentiles, standard deviation for small and large samples, Normal Distribution and skewness; typical business uses, e.g. statistical process control, buffer stock levels

Calculation techniques:

correlation - calculation and interpretation of the coefficient, use in business e.g. correlation between advertising spend and sales; index numbers - simple and weighted, CPI/RPI and other published indexes and their use in business; time series - trend, seasonal analysis, deflation, use in business e.g. forecasting.

Selection:.

factors influencing selection of suitable visual representation to present summarised business information - e.g. user requirements, resource availability, time pressure; influence of business function on format chosen - existence of specialist formats (e.g. variance reports, Gantt charts), individual functional needs

Creation:

e.g. line graph, pie chart, bar chart, histogram; report writing - examples of business use, e.g. (HR) staff absenteeism, (production) output statistics, (marketing) market research findings, (finance) variance reports; presentation software.

Interpretation:

scatter (XY) graphs, interpreting the relationship between two variables, limitations; linear trend lines - extrapolation for forecasting, limitations.

Management information systems:

importance of MIS; influences on MIS design and operation, e.g. organisational size, expertise, resource availability; computers and information-processing tools for operational, tactical and strategic levels of the organisation, uses in functional areas.

Inventory control:

economic order quantity, continuous and periodic review, Pareto analysis, material requirements, planning for manufacturing.

Project management:

networking and critical path analysis, Gantt and Pert charts.

Financial tools:

investment appraisal - discounted cash flow, internal rates of return; breakeven analysis, CVP , Risk analysis: risk versus uncertainty, decisions under risk and uncertainty; sensitivity and probability analysis, e.g. for capital expenditure projects; the role of decision trees in risk analysis; other examples of risk and uncertainty in business, e.g. sizing inventories, pricing decisions, portfolio analysis.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEVD-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Analytical Methods for Electronic Engineers
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Algebraic methods

Algebraic methods: transposition of formulae; polynomial division; factor and remainder theorem; rules of order; partial fractions

Sequences and limits, arithmetic and geometric series: notation; arithmetic and geometric progressions and series; Pascals triangle and the binomial theorem; Power series.

Properties of functions

Concept of mapping, domain and range, inverse functions, odd and even symmetry, periodic functions, piecewise functions, inequalities

Properties of standard engineering functions such as polynomials, rational functions, exponential, trigonometric, hyperbolic and logarithmic functions and their associated inverse functions. Properties and uses of the unit step function. Discrete and continuous variables.

Trigonometric methods

Trigonometric ratios; co-ordinate systems; radian measure; sinusoidal functions.

Trigonometric identities: trigonometric and hyperbolic identities; double angle and compound angle formulae; Angular frequency, period and phase of sinusoidal waveforms; simple trigonometric equations (e.g. A sin (t) = p)

The calculus

Concepts and definitions of the derivative; standard derivatives; product, quotient chain rules; indefinite integrals; standard integrals and applications.

Further differentiation: second order and higher derivatives; classification of turning points, logarithmic differentiation; differentiation of inverse trigonometric and hyperbolic functions;

The definite integral and area under curves, mean value of a function, root mean square value of a sinusoidal function.

Further integration: simple integration by parts; integration using partial fractions

Statistics and probability

data collection and graphical representation; concepts, methods and applications of:

  • Central tendency and dispersion
  • Regression, linear correlation
  • Probability and Probability distributions

Application examples in electronic engineering

The above theory will be related to problems arising from the performance and analysis of electronic circuits and components.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEEY-15-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Applied Statistics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
1. Design and Analysis of Experiments

The rationale for the one-way layout and the use of blocking including random selection and random allocation. Analysis of single factor designs including one-way analysis of variance, one-way block analysis, Kruskal-Wallis test and Friedman's test. Application of post hoc and a priori tests for one way designs.

Two factor experiments, the concept of an interaction and the associated analysis of variance. Post hoc and a priori tests for balanced factorial designs.

Two level fractional factorial designs (including confounding and aliasing) and their analyses.

Analysis of covariance.

2. Regression modelling.

The simple linear regression model and model diagnostics (residuals, Studentized residuals, leverage, Cook's distance). The interpretation of confidence intervals for estimation and prediction and validity and reliability of model based predictions.

Multiple regression model diagnostics (residuals, Studentized residuals, leverage, Cook's distance). Model building techniques (forward selection, backward elimination, best subsets) and their associated problems. Problems with near multicollinearity and its quantification (e.g., variance inflation factor). Two-way interactions between numeric variables. Partial correlations.

The use of dummy variables (referential coding) and interactions between numeric variables and categorical variables.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQETN-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Decision Modelling
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The course will aim to look at a wide range of decision modelling techniques. These will include:

Decision Problems under Conditions of Uncertainty. Single attribute utility functions, first and second order stochastic dominance, axioms of utility, utility elicitation. Risk analysis using simulation.

Structuring decision problems. Decision trees, assessment of decision structure. Assessing probabilities. Elicitation methods: Assessment probabilities for rare events: fault and event trees. Measurement of judgmental skill: calibration, Brier scores.

Revision of Opinion. Bayes theorem, the expected value of perfect and imperfect information.

Descriptive Decision Models. Lexicographic and semi-lexicographic ordering, elimination by aspects, satisficing prospect theory.

Decision Problems involving Multiple Objectives under conditions of certainty. The Simple Multi-Attribute Rating Technique: value trees, direct rating and value functions, swing and importance weights, mutually preference independence, efficient frontiers, sensitivity analysis, the axioms of SMART, rank-order centroid weights, SMARTER.

Linear Programming and applications of Linear Programming such as Goal Programming - both pre-emptive and non pre-emptive.

Integer Programming: including Branch and Bound method, knapsack problems, set covering problems and the use of integer programming in modelling a variety of real life constraints which linear programming cannot deal with - including set up costs, either/or constraints, if then constraints etc.

Dynamic Programming: including its relation to decision trees, Stagecoach problems, inventory and production problems, replacement and maintenance problems. Stochastic dynamic programming

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGD-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Advanced Statistics
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Design and Analysis of Experiments. fixed, random and mixed effects. CRD and orthogonal contrasts. RBD and tests of additivity. blocking and confounding, LSD, GLSD, HGLSD. hierarchical models. nested factional models. analysis of covariance. fractional replication and aliasing. single and multiple dependent variables.

Analysis of Variance for the above including MANOVA

Analysis of Covariance

Advanced regression techniques

Nonlinear regression

Loglinear Models: concepts, application to contingency tables, practical interpretation of models.

Binary, ordinal and nominal logistic regression models: application, theoretical underpinning, model diagnostics.

Generalised Linear Models: the canonical form of the experimental family and related theory, link functions, model diagnostics, model fitting and model building, a unifying.

Nonparametric/Robust Techniques: rationale, tests of randomness, monotonic estimation and testing, jack knifing, bootstrapping methods, robust regression.

Discriminant Analysis: applications and interpretation, theoretical underpinning, model diagnostics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFQEGE-20-1
rdf:Description.p:title: Statistical Reasoning
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Types of data. Sources, uses and limitations of published data. Data collection methods. Sampling methods.

Exploratory data analysis, methods of exploring, summarising and illustrating data.

Probability. Probability distributions. Bayes Theorem. Mathematical expectation. Moments. Elementary moment generating functions.

Discrete and continuous probability distributions including binomial, Poisson, uniform, exponential, normal.

Estimation. Sampling distributions. Confidence intervals.

Hypothesis testing : Z-tests, t-tests, f-test for variances, Chi-square tests for contingency tables and goodness of fit.

Introduction to correlation and regression.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UMED4C-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: The Economics of International Financial Markets

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEEHH-30-2
rdf:Description.p:title: CPU Architecture & VHDL
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
CPU architecture, the basic components and functionality

Parallel adders/subtractors, and multipliers, barrel shifters

VHDL modelling concepts, overview

The Dataflow/RTL model

The Structural Model

VHDL State machines

VHDL Subsets for synthesis

Design Processing

Test patterns and Simulation.

Digital Design principles

Optimisation of designs

Timing hazards

CMOS implementation of logic

Combinational Logic design Principles

Sequential Design Principles.

State machine synthesis

Use of diagrammatic tools for code synthesis

Synthesis Issues

Programmable devices, structure and function.

Synthesis process, download, testing and debugging in hardware

Developing tool chains, ancillary utilities. Use of Make, Flex etc.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFMEDU-10-M
rdf:Description.p:title: Aerospace Life Cycle Analysis and Cost Modelling
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
- A detailed understanding of the tools and techniques used for life cycle cost estimation and analysis in the Aerospace industry

- An illustration of how these tools and techniques are used through the use of case studies

- An understanding of how manufacturing cost models can be developed and the importance of architectural and integration issues associated with IT solutions to cost estimation

- hands on use of tools and techniques

- an overview of research in the area of cost modelling from an international perspective.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFEE5L-20-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Digital Signal Processing
rdf:Description.p:preRequisiteCondition: (UFEEHE-30-1 OR UFEE7A-20-1 OR UFEELS-40-1 OR UFEETS-20-1 OR UFEEU8-40-1 OR UFEEHP-10-0)
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
Theory: Time domain analysis (convolution), Frequency domain analysis (Fourier theory, z-transform), Digital filters, DSP chips, and a Case study.

Practical: A series of lab-based exercises using Code Composer Studio (CCS) and TMS320C6711 DSP processor. The programming language adopted is C/C++.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: UFCE4T-10-3
rdf:Description.p:title: Interface Engineering
rdf:Description.p:syllabus:
The contributions made by various disciplines to HCI

The contributions made by cognitive psychology to interface design, in particular investigations into areas such as memory, knowledge representation, and attention

User characteristics, environmental factors and interaction styles

Input/output devices

Task analysis

Relationship between HCI and software Engineering

Methodologies - user centred design, task centred design

New approaches to methodologies and research e.g. activity theory

Interface design guidelines

Interface design patterns

Metrics and evaluation methods

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Advanced Computation in Design and Decision-making
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Advanced Computation in Design and Decision-making
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The objectives of the ACDDM group concern the generation of high-quality information relating to complex design and decision-making domains. Such domains are typically characterised by uncertainty and poor problem definition where high levels of complexity confound understanding and limited domain knowledge may initially restrict meaningful machine-based problem representation. Qualitative aspects of the problem area may demand a high-level of user-interaction in terms of complete or partial user-assessment of generated solutions. Frequent redefinition of any machine-based problem representation is necessary as information gained leads to a better understanding of complex problem characteristics.

A human-centric approach is taken where experiential and arising user knowledge is integrated with powerful machine-based search and exploration. Concurrent, adaptive, non-linear search processes are proposed that generate diverse high quality solutions plus a wealth of background information appertaining to problem characteristics and the nature of the complex problem space. A further challenge is the extraction and processing of such information and its succinct presentation to the designer / decision-maker. The hypothesis is that off-line assimilation of such information contributes directly to the decision-makers' knowledge base and supports the further development of machine-based representations. Knowledge capture is thus intimated through the integration of experiential and arising user knowledge through further, iterative search of an evolving problem space. Objectives associated with this process relate to the development of highly user-interactive systems that support discovery, innovation and creative activities.

Developing interactive systems support and enhance the inherent skills and capabilities of the designer / decision-maker rather than attempting to replace them through the development of entirely machine-based processes. Although the curse of dimensionality presents extreme difficulties to the human decision-maker it is proposed that such difficulties can be overcome through an appropriate melding of machine-based search, information generation with human intuition, judgement and experiential knowledge. An inherent objective is to develop machine-based processes that relieve the cognitive load upon the user through a reduction of problem dimensionality and the provision of high-quality information. Innovative and creative activity is supported through appropriate human / machine interaction.

Design is considered here to be a generic activity. The process of design involves and impacts upon a diverse set of problem-solving and decision-making areas. Although previous research has concentrated upon the various stages of engineering design (Parmee I. C., 2001) areas currently under investigation involve compound design and drug discovery, portfolio design; supply chain design and management, schedule and resource allocation and software design and engineering. Each of these problem areas exhibit similar characteristics in terms of uncertainty, poor initial problem definition, a requirement for both qualitative and quantitative judgement, non-linearity, high modality within multi-variate space plus heavy constraint and multiple criteria.

The Institute for People-Centred Computation

The aims of this collaboration are - Encouraging research relating to the cross-disciplinary development and integration of generic human-centric computational support for complex design and decision-making processes emerging from the Discovery in Design (DiD) cluster.

Discovery in Design: People-centred Computational Issues. An EPSRC 'Designing for the 21st Century' Cluster http://www.ip-cc.org.uk/did.

The Institute for People-Centred Computation - http://www.ip-cc.org.uk/.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Artificial Intelligence Group
rdf:Description.p:remit: The Artificial Intelligence Group is concerned with the development and application of adaptive computing techniques. The UWE has a long history of A.I. research with the first publications and projects appearing in the early eighties. The group carries out internationally recognised research in a number of areas, with a strong emphasis on evolutionary computation. Our approach is to combine theoretical research with practical applications, based on collaborative projects with other academic institutions and industrial organisations. Recent partners have included Sandia National Labs (USA), British Telecom, Lloyds TSB and Hewlett Packard, as well as several EPSRC and EU funded projects. This research has covered areas such as heuristic optimisation, data mining, adaptive control, image processing, and bioinformatics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Applied Mathematics Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
Research in Mathematical Sciences

Much of the schools research is naturally inter-disciplinary, given the pervasive analytical power of the mathematical sciences. Every science uses mathematics to prove the validity of theories or principles.

Well over half of the 20 or so academic staff in the school of Mathematical Science are active researchers. The Applied Mathematics UoA23 submission obtained a 3a rating under in the 2001 Research Assessment Exercise, while several researchers contributed to the submissions in General Engineering and Computer Science. The school has an increasing number of PhD students.

Research in the school is grouped into 3 broad areas.

The Continuum Mechanics group is well-established, researching, for example, into acoustics and fluid mechanics, with expertise in numerical methods such as boundary element methods, finite element methods and spectral methods. Other research in the area of applied mathematics includes to the modelling and analysis of infectious diseases, and differential geometry and its applications to gravity theory and to other field theories.

Several staff are active in the Applied Statistical Modelling group, carrying out inter-disciplinary research with other UWE faculties, such as Applied Science and Health, who value, for example, the groups expertise on appropriate statistical designs for complex experimental work. The group also has strong external collaborative links on, for example, Bayesian imaging analysis (with Bristol University) and spatial-temporal modelling (with Queensland University of Technology, Australia).

The Computational and Decision Modelling group focuses not just on complex modelling issues, such as the optimization of production planning in the face of uncertain data, but also on algorithms and solution approaches to solve large-sized instances where, for example, the phenomenon of combinatorial explosion makes optimal methods unviable. This group is also interdisciplinary, working closely with computer science colleagues in the new Heuristic Optimisation group.

Research must be relevant to the end-applications and in turn be stimulated by them. The School has an active Applied Statistics and Quantitative Modelling Consultancy Unit, one of whose aims is to give opportunities for staff to use and expand their expertise by applying it in a real context.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Applied Statistical Modelling Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
Research in Mathematical Sciences

Several staff who are members of the Applied Mathematics Group are active in the Applied Statistical Modelling Group, carrying out inter-disciplinary research with other UWE faculties, such as Applied Science and Health, who value, for example, the groups expertise on appropriate statistical designs for complex experimental work. The group also has strong external collaborative links on, for example, Bayesian imaging analysis (with Bristol University) and spatial-temporal modelling (with Queensland University of Technology, Australia).

rdf:Description.p:groupName: Applied Statistics and Quantative Methods Consultancy Unit
rdf:Description.p:remit: Research must be relevant to the end-applications and in turn be stimulated by them. The School has an active Applied Statistics and Quantitative Modelling Consultancy Unit, one of whose aims is to give opportunities for staff to use and expand their expertise by applying it in a real context.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Academic Technologies Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
What We Do

The Academic Technologies Group (ATG) in I.T. Services supports and promotes appropriate development of effective e-learning (including the UWEonline virtual learning environment http://online.uwe.ac.uk) and ongoing development of the university web presence (including support for recruitment and portal initiatives http://www.uwe.ac.uk).

Why Academic Technologies?

Research in the school is grouped into 3 broad areas.

The term is used in preference to the more traditional "learning technologies" to emphasize the inclusion of teaching and research. Furthermore, "academic technologies" may be assumed to incorporate the media-oriented disciplines (design, video, photography, animation) which are increasingly fundamental to web-based learning and teaching in broadband environments.

The term "academic technologies" is not a local invention. Notably, one of the most senior positions in the IMS initiative, of which Blackboard and WebCT are partners, is "Director of Advanced Academic Technologies".

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Computational and Decision Modelling Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
Research in Mathematical Sciences

The Computational and Decision Modelling group focuses not just on complex modelling issues, such as the optimization of production planning in the face of uncertain data, but also on algorithms and solution approaches to solve large-sized instances where, for example, the phenomenon of combinatorial explosion makes optimal methods unviable. This group is also interdisciplinary, working closely with computer science colleagues in the new Heuristic Optimisation group.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Computational Mechanics Group
rdf:Description.p:remit: The CM Group exists to focus research synergies at UWE in the general fields of condition monitoring, computational mechanics and knowledge based engineering design. To date, work has focused on two contrasting fields; namely biomechanical engineering and aerospace structures. The group members have a strong track record of public output in these fields with the emphasis being on hybrid numerical methods and adaptive computing techniques. Research has benefited from the support of the EPSRC, research bursaries and in-kind support from collaborating organisations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: International Centre of Unconventional Computing
rdf:Description.p:remit:
We employ complex dynamics in physical, chemical and biological media to design novel computational techniques, architectures and working prototypes of non-linear media based computers.

The research is based on an interdisciplinary cooperation in modeling and experimental verification of novel principles of information processing and analysis in uniform distributed large-scale chemical and physical systems. We also apply these novel principles to the design of working prototypes of massively parallel computing devices with intrinsic functions that exploit the complex dynamics of non-linear systems.

Our research is structured in a way that is both clearly focused on specific and fundamental scientific questions: emergence of computation in non-linear media, controllability of disordered systems, computational complexity of dynamical physical systems, and broad applications: novel parallel computing architectures, chemical reaction-diffusion processors, hybrid silicon-wet-ware systems.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Differential Geometry Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
At present, the group consists solely of Dr. Tim Swift. His interests are in the general area of symplectic geometry and affine geometry. Under investigation are the following:

(i) the structure of spaces of submanifolds within a framework of symplectic fibrations and weak coupling;

(ii) the construction and application of moment maps for actions of symplectomorphism groups and of other infinite-dimensional groups;

(iii) the symplectic geometry of spaces of connections;

(iv) the interactions between affine geometry and symplectic geometry.

Tim Swift is also interested in applications of differential geometry to Physics - especially the theory of gravity - and also to Biology.
