rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Fluid Dynamics Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The collective expertise of the Fluid Dynamics Group spans non-Newtonian flows, multi-phase and interfacial flows, superfluid flows and direct numerical simulations.

Dr Rhys Gwynllyw has developed a robust numerical method to study the lubrication of two-dimensional dynamically and statically loaded journal bearings by both Newtonian fluid and non-Newtonian fluids. The numerical method used is a spectral element method with appropriate robust preconditioning in conjunction with the ALE methodology. The work has applications to oil lubrication of motor engine components. This moving grid numerical method includes extensions to include variable viscosity fluids, cavitation and viscoelastic effects. This work is in collaboration with Professor Tim Phillips at Cardiff University. Rhys Gwynllyw's research interests also include the numerical simulation of groundwater flows and is working in collaboration with Serco Assurance Ltd on this project. In addition he is also active in combinatorial research.

Dr Karen Henderson has developed mathematical and numerical models to compute the Taylor-Couette flow of superfluid helium II. The models are used to provide insight into superfluid flows, and to support experimental findings on superfluid flows. Recently she has considered the stability of a rotating superfluid jet and a column of rotating superfluid. Currently she is conducting research in the following areas, in collaboration with Professor Carlo Barenghi of Newcastle University and Dr Rhys Gwynllyw at UWE, Bristol:

- The motion of inertial particles in a Taylor-Couette flow.

- The nonlinear flow of superfluid helium in a rotating cylinder with imposed axial flow.

Dr Alison Hooper has been studying the stability of two-fluid Newtonian flows. Recent study of transient energy growth in two-fluid flows has revealed problems of non-convergence associated with the presence of the interface. These problems were overcome by a judicious choice of norm which is related but not equivalent to an energy norm.(South and Hooper(1999). Further work has taken place whereby the interface is replaced by a miscible layer. One of the shear modes of the flow transforms into an interfacial-type mode as the thickness of the miscible layer decreases and becomes comparable with the thickness of a critical layer,(Malik and Hooper(2005)) Work is underway to look at transient energy growth with respect to three-dimensional disturbances and we are investigating novel approaches to overcome convergence problems associated with the interface.

Transient linear growth of disturbances is related to pseudospectra ideas and transition to turbulence mechanisms. Hooper and Grimshaw (2001) looked at a simple model of transient growth to display the interplay between transient linear growth and nonlinear effects.

See also Proceedings of Complex Fluids 2003.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Human Computer Interaction Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
This is the UWE HCI Special Interest Group Website. It is intended to function as a focal point for assimilating HCI oriented research and education material and communicating and co-ordinating HCI related research activity within the faculty

Accessibility

Designing with Children

Assistive Technology

Home-Based Rehabilitation

Sonified Virtual Environments

Visual Interactive Feedback Learning

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Institute of Grinding Technology
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The Institute of Grinding Technology (IGT@UWE) is involved in fundamental research activities and specialises in technology transfer activities aimed at assisting all industries involved in abrasive machining processes.

It was set up in 1986 at the University of Bristol , specifically to work closely with industry, following a major 10 year programme of fundamental research into the grinding process as part of a national programme across a number of universities. DTI funded applied research projects were carried out in the areas of creep feed grinding and internal grinding with CBN wheels. Technology transfer activities evolved out of these projects, particularly the Annual IGT Seminar, Training Programmes and the Grinding Manual. Consultancy services are provided, including monitoring of grinding processes, advice on coolant application and measurement of vibration. An industrial Membership scheme is available and Members sit on an advisory council.

At the start of 2004, the IGT transferred to the University of the West of England, Bristol to share the facilities of the RAMP Laboratory, which was opened in April 2003. This brings together machining and grinding activities under the umbrella of the AMRC, so that both groups can benefit from the synergy.

More information is available at http://www.uwe.ac.uk/cems/research/centres/amrc/igt.html

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Learning Classifier Systems Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
Learning Classifier Systems (LCS) are a machine learning technique which use reinforcement learning, evolutionary computing and/or heuristics to develop adaptive systems.

The Group aims to further formal understanding of LCS, develop new algorithms within the paradigm, and to apply LCS to complex tasks. Previously, the Group has successfully applied LCS to various problems including data mining and classification, the control of road traffic junctions and robots, and to agent modelling tasks such as concept aircraft testing and on-line markets. Thus UWE has a long history of LCS research, the first publications and projects appearing in the early nineties.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Music and Audio Systems Research Group
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Music and Audio Systems Research Group
rdf:Description.p:remit: Interests span a wide area - from programming to synthesis to psychoacoustics to sonification to design for visually impaired sound engineers to multimedia - and beyond!

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Mathematical Biology Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
Ana Sendova-Franks' main research interest is the understanding of social insect colonies, and ants in particular, as models of decentralised adaptive complex organisation honed by natural selection over millions of years. This involves mathematical modelling which is often facilitated by initial individual-based computer models seeking to link individual rules of behaviour with patterns and processes at the colony (population) level. Recent work includes models of task switching in the division of labour, building, worker sorting, as well as work on collective learning and brood sorting.

Rob Laister's main interests are in the qualitative solution behaviour in systems of non-local reaction-diffusion equations. The term `non-local' means that the nonlinearities depend on population levels at previous times (delay) and/or weighted averages of the spatial distribution of population densities. Such equations arise naturally in models of infectious diseases or where resources take time to regenerate.

Recent work has looked at the effects of both degenerate diffusion and non-Lipschitz nonlinearities in bistable reaction-diffusion equations (such as those that arise in the Nagumo equation of nerve impulse propagation, cumbustion theory and population genetics). In particular, novel travelling wave solutions (`catch-up' and `splitting' waves) exist where they otherwise would not in the classical Lipschitz case.

Fatima Fahr's research interests covers mathematical modelling and numerical solutions to differential equations in the field of population dynamics, epidemiology, biological and medical mathematics, statistical biology and business statistics. Some examples of these applications are as follows:

1. Mathematical modelling of transmission dynamics of HIV / AIDS.

2. Modelling of natural phenomena such as hurricanes, earthquakes and floods.

3. Modelling of cancers by study of influencing factors.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Maths Resource Centre
rdf:Description.p:remit:
CEMS Mathematics Learning Support

Drop-in sessions are now available in the Mathematics Resource Centre (MRC) located in 2Q53 at the following times

Monday 3.30 4.30 Guy Roberts
Tuesday 1.30 - 2.30 Guy Roberts
Wednesday 12.30 1.30 Alistair Treen
Thursday 12.30 1.30 Peter Graham

No appointment necessary.

On-line courses and video tutorials in algebra, trigonometry, differentiation and integration are available from the MRC webpage http://www.cems.uwe.ac.uk/mslc.

For further information on what help is available, contact Kevin.Golden@uwe.ac.uk.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Student Advice Centre
rdf:Description.p:remit:
UWE offers a range of support and information services to help you settle in and address any needs you may have during your time here. The Student Support section of the UWE handbook outlines these in detail.

In CEMS, your first port of call for any queries on your programme of study, money and personal issues may be one of our Student Advisers. They have expertise in the structure of your course as well as experience in some of the financial and personal worries often faced by students. Most of your queries will be dealt with on the spot. If your needs are more complex, the student advisers will be able to refer you to the appropriate central university support service.

You will need to make an appointment to see a student adviser. To do this, go to Reception in N Block 2N44 (contact details below) during normal office hours. The Student Advisers are based in Room 2N9.

Here are just some of the things student advisers can offer help with:

  • Clarification on UWE regulations and how they affect you.
  • Guidance on your programme of study (implications of choosing options, etc.).
  • Guidance on extenuating circumstances and late work procedures.
  • Explanation and advice on tuition fees, student funding and financial support.
  • Sympathetic and impartial support if personal matters are affecting your studies.
  • Advice on alternative study routes, e.g. transferral to another course or temporary withdrawal.
  • Advice on special examination needs and arrangements.

We want your time at UWE to be productive and enjoyable. If you have any concerns please do not hesitate to contact us.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Quality Enhancement Team
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The Quality Enhancement Team's areas of responsibility include the following:-

  • Involvement with the Facultys Academic Plan in relation to the development of new programmes and validation of new programmes
  • Prepare documentation for new programmes, new modules and review ISIS2 academic infrastructure/definitive documentation
  • Checking programme and module specifications are accurate in accordance with University practice
  • Programme and module changes through the Faculty Curriculum Oversight Group (FCOG)
  • Updates to programme structures and module specifications and notification of changes to relevant members of staff
  • Updating FOLD (Faculty based) and CEREUS (UWE based) information systems for the Modular Scheme Administration team
  • Assistance with Accreditation visits, Internal Audit and Review
  • Provide information to Student Advisers for transcripts i.e. programme/module history
  • Responsibility for updating all standard forms for Modular Scheme Administration team and uploading this information on to PLONE
  • General housekeeping of ISIS2 academic infrastructure and definitive documentation
  • Production of Information Booklets for new students in consultation with relevant members of administrative and academic staff
  • Preparation of Level 1 Option Choices on FOLD (Students Online) for new students
  • Production of Programme of Study forms for option process for level 2, 3 and M students
  • Preparation of the Student Module Evaluation Questionnaire, updating all associated paperwork for teaching blocks 1 and 2
  • Clerks to Learning, Teaching and Assessment Committee and the Faculty Curriculum Oversight Group and any relevant working groups/meetings
  • Responsibility for checking Designated/Discretionary course dates and tipping values for SARI
  • Responsibility for the mapping of IRIS to ISIS codes in the infrastructure and the rolling-in of new students from IRIS to ISIS

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Nonlinear Systems and PDEs Group
rdf:Description.p:remit: Dr Rob Laister has focused on the qualitative structure of solutions in differential-algebraic equations (DAEs) and their applications to quasi-linear PDEs. DAEs take the general form dx/dt = f(x,y), 0=g(x,y) and have interesting, novel solutions due to a lack of uniqueness at special points in the phase space. In particular they provide a new line of attack when seeking special solutions (e.g. travelling waves) of PDEs (degenerate elliptic and parabolic, quasi-linear hyperbolic). At present we are pursuing possible implications for nonlinear lattices.Dr Laister's work is in collaboration with Dr R. Beardmore, Imperial College and Dr A.T. Peplow, KTH, Stockholm.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Power Systems and Electronics Research Group
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Power Systems and Electronics Research Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The Power Systems and Electronics Research Group of UWE is one of the strongest Modern Power Engineering Groups among the new Universities in the UK.

Group members have many years of experience in the area of Power Systems, Electrical Contacts/Switchgears, Electro-magnetic and the application of Power Electronics, Microprocessors, Control, ANN/Fuzzy and Signal Processing in Power Engineering, which is recognised Nationally and Internationally. The group also conducts research into alternative energy systems, transport and industrial plants.

The group has collaboration with five European Universities, two Iranian Universities , One Japanese University and a number of UK companies.

In recent years the group has hosted two major International Power Engineering Conferences. Group members are actively involved in the review of IEE, IEEE and many International Power Engineering related Journals as well as serving on Canadian, German and Japanese Editorial boards of Power Engineering Journals and various Scientific Committees of Power Conferences. In total, over 300 papers have been published among group members in refereed Journals and Conference Proceedings.

To date the group has received funds from EPSRC, The Leverhulme Trust, The British Council, EU, HEFCE and from a number of UK Companies.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Quality Systems Research Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The role of the QSRG is to undertake research into the application of quality systems and techniques in a wide variety of sectors. QSRG has been active since the late 1980s, although it has only fairly recently adopted its present name. As a matter of policy, the research which QSRG pursues has a high level of industrial collaboration. Sponsors to date include the Bristol Quality Centre, Post Office Counters Ltd, and Business Links West.

The activities of QSRG are managed by a team of four members of the Faculty of Engineering, each of whom have been active in research relating to quality for a number of years. As a result of the broad range of interests of its key personnel, QSRG has in its current portfolio a very wide variety of projects.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Revolutionary Aerospace Machining Project
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The RAMP group researches High Speed Machining. The Revolutionary Aerospace Machining Project Laboratory is the key facility for this.

This new 1m facility provides a centre of expertise for aerospace manufacturing research in the machining of high temperature alloys through a combination of grinding and milling. RAMP works with companies such as Airbus, Rolls-Royce and Stellram on projects funded by EPSRC and the DTI including work on:

Advanced Monolithic Machining Parameters.

Surface Indentation Stress Measurement.

Compensation of Billet Residual Stress.

Enhanced Fatigue Recovery using Lasers.

The facility provides an advanced manufacturing technology for the benefit of the global aerospace industry and should allow UWE to become the leading European institution for advanced machining techniques for the aerospace and related industries. The laboratory researches high velocity machining and thus opens up opportunities for new methodologies for Ultra High Performance Machining.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Aerospace Manufacturing Research Centre
rdf:Description.p:remit:
This centre has established itself as a leading research group of national significance. Since its inception in 1994, the Centre has been involved in a large number of substantive research projects. These vary from EPSRC funded projects to research funded directly by aerospace companies, many from the local region as well as from further afield including mainland Europe and the United States. The aim of the group is to provide a national centre of expertise for aerospace manufacturing research. The focus of the research is on providing pragmatic solutions that meet the needs of industry.

The aim of the group is to provide a national centre of expertise for aerospace manufacturing research. The focus of the research is on providing pragmatic and applied solutions that meet the needs of industry.

The Objectives of our research is to provide pragmatic and applied solutions that meet the needs of both industry and the environment.

Principal interests

Primary aerospace processes such as Ultra-High Speed Machining (UHSM), grinding, superplastic forming and diffusion bonding, laser drilling and powder metallurgy.

A company LisTechnology has been formed to commercialise a technology called Superplastic Laser Induced Component Equipment (SPLICE). This was pioneered AMRC, in collaboration with the University of Central Florida, enabling the lightest, strongest, most corrosion resistant and fatigue enduring, complex structures ever to be produced.

IT tools to support the aerospace design process. These include cost modelling tools, project management tools, materials analysis tools.

Further Information can be accessed here: http://www.cems.uwe.ac.uk/amrc/

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Bristol Robotics Laboratory
rdf:Description.p:remit:
Launched in December 2005 the Bristol Robotics Laboratory is a collaborative research partnership funded by the University of Bristol, the University of the West of England and HEFCE. Under the direction of Professor Chris Melhuish the laboratory is an evolution of the Intelligent Autonomous Systems Laboratory (IAS). The IAS was already a well established research centre with the aim of conducting research into intelligent (ie. robotic) systems capable of unsupervised operation in unknown, noisy or dynamically changing environments, with a strong emphasis on the transfer of theoretical concepts into engineering realisation.

The BRL researches ways in which autonomous robots - large and small, walking, climbing, flying - can be developed to do the right thing at the right time without external supervision. This can be summed up in the goal to ' create robots which can do things you do not want to do, in a place you do not want to be, and at a time you do not want to or cannot be there. '

The BRL draws expertise from evolutionary biology and studies in animal behaviour, artificial intelligence and artificial life.

Our mission is to understand the science, engineering and social role of robotics and embedded intelligence. Our multidisciplinary approach aims to create autonomous devices capable of working independently, with each other, or with us in our human society.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Centre for Complex Cooperative Systems
rdf:Description.p:remit:
CCCS undertakes research into the application of technologies for the development of large-scale distributed information systems. Formed out of successful cooperative research ventures with leading research institutions and commercial organisations including CERN and Motorola, it is currently involved in research with several leading research centres and commercial organisations.

Click for a case study; a collaboration scheme between CCCS and OPNET.

Click for a case study; a collaboration scheme between CCCS and Motorola.

The Center for Complex Cooperative Communicating Systems was formed with the express aim of providing a focus for research in the application of the following technologies for the development of very large distributed systems :

Object Oriented Development Techniques

Object Oriented Distributed Systems

Object and Temporal Databases

Distributed Artificial Intelligence

Intelligent Agent Technologies

It was formed out of successful cooperative research ventures with a number of leading research institutions and commercial organisations, including CERN and Motorola , and has been successful in attracting new funded research through continuing collaborations.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Centre for Innovative Manufacture and Machine Vision System
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Centre for Innovative Manufacture and Machine Vision System

p:intranetPage.rdf:resource: http://fold.cems.uwe.ac.uk:8080/exist/servlet/db/fold1/prod/group.xql?name=Centre for Innovative Manufacture and Machine Vision System

p:publicPage.rdf:resource: http://www.cems.uwe.ac.uk/exist/group.xql?name=Centre for Innovative Manufacture and Machine Vision System

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Community Information Systems Centre
rdf:Description.p:remit:
CISC is interested in the use of information and communications technologies (ICTs) in communities of all kinds. We work in partnership with people in their own community settings to use, understand, develop or optimise information systems in line with their particular needs and practices.

We aim to extend the scope of ICT use in ways that enfranchise marginalised people and groups, and align closely with their strategic aims. We believe that inclusive, creative and enabling applications of technology are desirable, possible, and increasing available.

We are responding to the spread of ICTs beyond business organisations, and beyond the boundaries of organisations of whatever kind, into the home, the street, and into society as a whole. With the rise of the World Wide Web, interactions between people and ICT are becoming more extended and more interlinked, and nowadays include groups within larger organisations.

Most of our projects involve us in action research, consultancy, training and evaluation work in collaboration with practitioners. Current or recent partners include Voscur, Barton Hill Settlement, Southville Centre, St Pauls Carnival Association, Bristol City Council, Women Connect, National Council for Voluntary Organisations, Hi8us, Mental Health Media, and Hewlett-Packard. We are also active in a range of academic and practitioner networks locally, nationally and internationally.

More details: see About CISC...

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Engineering and Medicine Elastomers Research Centre
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Engineering and Medicine Elastomers Research Centre
rdf:Description.p:remit:
EMER performs research to benefit society and industry and particularly in health-related areas - underpinned by fundamental work. Much of our work focuses on: improved understanding of processes at the nm-scale; generation of generic multiphysics solution algorithms in finite element and related analyses by artificial intelligence and other means. Reflecting the interdisciplinary nature of our work, EMER members include academics from the faculties of CEMS, Health and Social Care, Applied Science and the Built Environment. More widely we have recently collaborated and worked with the following companies and industries: Argonne National Laboratory, Avon Rubber, BNFL Magnox Generation, Bristol University, British Energy, European Joint Research Centre Petten, Football Association, Hahn-Meitner Institute (Berlin), Health and Safety Executive, Institute de Soudure, Jaguar Cars, KeyMed (Olympus group), Lancaster University, North Bristol NHS Trust, Oxford University, Rutherford-Appleton Laboratory, SINTEF (Norway), SSL International, Staatliche Materialprfungsanstalt, Univ. Stttgart, Trelleborg (formerly Dunlop), TU-Berlin, UKAE Culham.

The Centre has many years of research experience in the study of sustainable energy; prediction of mechanical behaviour and life of components; studies on bridge instabilities; avoidance of occupational and sports injury; physiological modelling; innovation in finite element and related methods. Notable experimental facilities available to the Centre include those for sound and vibration, testing of materials including elastomer and concrete composites and physiological measurements.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Reading Strategies Implementation Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
Overall aims

To carry through the recommendations made in 2004 by the Reading Strategies Working Group (a time-delimited sub group of TLAC) - taking into account the amendments suggested by UMMC.

To embed the concept of reading strategies (which largely focuses on access to information and skills for finding relevant information) within the wider context of faculties aims to encourage appropriate reading and critical analysis of information for study and research purposes.

Objectives

To oversee the implementation of the reading strategies proposals in each faculty by devising appropriate means to ensure that:

The entitlement and expectations of students with regard to access to reading materials are met

There is clarity regarding the proposals - organising further seminar sessions with library staff where this is not the case

Programme leaders in all faculties subscribe to the concept of reading strategies and take an overview of where, within the programme, information skills sessions for students might be most productively organised

Module leaders produce a relevant reading strategy for students and faculty librarians prior to the run of the module in a form appropriate to the faculty context, e.g. a module handbook, a section on UWEonline, etc

The module specification template is altered to include a reading strategy section so that, in future, it is made clear that any specific reading/indicative sources list mentioned is for validation purposes only and that annual, up-to-date reading strategies are available as appropriate to the faculty (see above)

The timetable for the introduction of reading strategies is adhered to or bettered

To co-ordinate with the Librarys Access to Course Readings Group to ensure that

To advise the library on:

- the development of the Librarys Reading Strategy Toolkit which also aims to assist academic staff in the implementation of reading strategies

- the most appropriate activities for Faculty Librarians to undertake in order to make quick and effective progress in embedding RS within the faculty

To advise the Students Union on facilitating the buying and selling second hand books

To identify particular modules within each faculty for particular monitoring and evaluation in order to inform the further development of reading strategies across the institution.

Mode of operation

The group will report to TLAC annually, through the Chair

Members of the group will maintain a close dialogue with their respective faculty/service on the issue of Reading Strategies, ie by reporting into and back from a relevant committee, as specified by them (e.g. Faculty Teaching and Learning Committee). It is appreciated that a lot of the discussion and decision-making may take place between the meetings.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Systems Engineering Estimation and Decision Support
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Systems Engineering Estimation and Decision Support
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The Systems Engineering Estimation and Decision Support (SEEDS) team is part of the Aerospace Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC). Our expertise is in working with aerospace organisations' to apply techniques in managing, categorising and visualising information to support costing of complex products within the aerospace sector.

The tools and techniques we provide can be applicable to organisations outside this field. We are experienced at liasing with industrial partners to ensure our projects meet their needs and so have a successful outcome. Our main area of research is in software techniques for analysing and reporting on the costs involved in design and manufacture of products, and integrating such tools into the infrastructure that exists in an organisation.

We are involved in cost modelling solutions, and have experience of working with aerospace organisations.. We have been working with Rolls-Royce aerospace and Airbus.

Further Information on SEEDS can be accessed here: http://www.cems.uwe.ac.uk/amrc/seeds/

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Systems Modelling Research Group
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The primary research focus of the Systems Modelling Research Group (SMRG) is processes. In particular, we are engaged in investigating, modelling, analysing, re-engineering, designing, and simulating processes. We also research how processes may best be supported by IT. Within the group, members have a range of research interests, including: process enactment with mobile devices, enactable declarative process models, language action and process models, narratives and processes in organisations, multi-agent support for business processes, process modelling and health informatics, and process architectures.

The members of the group are drawn from the Schools of Computer Science and Information Systems at UWE, and from the School of Management at Bath University . A number of PhD students are closely associated with the group, as are a number of external academics and members of the process community from industry.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Department of Computer Science
rdf:Description.p:remit:
Research

Research within the School of Computer Science is largely concentrated within Research Centres and Research Groups all of which are active at a National, European and International level. Main areas of research are in Artificial Intelligence / Computational Intelligence and Distributed Systems / Data Management.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Department of Information Science and Digital Media
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Department of Information Science and Digital Media
rdf:Description.p:remit: The School's interests cover a range of areas but are mainly focussed around matching the capabilities of technologies to the needs of organisations, individuals, and societies. Activities of interest include requirements analysis; systems design; the implications of new forms of technology and information; and the evaluation and critique of information systems. We are currently involved in the business, community, government, and healthcare domains. We also host the well established Community Information Systems Centre.

p:intranetPage.rdf:resource: http://fold.cems.uwe.ac.uk:8080/exist/servlet/db/fold1/prod/group.xql?name=Department of Information Science and Digital Media

p:publicPage.rdf:resource: http://www.cems.uwe.ac.uk/exist/group.xql?name=Department of Information Science and Digital Media

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Department of Design and Engineering
rdf:Description.p:remit: The School is engaged in intensive research activity in a diverse range of disciplines including Aerospace Manufacturing, Machine Vision, Reverse Engineering, Numerical methods in engineering, particularly in solid and fluid mechanics, Knowledge based systems for manufacturing processes, Stone processing, Concurrent Engineering, Quality Systems and Computational Mechanics.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Department of Mathematics and Statistics
rdf:Description.p:remit: The School has an increasing number of research staff and PhD students. Over half of the School's academic staff are active researchers, mostly outside the research centres. Research in the School is grouped into four broad areas and is often interdisciplinary, given the pervasive analytical power of the mathematical sciences. The Applied Mathematics Group is well-established, researching into acoustics and fluid mechanics, with expertise in numerical methods. Other research in the area of applied mathematics includes the modelling and analysis of infectious diseases, and differential geometry and its applications to gravity theory and to other field theories.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: The Association of Professional Recording Services
rdf:Description.p:groupName: The Association of Professional Recording Services

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: British Computer Society
rdf:Description.p:remit:
Established in 1957, the British Computer Society (BCS) is the leading body for those working in IT.

With a world-wide membership now over 50,000 members in over 100 countries, BCS is the qualifying body for Chartered IT Professionals (CITP).

BCS was incorporated by Royal Charter in 1984. Its objects are to promote the study and practice of computing and to advance knowledge of and education in IT for the benefit of the public. BCS is also a registered charity.

BCS is licensed by the Engineering Council to award Chartered Engineer status (CEng) and Incorporated Engineer status (IEng); and more recently by the Science Council to award Chartered Scientist status (CSci).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Beijing Institute of Technology
rdf:Description.p:remit:
CEMS has an International partnership agreement with The Beijing Institute of Technology.

For more information on CEMS International Partnerships visit http://www.uwe.ac.uk/cems/international/partners.html.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: University of Bordeaux 1
rdf:Description.p:remit:
CEMS currently has an agreement with the University of Bordeaux 1 under the Socrates-Erasmus Programme.

For more information on the programme, visit the Socrates-Erasmus Website.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Fachhochschule Osnabruck - University of Applied Sciences
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Fachhochschule Osnabruck - University of Applied Sciences
rdf:Description.p:remit:
CEMS currently has an agreement with Fachhochschule Osnabruck - University of Applied Sciences under the Socrates-Erasmus Programme.

For more information on the programme, visit the Socrates-Erasmus Website.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: International University
rdf:Description.p:remit:
CEMS has an International partnership agreement with HCMIU.

For more information on CEMS International Partnerships visit http://www.uwe.ac.uk/cems/international/partners.html.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Huazhong University of Science and Technology
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Huazhong University of Science and Technology
rdf:Description.p:remit:
CEMS has an International partnership agreement with Huazhong University of Science and Technology.

For more information on CEMS International Partnerships visit http://www.uwe.ac.uk/cems/international/partners.html.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
rdf:Description.p:groupName: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The IEEE, a non-profit organization, is the world's leading professional association for the advancement of technology.

The full name of the IEEE is the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc., although the organization is referred to by the letters I-E-E-E and pronounced Eye-triple-E.

Who the IEEE Serves

Through its global membership, the IEEE is a leading authority on areas ranging from aerospace systems, computers and telecommunications to biomedical engineering, electric power and consumer electronics among others.

Members rely on the IEEE as a source of technical and professional information, resources and services.

To foster an interest in the engineering profession, the IEEE also serves student members in colleges and universities around the world.

Other important constituencies include prospective members and organizations that purchase IEEE products and participate in conferences or other IEEE programs.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Institution of Engineering and Technology
rdf:Description.p:remit: We are a new institution formed in spring 2006 by the coming together of the IEE and IIE. We aim to serve a global community engaged in engineering and technology, providing a knowledge network accessible whenever or wherever you choose.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Institution of Mechanical Engineers
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The IMechE is the United Kingdom's qualifying body for mechanical engineers and has been the home of Mechanical Engineers for over 150 years.

Around 75,000 engineers world-wide are members.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: INTI College
rdf:Description.p:remit:
CEMS has an International partnership agreement with The INTI College.

For more information on CEMS International Partnerships visit http://www.uwe.ac.uk/cems/international/partners.html.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Institute of Directors
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The IoD is the professional body for business leaders and we have been supporting and representing individual directors from all sectors for over 100 years.

If you are responsible for the strategic direction of your company, we can support you both now and in your future career. We are not industry biased - our members are from the complete spectrum of business.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Institute for People-Centred Computation
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The aims of this collaboration are - Encouraging research relating to the cross-disciplinary development and integration of generic human-centric computational support for complex design and decision-making processes emerging from the Discovery in Design (DiD) cluster.

Researchers within the Institute are intent upon the identification of common languages, methodologies and practices that allow us to cease working in isolation and to realise mutual benefit from our collective experiences.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: International Council on Systems Engineering
rdf:Description.p:remit:
The International Council on Systems Engineering (INCOSE) is a not-for-profit membership organization founded in 1990.

Our mission is to advance the state of the art and practice of systems engineering in industry, academia, and government by

promoting interdisciplinary, scaleable approaches to produce technologically appropriate solutions that meet societal needs.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Operational Research Society
rdf:Description.p:remit: The OR Society, with members in 53 countries, provides training, conferences, publications and information to those working in Operational Research. The Society also provides information about Operational Research to interested members of the general public.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Peking University
rdf:Description.p:remit:
UWE is involoved in a collaborative pilot scheme run with Peking University in China called The Internetics scheme.

The aim of the Internetics scheme is to increase the range of modules which we can offer to students to allow them to learn

and study in a novel way and to play a part in developing an unusual international collaborative arrangement.

For more information visit the Internetics Scheme Site

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Royal Statistical Society
rdf:Description.p:remit:
We are one of the premier statistical societies in the world, with a high international reputation. Founded in 1834, we are both a learned and a professional society, with some 6500 members based in the United Kingdom and overseas. Over 1700 of our members are professionally qualified.

Our main purposes are:

  • To nurture the discipline of statistics by publishing a Journal, organising meetings, setting and maintaining professional standards, accrediting university courses and operating examinations.
  • To promote the discipline of statistics by disseminating and encouraging statistical knowledge and good practice with both producers and consumers of statistics, and in society at large.
  • To provide effective and efficient services to our members which will support their professional and academic interests and their endeavours to advance the other objectives of the Society.
